title: F.D.R. Drive to Be Closed

The closing is to allow the Con solidated Edison Company to remove coal chutes suspended over the drive between 39th and 41st Streets.

description: IQUITOS, PeruThey rise in the snow fields of the towering Andes Mountains of Peru, Ecuador and Colombia, the mountain rivulets that fold gently to gether and grow into the Maranon River which is joined by the Huallaga River, and later by the waters of the Tigre and the Corrientes, and the Ucaya??, and here at Iquitos in the northeast corner of Peru deep in the jungle their muddy waters suddenly become the Rio Ama zonas.

Woods, now looking back at his younger self in Vibra tions. One doesn't offer this not so wild surmise merely be cause Mr. Woods grew up in

description: ATLANTA, Oct. 29The Re publicans are not so optimistic as they were three months ago about gaining large numbers of new offices in the South this year, despite allout efforts by top party leaders.

title: 3 Local G.M. Accords
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 (UPI) Representatives of the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, negotiating on national contract talks to end a 47dayold strike, today announced three more local plant settlements. The set tlements, at Willow Run, Mich., Southgate, Calif., and Salt Lake, brought to 63 the number of local plants that have reached settlement of 155 bargaining units in the United States and seven in Canada.

title: Unbought And Unbossed
description: As the first black woman elected to Congress, Shirley Chisholm could have claimed headlines without ever saying a word. But the fraillooking, 100 pound educator from Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District is proud that she has not been silent in the almost two years since she's been in Washington. She has consist ently spoken out against the things she believes wrong and stanchly supported the causes she believes to be in the best interest of her urban, mostly poorblack constituents.

title: Japan's First ComputerRun Large Tanker Ends Maiden Trip
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Oct. 31Japan's first computer controlled large tanker, an experimental ship that ap pears to be among the most advanced on the seas, sailed back to Yokohama this week after her maiden voyage to the Persian Gulf.

title: LIMIT TO REASON VICTOR AT LAUREL
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31  Brookmeade Stable's Limit to Reason coasted to a fourIength victory today in the $197,040 PimlicoLaUrel Futurity for 2 yearolds at Laurel Race Course, scoring his second triumph in a row in a $100,000 race.

title: S. I. Transit Post Filled
description: The appointment of Edmund A. Duszak as general superin tendent of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Operating Au thority was announced yester day. He will take up his post today. The announcement was made by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, of which the 14mile Staten Island line is a subsidiary.

title: NATHANIAL E. WHEELER
description: MERRICK, L. I., Oct. 31 Nathaniel E. Wheeler, a lawyer who was formerly bonding sec retary for the Royal Globe In surance Company, died today at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Rockland Center at the age of 77. He lived at 33 Fox Boulevard here.

title: MARYLAND BEATEN BY CLEMSON, 2411
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 31 (UPI)Don Kelley, a Clem son cornerback, broke open an Atlantic Coast Conference game today with 85 and 54yard re turns on the fourth quarter and led the Tigers to a 2411 victory over Maryland.

description: The bulletscarred Jordan InterContinental Hotel, on the highest hill of Amman near the city center, was regarded as a prime target, prize and vantage point by both the Jordanian Army and the Palestinian guerrillas during their recent fighting.

title: Suit Charges State Training Schools Abuse Children
description: Many children at state train ing schools are placed in what amounts to solitary confine ment even though state regu lations prohibit such confine ment, according to a suit filed in Federal Court by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: United Parcel Strike Ends In Six New England States
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31 (AP)  Drivers and other employes of United Parcel Service in six New England states have voted to accept a new threeyear con tract, ending a fiveweek strike, the company announced today.

title: Before Chaos Takes Over
description: AMMAN, JordanThere are, four real forces in the Middle East today, Russia, America, Egypt and Israel. The rest, including China and the Palestine guerrillas, don't yet count as much although their influence is bound to grow if disorder continues. Therefore, if the four real forces cannot make a settlement among themselves, and rela tively soon, their respective influences will diminish.

title: Survey Finds Many Medical Students Use Marijuana
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 Medical students show a higher incidence of marijuana use than most other groups, a panel of physicians has con cluded from a study conducted at four medical schools.

title: What's New At the Movies?
description: THIS MAN MUST DIE, di rected by Claude Chabrol, is surely one of the best new movies, writes Roger Greenspun. It is a revenge melodrama about a young father who sets out to dis cover and murder the hitandrun killer of his lit tle son. In the Chabrol world revenge is never sim ple, or without its own in terdependencies and moral ambiguities. In its preoccupations, its surprises, its dislocations, the glorious excesses and precise dis closures of its camera, This Man Must Die re sembles earlier Chabrol. There are the usual great Chabrol eating sequences, the usual unequalled abil ity visually to orchestrate a range of behavior among several people in any given scene, and the usual superb capacity to implicate an entire countryside in the movements of his drama. This alone places Chabrol among the best directors of thrillers, and in `The Man Must Die the sea and the Atlantic coast of France collaborate in a quest that is also an expression of universal doom.

title: FourTime Loser Sits Out the Election
description: A fourtime candidate for President is out of politics, at least for this election. He is Eric Hass, who has resigned from the Socialist Labor party, by his own account, and who has been expelled, in the party's version.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A contemporary music festival that offers the chance to hear 11 new commissioned works in three concerts can throw one into the kind of shock that at tacks him when he enters one of those allthesaladyoucan eat restaurants.

title: Squires Defeat Condors As Carter Excels, 113110
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 31 (AP) George Carter scored a ca reerhigh 32 points tonight as he led the Virginia Squires to a 113110 American Basketball Association victory over the Pittsburgh Condors.

description: The municipal bond mar ket recently has been groan ing under the weight of an extraordinarily heavy sched ule of new financing, and interest rates have moved back to their highest levels since July. title: The PostElection Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  At me end of the American elections of 1970 most of the people concerned are agreed on one or two points: They are glad it is over; most of the candi dates for office are exhausted, broke and vaguely unhappy about their own arguments; the men around the Presi dent and the Vice President feel troubled and trapped by the political system, and even the most partisan voters, in their reflective moments, agree that something is wrong.

description: EARLY IN THE morning devotees gather on the beachesIpanema, Lotion, Fla mengo, Copacabana and the rest. This festival takes place in and near Rio de Janeiro on Dec. 31for the practitioners of macum ba it is the Day of Iemanjama, Protec tor of Women, Goddess of the Sea, and of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Dance
description: IS it possible that in Amer ica we expect our ballet companies to be over pro ductive? In Europe, ballet companies are more leisurely over their production sched ules. Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet has in the last five years produced new versions of The Nutcracker, Sparta cus and Swan Lake. Next season in Leningrad the Kirov Ballet is to stage the premiere of a new Sergeyev ballet, Hamlet. I forget when it performed its pre vious premiere but it must have been about three years ago.

The Janacek/Corsaro opera will have a preview tonight at the New York State Theater, and the premiere takes place Tuesday.

title: Thousands of Foreign Military Men Studying in U.S.
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan. Thousands of foreign military officerssome of whom may face each other later on oppo site sides of the firing line and others who may well become leaders and supporters of gov ernments hostile to the United Statesare being molded by American military education.

title: The Three Strategies Of a Master Politician
description: WASHINGTON. MIDWAY through his 1968 cam paign for the Presidency, Richard M. Nixon stopped at a school for the deaf in Washington. He spoke to the children through signlanguage interpreters, and that night brooded about them in his suite with Billy Graham, his evangelist friend. Reporters learned of all this, and the next day stories appeared throughout the land telling how Nixon, the supposedly calculating man, had succumbed to real emotion. Later research, however, turned up the interesting fact that Mr. Nixon had made a similar visit to the Iowa School for the Deaf during the 1960 campaign; the earlier visit had yielded the same kind of heartthrob coverage.

title: Mrs. Meir Given Ovation At Metropolitan Opera Gala
description: Mrs. Golda Meir, the Prime Minister of Israel, was given spontaneous standing ovation last night at a gala perform ance of the Metropolitan Opera when the crowd noticed her re turning to her box following an intermission.

title: Television

title: A Minister of Music To Stay on the Job Despite a Windfall
description: PRATTSVILLE, Ark., Oct. 31 (UPI)Jack Buras is a minister of music at the only church in town. He earns $110 a week and he says he would not want to be doing anything else or living anywhere but here.

description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 31Rich McKay, a quarterback, rallied Lafayette to a 2114 victory over Gettysburg today with two long touchdown passes in the second half.

title: AUBURN TROUNCES FLORIDA BY 6314
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 31 (UPI)  Pat Sullivan passed three to Terry Beasley, and ran for a fourth as Auburn trounced Florida, 6314, today before crowd of 63,560.

title: ECHOES BY CRUMB PLAYED BY JUILLIARD
description: George Crumb's Echoes of Time and the River won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1968, and has since enjoyed numerous performances in this country. New York heard the work for the first time on Friday night, played by the Juilliard Theater Orchestra under Harold Farber man, its guest conductor, in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A study of warhot and coldas portrayed in the espi onage fiction of the past half century could prove instruc tive. More particularly, a view of a changing public image of international conflict might emerge, a possibility suggested by prolific English novelist James Graham's first appear ance on these shores, A GAME FOR HEROES (Doubleday, $5.95). War, we now seem agreed, is hell. Once, runs Mr. Graham's tale, it was a contest waged, necessarily but regret tably to the death, between gentlemenwho, when faced with a common need, were as likely as not to unite to meet it.

title: DR. L. EDWARD GIOVINE
description: Dr. L. Edward Giovine died on Thursday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 121 Malba Drive, Whitestone, Queens, and had an office in Woodside, Queens.

title: Article 4  No Title
WASHINGTON NOTE IS SHOWN AT BANK
description: During all the years that George Washington was first in war, and much of the time that he was first in peace, the Bank of England continued to pay dividends on his 1,650 in bank stock.

title: Rummage Sale in Saigon Turns Chaotic
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31The American and British women of St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Saigon held a charity rummage sale to day that quickly turned into a rout. Half of the goodsmostly clothing discarded by departing Americanswere stolen.

title: New Unit to Represent Mrs. Court and Roche
description: The Chemold Corporation, manufacturer of aluminum tennis racquets and golf balls, has broadened its operations to include athlete manage ment.

title: Fialka: He's Very Secial
description: WHAT can I tell you about Ladislav Fialka? If you live in New York and you saw him, you will know. And if you live in New York and you didn't see him, you have already missed him by a week. (Take heart, he is touring.) And Fialka is very special.

title: Tarkenton Is No. 1 Target
description: Against the Giants today, the Jets have nothing to lose and all of New York to gain.

title: Mrs. Clarke is Bride Of Alexander C. Ewing
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Oct. 31Mrs. Sheila Cobb Clarke. the widow or Michael deS. Clarke of Katonah, and Alexander Cochran Ewing of Millbrook, were married here today at St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. John C. Humphries. Mr. Ewing is the general director of City Cen ter Joffrey Ballet in New York and president of the Foundation for American Dance.

title: Cowboys Reactivate Asher
description: DALLAS, Oct 31 (AP)  The Dallas Cowboys reactivated rookie center, Bob Asher, today and put a guard, Halvor Hagen, on the taxi squad.

title: The Puerto Rico Most Tourists Miss Seen From a Publico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.A quick and inex pensive way to get acquainted with Puerto Ricoand Puerto Ricansis by taking the publicos, those American six passenger sedans that cruise around the island on more or less regular routes.

title: ANTIWAR RALLIES HELD ACROSS U.S.
description: Protesters in cities across the country staged generally peace ful demonstrations, parades and rallies against the Vietnam war yesterday, three days before the Tuesday elections.

title: Bombs Used in 3 Attacks Differed
description: The bomb that went off in the police motorcycle head quarters early Friday morning was different from the two that exploded In two Queens ar mories about the same time.

title: LILCO CHALLENGED ON PLANT'S SAFETY
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 31  Conservationists challenged the adequacy of security precau tions at a proposed nuclear power plant in Suffolk County this week resumed hearings of the Atomic Energy Commis sion.

title: Author's Query
description: I would deeply appreciate any reminiscences, information and memorabilia concerning the late American playwright Phil ip Barry (18961949). This pro jected biography of Mr. Barry will be a reevaluation of his place in the history of the American theater.

title: RAMIRO GUERRA, 90, AUTHORSOCIOLOGIST
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP)  Dr. Ramiro Guerra Sanchez, author and sociologist, a former pro fessor at the University of Ha vana, died last night, the Cuban radio reported today. He was 90 years old.

title: OYOLA OF LINCOLN WINS SCHOOL RUN
description: Al Oyola of High was headed for his third staright secondplace finish in the Brooklyn Public Schools cross country race yesterday, when his strategy paid off and he triumphed in the 2.5mile run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: 5 Osteopath Groups Install New Presidents
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 (AP) New presidents for five groups allied with the Amer ican College of Osteopathic Surgeons have been installed.

title: Philympia Souvenir Available
description: THE souvenir card given free to visitors to Phi lympia, the recent in ternational stamp ex hibition in London, is now available at $1 each to Amer ican collectors. Originally, the distribution was to have been an exclusive American gift to visitors at the London show. The Postal Service has a sup ply on hand and will sell these as long as this supply lasts. Orders are limited to five to a customer, payment by check or money order. The normal handling charges for philatelic mail are being waived. Orders must be sent to Philatelic Sales Unit, City Post Office, Washington, D.C. 20013.

title: Coop Residence for Students In Toronto Fights to Stay Open
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31A two yearold experiment in coop erative, highrise housing for young people has been moving closer to a conventional life style in an effort to stave off narcoticssquad raids and finan cial collapse.

title: Nixon Orders a Detailed Draft Of ValueAdded Tax Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The White House has ordered the Treasury department to draft a detailed plan for a value added tax, a type of national sales tax, in the hope of being able to recommend its adop tion next year.

title: AMERICAN HOCKEY LEAGUI
U.S. DEVELOPING INSTANT AIR BASES
description: LANGLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Va.Fighter squadrons of the United States Tactical Air Command now can be de ployed overseas ready for com bat within 72 hours.

title: Junior League Will Present 34 Debutantes
description: Thirty  four provisional members of the New York Junior League will be pre sented at the league's annual Debutante Ball on Thanks giving Eve in the Grand Ball room of the Plaza.

title: The Grail Will Come to Parsifal
description: YOU will be able to see what is going on all the time in the Metro politan Opera's new production of Parsifal, which will be shown for the first time on the night of Nov. 14. That is the promise of Nathaniel Merrill, who is staging it. He speaks for him self and the designer, Robert O'Hearn, with whom he has collaborated on several suc cessful works in the Met's repertory  Aida, Die Meistersinger, Die Frau ohne Schatten, Hansel and Gretel, Der Rosenkavalier.

title: In New York, Looking Ahead to Spaghetti Partoes for Eight...
description: For a while, it looked as if what New York's chic upper echelons call this new mood Might have been nothing more than a variation of the old Marie Antoinette game: the rich tiring of their diamonds andstrictly for the fun of it casting them aside and dressing like the poor. But it goes a lot further than that.

title: Influence of the U.S. Military Is Expected to Wane in Latin America
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  The emergence of leftistori ented regimes in Latin America and the changing character of some LatinAmerican armed forces is expected to reduce the United States military's influ ence on political events in the region.

title: Moroccan Detour At the Whim Of a Scalawag
description: ABDUL, OUR driver, argued nobly with the border police to pass us through from Ceuta, a Spanishowned harbor on the coast of Moroccobut we still had to wait an hour in the sunroasted car. Finally an official slapped a sticker on our windshield and we were off on a day's journey to some inbetween places in Morocco, places too small for a map, too unimportant for a mention in an atlas.

title: French Line Charters 747
description: LE HAVRE, France, Oct. 31 (UPI)The French Line chart ered a Boeing 747 jet today to fly 361 stranded passengers to New York after a strike by touristclass waiters tied up the liner France. The waiter are demanding an hour's extra pay for work after 10 P.M. [The plane reached New York at 9:50 P.M.]

title: Philharmonia Benefit Is Set for Wednesday
description: The women's committee of the Brooklyn Philharmonia, which begins its 17th sub scription season with a per formance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Nov. 21, will hold its annual lun cheon benefit at the Tavern ??ntheGreen on Wednesday.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 (AP)  The New Orleans Saints suspended Andy Livingston run ning back, today for unspecified disciplinary reasons.

title: ROLES OF LIN PIAO GROWING IN CHINA
description: PEKING, Oct. 31The waiter on the train between Shanghai and Nanking was dressed in blue pants, white jacket and red badge, as are most waiters in China.

title: TRADE BY FRANCE WITH HANOI SMALL
description: PARIS, Oct. 31  Lacquered screens, straw mats, wicker baskets, specialty rice em broidery and a very high qual ity of hard coal are some of the products offered French consumers as a result of trade agreements with North Viet nam stretching back to 1955.

title: STUDY CRITICIZES U.S. ON MIGRANT HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Government efforts to help provide decent housing for migrant farm workers have been an almost total failure, a private, nonprofit group said today.

title: Norman Rockwell
description: At first blush there is something vulgar about a onepound album of Norman Rockwell's paintings. But at second blush there is something rath er wonderful about it, as if the Amer ica we remember (or at least like to think we remember) existed after all, unobscured by presentday pol lution, racial conflict and student dissent.

title: Peking and Hanoi Sign Pact
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31 (UPI)Com mu??st China and North Viet nam signed an agreement today covering living standards and working conditions for Chinese technicians working Vietnam, Hsinhua, the official China Press Agency, said in a broad cast monitored here

description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 31 (UPI)  Mike Rasmussen passed for four touchdowns, a school record, to spark Michigan State to a 327 Big Ten victory over Indiana to day.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Fair Campaign Practices Com mittee has told Representative Richard L. Ottinger that it has not been able to verify a com plaint that about 400 voters in the New York City area had been bothered by abusive or latehour telephone calls from persons purporting to represent his senatorial campaign.

title: Paraplegic Seeks Cab Company Operated by the Handicapped
description: A Bronx resident, who say he was refused a hack license because he is a paraplegic who must use crutches, is seeking to organize a taxi company oper ated by physically handicapped persons.

title: VIRGINIA TECH DOWNS W. AND M. BY 3514
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 31 (UPI)Virginia Tech, with Jimmy Quinn, a wingback, scar ing in a pair of touchdowns, linked a powerful ground at tack with a stubborn defense today and defeated William and Mary, 3514.

Negotiations Resume Today Between Guild and Papers
description: Negotiations were scheduled to resume today between the Newspaper Guild and The New York Times and The Daily News in an effort to avert a strike threatened for one of the papers at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: AUSTRALIA TO BUILD NAVAL BASE IN WEST
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 31 The Government has announced a fiveyear plan to build a $40 million naval base on Aus tralia's western coast.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The turmoil of the last year in the United States Bureau of Mines, normally one of the Govern ment's most tranquil regulatory agencies, appears to be sub siding under its new director.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Despite President Nixon's order this week that federally owned vehicles must use unleaded or lowlead gasoline, officials dis closed today that for the next year gasoline purchased by the Government will largely be leaded.

HAPEXAPS 70 (sponsored by the host group, the Hawaiian Philatelic Soci ety), the Bureau of Engraving and Print ing will release a special engraved card featuring designs of three United States stamps that have been identified with Hawaii. The conventionexhibition is sched uled for Nov. 58 at the Ilikai Hotel, Wai kiki, Honolulu.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) The Nixon Administration said today that it would channel educational oportunity grants next year so that col lege students coming from families with the lowest in comes got funds first.

description: GLEN COVE, L. LAt first glance, the large baronial mansion set in the midst of spacious lawns seemed to b?? waiting patiently for horse drawn carriages to deposit guests at a turnofthe century festivity.

Most tourists, unless they are sportsmen or conservationists, whiz along U.S. 264 and pass through this little town on the southern shore of Lake Mattamuskeet unaware of the events that took place here before the Federal Gov enn??ent tamed the area into a wildlife preserve.

description: Miss Jean Goldfrank and Peter E. Bronstein will be married here on Dec. 19.

title: White House Accused on Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  A Senate Foreign Relations sub committee said today that the executive branch engaged in excessive secrecy on foreign agreements to the point of try ing to prevent publication of questions raised by Senators and to censor information al ready made public.

title: Benefits of Campaign TV Vary
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The blessings of campaign televi sion, the politician's favorite medium, are unevenly distrib uted around the country. For all its magic, television is dispro portionately expensive in many areas and virtually unusable in a few.

description: SIDELDICKSTEINMr. and Mrs. Abner Dick stein of Woodmere, N. Y., announce the marriage of their daughter, Helene Ruth, to Mr. Michael Allan Side?, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sidel of Cedarhurst, N. Y., and Hollywood, Fla., on Sunday, Oct. 4, 1970.

title: Coins
description: MARY T. BROOKS, Di rector of the Bureau of the Mint, has an nounced that orders for 1971 proof coin sets are now being accepted by the San Francisco Assay Office. Nov. 1 is the traditional open ing date for the annual of fering.

title: Kathleen Nace, George C. Day Plan to Marry
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 Dr. Paul Foley Nace, pro fessor of zoology at Indiana University, and Mrs. Nace have announced the engage ment of their daughter,. Miss Kathleen Sally Nace, to George Clifton Day, son of Pomeroy Day of Hartford and the late Mrs. Katherine Long Day. The prospective bridegroom is the stepson of Mrs. Day. Both families have summer homes in Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Religion

description: SHAWHarvey and Jill (nee Madison) joy fully announce the birth of Erin Pamela Shaw, on Oct. 19, 1970. The proud grand parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Shaw and Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Madison.

title: Yale Freshmen Are Victors On Late Field Goal, 107
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 31  A 24yard field goal by Brian Clarke late in the final period today gave the Yale freshmen a 107 victory over the Dart mouth freshmen at DeWitt Cuvler field.

title: Art
description: FOR the past month, the University of Kansas Museum of Art, with the support of the Kansas Cultural Arts Commission, has been holding an exhibition of painting by a native son, John Steuart Curry, under the dome of the Kansas State Capitol in Topeka. Finding myself in that part of the country a couple of weeks ago, I went to see it, and I think it is worth, a report even though what the organ izers presumably expected to be a resurrection turns out to be an exhumation and postmortem.

title: Pamela Gail Senor Engaged To George Rene Boltres Jr.
description: Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. J. Edwin Murdock Jr. of Scottsdale, Ariz., formerly of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, of the engagement of Mrs. Murdock's daughter, Miss Pamela Gail Sener, to George Rene Boltres Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Boltres of Forest Hills. A February wedding is planned.

title: CLEAVER SPEAKS
description: Of course, it's frustrating to live in exile. I'd much prefer to be there [in the United. States]. For a while I was at a loss on how to proceed, but with per severance I have been able to do some meaningful work that helps carry on our struggle. All I do is toward the idea of going back, but not to surrender myself to those pigs. My difficulty there is to maintain the positionI had in the past. In the past I said rd go back if my parole was reinstated and if I could go back in bail. But given subsequent developments, with brothers on trial bound and gagged in the courtroom, I find it impossible to relate to the judicial system in the U.S. I feel like the young brothers who went in the courtr??om and offed the judge. That's how black people Should treat the courts in Babylon.

title: What did we do? What did we mean to do?
description: On April 28, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson ordered United States troops into the Dominican Republic, four days after the outbreak of a popular rebellion which toppled the rul ing military junta and sought to replace it with a constitu tional, democratic government. The intervention snatched vic tory from the grasp of the in surgents. It also triggered, both

The question is not academic, as Toni Morrison is an editor with a New York publishing firm, and this is her first novel. She reveals herself, when she shucks the fuzziness born of

title: Plainedge Pins First Setback On Syosset in 18to14 Upset
description: Plainedge shocked Syosset and Locust Valley nearly did the same to Carle place in a major upset and an almost up set that highlighted North Shore football action in Nassau County yesterday.

title: Defying Convention With a Visit to Cadiz
description: CADIZ, SpainThis is one city in the Andalusian region or southwestern Spain that is virtually ignored by travelers. Like Torremolinos, Cadiz has its beaches, shorefront hotels and yacht clubs. Like Seville, it has Its monuments, folklore and fiestas. And yet the reasons for its neglect by travelers are plain enough. For, unlike both its neighbors, Cadiz has unpredictable weather (Spanish tour folders call it complex) and a bustling, businesslike personality. A thriving port and manufacturing center of some 129, 000 inhabitants, the city caters to com merce, not tourism.

title: G.O.P. GAINS LIKELY IN VIRGINIA RACES
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 31With Democratic party ranks in dis array, Virginia is likely to be come the first Southern state since Reconstruction to send Republican  dominated delega tion to the United States House of Representatives.

title: A need to move outward
description: For some years preceding his death this past spring, Tarjei Vesaas was the Norwegian au thor most seriously considered for the Nobel Prize in Litera ture. If this brief novel is too slight to substantiate his claim to that high honor, its classically spare story with its intaglio of powerfully evoca tive symbols would be suffi cient to establish him as a writer of rare imaginative vi tality and perception.

title: HANOI AGAIN BLOCKS VISIT BY INDIAN AIDE
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 31 India has been rebuffed again by North Vietnam in her at tempts to play an intermediary role in Vietnam peace negotia tions.

title: Education
description: An old faculty reverie i?? What a pleasant place a university might be without students. More recently, growing numbers of res tive students have been saying, in effect, that higher education could be greatly improved by ending the need to attend classes. Last week, the head of one of the most influential foun dations told of a plan that could make those dreams come true.

title: ARKANSAS TRIMS TEXAS AGGIES, 456
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 31 (UPI)Bill, Burnett, Arkansas star running back, suffered a careerending Shoul der separation today, but not before he scored three touch downs to lead the Razorbacks to a crushing 456 victory over Texas A. and M.

title: Pons to Retire Dec. 31 From Rockingham Park
description: O. E. (Eb) Pons, the direc tor of racing and chief stew ard of the thoroughbred rac ing at Rockingham Park for many years, will retire Dec. 31. He has held an executive position at Rockingham Park since parimutuel racing was introduced in 1933.

description: WDIA, GOSPEL AND ELVIS

title: Ships Wary of Highjackings, Too
description: Following the lead of hijack wary airlines, passengerships are tightening security at sea despite the fact that only two vessels were hijacked in the last decade.

title: Approaching the Elections
description: WASHINGTON  At an afternoon rally before a sizable student crowd at the University of Tennessee, Sen ator Albert Gore recently declared that Vice President Agnew is our worst disaster since Vietnam. As one man, the students leaped to their feet, cheering and whistling; even Mr. Gore, one of the best stump orators in the country, appeared taken aback by the enthusiastic response to his remarks; and the uproar went on for well over a minute.

title: Miss LisaMargaret Stevenson Is Wed to Alexander C. Sanger
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 Miss LisaMargaret Steven son and Alexander C. Sanger were married tonight in the Princeton University Chapel by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, an Episcopal clergyman.

title: 400 at Albany Rally
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31 (UPI)An estimated 400 young persons staged a peaceful antiwar dem onstration outside the state Capitol here today.

title: Article 7  No Title

description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31In the pastoral hamlets and industrial towns of eastern Con necticut, the election for a Con gressman from the Second Dis trict promises to be a close one, although there is little dissen sion between the two candi dates.

title: A Vacant East Side Lot Becomes Neighborhood Antipollution Unit
description: A dozen children, carrying loads of old bottles, cans and newspapers and wearing signs saying Stop Pollution, helped open a neighborhood antipol lution center in an East Side lot yesterday.

title: Murray Brothers Sparkle for River Dell
description: The Murray brothers, Joe and John, led undefeated River Dell to a 516 victory over Old Tap pan yesterday for its sixth straight success. River Dell paced its eighttouchdown pa rade with two scores each quarter.

title: 30Car Crash in France Kills One and Hurts 19
description: BEAUNE, France, Oct. 31 (AP)One person was killed and 19 were injured early today in a collision involving 30 automobiles near here. The site was a stretch of superhighway opened two days ago by President Pom pidou.

description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 31 Rolling to its highest score of the season, Montclair State opened defense of its New Jer sey State, College Conference championship at Sprague Field tonight by trouncing Trenton State, 470 for its sixth vic tory.

description: GENEVA, Oct. 31  Im proved standards for assuring seamen a better life both aboard ship and in port were adopted by a 65nation mari time conference held here this month by the International La bor Organization. The confer ence ended Friday.

title: Judge Halts DeerHunting At Cease Pond State Park
description: MONROE. N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP) Deerhunting came to an abrupt halt shortly after it be gan at sunrise today In Goose Pond StatePark in this south eastern New York area.

description: Fordham staged a strong secondhalf comeback yesterday to gain a 2121 tie with St. John's before 3,100 fans at the Redmen's stadium.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN BOXING ROBBERY

title: The New Plays
description: PAUL SILLS STORY THEA TER, an entertainment with music, was cheered by seven critics, turned down by one and approved with reservations by one. Clive Barnes: I had a great evening last night at Paul Sills Story Theater. I adored the show, which brings back magic and in nocence to Broadway, raises charades to the strange eminence of an art form, and demonstrates the essen tial theatricality of chil dren's games. Mr. Sills takes some fairy tales from the Brothers Grimm and trans forms them into the eve ning hilarious. The actors have worked out the story, the lines, the action, and it has all been marvelously pulled together by Mr. Sills staging and miraculously reendowed with sponta neity. The eight actors are evenly matched and mar velous. And they are terri bly funny. The evening is rehearsed to a sharp knife edge of perfection, and part of its special joy is the dizzy deftness of the per formers. Go and just enjoy this one. It has no message other than that the thea ter lives and renews itself. Great, unequivocally great.

title: The Chileans Have Elected a Revolution
description: SANTIAGO. THIS Wednesday, Dr. Salvador Allende will become President of Chile in circumstances that promise one of the most tense peri ods in Latin America since the early years of the Cuban Revolution. In the Sept. 4 election, his Unidad Popular  an uneasy, minority coalition of Communists, Socialists, middleclass Radicals and a clutch of miniparties  squeezed out a 1.4 per cent plural ity  fewer than 40,000 votesover conservative exPresident Jorge Ales sandri in a bitter threeway race. (The third candidate, the Christian Demo crats Radomiro Tomic, trailed badly.) The Chilean Constitution requires that Congress choose the new Presi dent from the two leading candi dates if neither wins an absolute majority; theoretically, Congress can choose freely, but a powerful tradi tion has always dictated selection of the frontrunner, and the Congres sional vote on Oct. 24 was no excep tion, making Dr. Allende the first freely elected MarxistLeninist Presi dent of any nation in the world.

title: How Much More Is Still Hidden?
description: ONE FINE DAY around 1880 the beautiful Miss Mary Anderson, then aged about 20 years and already a popular actress, put on a fetching new hat of shirred silk trimmed with pearls and os trich plumes and went to Na poleon Sarony's photographic studio on Union Square to have her picture taken. In those days photographers still had to keep their sitters motionless by clamping them into iron instruments of tor ture, and most photographic portraits were stiff and bug eyed. But Sarony was famous for natural poses and ani mated expressions, and he did Miss Anderson proud. In his study of her delicately classical profile, currently on view in a large and varied show of old photographs at The New York Historical Society, he gave her the de mure and yet provocative expression of a Boucher nymph, and Miss Anderson, who charmed two decades of theatergoers before retir ing at the age of 32, charms us still.

title: Photography
description: COLOGNE. Although the United States participated, with 23 other countries, Germany, the host country, and Japan, dominated the scenemostly with camera and lenses.

title: Architecture
description: ONE of the most fright ening and repellent documents of modern history is high on the best  seller list this fall: Albert Speer's memoirs, In side the Third Reich. Con currently, a small show of architectural sketches from Hitler's own hand and photo graphs of Speer's models based on some of the draw ings are on display at the New York Cultural Center at Columbus Circle through Nov. 8. Reading the book and look ing at the show adds up to a pretty depressing experience.

title: In Rome, Doing As the Romans Don't
description: ROME. THE neighborhood of the American .Academy in Rome, high on the Janiculum hill and far from the noise and crowds of the, modern city, is quiet and green. Umbrella pines, cypress trees and azaleas sur round the scattered build ings. Beyond the whizzing traffic of the nearby San Pancrazio Gate, the neglected gardens of the Villa Doria Pamphili stretch away in a 19th century slumber, remind ing the visitor of Rome as it used to be, and from the rooftop terraces of the Villa Aurelia, the Director's resi dence, a justly celebrated view of ancient domes and monuments spreads out like a picture on a Cinerama screen.

title: George Dethriffe, an uneasy standin for
description: To anyone who came to maturity in the fifties the sen timent of Alfred Moulton, nar rator of the first half of The Great Dethriffe, will ring en gagingly true: without any stylish era to call my own I had become an heir to a previ ous generation's myth, content to keep up appearances until something grander came along. C. D. B. Bryan's point is essentially true: the legend. of F. Scott Fitzgerald, which is more or less the subject of this novel, in many respects had more meaning to us chil dren of the Ike Age than to those of the Jazz Age. Un happily, the novel has not much more to offer than that premise, itself not especially original.

What they're after is a 50 per cent representation in the mam moth, somethingforevery body Whitney Annual, open ing Dec. 12. But black women are in there pitching, too. With the whites support, they demand that half of the 50percentwomen quota be black.

title: Room with bath
description: Many of the most beautiful homes are sadly marred by the drabness, unoriginality or plain discomfort of their bathing arrangements, says internationally known interior designer David Hicks. In his new book, David Hicks on Bathrooms, the designer suggests that a bathroom need not be a mundane, overly antiseptic cubicle, but instead should be thought of as a room offering the freedom of a wide range of decorating possibilities. Why not use paintings or prints, a favorite collection, or a hand some piece of furniture in the bathroom? While the Hicksdesigned bathing parlors on these pages may be too elaborate for everyone's taste and budget, the ideas are adaptable to simpler surroundings.

title: IOWA'S LATE SCORES TIE MINNESOTA, 1414
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 (AP) Tim Sullivan plunged for two fourthperiod touchdowns to day as Iowa overcame a 140 Minnesota lead and tied the Gophers, 1414, in a Big Ten same.

title: Economic Aide for City Named by Mayor Lindsay
description: The appointment of John H. Lotz as Deputy Administrator of the Economic Development Administration was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. He will also serve as Acting Commissioner of the Depart ment of Commerce and Indus try.

title: ART GROUP HOLDS FIRST CONVENTION
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 31With a ??iery manifesto, a reformist platform and plenty of free winging rhetoric, the New Art Association has opened its first national convention on the campus of the State University of New York at Buffalo. It has attracted more than 100 art teachers, historians, curators, graduate students and artists from the United States and Canada who have gathered less ??o celebrate art than to ques sion its role in societythe way it is taught, evaluated and exhibited.

description: FOR MONDAY

description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Recommended New Titles
description: AKENFIELD, by Ronald Blythe. (DellDelta, $2.45.) The realities of contemporary English village life portrayed through the clear voices of a farmer, a saddler, a schoolmaster, a nurse and many others.

description: Qualified voters may take ??ff only such time from their ??obs on Election Day as may ??e necessary to vote, and ??ot more than two hours of ??his need be paid for by the ??mployer.

title: Taking a Trip With Andre and His Alice
description: I AM Alice, announced director Andre Greg ory, tucking a hank of longish brown hair into his fashionably funky nobe ??p and folding himself, yog??style, onto a narrow bench. He didn't look like Alice. He looked more like the metaphysically inclined, hookahsmoking caterpillar in his turnedon version of Alice in Wonderland.

title: Floridians 2dHalf Rally Downs Pacers, 116104
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP)Mack Calvin scored 15 of his 30 points in the third quarter tonight; when the Flo ridians overcame a 5450 half time deficit and went on to whip the Indiana Pacers, 116 104, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Stars Top Rockets, 122113 For Fifth A.B.A. Triump??
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 31 (AP)Donnie Freeman scored 32 point, 20 in the second half, to pace the undefeated Utah Stors to their fifth American Backetball Association victory, 122113 over the Denver Rockets tonight.

title: City to Test New Traffic Restrictions
description: In an effort to cut traffic congestion, airpollution and streetcleaning problems, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a series of parking, stop ping and turning restrictions would be put into effect in sections of midtown Manhattan for two months starting Nov. 9.

title: Schmellers Have Son
description: A son was born on Oct. 19 in Flushing Hospital, Queens, to Dr. and Mrs. Kurt R. Schmeller of Bayside, Queens. Dr. Schmeller is president of Queensborough Community College. Mrs. Schmeller is the former Miss Beata Sowka, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul N. Sowka of Stevens Point, Wis.

title: SHIP LEAVE, $11, FIRST IN TRENTON
Why Is Freaks Still a Great Horror Film?
description: IF it's true, as I think it is, that all narrative movies are to a greater or lesser extent about outsiders, people whom fate and circum stances have placed at odds with their environment or their society, there is a kind of quintessential outside ness about the beings who inhabit horror movies. For Frankenstein's Monster, for Dracula, for werewolves, and for all those creatures called up from the deep, defrosted from an ice cap, or drawn into earth's orbit from outer space, outsideness is a condi tion for which there is no cure but annihilation, which may or may not mean physi cal death.

title: This Is The Battle Of the Titans?
description: ARTHUR J. GOLDBERG looked out of the win dow as his plane left Terre Haute, Ind., where he had received an award from a labor group, and said to no one in particular: You know if I ran for Governor of Indiana, or Iowa, I'd win in a walkbut in New York no one has any respect for anyone.

title: C.H.S.A.A. RUN WON BY POWER MEMORIAL
description: Power Memorial captured its seventh meet in as many out ings this season by winning the crosscountry championship of the New York Archdiocese at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

title: BRUINS WIN BY 60 GAIN TIE FOR FIRST
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31  The Rangers quite suddenly forgot to police the area in front of their net tonight and the power ful Boston Bruins, unmolested, rammed shot after shot past Ed Giacomin and wound up with a 60 victory.

title: NIXON SHARPENS DRIVE ON THUGS
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 31 President Nixon condemned to day those who threw eggs and stones at his limousine in San Jose as a thousand haters, and said the time had come when appeasement of the thugs and hoodlums in American society must end.

title: PUBLIC WORKS AID TO INDIANS EASED
description: RUIDOSO, N.M., Oct. 31  The Nixon Administration has announced a change in its pub lic works policy designed to speed up betterment projects on improverished Indian reser vations.

title: Common Setup For Accounting
description: Professional accounting so cieties of the United King dom, Canada and the United States have moved toward the development of common accounting standards for the three countries, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants has announced.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL SOME CAMPAIGN ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee accused the Committee for a Responsi ble Congress today of using what it called artfully con trived and deceitful newspaper advertisements in an attempt to link some Democratic can didates with extreme and radi cal positions.

title: Liberace Scores a Victory Over U.S. Revenue Service
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Liberace, the pianist, has won a victory over the Internal Revenue Service, which had refused to believe that his Los Angeles home was main tained largely for business purposes.

title: Science
description: In 1818, Percy Bysshe Shel ley, his wife Mary and Lord Byron spent part of a wet summer in Switzerland. To while away the rainy days, Mary wrote a chilling tale about a Swiss scientist who learned how to invert life to a homemade man, formed of parts stolen from mortuaries and dissecting rooms.

title: Law
description: The conclusion is inescap able that the report neither serves nor was intended to serve any purpose, but . . . to ??????bit further speech on college campuses by those listed individuals and others whose political persuasion is not in accord with that of members of the committee.

title: Medicine
description: The black community, increas ingly healthconscious, has been sounding the alarm for some time that sickle cell anemia is one of the most neglected health problems in America today. Last week, an article and an edi torial in the Journal of the American Medical Association brought this argument to the at tention of the medical profession.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE??; Sportswear For Men Sells Well As Suits Decline
description: Men's sportswear, as dif ferentiated from men's tail ored clothing, is a booming business. At least there was an optimistic mood prevail ing at the annual show of the National Outerwear and Sportswear Association in New York last week. It was a mood in sharp contrast to that of many manufacturers in the men's suit and over coat industry.

title: Japanese Cosmetics vs. U.S.
description: American women spend some $2billion a year on beauty preparations ranging from mascara to skin cream, most of which is manufac tured by American com panies. Now a Japanese com pany, Shiseido, plans to move into this market.

title: Utah's Dead Sea' Alive and Well Again After. Years of Neglect
description: GREAT SALT LAKE, UtahAfter three decades of neglect, the West's dead sea is alive and well once again, at tracting bathers, boaters, campers and sightseers in force. To help effect the rehabilitation of Utah's Great Salt Lake, approximately $1million has been spent on land acquisition, road  building and beach reclamation, and a sizable, state park has been opened on the Great Salt Lake's Antelope Island.

title: Airlines vs. C. A.B.
description: Government's dual role as both stern monitor and ben eficial guardian of regulated industries  always an un easy, blend in America's mixed economy  appears headed for a critical test in the case of the nation's air line service.

title: Syrian Party Session Opens After Delay of Four Days
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31 (Reuters)After a fourday de lay, a special congress of lead ers of the Baath, or Arab So cialist party, opened yesterday in Damascus to discuss who will lead Syria.

title: Holt Guides Unbeaten Andover To a 35to6 Rout of Deerfield
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 31 Andover's Milt Holt gave Deer field a lesson in how to throw a football today. The quarter back had an outstanding day as he led the visitors to their fifth straight victory, a 356 trounc ing of the home team.

title: Organized Crime Is Growing in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Underworld leaders here have a reputation for dealing summarily with their enemies, and the result has created a political issue.

title: G.M. Key: Getting It All Together
description: DETROITGetting it all together is the key to a set tlement of the strike at the General Motors Corporation.

title: STONITSCH FIRST IN RUN AT ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Oct. 31Ron Ston itsch of C. W. Post College won the varsity division of the fourth annual State University at Albany crosscountry run today in the record time of 24 minutes 51.5 seconds for the five miles.

title: TOLEDO WINS, 1413, FOR 19TH STRAIGHT
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 31 (UPI) Chuck Ealey, Toledo's quar terback. scored the decisive touchdown late in the game to day to give the Rockets their 19th straight victory, a 1413 triumph over Miami of Ohio and Toledo's second straight bid to the Tangerine Bowl as MidAmerican Conference cham pion.

title: Jane Lewis Wed to Robert Melito
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 Miss Jane Sherman Lewis and Robert Michael Melito were married here this after noon in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill.

title: Celtics Conquer 76ers, 133102 After Scoring 74 Points in the Second Half
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (UPI)John Havlicek poured in 33 points tonight as the Boston Celtics spurted in the second half for a 133102 vic tory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball As sociation game.

title: Football Scores
description: East East

title: Churchill Foundation Elects
description: Lady SpencerChurchill, widow of Sir Winston Churchill, and Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower have been elected honorary trustees of the United States Churchill Foundation, and Win ston Churchill, grandson of Sir Winston, has been elected a trustee. The foundation pro motes cooperation between sci entists in the United States and Britain on student, teacher and research levels.

title: Longboat Key: Sanctuary for Man and Beast
description: LONGBOAT KEY, Fla.  Drive west on the Ringling Causeway from down town Sarasota, turn right at a dollop of overpriced shops on St. Armands Key and head north on State Route 789. Sweep across a concreteandsteel draw bridge draped with aging fishermen decked out in loud shirts, short pants and anxious expressions.

title: Housing Woes Dim Hopes of City
description: New York has a housing problem that has a wretched persistence. Farther down on this page appears an article published in Harper's New Monthly Magazine 88 years ago. Change a dollar figure here and there and the article could have been written last week.

title: Texas Wins No. 26, Beats S.M.U., 4215
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 31 Steve Worster ran for four touchdowns and set three school scoring records today as he led Texas to a 42 15 victory over Southern Metho dist. The triumph extended the nation's longest winning streak to 26 games.

title: Sculpture Found In a Rag Factory
description: OF ALL the dizzy new things that have been happening in art late ly, the trend in sculp ture sometimes (inadequate ly) called Informal is prob ably the most vigorous and disconcerting, and a sofar unadvertised new gallery at 112 Greene Street that is showing works by eight art ists more or less in the canon is fittingly perhaps the oddest art showplace in town. Dingi ly lighted, with crumbling walls and rugged floors, the huge ground floor and base ment premises of this name less, casually organized en terprise (in a building owned by one of the artists) cur rently hold pieces of which some are scarcely dis tinguishable from the ruined fixtures of what used to be a ragpacking factory and warehouse. The works were created in and for the spaces they occupy, sometimes with materials scavenged in or around the building, and all but a few are doomed to destruction when the show comes down.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: MERGER PACE QUICKENS. American Airlines and Western Airlines said they were holding merger discus sions. Acquisition agreements were announced by Squibb BeechNut and LanvinCharles of the Ritz . . . American Brands and Andrew Jergens . . . Transnation Development and Madison Square Garden, which also plans bid for mi nority interest in Roosevelt Raceway . . . Northwest Indus tries agreed to buy Buckingham Corporation, distributor of Cutty Sark Scotch whiskey, from Schenley . . . The New York Times will acquire several properties from Cowles Communications, Inc., including Family Circle mag azine, three Florida daily newspapers, a Memphis television station, a group of medical magazines and a textbook pub lisher; Cowles will retain Look magazine. . . . Time, Inc., agreed to sell four television stations and six radio sta tions to McGrawHill.

title: Du Pont Is Using Pollution Issue In His Race for Delaware Seat
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 30 Name recognition is no prob lem for Pierre S. du Pont 4th in his first contest for elective office.

title: blueblack and bruised
description: Ireland, you might think, has been drained to its last literary drop. Yet here is Sean O'Faolain, stepping out of the familiar and maybe dear old place where the bogland white cot tages have small windows like pigs eyes and where the river Liffey still acts like a charm. Saint Killian's Col lege at Coonlahan, the Glasnevin cemetery, Phoenix Park, Father O'This and Father O'That, divil a thoughteven a bejasus or two does not come amiss on the regular scenic tour. The Irish may grow writers the way other people grow beans, but they do have a price to pay for it.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: IN AN economic sense, the elections of 1970 may carry highly significant implications for future national policy. At the moment, the economy re mains, as Paul W. McCracken, the Persident's chief economic adviser, remarked a few days ago, in a state of suspended animation. With no signs of an immi nent settlement of the sevenweek General Motors strike, it will continue that wayrather quiescent for some time.

title: Miss Nixon Stumps for Taft
description: PARMA, Ohio, Oct. 31 (UPI) Miss Tricia Nixon stumped today for Representative Rob ert Taft Jr., Republican candi date for the Senate and a long time friend of her father. The President's older daughter came to the Parma town shopping center in a threecar motor cade. She was flanked by Mr. Taft and Representative Wil liam E. Minshall, a Republican candidate for reelection.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt is no great pleasure for this ob server to blow a whistle on the Nixon Administration Council of Economic. Advis ers, nor, Indeed, on the Ad ministration's economic pol icy. A very strong case ca?? be made that the policy ha?? been right, and that it can work in its goal of checking inflation.

title: Panel Asks Wide Reform Of College Board Exams
description: A special study group ap pointed by the College Entrance Examination Board, in a report made public yesterday, has ac cused the board's national test ing program of focusing mostly on the interests of colleges while failing to serve the in terests of many students.

description: WHEN we first told our 5 old son that he would soon have a brother or sis ter, Paul said, I'd rather have dog. And one of his contempora ries, upon seeing her new brother for the first time, suggested, Send it back to the hospital.

description: Dr. Joseph H. Diamond, a specialist in internal medicine and a former president of the Richmond County Medical So ciety, died Friday of cancer at his home, 45 Grymes Hill Road, Grymes Hill, S.I. His age was 73 and his office was at 195 Westervelt Avenue, New Brigh ton.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 31 (AP) Craig Barry kicked a 20yard field goal with no time remain ing today to keep seventh ranked Air Force unbeaten and defeat the University of Ari zona, 2320.

C., Oct. 31 (UPI)  A sophomore quarter back, Eddie McAshan, connect ed with Brent Cunningham for a 49yard touchdown pass to go ahead in the third period and Stan Beavers dashed 75 yards with an intercepted pass with 49 seconds to go for an insurance score as Georgia Tech downed Duke, 2416, today.

title: DOCTORS IN ROME GET TAX CHECKUP
description: ROME, Oct. 31City Hall is subjecting the entire medical profession to a checkup in the wake of a survey indicating that only three out of every 10 Roman doctors were paying reasonable taxes.

description: BOGENMax. In fond and loving memory of a beloved husband, adored father, darling poppy, November 3, 1969.

description: The Brooklyn College rifle team, led by Todd Berman's 263, defeated Pratt Institute Fri day night, 1,029935.

title: Books:
description: Fashions in business books change almost as fast as skirt lengths, but in a more meaningful way. A few years ago when short skirts were in, so were books on short cuts aimed at making money quickly in common stocks. Now that skirts are longer and many attitudes more conservative, some financial books are taking a long, se rious look at inflation.

title: Brockport Eleven Wins
description: BROCKPORT, N.Y., Oct 31 (UPI) Steve Lashbrook ran for two touchdowns today and Brockport State College put on a rugged defense to blank Bridgewater (Mass.) State, 260.

title: BUCKLEY BUOYED BY WESTCHESTER
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 31 With Mario A. Procaccino and John J. Marchi, the two un successful candidates for Mayor of New York City last year, teaming to enliven crowds for him, James L. Buckley spoke at a series of flagfluttering rallies in the Westchester County sub urbs today.

title: IDLE DICE TAKES JUMPERS CROWN
description: WASHINGTON., Oct. 31 Idle Dice went fast and flaw lessly over the nine fences of a jumpoff course to win the leaping competition of the Washington International Horse Show tonight. The 6 yearold roan gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gill of Collegeville, Pa., was the only open juniper to make jumpoff otherwise dominated by mounts of the international teams Rodney Jenkins his rid er, was the only professional.

title: Unbeaten Ossining Rallies to Conquer Port Chester, 2117, for 7th Victory

title: Susan Lauzon Bride of R. J. Brown 3d
description: BERNARDSVILLE. N. J., Oct. 31  The marriage of Miss Susan Ruth Lauzon to ??chard Joshua Brown 3d took place here today in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. John R. Torney per formed the ceremony.

description: NEWBURGH, Oct. 31What started out as a clearcut race between a conservative Repub lican and a liberal Democrat in the traditionally conserva tive 27th Congressional District in the Hudson Valley area has turned into a clouded, hard fought campaign.

title: Ziegfeld Club to Dance
description: The 33d annual Ziegfeld Club charity ball will be held on Friday at the Pierre. The event, which will include a cocktail reception at 7 P.M. and dinner at 8:30 P.M. in the Grand Ballroom, aids the club's charitable and hu manitarian work for women of the entertainment world. Tickets at $30 each are avail able from the club at 55 West 42d Street.

title: Anniversaries
description: LYMANMr. and Mrs. Aaron. Happy 68th wedding anniversary. May you live to have many more, together with your children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. In good health.
