description: About 15 years ago the ad vertising manager for a ma jor department store was the talk of the business with her sparkling, creative and ef fective advertisements. Ad dressing the New York Finan cial Advertising Association she described financial ad vertising as dull, unimagin ative, outofdate, dismal and so forth.

title: 60,820 See Indians Gain Sixth Triumph
Political Strengths Emphasized on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 31 Two themesRepublican part nership at all levels of govern ment in Nassau County and the need to preserve the twoparty system in the countyare the basic differences separating the major candidates in the contest for County Executive.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: President Nixon's first do mestic priority on assuming of??ice was to temper exces sive inflationary pressures while avoiding a recession. Now there are some signs that prices are rising less rapidly and that the economy is beginning to pick up steam (adjusting for the General Motors strike). Yet, the cost of the Administration's pol icy of economic restraint in terms of unemployed re sources has been consider ably higher than originally planned.

title: Author's Query
description: We are collecting for publi cation the letters of our late father, Charles A. Beard (1874 1948), American historian and political scientist, and would be grateful for any letters or infor mation bearing on his life and work.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES TO CORNELL, 3120
description: Cornell's football team bounced back from a 130 defi cit in the first quarter yester day to beat Columbia, 3120, in an exciting game at Baker Field.

title: THIEU SAYS PEACE CAN'T BE OBTAINED AT TALKS IN PARK
description: SAIGON, Oct. 31President Nguyen Van Thieu declared to day that the Communists had no intention of negotiating a settlement of the Vietnam war unless they were assured of total domination of the country.

title: Growing Trend: Paychecks Shrink
description: A few weeks ago John Hansen, a 44yearold Mas sachusetts business manager, told his teenage daughter Karen that she would have to forego her weekly $5 rid ing lesson at the local stable.

title: Tuition Raised at Williams
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP)Williams College has announced that it will increase tuition by $100 to $2,350 begin ning next September. The school also said it would in crease room and board charges $80, to $1,330.

title: Jewish Congress Reporting On Conditions in Sovie??
description: The American Jewish Con gress has set up a hot line telephone number for the dis semination of current Informa tion on the Jewish community in the Soviet Union.

title: Environment
description: WASHINGTONA decade ago, an outpost of scientists in the Antarctic studying the physiology of penguins made a discovery that amazed them. Residues of DDT insecticide were found in the fatty tis sues of the birds, even though they lived thousands of miles from the nearest farm.

title: New Nuclear Spiral
description: Strategic theories that only recently were thought discredited and that would require a tremendous further missile buildup seem to be reviving in Washington. The stimulus comes from a highlevel nuclear study, coupled with pessimism over the strategic arms limita tion talks (SALT) with Russia, which resume in Helsinki tomorrow.

title: Resumed Rise in Home Costs Seen
description: MIAMI BEACHThe cost of new homes in the United States is likely to resume its rise next year, in the judg ment of mortgage bankers, Government officials and others who attended a con ference here last week. The recent loosening of mortgage money is considered likely to be shortlived.

title: Tamarack Flames
description: Most people call them tamaracks or hackmatacks, names that have obscure Indian origins. Some call them larches, from the Latin larix, though that name is more common in the West. Whatever you call them, they are the most striking conifers in the woodland, particularly in late autumn. They are rare conifers, to be sure, being deciduous; but before those needles fall they turn the color of bright, burnished brass, just a shade darker than gold. A tamarack in the woodland now, with so many of the other trees naked by November and the tamarack slow to shed, is like a goldentan candle flame, luminous and spectacular.

title: COLONELS SET BACK NETS FIVE, 113100
description: LOUIS VILE Ky., Oct. 31 (AP)  Kentucky's rookie center, Dan Issel, scored 33 points to night in leading the Colonels to a 113100 victory over the New York Nets.

title: The Last Of the Giants
description: During his long and distinguished career as a newspaperman, C. L. Sulzberger has always be lieved that men are more important in history than things, and, in looking for answers to the com plicated problems of foreign affairs that have plagued our times, he has always sought out the principal actors in the world drama. What they have told himand they have generally talked with a freedom that is more a tribute to his ability to win their confidence and his skill as an interviewer than to their being, as he modestly suggests, dominated by some conversational afflatushe has methodically copied down in notebooks that were originally designed not for publication but as sources of in formation for his reports to The New York Times and, after 1954, for his column Foreign Affairs. As time passed, items in these books that once seemed confidential lost that character, and this removed the principal reason for keeping the diary private. Mr. Sulzberger decided therefore to publish it in three volumes, and when the first of them appeared last yearA Long Row of Candles, cov ering the years from 1934 to 1954it was imme

title: W. Michigan's 592 Yards Crush Ohio U. by 5223
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 31 (UPI)Western Michigan, with Ted Grignon passing for three touchdowns, rolled to a school record of 592 yards in total of fense today in a 5223 rout of MidAmerican Conference rival Ohio University.

title: Lois E. Gilfillan, Air Stewardess, Becomes Bride
description: WARREN, Pa., Oct. 31  Miss Lois Ellen Gilfillan, ?? hostess for Pan American World Airways, and Charles William Garrison 3d, a public relations officer for Bom bardier, Ltd., of Montreal, snowmobile manufacturers, were married here today in the Grace Methodist Church. The Rev. Wayne B. Price per formed the ceremony.

title: Article 9  No Title
A year of madness, a mix of opposites
description: When Police Inspector Roger Ga voury stepped into the darkened apartment and saw the pale, astral glow of the pity beyond, he had sudden presentiment of danger. . . Something stirred behind him; three shadows pressed forward in the room, hemming him in as he tried to turn. He shouted for help just before the board smashed down on his head and fingers wrapped themselves ex pertly around his throat. The blade leaped out like a Sliver of light and drove at his heart, once and once again.

title: Burton, With Total of 1,418, Leads Bowling in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31Nelson Burton Jr., of St. Louis, already the winner of four Profession al Bowlers Association tourna ments this year, was off to a strong start today in quest of his fifth title.

title: Senate Candidates Differ In Their Appeal to Voters
description: The findings of The New York Times/Yankelovich Sur vey indicate that interviewed voters favoring Senator Charles E. Goodell are impressed with their man's personal character; voters favoring Representative Richard L. Ottinger like him for his general liberal Democratic positions, and voters favoring James L. Buckley are attracted by his attitudes relating to law and order.

title: Syracuse Trounces Pittsburgh, 4313
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 31 Syra cuse, given little chance for even a .500 season two months ago, ran, passed and tackled its way into the bowl picture today with an impressive 4313 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Chess
description: A RECORD 60 countries competed in the recent 19th chess Olym piad in Siegen, West Germany. Many of the players represented remote lands, unknown even to Caissa's experts and some had not ever played in an international event.

title: A New Home for Miami's Booming Fleet
description: MIAMIWhen Florida's new $3million marina was unveiled here recently with in a stone's throw of the city's tallest skyscrapers, stones figuratively began to fly in the way of criticism.

title: Consciousness IV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Life is for ever playing cruel jokes on us Con sciousness IV people, and who can blame it? We of Consciousness IV must be an infuriating bunch, even to an abstraction so detached as Life, with our apparently limitless ability to roll with a cruel joke and come back shrugging.

title: STUDENTS IN POLL BACK ARMY DUTY
description: A nationwide survey of 25,000 high school students has found that 43 per cent say they would volunteer for two years of mili tary service if the pay was in creased and the draft ended.

title: Nebraska Subdues Colorado, 29 to 13, For 7th Triumph
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 31 (AP)  Nebraska overcame stubborn Colorado, 2913, to day in a Big Eight Conference football game televised to much of the nation.

title: Births
description: BERGERDr. and Mrs. Dirk M. (nee Bran denburg) joyfully announce the birth of their son, Matthew Adam, on Oct. 20, 1970. Proud grandparents are Mrs. Mat thew H. Brandenburg and Mr. and Mrs. Murray Berger of New York City and greatgrandmother, Mrs. Rose Cohen of Long Beach, N. Y.

title: Black Fraternity to Honor 41 African Ambassadors
description: The New York Alumni Chap ter of Kappa Alpha Psi Frater nity will honor the 41 African Ambassadors to the United Nations at its 39th annual Kappa Kostume Karnival, Fri day, Nov. 27. The affair will be held at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle.

title: For Young Readers
description: This is ridiculous . . . sitting here in front of a typewriter for three hours . . . and nothing . . . not a word. Oh, I've written a few things . . . letters, paid some bills, picked accumulated gook out of the letter o on my typewriter with a pin . . . but the review . . . nothing.

title: Money Is a Scarce Commodity For Many Underdog Candidates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31If Pat Driscoll had a thousand dollars, he could pass around some leaflets in Michigan's 12th Congressional District this weekend to let the voters know he's opposing Represent ative James G. O'Hara.

title: Deborah H. Oakley Wed in Manhasset
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 31Miss Deborah Hunting ton Oakley and Kenneth Mar tin Bodner, who were gradu ated last spring from the State University in New Paltz, were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frank Johnston.

title: Mobutu Is Only Candidate In Congo Presidential Vote
description: KINSHASA, Congo, Oct. 31 (AP)Two days of voting for president began in this former Belgian colony today. The only candidate is the incumbent President, Gen. Joseph D. Mo butu.

title: Carol A. MacIntire Plans Marriage
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 31  Mr. and Mrs, Rob ert S. Maclntire have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann Maclntire, to Clark, Ed ward Tucker 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tucker Jr. of Kan sas City. Kan.

title: Hammer Found in Death of Teacher
description: The police were reported yesterday to have the hammer with which Patrice Leary was bludgeoned on Thursday when she was slain in her apartment at 310 West 73rd Street.

title: Desperation so quiet it's unconscious
description: Vance Bourjaily belongs to an un fortunate group of, American novel ists who have been for too many years, like Leopold Bloom, almosting it. Generally favorable reviews, an occasional thin analytic article, an alphabetical listing in an index of promising postwar fictionwriters. Their names are familiar, all honor able craftsmen: Wright Morris, Cal der Willingham, Walker Percy, Fred erick Buechner, James Drought, Herbert Gold. Too often their talents are referred to as foils for larger reputations like those of Malamud, Bellow, Styron, Capote.

title: Dog Show Stewards Labor for Love
description: The unsung hero of the dog show world is the steward.

title: AN OLD CITY LIES SILENT IN JORDAN
description: PETRA, Jordan, Oct. 31 (UPI) The rosered city of Petra, an awesome collaboration be tween man and nature, is sink ing back into the silence that enveloped it for centuries.

title: A Bogart to Go, Please
description: ACCORDING to the vireo visionaries, a typical eve ning in front of the TV set in 1975 should go something, like this. In the living room, Dad peruses a shelf stocked with dozens of small, square boxes and selects one labeled The Maltese Falcon. He opens the box andremoves a cassette (a plateshaped cart ridge containing film or videotape), slips it through a slot in a briefcasesized unit attached to the top of his TV set, fiddles with some knobs and then settles back to enjoy his favorite golden oldie.

title: Vatican Journal Scores Press in Coast Killings
description: ROME, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Vatican magazine L'Osserva tore della Domenica said this week that press reaction to the Santa Cruz massacre in California indicated that hip pies were the object of a witch hunt.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SINGAPORE FIGHTS DIRT AND SMOKE
description: SINGAPORE, Oct 31 (AP) A man who flips a cigarette butt onto the street in Singa pore faces a $165 fine. This is an indication of an antidirt and antipollution campaign that works.

title: U.S.C. Is Upset, 1310
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (UPI) Randy Weisching booted a 46yard field goal, the longest of his career, in capping a 10 point outburst in the fourth period today as California up set the University of Southern California, 1310, in a Pacific8 football game.

title: Young Stars for Kings Poin
description: KINGS POINT, L. 1., Oct. 31 (AP)  Bob Young, a freshmar halfback, ran for a team record of 182 yards and scored, tw?? touchdowns, leading Kings Point to a 2714 victory today over Hobart.

title: HIJACKED JET HELD IN CUBA 20 HOURS
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP)  A National Airlines jet was hi jacked to Havana last night, but Cuban red tape kept it there for 20 hours. The delay, the plane's captain said today, was made so we had to take off in darkness and couldn't see something they don't want us to see.

title: Sharon A. Long Engaged to Wed Jerry G. Strong
description: HANOVER, N. J., Oct. 31 The engagement of Miss Sharon Anne Long to Dr. Jerry G. Strong, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vilo G. Strong of Mount Pleasant, Tex., has been announced by the fu ture bride's mother, Mrs. Thomas H. Long of Hanover. A wedding is planned for March.

title: NEW LINDSAY PLAN ALTERS PRIORITIES FOR CAPITAL FUND
description: Mayor Lindsay proposed top priorities yesterday far sanita tion, schools and transit in the city's construction plans for the next budget year starting July 1.

title: Floating Cafe Due To Open in Summer In the East River
description: A floating restaurant is to be constructed in the East River close to the Manhattan shore line at 30th Street and should be open by next summer, the city's Department of Ports and Terminals reported yesterday.

title: Texas Tech Tops Rice, 30, On 3dQuarter Field Goal
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Dickie Ingram kicked a 43yard field goal in the third quarter tonight to give Texas Tech, a 30 victory over punchless Rice.

title: OKLAHOMA BEATS IOWA STATE, 2928
description: AMES, Iowa, Oct. 31 (UPI) Joe Wylie punched over for 16yard touchdown today with just over 2 minutes left in the game, and Greg Pruitt followed with a 2point conversion to give Oklahoma a 2928 Big EightConference triumph over Iowa State.

title: Penn State Routs West Virginia, 428, Scoring Twice in First Six Minutes
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 31 (UPI)Mike Smith's 75yard punt return and a blocked punt by Gary Hull set up two touch downs today in the first six minutes and Penn State, be hind a brilliant defense, crushed West Virginia. 428.

title: TENNESSEE BEATS WAKE FOREST, 417
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 31 (UPI) Steve Wold, a reserve fullback, scored two of three. Tennessee touchdowns in a 5minute in terval today to lead the Volun teers to a 417 victory over Wake, Forest.

title: Down and Out Along Route 128
description: LEXINGTON, Mass. ARNOLD LIMBERG, Wayne Lees, Phil Blum and David Gernes don't know each other, but they should, for they have much in common. They are all scientists or engineers who live within a few miles of each other in Lexington, Mass., a prosperous, well  groomed suburb of Boston. They are all married, with two children, two cars and comfort able homes. To the extent that salary represents any measure of a technical man's worth, they are all competent, successful men, who until recently were earning more than $15,000 a year. This year, they all acquired a new experience in commonthey've been fired.

title: 1,000 in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (UPI)About 1,000 young peo ple marched to the city's Civic Center today to demonstrate their opposition to the war in Vietnam and President Nixon.

title: Late RadioTV Listings for Today
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section

title: Town Will Rise on Seine Near Rouen
description: PARIS, Oct. 28  France is preparing to build a city de signed from underground up to be as free from pollution and noise as modern technology will permit.

title: THE BIG TEN OFF BROADWAY
South African Blacks Protest at Train Crash
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 31 (Reuters) Policemen armed with sub machine guns today broke up an infuriated crowd of black Africans at the scene of a rail crash in which 13 black work ers were killed and more than 100 injured.

title: HARRY L. BLOOMBERG
description: Harry L. Bloomberg, an oil industry executive, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 940 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Louisville Triumphs, 1413
description: LOUISVILLE, Oct. 31 (AP) Louisville's secondstring quar terback, Gary Inman, left the bench for one play in the fourth quarter and fired a 10yard Scoring pass to Cookie Brink man as the Cardinals edged Kent State, 1413, tonight. Scott Marcus added the conversion for the winning point.

title: Bowdoin Foils Bates
description: LEWISTON, Me., Oct. 31 (AP)  John Benson tossed a pair of touchdown passes and the Bowdoin defense held Bates to a field goal today as Bow doin won, 21.3, to capture its third state football title in a row.

title: Miss Wade Wins Net Final From Mrs Jones in Wales
description: PORT TALBOT, Wales, Oct. 31 (Reuters)  Virginia Wade scored her second victory in a week over her old rival, Mrs. Ann Jones, in winning the wom en's singles final, in the Dewar Cup tennis tournament here to day, 63, 16, 75.

title: Columbia, Led by Chamma, Tops Cornell in Soccer, 51
description: Omar Chamma scored two goals and made one assist to lead Columbia to a 51 victory over Cornell in an Ivy League soccer match at Baker Field yesterday.

title: Port Chester Teacher Resists Denial of Tenure
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 31The refusal of the Board of Education here to grant tenure to a junior high school teacher has brought widespread pro tests from those who contend that the reason for the board's action was Political.

title: Taiwan Is Festive As Chiang Observes His 83d Birthday
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 31 Once a year a presidential order from Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek is disobeyed. The President, who became 83 years old today, calls annually on the Government and the public not to observe his birth day with undue fanfare, but every Oct. 31 schools and public offices are closed as the nation pays its respects to him.

title: Costa Ricans Assail Proposals On Milk Prices and a Synthetic
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 31 (UPI)A proposed 2cent increase in the price of milk and suggestions that some milk be replaced by a substance called Incaparina  an almost tasteless proteinenriched flour have become major problems for President Jos Figueres Ferrer.

title: DR. F. H. VAN WINKLE
description: AVON, N. J., Oct. 31Dr. Franklin H. Van Winkle, a den tist in Newark for more than 50 years, died Thursday at a nursing home in Neptune. His age was 86.

title: Bay Shore Sets Back Sachem; Port Jefferson Tops Greenport
description: Bay Shore, its back against the wall in the Suffolk League Two race, upset Sachem, 2220, yesterday to retain a chance for a fifth straight league championship.

title: CONCESSION RENTALS RAISED AT PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) The Government has told the Defense Department to give the Treasury a greater share of rental receipts from conces sionaires that now finance everything from influenza shots to bowling tournaments for Pentagon employes.

title: The making of an American folk hero
description: On Sunday night, Oct. 16. 1859, a band of 22 men seized the Federal arsenal and armory at Harper's Ferry, Va. John Brown's raid, although a mil itary failure, transformed its leader into an American folk hero, who was immediately im mortalized in song and legend.

title: Paperbacks
description: FICTION

title: Sisterhood Lunch Set
description: The Sisterhood of the Brooklyn Jewish Center will give its annual luncheon Thursday at the center, 667 Eastern Parkway in Brook lyn. Tickets for the event are $12.50 and may be obtained from Mrs. William Sauler at the center.

title: Hofstra Downs Bridgeport On Burst by Knaus, 2015
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31  Dave Knaus ran 13 yards for the winning touchdown to cap an 89yard drive tonight that gave Hofstra a 2015 vic tory over Bridgeport.

title: EXHIBITIONS
description: MUSEUM OF MODERN ART11 West 53d Street. East 100th Street. Photos by Bruce Davidson of a block of East Harlem. Through Nov. 29. Also: Stories by Duano Michals, through Dec. 6.

title: Boutique at Gotham To Aid Camp NYDA
description: The junior division of the Camp NYDA Service Group has arranged its 10th annual boutique at the Gotham Hotel for three days starting next Sunday. The first day will be a champagne party, for which tickets will be $5 each. On the other days admission will be $1.

title: Edinboro 170 Victor
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 31 (AP)  Edinboro State dropped Central Connecticut from the unbeaten ranks in college football today by shut ting out the Blue Devils, 170.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONMore than most, the 1970 state and Congres sional elections are coming to an end in a blaze of uncertainty. No doubt reflecting the unset tled state of the economy and of much of American society, cam paigns from Vermont to Califor nia appeared in the last week to be close individually and to form no pattern generally.ANDREW H. MALCOLM

title: Joseph B. Martinson, 69, Dead; Art Patron Led Coffee Concern
description: Joseph B. Martinson, a leader in the city's cultural activities and former head of Martin son's Coffee, Inc., died Friday of a leg infection in Singapore while on a trip. He was 59 years old and lived at 200 East 57th Street. He also had homes in CrotononHudson, N.Y., and in Puerto Rico.

title: The Nixon Poems
description: Eve Merriam has very little to say about fields of golden daffodils in this bitterly witty collection of poems, fables, checklists, free associations, communiqus and firebombs of pure outrage. But her subject, after all, is demoralized, de humanized, Nixonized America, and it doesn't much make for pretty panoramas. In the cities people walk the streets with guns and terror, and in The Peaceable Kingdom of the sub urbs the tidy housewife mur ders her 2yearold child. A wistful letter to the editor re calls those happy oldtime riots when they burned and stoned and stayed mainly in the fara way part of town. Meanwhile back at the White House, our President reassuringly pro claims, I lead the crusade against noise pollution by de claring the silent majority.

title: Walter Kerr on Saved
description: I THINK the British work ing classes should ask for equal time. They have been much used of late, in novels and films, and plays, and as is certainly the case with Edward Bond's Saved the dinginess of their lives, noisy bedsprings and long woolen underwear and broken teapots and all, has been recorded with what must be enormous fidelity. It is probably also recorded with what is meant to be pity; when a character, a sure loser, says, This is the life, you are to understand that in fact this is no life at all.

title: Maine Beats Northeastern On LastSecond Touchdown
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP)  With one second re maining, the Maine quarter back, Henry Hastings, threw a 35yard touchdown pass to Dave Paul today that defeated Northeastern, 2417.

title: Trupia Gets 3 Touchdowns As Post Tops Adelphi, 4112
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct 31 The C. W. Post Pioneers racked up a total of 462 yards in defeating Adelphi University, 4112, today at Stiles Field.

title: Road Race of Champions Draws 400 Drivers to Georgia Site
description: It may be stretching your criteria a bit to accept the promotional ballyhoo that a roster of 400 drivers makes the seventh annual American Road Race of Champions the world's largest race, but you would be safe in considering it one of the best shows in racing.

title: Wesleyan Final Play Score Defeats Hamilton, 25 to 22
Senior Reserve Leads Georgia To 5234 Rout of So. Carolina
description: ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 31 (UPI) Paul Gilbert, a hometown senior who has spent most of his college career on the bench, took over at quarterback today midway through the second period with his team 18 points behind and led the Georgia Bulldogs to a 5234 victory, over South Carolina.

title: St. John The Baptist Deals Holy. Cross 2116 Setback
description: St. John The Baptist, after leading by 140 at the half, staved off a Holy Cross rally to gain a 2116 victory in a Long Island Division Catholic High School Football League game yesterday.

title: Mexicans Coming Nov. 11
description: The Mexicans Are Coming, a variety show from Mexico City, including 68 dancers, singers, musicians and comedi ans, will open at the Mark Hel linger Theater on Nov. 11 in stead of Wednesday. Produced by Umberto Cecchi, the enter tainment features Luis Gascon, Ema Pulido, Luis Elliot, Miguel Alberto, the Tex Mex Trio and Daniel Armas.

title: Austria Weighs a Parley On Relations With Peking
description: VIENNA. Oct. 31 (AP)For eign Minister Rudolf Kirch s??hlger said today that Austria might establish diplo matic relations with Commu nist China.

title: Bridgeport Wins in Soccer
description: TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 31  The University of Bridgeport soccer team defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, 41, today in a game in which Lutz Hoemke, the Fairleigh Dickinson goalie, suffered a broken arm in the second period.

title: 1940 Offer by Churchill To Ireland Is Disclosed
description: LONDON, Oct. 31Prime Minister Churchill pledged in 1940 that Britain would work for the reunification of Ire land if the republic would give up its neutrality and join the war against Ger many, according to a book to be published here on Monday.

title: President Frei, in Farewell Address, Urges Chileans to Defend Democracy
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 President Eduardo Fre?? Montal va, a Christian Democrat, who will hand over power on Tues day to Dr. Salvador Allende, a Marxist, called today on the moral energy and courage of Chileans to defend democracy here.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: F.A.A. May Require Crash Signal Device On All Light Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) The Federal Aviation Admin istration is planning to require installation aboard light air craft of radio direction signal transmitters to aid searchers in the event of a crash.

title: MANY WOULD PAY TO INSURE INCOME
COLGATE VICTOR OVERLEHIGH, 2112
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 31 Colgate, behind the hard run ning of Steve Morgan, downed Lehigh in football today, 2112. Morgan had this second straight 100plus yardage game, carry ing the ball 22 times for 122 yards and scoring a touchdown.

title: Aluminum Producers Resilient
description: As the economy struggles to recover from a recession, with a strike against the General Motors Corporation heading for its eighth week, with the capitalspending plans of industry being re vised downward, the nation's aluminum producers are not, by any criterion, enjoying boom times.

title: SADAT DESIGNATES 2 VICE PRESIDENTS
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31President Anwar elSadat appointed two Vice Presidents tonight and or dered a broad series of meas ures, including price cuts, to improve the life of the Egyp tian people.

title: Portrait of the President as the last liberal
description: The literature on the present oc cupant of the White House is slim. He has not, after all, resided there very long; and before he won elec tion by the narrowest of margins in 1968, there were few authors of ambition who regarded him as a com pelling enough subject matter to just ify a year's labor at the typewriter. Hence, Six CrisesNixon's own work  stands today as the single most revealing document on the 37th President. The rest of the Nixon literaturewith the exceptions of Earl Mazo's remarkably straightforL ward biography of 1959, and the contemporary reportorial efforts of John Osborne and Jules Witcover is given over to literary testimonials or arduous pilgrimages seeking the real Nixon.

title: Denison U. Gets $1.2Million
description: GRANVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 31 Denison University has re ceived a bequest of $1.25mil lion, the largest in its 140year history, from the estate of Edmund Glenn Burke, a New Yorkreal estate developer who died in 1966. Joel P. Smith, the university president, said that Mr. Burke had been instru mental in creating the Denison art treasures collection, to which he donated many works of art.

title: Unheavenly City
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 14  No Title
description: HONG KONGWily businessmen and oneday tailoring, teeming streets and Suzie Wong night life, fishing boats and rickshaw ridesthese are the ster eotypical images most visitors bring to and take away from Hong Kong.

title: Few Americans Fly to the Canaries
description: ARRECIFE, Lanzarote, Canary Islands Few Americans, except for those whose cruise ships have called at Las Palmas or Tenerife, have discovered the Canary Islands. But for many Scandinavians, Germans and Britons, a winter vacation on this Spanish archipelago off the coast of northwest Africa is the equivalent of migrating to Florida when the cold grips the northern states.

title: Results in Other Sports
description: CROSSCOUNTRY

title: Og could slice, gouge and hammer
description: Since Frederick Jackson Turner officially closed the American frontier, we have loved to read tales of those col orful, hardy and violent years. Books about the West are as many as the buffaloas the Cheyenne used to say when there were enough buffalo to sustain the simile. Most of them, of course, are romantic trash. A few are unforgettable, sufficiently thoughtful and deeprunning to reflect the big, bright, empty land.

title: CITY BRIDGE TEAM LEADS IN PLAYOFF
description: Four New York area experts appeared headed for victory yesterday in a match here to determine the United States representative in the 1971 World Bridge Championship.

title: Unbeaten Harvard Downs Penn in Soccer, 30, for No.7
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 Harvard's unbeaten soccer team scored its seventh victory today, a 30 Ivy League triumph over Pennsylvania.

title: American University Downs Fairleigh Dickinson, 2718
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 31 Rich Helms scored one touch down and passed for two more to lead American University t?? a 2718 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson in a club football game today.

title: R.P.I.'s Rally in 4th Period Tops Worcester Tech, 1514
description: TROY, N.Y., Oct. 31  A fourthquarter rally gave Rens selaer Polytechnic Institute its first victory of the season, 15 14, over Worcester Tech today. Rick Tasmer, plunged 2 yards for his second touchdown of the game at 3:26 of the final period. Ken Morse then scored the winning 2point conver sion on a pitchout.

title: TULANE SETS BACK VANDERBILT BY 107
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 31 (UPI) Dave Abercrombie, who almost became the goat, ran 21 yards for a touchdown and Lee Gib son kicked a 40yard field goal to lead Tulane to a 107 victory over Vanderbilt today.

title: The Land of the FourHour Siesta
description: COZUMEL, Mexico  This island off the eastern coast of the Yucatan Pen insula is the land of the fourhour si esta, the longest in Mexico. Nobody does a lick of work between noon and 4 P.M. Indeed very little of it is done before or after those hours, making the island an ideal place for those whose tastes and ambitions run to loafing. Cozumel is semitropical, with miles of beaches and coconut palms swaying above a scrub jungle; a land of lan guorous escapism.

title: Home Improvement
description: NEWLY developed tran sistorized units, plus improvements made in older models, have made home intercom systems more dependable than ever and has greatly simplified in stallation problems for the economyminded homeowner who would like to install the units himself. A modern sys tem will not only enable members of the family to talk from one room to another

title: Capital's Filling Stations Rebel on Trading Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)  About half the 400 large gasoline stations in the District of Columbia and suburban Maryland have decided to stop giving trading stamps, a spokes man has announced. He called the stamps legalized black mail.

title: BEAUX ARTS TRIO PLAYS AT HUNTER
description: The Beaux Arts Trio has be come almost a subsidiary insti tution in the Hunter College concert offerings. On Friday night, it was back at the Col lege Playhouse to open its seventh consecutive year there. It played the first of three programs scheduled for this season, in each of which it is being joined by Walter Trampler, the distinguished violist, for a piano quartet.

title: Bowling Green's Field Goal Sets Back Marshall, 2624
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Oct. 31 (UPI)Steve Shestina kicked a 38yard field goal with about a minute remaining in the game today and Bill Pittman gained 360 yards in total offense as Bowling Green edged Marshall University?? 2624.

title: COAST CHIEF TELLS OF FEAR FOR NIXON
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 31 Police Chief Ray Blackmore said today that police lines were in danger of breaking down Thursday night when President Nixon was standing on the roof of his automobile, waving to an unruly crowd after a political rally here.

title: Article 16  No Title
L. I. Antiques Dealer Held as F .B .I. Finds $500,000 in Stolen Goods
description: An antiques dealer de scribed as the biggest fence on the East Coast was arrest ed by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yester day after the police said they found more than $500,000 in stolen silver, antiques and art objects in his home and shop on Long Island.

title: Leo Welt, Consultant, Is Fiance Of Miss Johanna H. Singletary
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 31 Miss Johanna Hewgley Sin gletary, an associate methods analyst for Alco Chemical Corporation, a division of At lantic Richfield Company, in Chicago, and Leo G. B. Welt, an international management consultant in the heavy in dustrial machinery field, plan to be married in Wilmette, Ill., on Nov. 28.

title: Patricia A. Mertens is Married Here to Stephen R. Beckwith
description: Miss Patricia Ann Mertens was married here yesterday afternoon to Stephen Ross Beckwith in the Chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Dr. J. Burton Thomas.

title: Miss Constance Gray Is Married To Dr. Achille Elisha, U.N. Aide
description: Miss Constance J. Gray, assistant director of Brook wood Child Care in Brooklyn, was married here yesterday morning to Dr. Achille M. Elisha of Ouidah, Republic of Dahomey, and New York, officer of the Training Pro gram in Diplomacy at the United Nations.

title: SWEDEN PRESSING POLLUTION CURBS
description: STOCKHOLM. Oct. 31By day, children in Sweden are carefully taught in classrooms that smoke and automobile ex haust cause pollution. By night governmentrun courses in en vironment protection are at tended by more than 150,000 persons.

title: Airline Strike Settled
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. Oct. 31 (UPI)A 12day strike by pilots at Puerto Rico International Airlines ended after a 16hour negotiating session with a Fed eral mediator. The contract pro vides for a 36 per cent wage increase over three years and a maximum of 105 flying hours a month.

title: HOUSTON TRIUMPHS OVER TULSA BY 219
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Tommy Mozisek revived a sput tering University of Houston with two fourthquarter touch down runs today to spark, the heavily favored Cougars to a 219 victory over the University of Tulsa.

title: Seven Key Races in the Battle for Control of the Senate..

title: OTTINGER CHARGES VIOLENCE POLITICS
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged yesterday that President Nixon had been stirring up people's emotions on the violence issue in an unconscionable way.

title: Miss Mary Jane McInerney Is Married
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 At the Walter Reed Army Medical Center Memorial Chapel here today, Miss Mary Jane McInerney was married to William Lewis Krinsky by the Rev. George Shoup, a Jesuit priest.

title: The Nixon Campaign
description: A long tedious campaign nears its climax. Through weeks of apathy, Republican candidates across the country  led first by Vice President Agnew, then by President Nixon himself  have sought to whip up emo tions about crime, campus disorders and pornography. A cynical, coolly calculated effort has been made to dis tract attention from the Administration's record in eco nomic affairs, and foreign policy  a deliberate effort to create scapegoats and then identify the Democrats with them.

title: Show of Mrs. Woolworth's Art to Aid. Girl Scouts
description: Mrs. Norman B. Woolworth of Winthrop, Me., will show her collection of 19thcentury and 20thcentury American paintings at two days of pre views on Nov. 10 and 11. The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will benefit.

title: Cheesecake sensation
description: Promenade cheesecake is a delectable dessert that has two paramount virtues. It is one of the most delicious cheesecakes conceivabledelicate, finetex tured and richand it is also one of the easiest to make. It is the creation of William Irle, the chef of the Promenade Restau rants in Rockefeller Plaza. The cake is excellent without em bellishments, but it may be

title: The Case History of a Housing Failure
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29  In the midst of an acute hous ing shortage, St. Louis is boarding up 26 elevenstory apartment buildings, part of a $36million housing project built 15 years ago and not yet paid for.

title: Chess
Alsace, Looking East Again, Builds an Industrial Maginot Line
description: STRASBOURG, France Alsace, the most disputed and warravaged region of France, is building new de fenses against a new form of challenge from her German neighbors.

title: New York A,C. Runners Capture 3,000Meter Title
description: The New York Athletic Club placed five runners among the first seven finishers yesterday and won the national Amateur Athletic Union 3,000meter team title at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The Winged Foot runners triumphed with 21 points. C. W. Post College was second with 63.

description: ATLANTA, Nov. 1 (AP) Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth, Tex., a 10year competitor on the women's professional golf tour, has been named the Ladies Professional Golf As sociation 1970 Player of the Year, an award Kathy Whit worth had won annually since its inception in 1966.

title: Murphy Considers Using Police Cars With One Man
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he might consider a partial re turn to the system in which only one policeman was assiged to a patrol car.

title: Marvin Krauss Weds Mrs. Annette Schapiro
description: Mrs. Annette Rubinberg Schapiro and Marvin Krauss, vice president and marketing director of Esquire magazine, were married here yesterday afternoon by Rabbi Judah Cahn in his study at the Met ropolitan Synagogue.

description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1Most of the news was bad for steel producers last week.

title: Israeli Navy Sees Threat In Soviet Mideast Bases
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 1 (Reuters) The commander of the Israeli navy, Maj. Gen. Avraham Bot zer, today described Soviet naval bases in Egypt and Syria as the foundation for Soviet military activity in the Mediter ranean.

title: Scientists Assail Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1The Federation of American Scien tists charged today that the Nixon Administration's propo sals for strategicarms control was a sham because they would legalize an accelerated arms race through improve ments in weapons.

title: ExNavy Officers Call Nixon Superb As a Poker Player
description: Men who served with, Rich ard M. Nixon in the Navy in World War II say he was a consistent winner at poker, Life magazine said yesterday.

title: Miss Rose A. Stargardter Married
description: Miss Rose Ann Stargard ter, a doctoral candidate at Harvard, was married here yesterday afternoon to Til den G. Edelstein, a history professor at Rutgers Univer sity in New Brunswick, N.J., where the bride is a lecturer.

title: Jets Sneak for Daylight and Find Nightmare
description: At their peakwhich came with five minutes to go in the third quarterthe Jets held a 103 lead over the Giants; they had just halted the Giants on the 1foot line and they had held their own in a brief freeforall on the field.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Little
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dwight R. Little Jr. of Haydenville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Katherine Bradshaw Little, to Warren Bicknell King, son of Mrs. Elizabeth King of Cleveland and the late RaI??h??T. Kin??.

title: B. B. GEYER DEAD, ADVERTISING MAN
description: Bertram B. Geyer, long a leader in the advertising agency field, died on Saturday at Doc tors Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.

title: American and Western Air Reach Merger Agreement
description: American Airlines and West ern Air Lines said this weekend they had agreed to merge the two carriers. All employes of Western are to become em ployes of American. The agree ment is subject to approval by both companies boards and stockholders, the Civil Aero nautics Board and President Nixon (because some interna tional air routes are involved).

title: Flyers Beat Penguins, 32, And Tie Blues for 2d Place
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP)  The Philadelphia Flyers gained a 30 lead over the Pitts burgh Penguins tonight and then had to stave off a rally to score a 32 victory.

title: DR. WILLIAM SINGER
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Nov. 1 Dr. William I. Singer, a dentist with an office in Journal Square, Jersey City, died yesterday at his home, 1331 Anderson Ave nue. He was 75 years old.

title: Screen: Allusive 'WUSA':Newman Stars in Tale About Radio Station
description: Booze in his thermos, a garment bag slung over his shoulder, out of the morning strolls Paul Newman, itinerant radio announcer, to offer his services to WUSA, patriotic hate station broadcasting from New Orleans.To Newman comes Joanne Woodward, a wandering harlot with a heart of gold, a loving nature, a carved-up face, a certain vulnerability, and a fund of moral rectitude deep enough to float a generation of movie whores. And to them both comes Tony Perkins, shy social worker engaged among the black poor in a mysterious research projectwhich he learns too late is a fraud designed to discredit welfare, a fraud perpetrated by Pat Hingle, power-mad master of WUSA.Thus Stuart Rosenberg's "WUSA," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse and Plaza theaters, sets the stage for what it clearly intends as a major understanding of social forces at work in Americareactionary social forces, and in the South.If it were an ordinary bad movie (and it is a very bad movie), "WUSA" might, in spite of the distinguished names, and less distinguished presence, of its leading actors, be dismissed with no more than a nod to the tension between Rosenberg's ponderously emphatic direction, and Robert Stone's ponderously allusive screenplay. I suspect Stone wins out, for "WUSA" feels more like poor theater than poor moviemakingso, that it continually suggests a failed version of "The Balcony," even though it strives to fall short of "The Manchurian Candidate."But at least in its ambitions, "WUSA" is not an ordinary bad movie. For in its climax, a huge white-power rally sponsored by WUSA, it means to hold a mirror up to middle America, to show the hate behind the innocence, the chaos implicit in the call to law and order.So, while Perkins stalks the auditorium catwalks with high-powered rifle, like the shade of Laurence Harvey (who is also in this movie, but in another role), Newman prepares to purge himself, to tell the country what it is like it is, when all hell breaks loose after the firing of the would-be assassin's bullet.In this sequence, during which Newman explains Vietnam to a panic-ridden, rioting mass of the thin-lipped pinch-faced silent majority, "WUSA" has its crucial image, and, presumably, its rational. But in this sequence it displays most brazenly the utter gratuitousness of all its images, the bad faith that informs its self-righteous view of Southern demagoguery, the poverty not of mainstream America but of its own ideas about mainstream America.Despite its obsession with collecting evidence, and its handy school of pseudo-documentary, "WUSA" fights unreal battles with an unseen enemy. Lacking either the grace of art of the vitality of guerrilla theater, it can offer only the coarsest nourishmentand only to the elaborately self-deceived.

title: David B. Townsend Is Fiance Of Miss Elizabeth Van Siclen
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. John Wyck off Van Siclen have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Van Siclen, to David Bruce Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riger Wilmoth Town send of Nutley, N. J. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: SQUEEZE PINCHING OIL CORPORATIONS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 1 The extra $330million finan cial burden imposed by the revolutionary Libyan Govern ment on United States and British oil producers is having repercussions throughout the oil world.

title: Unconventional Japanese Princess Becomes a Working Woman
description: TOKYOEven in the most royal of families, children don't always tell their Parents what they are going to do. And so it was when Mrs. Takako Shimazu, daughter of Emperor Hirohito, decided to break with family traditionand take a job.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1970

title: Port Authorities Establish Environmental Affairs Unit
description: The formation of a commit tee on environmental affairs has been announced by the American Association of Port Authorities.

title: HalfTime Battle Show Results in 4 Casualties
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (UPI)Four persons were injured today when an an tique, muzzleloading cannon discharged prematurely dur ing a football halftime show. The show, during the New Orleans SaintsLos Angeles Rams football game, featured a recreation of the Battle of New Orleans.

title: Giants Defeat Jets, 2210.
description: The Giants defeated the Jets yesterday, 2210, before a record crowd of 63,903 at Shea Stadium. (See Page 71).

title: Innovations at Fort Carson Make Army Life More Bearable for Draftees
description: FORT CARSON, Colo.Spe cialist 5 William J. Rosendahl is an unusual soldier.

title: Weyand Gets Fourth Star
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Lieut. Gen. Fred erick Weyand today received fourth star to make him a full general and at the same time became deputy commander of United States forces in Viet nam.

title: KIDNAPPED GENERAL IN ECUADOR FREED
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Nov ?? (AP)  Gen. Cesar Rohn San doval, commander of Ecuador's Air Force who was kidnapped Tuesday, was freed today. A Government communiqu said he had stepped off a bus alone in front of an air force base on Quito's outskirts.

title: Stanley C. Allyn of National Cash Register Dies
description: Stanley Charles Allyn, who retired at the end of 1961 as chairman of the board of the National Cash Register Com pany, died Saturday night in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital at the age of 79. He lived in Day ton, Ohio, and also had a home in Greenwich.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On Aug. 1, 1925, Timothy J. Mara and Will Gibson were granted the New York franchise in the National Foot ball League for $500, an event that was not sanctified for more than a generation. The professional game was looked down upon: College football was not minor league then, but the true sport, and Westbrook Pegler could reflect the general disdain by writing of the alleged Giants. The pro owners were sportsmen, which meant they. some times owned horses and bet baseball, and they often held their league meetings in hotel rooms, breaking for card games across the twin beds, and .for serious drinking.

title: U.S.SOVIET TALKS TO RESUME TODAY
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 1 The Soviet delegation ar rived by train from Moscow today for the resumption to morrow of negotiations with the United States on the limi tation of strategic arms.

title: IDLE DICE GAINS PRESIDENT'S CUP
Nixon Plea on TV Tonight; Democrats Ponder Reply
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Re publicans completed arrange ments today to put a final elec tion appeal by President Nixon on television tomorrow night. Democrats, meanwhile, consid ered whether they should coun ter with an appearance by Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie.

title: French Fire Is 28th To Kill 100 in Century
description: Fires that have taken 100 or more lives have struck around the world 28 times in the last 100 years, including the latest fire, at SaintLaur entduPont, France.

title: Store Suggests Men Think Mink, Instead of Blue Denim
description: The work jacket in dark brown mink for men isn't revolutionary, see; because the revolution is over. That's the word from Bonwit Teller, which began agitating for men's fashion reform just five years ago. Now its men's

title: ACQUISITION SLATED BY ECONOMICS LAB
description: Economics Laboratory, Inc., said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the busi ness of the process chemicals and marine divisions of the Drew Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Slick Corpo ration.

title: Jersey Brothers, 11 and 12, Found Dead in a Sand Pit
description: WAYNE, N. J., Nov. 1 (AP) Two brothers who went hiking were found dead today in a sand pit where they apparently had been playing, just 75 yards behind their home. The police theorized that the boys were building a fortress, which collapsed and suffocated them.

title: South Africa Widow Seeks Damages for Prison Death
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Nov. 1A claim for $14, 000 damages has been lodged against the Minister of Police and a security branch interro gator by the widow of an Af rican who was found hanged in a prison cell last year.

title: Strike Deadline Set For Off Broadway Passes
description: A midnight strike deadline threatened by Actors Equity Association against the Off Broadway theaters passed early today with both parties con tinuing their talks but with absolutely no progress re ported on the major wage de mand issues.

title: 2 Bombings in Fresno Damage Draft Center and a Newspaper
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) Two predawn dynamite ex plosions ripped a military in duction center and the office of a conservative newspaper today.

title: In Memoriam
description: ROSSMath??lda (Mettle) In memory of my beloved wife who graced and enriched MY life. I miss her. ARTHUR LEONARD ROSS

title: HUME TRIUMPHS IN CANAM FINALE
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. (UPI)  Denis Hulme of New Zealand led from the start to day as he captured the 201.3 mile annual Times Grand Prix by 8.2 seconds from Jackie Oliver of England. It was the final event of the. Canadian American Challenge Cup series.

title: Famed Indian Statue Enters a Museum
description: OKLAHOMA. CITY, Nov. 1 The End of the Trailthe statue of an Indian warrior slumped over the back of an exhausted war pony  was moved to a special exhibition hall here this weekend.

title: Rangers Hand Hawks a 5to2 Defeat
description: Syl Apps last night learned something they never taught in Psych 1 at Princeton: Don't get Bobby Hull unnecessarily angry.

title: Singapore Leader in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (Reu ters) Lee Kuan Yew, the Singapore Prime Minister, ar rived here today for four days of talks with Government lead ers, including President Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger, foreign affairs adviser.

title: 20 Die in Venezuela Police Drive
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 1 Here Is No. 19, a police of ficial said as he handed out photographs to newsmen yes terday.

title: Egypt's Price Cuts Sweeten Ramadan
description: CAIRO, Nov. 1  Their spirits buoyed by price re ductions on a range of prod ucts that include the all important tea and sugar, the Moslems of Egypt en dured the second day of Ramadan todaygoing with out food, drink and even a soothing puff on a water pipe from dawn until sunset.

title: Appeal to Fear
description: One need not be overwhelmed by a poll that four years ago had Frank O'Connor trouncing Nelson Rockefeller to recognize that James L. Buckley is running a strong race for the United States Senate. Some of that strength, we suspect, may dissipate when voters step into the polling booths tomorrow and ask themselves what they expect the Conservative party candidate to deliver that could possibly justify their votes.

title: Campus Unrest Panelist Says Real Issues Are Being Ignored
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 1 (AP) Joseph Rhodes Jr., a member of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest, charged today that President Nixon had de liberately ignored our real problems and had sought to play on our fears and hatred for his own political gains.

title: Books of The Times
description: The second installment of James Flex ner's multivolumed life of Washington left the general at Yorktowna vindication of nine years battling in the field. However, that earlier book did not show Washington as an altogether brilliant commander.

title: 40 Held Up in Rochester; Gunmen Wound 2 Policemen
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 1 (AP) Forty persons were held up early today at a party by three masked men who fled with four hostages and then wound ed two policemen. Two suspects in the robbery were captured in a shootout and the hostages were rescued unharmed.

title: Yale Regains a Bit of Its Boola Boola
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1 When a massive antiwar demonstration was proposed recently for the Town Green here this weekend, many peo ple at Yale fretted that it might hurt local peace can didates because voters were getting weary of all demon strations. There were other misgivings, too.

title: Rum Customer Rated Choice Of Six in Nassau Pace Tonight
description: Rum Customer will get under way from the rail, with Billy Haughton driving, seeking his 11th triumph in 30 starts this year.

title: INDIANS IN MAINE GET SEWER GRANT
description: INDIAN TOWNSHIP, Me., Nov. 1The Economic Devel opment Administration has granted $436,000 to the Passa maquoddy Indians.

title: Coaches Faces Often Tell the Story
AMERICAN SYMPHONY BOWS IN NEW SERIES
description: The American Symphony has made Carnegie Hall its home ever since the orchestra was founded 10 years ago by Leopold Stokowski. This sea son, in addition to its Carnegie concerts, a new Philharmonic Hall series has been inaugu rated, and the American Sym phony presented its first pro gram there yesterday afternoon.

title: Woman, 25, Seized After Driving Car From a City Pound
description: A 25yearold Philadelphia woman, apparently outraged that her car had been towed away, staged a driveout at the city's car pound, the police said, crashing the chain barrier and knocking down a policeman be fore being captured 13 blocks away.

title: Grace O'Connor Presents Recital of Arias and Songs
description: Grace O'Connor returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Sat urday night with a highly di verting program of arias, art songs and folk airs.

title: Religious Agencies Join in Drive To Recruit Foster Parents Here
description: An experiment that will seek to solve the continuing crisis of inadequate care for the city's 3,000 homeless children by intensive doortodoor ef forts to recruit foster parents was begun yesterday by three religious federations.

title: No School Strike in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Hartford Federation of Teachers voted narrowly to continue to work for at least two weeks during contract ne gotiations, averting a threat ened strike. The vote to con tinue working was 346 to 325.

title: Pope Urges Extension Of Mideast CeaseFire
description: ROME, Nov. 1Pope Paul VI said today that all must pray for an extension of the Ceasefire in the Middle East after Thursday.

title: Gary Player Takes Dunlop With a 282; Trevino Ties for 2d
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 1 (AP)Gary Player of South Africa captured his second ma jor Australian golf tournament in two weeks today with a fi nal round of 71 for a 282 total in the Dunlop international. His prize today was $4,480.

title: Key Polish Official Is Killed by Truck At Karachi Airport
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 A Polish Deputy Foreign Min ister, Zygfryd Wolniak, and three Pakistanis were killed to day at Karachi International Airport when an airline van ran into a reception line formed to welcome the Polish President, Marshal Marian Spychalski, here.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: Five IronFront Buildings Here Dating From 1848 to Be Saved
description: Five rusting, shaky ironfront buildings, huddled forlornly on a downtown street and ap parently abandoned by every once except derelicts, are crime covered gems with a future.

title: Dancers of Brigham Young Offer a Colorful Medley
description: The International Dancers of Brigham Young University are bright, shiny and enthusiastic. The dancers, all students, are also something less than pro fessional but more than ama teur. They have folk dances from a dozen countries in their repertory and present them with the relentless gaiety of a color spread in the National Geographic.

title: GOVERNOR, RIVALS ARGUE ON CHANGE IN ABORTION LAW
description: Governor Rockefeller and Ar thur J. Goldberg, debating for the last times in the guberna torial campaign, sharply dis agreed yesterday on the need for changes in the state's abor tion law: a possible commuter tax increase and the campaign tactics of President Nixon and Vice President Agnew.

title: Radicals Say Nixon Exaggerates Violence in Incident at San Jose
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 1 The young radicals who planned the demonstration against Pres ident Nixon here last Thursday feel that the President has ex aggerated what happened that night for his own political ad vantage.

title: ArabAmerican Meeting Hears Chomsky
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 1Dr. Noam Chomsky told the third annual convention of the Asso ciation of ArabAmerican Uni versity Graduates today that neither Israel nor the Palestin ian commando movement could really win the Middle Eastern conflict.

title: Paper Believes Jack the Ripper Was Queen Victoria's Grandson
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP)The Sunday Times expressed belief today that Jack the Ripper, in famous London murderer of nearly 100 years ago, was Ed ward, Duke of Clarence, grand son of Queen Victoria and older brother of King George V.

title: A Cap With Its Own Hair
description: If you can't decide whether to wear a wig or a hat, how about a combination called the hatwig, espe cially for winter sports? The hatwig, as sold at the salon of its creator, Kenneth, of 19 East 54th Street, is a crocheted skull cap with Dynel hair that is at tached in back with a strip of Velcro. The hair short and curly, or longer and not so curlycomes in a variety of colors. Its permanent set is wash able. The cap itself varies in color and fabric. The hatwig sells for $25; with metallic thread, it's an other $10. Bald caps are $12 and $20.

title: ALBERT PLEYDELL, EXCITY AIDE, DIES
description: Albert Pleydell, who served as Commissioner of Purchases under Mayors Fiorello H. La Guardia and William O'Dwyer, died yesterday at his home. He was 65 years old and lived at 8823 Gettysburg Street, Belle rose, Queens.

title: Slaying Spurs Disorders
description: NEW CASTLE, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP)A black Vietnam veteran was shot to death in front of a tavern early today and the resulting disorders brought in jury to nine persons, including five policemen, the police said. According to the police, more than 100 persons poured onto streets from taverns on the city's south side and began smashing windows after Ronald Mitchell, 21, was shot in the stomach from a passing vehicle. The police said they had no sus pects in the shooting.

title: Puerto Ricans Get Vote at 18
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 1 (AP) Unofficial returns showed Puerto Rican voters giving overwhelming approval today to a proposal to lower the voting in age from 21 to 18. With 70 of 87 precincts reporting. the referendum tally was 152, ?? yes and 85,862 no.

title: Brandeis Dedicates Center
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Nov. 1 (AP)Brandeis University dedi cated today a $4.5million stu dent center, a complex of five buildings.

title: 6 Grants Totaling $800,000 Go to Drug. Programs Here
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced the approval of six grants totaling more than $800, 000 to youth drug abuse pro grams in the New York City metropolitan area yesterday.

title: 160 Penn Central Cars Get a Radio Link Today
description: A radio network to enable crewmen on 160 Penn Central commuter and raildiesel cars on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines to report trouble immediately instead of having to stop the train and go to the nearest wayside tele phone will go into operation today.

title: Prof. Dan F. Bradley, 41, Dead; BiopolymerResearch Specialist
description: Dr. Dan F. Bradley, profes sor of polymer chemistry at Polytechnic Institute, Brooklyn, and a leading specialist in bio polymer research, died Satur day of a massive cerebral hemorrhage. He was 41 years old and lived at 32 Livingston Street?? Brooklyn.

title: $100MILLION RISE IN REQUIRED COSTS IS FACED BY CITY
description: The city's Budget Director said yesterday that mandatory increases in costs alone could result in an increase of $100 million in spending out of city tax funds above the original estimates for the current budget.

title: George Brown Was No Diplomat, His Critics Say
description: LONDON, Nov. 1Diplo mats who burned silently at the behavior of George Brown when he was Foreign Secre tary are getting their own back.

title: Hartford Life Organizing A General Agency System
description: The Hartford Life Insurance Company, with nearly $3bil lion of life insurance in force, has announced what it termed a completely new business approach for the company, with the formation of a general agency system to supplement its independent agents and brokers.

title: China Asks Nuclear Parley
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 2Communist China has re vived a proposal, advanced oc casionally in the past, that a conference of big and small powers be held to discuss the prohibition and destruction, of nuclear weapons.

title: K.E.Green Weds Miss Arenberg, A Teacher Here
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 1 Miss Barbara Jay Arenberg, a teacher at the All Day Neighborhood Schools in New York, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Eric Green, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank M. Green of Rockville Centre, L. I.

title: Field Goal Record Set
description: WINNIPEG, Nov. 1 (Canadi an Press)Larry Robinson es tablished a Canadian Football League career fieldgoal record today as the Calgary Stamped ers defeated the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, 116, in the final Western Football Conference regular season game for both clubs. Robinson kicked a 29 yarder, giving him 115, one better than the retired Don Sutherin.

title: State U. Rolls at Peak
description: ALBANY, Nov. 1  The 69 campuses of the State Univer sity of New York have fulltime enrollment exceeding 209,000 this fall. Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer announced today that preliminary figures showed an increase of more than 29,000 over the 180,341 enrolled in 1969. The increase is also the largest in a single year in the university's history. the pre vious high was recorded in the fall of 1968, when the enroll ment was up 20,715 to 159,928.

title: Buffet and Art Show to Aid Sport Museum at Garden
description: A cocktail buffet?? will be held at the National Art Museum of Sport at Madi son Square Garden Center Wednesday evening to pre view a twoweek exhibition and sale of English field and yachting paintings of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.

title: Books of The Times
description: Tuesday, June 9, 1964. A day in the life of Lady Bird Johnson. In the morning she flies to Boston to deliver the baccalaureate address at Radcliffe, an event she has been dreading. But, first, a small luncheon at Radcliffe president Mary Bunting's resi dence. Then her talk. She performs well.

title: Japan's Forces Mark 20th Anniversary
description: TOKYO, Nov. 1  Premier Eisaku Sato, reviewing the 20th anniversary parade of Japan's SelfDefense Forces today, re affirmed his Government's policy of reliance on its own defense efforts plus its secu rity treaty with the United States to maintain peace and security in the Far East.

title: Oil Leaks Into Gowahus
description: About 50 barrels of fuel oil, totaling 2,100 gallons leaked into the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn late last night; accord ing to fire officials, from Esso Barge 31, as the oil was being unloaded and part of a pipe broke. Firement worked at clearing the oil late into the night.

title: SplitPersonality Quarterback
description: For years, Fran Tarkenton played the square to Joe Namath's swinger. Yet, the quarterbacks traded roles on the field. Tarkenton, the non smoking, nondrinking son of a Methodist minister, was a scrambler who put on, said one observer, a highwire act on a football field.

title: C.B.S. in Housing Venture
description: Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, Inc., said yesterday it had paid $10million for a 49 per cent interest in the Klingbeil Company, a Columbus, Ohio, developer of residential corn munities. This is C.B.S.'s first venture into the housing field.

title: Pennsy's Diversification Called Factor in Collapse
description: Representative Wright. Pat man, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee, charged yesterday that an aggressive diversification pro gram that the Penn Central Transportation Company began in 1963 contributed signifi cantly to the railroad's ulti mate financial collapse last June 21.

title: Rockefeller Leads in Final News Poll
description: The Daily News, publishing the results of its third and final straw poll yesterday, predicted victory by a wide margin for Governor Rockefeller, but it described the United States Senate contest in New York State as too close to call.

title: RECITAL SUCCESS FOR MISS SCOTTO
description: Renata Scotto, a popular fig ure at the Metropolitan Opera since herdebut there in 1965, is also a superb recitalist. Inaugu rating a new series of Sunday afternoon concerts at the Hun ter College Assembly Hall, the soprano delighted a large and friendly audience with a divert ing assortment of Italian arias and songs: ranging more or less chronologically from Carissimi (16051674) to Verdi.

title: EPICURE, SHELTIE, IS BEST IN JERSEY
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 1 A sableandwhite Shetland sheepdog, Ch. Pixie Dell Epi cure, did the impossible to day, when the 6yearold was named best of the 608 dogs at the 31st Union County Kennel Club fixture at the Elizabeth National Guard Armory.

title: Stage: Thoreau in jail
Shells Said to Kill 6 in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 2 (AP)Vietcong gunners were reported to have shelled Saigon early today for the first time in three months, and authorities reported six Vietnamese were killed and 15 wounded and a cluster of hous es was destroyed.

title: POLITICAL DONATIONS BY BANKERS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)  The Justice Department is investigating campaign dona tions by bankers after the dis closure that large contributions went to lawmakers closely in volved with a bank bill now pending in Congress.

title: PRICE RISES SLOW IN RETAILERS ADS
description: If prices of items that are predominantly advertised by the nation's department, spe cialty and general merchandise stores are a criterion, it appears that inflation was practically halted in September.

title: Screen: Pizza Triangle, Italian Jest
description: The Italians, of course, did not invent the sardonic view of love and jealousy, but their moviemakers have been trying to leave that impres sion, occasionally with great success, as in, say, Divorce, Italian Style. The Pizza Tri angle, once specifically la beled Drama of Jealousy, and later Jealousy, Italian Style, arrived at the Trans Lux East yesterday, and earnestly essays to follow in the noble lampoon tradition of Divorce. It succeeds only sporadically in being really funny about either love or ??ealous??.

title: Cochran Conquers Pottle In NorthSouth Final, 1 Up
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov (AP)Bob Cochran of St. Louis never lost his poise in the face of steady pressure and defeated John Pottle of Linville, N.C., up, today for the NorthSouth seniors championship.

title: Rush, Patriot Pilot, Suffers An Irregular Heart Beat
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. ?? (AP)Coach Clive Rush of the Boston Patriots suffered an ap parent minor heart disorder to day and missed most of the first half of the National Foot ball League game with the Buf falo Bills.

title: Scurrilous Campaign Tactics
description: At both the national and state level, this campaign has been disfigured by deceitful advertising and ruthless dis tortion. President Nixon has set a bad example by his effort to link the Democrats with thugs and hoodlums.

title: Man, Dead in Cell, Identified As an Insurance Executive
description: The prosecutor said that Mr. Marshall was found hanging from the cell door and that his shirt had been used as a noose.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS RACING DEADLINE
description: Negotiators for the News paper Guild and for The Daily News and The New York Times attempted last night to work out agreements in separate ses sions that would avert a strike at one of the newspapers today.

title: Jordanian Curfew Lifted
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 1 (Reuters)The 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew in effect here since Sep tember 17 was lifted today by order of Wasfi elTal, the new premier.

title: Congolese Voting Ended
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Nov. (AP)As polling stations closed tonight, Government officials said that all indications were that there had been a large vote in favor of the only can didate in the Congo's presiden tial electionPresident Joseph D. Mobutu. He came, to power in an army coup in November, 1965.

title: CHEER LINGERING IN BOND MARKET
description: The credit markets are thor oughly convinced that the slug gish economy and the General Motors strike will force the Federal Reserve to take some step toward monetary ease this month.

title: TARKENTON FIGHT INSPIRES GIANTS
description: At halftime, losing, 73, the Giants were told off in blunt and impassioned tones by Alex Webster, their coach, who isn't ordinarily given to lockerroom oratory. The Giants weren't hitting, they were letting the Jets come at them instead of the other way .round, and they were letting their most import ant game get away.

title: THOMAS V. WINN
description: CONGERS, N. Y., Nov. 1 Thomas V. Winn, vice president in charge of sales of Montfort Br??s?? of Fishkill, manufacturer of concrete building blocks, died in Nyack Hospital today. He was 71 years old.

title: List of the Candidates in State and Local Elections Tomorrow
description: Following is a list of the candidates in New York City in tomorrow's election. As terisk (*) denotes incumbent. Party abbreviations are R., Republican; D., Democrat; L., Liberal; C., Conservative; S. W., Socialist Workers; S. L., Socialist Labor; Corn., Communist; E., Environment; C. S. I., Civil Service Inde pendent; A., Independent Al liance; N. P. New Progres sive; U. M., P., Manhattan Apartment Building; S. M.; Silent Majority; LI., Liberty and F. I., Flatlands Independ ent Voter Committee.

title: TV: Weill Retrospective
description: The amazing versatility of the late Kurt Weill, the com poser, has been suitably re membered on television since his death in 1950 but not often quite so interestingly as in last night's hour star ring Georgia Brown, the British vocalist. The program was seen on the Public Broadcasting Service (Chan nel 13).

title: Opel Adds Four New, Larger Cars to Its 1971 Line
description: The Germanbuilt Opel au tomobile line for the United States market has been ex panded to 10 models for 1971 with the introduction of four new cars in the 1900 series. All the cars are manu factured in West Germany by the General Motors Cor noration.

title: Lemm Is Reported Quitting Oilers at End of Season
description: HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 1 (UPI) Wally Lemm, the head coach of the Houston Oilers, told his players last night, after a hu miliating 440 loss to St. Louis, that he would resign at the end of the season.

title: Coast Airliner Hijacked And Is Headed for Cuba
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) A United Air Lines Boeing 727 jet with 67 passengers and a crew of six was on its way to Cuba tonight with a hijacker in the cockpit. The Federal Aviation Administra tion said the hijacker, an unidentified man, had a gun.

title: MEHTA INTRODUCES A LIGETI WORK HERE
description: Imagine a spacious nonrep representational painting in shades of gray against which a splash of bright orange red is placed somewhat to the right and slightly above the center. This is one man's visual equivalent of Gyorgy Ligeti's Lontano, which was given its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night by the Los Angeles Phil harmonic under the direction of Zubin Mehta.

title: Threat to Europe's Oil Route Seen
description: Britain's defense program an nounced last week slows but does not stop her gradual with drawal from global military re sponsibility.

title: BIG MINH IMPLIES HE'LL FIGHT THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Mon day, Nov. 2Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh, one of the most pop ular figures in South Vietnam, broke a yearlong political si lence yesterday with a broad hint that he would challenge Nguyen Van Thieu for the pres idency next year.

title: Letters to the Editor
8th Ave. Is Microcosm of Police Problems
description: Midtown Eighth Avenue, where crowds lingering seven days a week include drug addicts, homosexuals, prosti tutes, vagrants and thieves?? has one of the highest arrest records in the city and some of its toughest problems of law enforcement.

title: DOUBLEDAY NAMES VAUGHAN PUBLISHER
description: Samuel S. Vaughan, execu tive editor of Doubleday & Co., has been named publisher of the 73yearold company. He becomes the first executive to be given the title since it was retired in 1928 with Frank Nel son Doubleday, founder of the publishing house.

title: DR. FREDERIC P. LORD
description: HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 1 Dr, Frederic Pomeroy Lord, a retired professor of anatomy at Dartmouth Medical School, died yesterday in a nursing home at the age of 94.

title: Taps for Butskellism??
description: Prime Minister Heath prOjects an economic and social policy for Britain dramatically different not only, from that of the preceding Labor Government but from those of his Tory predecessors from 1951 to 1964. The pro fessed aim is to enable the individual to keep more of his earnings and have more incentive to increase them, but some experts say it may not work that way for many middleclass Britons.

title: Pro Football: Colts Win
description: Jim Duncan, who played un der Don Shula for only one year, and Ron Gardin, who never played for him at all, helped the older Baltimore players frustrate their former coach yesterday as the Colts handed Miami its second straight shutout, 350.

title: Subway Runs to Brooklyn Curtailed by Bomb Scare
description: Service on local BMT lines between Manhattan and Brook lyn was suspended for three hours last night after a Transit Authority employe found what he thought was a bomb on the Court Street station platform.

title: AUSTIN MONTGOMERY, STOCKBROKER, DIES
description: Austin Philips Montgomery, who retired in 1968 as president of A. P. Montgomery & Co., overthecounter stockbrokers, died Saturday night in Midtown Hospital. He Was 84 years old and lived at 51 East 90th Street.

title: HEINRICH BLUECHER
description: Heinrich Bluecher, professor emeritus of philosophy at Bard College, AnnandaleonHudson, N. Y., died Saturday after an ap parent heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 370 Riverside Drive.

title: Crash Spills Grass
description: MADERA, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI) Three young persons were arrested today when 25 pounds of marijuana scattered from their small foreign auto after it rammed a utility pole. The three, booked on charges of possession of marijuana for sale, were Danny J. Gallegos, 22 years old, and Joseph M. Vargas, 25, both of San Fran cisco, and Miss Lora Figone, 20, of Daly City.

title: JAVITS SAYS LIBERALS SEEK DISORDER CURE
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that liberals were just as concerned with law and order as conservatives. The dif ference, is that the conserva tives only remedy is re pression while the liberals are ready to attack the causes

title: SCHOOLS IN TRENTON TO REOPEN TODAY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1 The school board voted tonight to reopen the city's public schools, closed last Friday because of clashes between black and white youths over a plan to bus students between predom inantly black and white schools.

title: MORE STUDENTS ENTER MEDICINE
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1De spite the financial plight that has forced many medical schools almost to bankruptcy, medical schools generally have sharply increased their total enrollment and the number of minority students this fall, the Association of American Medi cal Colleges reported at its an nual meeting here today.

title: U.S. Women in Net Play
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 1 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King will lead seven other top Amer ican women stars in the Brit ish Embassy open tennis cham pionships, Nov. 16 to 21. The eight women, who rebelled against playing in tournaments because of insufficient prize money, have formed their own group under. Mrs. Gladys Held man of New York.

title: Last Senate Race Debate Marked by Harsh Charges
description: New York's three Senatorial candidates attacked one an other with such phrases as misrepresentation and fraud, despicable and if you can read English yesterday in their fourth and final television de bate of the campaign.
