title: Indians Seize Army Center For Use as Cultural Base
description: DAVIS, Calif., Nov. 3 (Reu ters)Scores of Indians scaled a barbed wire fence and seized an old Army communications center here today, unimpeded by four soldiers whose job it was to guard the facility.

title: Market Summary
The Population Bomb
description: A preliminary census report was re cently released which indicates that the population of the United States may grow by only 75 million people by the end of the century. Incredibly, this announcement has been greeted by some as a sign of the end of the population explosion in this country. Derision has been heaped on the heads of Prophets of Doom who seek stronger societal action to curb popu tion growth at home and elsewhere.

title: West Tops Watson in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA S. C., Nov. 3 Albert S. Watson, an arch conservative Republican candi date for Governor who was strongly supported by the Nixon Administration and by Senator Strom Thurmond, was rejected today by the voters of South Carolina.

title: G.O.P. IS SET BACK IN MAJOR STATES
description: Democrats apparently made a net gain of seven governors offices, and possibly more, in yesterday's elections.

title: Dean Is Appointed at L.I.U.
description: Dr. Alvert E. Johnson, 38 years old, yesterday was ap pointed dean of the School of Business Administration of Long Island University's Brook lyn Center. Dr. Johnson, a university administrator and authority in the field of financial management, assumes his new position immediately. A resident of Port Jefferson Station, L.I., he has been teach ing at the Arthur T. Roth School of Business Administra tion, Greenvale, L.I.

title: Friends of Channel 13 Plan a Ball at Lincoln Center
description: The Friends of Channel 13 will sponsor An Evening of Pure Pleasure, a benefit ball to be held in the Promenade of the New York State Thea ter at Lincoln Center on Nov. 16.

title: State Halts Westbury Race Bets On Evidence of Tranquilizing
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 3 Evidence of tranquilization led the New York State Harness Racing Commission to eliminate wagering tonight in the sixth race at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Article 2  No Title
Pistons Top Royals On 8 Free Throws In Last 2 Minutes
St. Bonaventure to Shut If Coed Visits Keep Up
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 3 (AP)  The president of St. Bona venture University said to day that he would close the university Thursday unless students stopped violating a rule that forbids men and women students from visit ing each others dormitories.

title: St. Francis Prep Wins, 306
House Delegation Elected By North Carolina Voters
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 3 (AP) Ten Congressional races held the major attention today as North Carolina went to the polls.

title: DePugh Aide Gets 3 Years
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 3 (AP) A Federal District Court Judge sentenced Walter Patrick Peyson, 28yearold former lieu tenant of the leader of the Min utemen, Robert DePugh, to three years in prison today on a bondjumping conviction.

title: Frog Satellite Delayed Again
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) ??or the 10th time, an at tempt by the National Aero nautics and Space Administra tion to orbit a frog experiment has been postponed. The fro?? experiment, which was to have been launched at 3 A.M. today from Wallops Island, Va., failed to get off the ground because of difficulties with with the frog experiment package.

title: Dolphins on Loan Escape
description: RIO DE JANEIRO (AP)Two of five dolphins on loan from Miami got out of their aquar ium, slithered across the beach and escaped into the sea, offi cials said.

title: William F. Fielden Dies; Tobacco Executive Was 55
description: William F. Fielden, an ex ecutive in the tobacco industry, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 165 East 66th Street.

title: Jury Panel Exhausted
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 3 (UPI) The prosecution and defense in the murder trial of the widow of William E. Thoresen 3d, wealthy gun collector, ex hausted a panel of 45 prospec tive jurors today. The proceed ings were adjourned until to morrow morning. Mrs. Louise Thoresen, 34 years old, is ac cused of firing five .38caliber bullets into the body of her husband, who was found in a bedroom of their home here June 10.

title: Activities Offered for Children
AllisChalmers Buys Right To Use RollsRoyce Engine
Deadline for Railroad Strike Is Extended for Six Days
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) Labor unions and railroads have agreed to another exten sion of their wage dispute, making Dec. 10 the earliest date a nationwide rail strike could occur.

title: Price of Simca Rises $72
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3A price increase of $72 on 1971 Simca cars was announced today by the ChryslerPlymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation. The twodoor sedan will now sell for $1,947 and the four door sedan $2,032. The com pany, which markets the French built automobiles in this coun try, reported that it has reduced the cost of optional aircondi tioning on Simcas by $100 to $265.

title: No Lunch on Coffee Break
description: FRANKFORT, Ky. (AP)The state has closed its cafeterias during traditional midmorning and midafternoon coffeebreak hours to eliminate elongated breaks.

title: Governor Rockefeller Again
description: Campaigning on a record of having done a lot and promising to do more, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller has been reelected to a fourth fouryear term. His place in the state's political history is secure. He becomes its most durable modern chief executive.

title: Deadline Extended 6 Months On New Car Safety Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) The Department of Transpor tation yesterday granted auto makers an additional six months, until July 1, 1973, to begin installation of automatic crashprotection systems, such as automatically inflating air bags on new cars.

title: New Jersey Vote
Muskie Elected to 3d Term in Maine
description: PORTLAND, Me., Wednes day, Nov. 4 (AP)Senator Ed mund S. Muskie, Maine's cham pion Democratic votegetter, was elected to a third term yesterday in a contest widely regarded as a key test of his Presidential prospects.

title: Liquidated Brokerage Firm Pays Off All of Its Accounts
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 3 (UPI)  All customers and broker accounts of May & Co., Oregon's second largest broker age firm, which closed two months ago, have been paid, a liquidation referee announced yesterday.

title: OFFICIAL DISPUTES MISS DAVIS'S SUIT
description: The superintendent of the Women's House of Detention said yesterday that Angela Davis was being held In segre gation because she had become a center of attraction for other inmates and had disrupted prison routine.

title: W. 86th St. Traffic Halted By Break in Water Main
description: A broken 10inch water main disrupted traffic for three hours yesterday morning on 86th Street between Amster dam and Columbus Avenues.

title: ENEMY IS REPORTED NEARING PNOMPENH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Nov. 4 (AP)A Cambodian military spokes man said today that elements of a North Vietnamese division had moved into flooded areas just across the Mekong River from Pnompenh with the ap parent mission of battering the capital's defenses.

title: Kirk Defeated in Florida; Cramer Loses to Chiles
description: MIAMI, Wednesday, Nov. 4 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. was defeated yesterday in his bid for reelection by Reubin As kew, a young Democratic leg islator, who rose from relative political obscurity to challenge Florida's first Republican Gov ernor since Reconstruction.

title: Reagan Reelected; Murphy Is Defeated
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3Gov. Ronald Reagan, a Republican, was elected to a second four year term today, easily defeat ing Assemblyman Jess Unruh.

title: STATEMENT BY HANOI IN U.N. ACCUSES U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3A North Vietnamese statement accusing the United States forces of a general pol icy of civilian massacres in South Vietnam has been circu lated here to all members at the request of the Hungarian Government.

title: Entertainment Events
Advertising
description: Remember those clever fullpage newspaper ads for Arpege that ran just before Mother's Day? Well they weren't the end, they were just the beginning. Just a warm up for the big push for Christmasa time of promise.

title: Jet With 162 Loses Wheel During TakeOff on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. (AP)One of the 18 wheels on a Boeing 747 jetliner carry ing 162 persons fell off during takeoff at San Francisco In ternational Airport today, but the craft landed safely an hour later at the same airport.

title: Buckley's Views on Issues That May Confront Him
description: Following are the views of Senatorelect James L. Buckley on some major issues that may confront him in the Senate:

title: CUNNINGHAM BACK FOR A 12DAY RUN
description: Merce Cunningham and his dancers, who had one of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's most successful dance engage ments last winter, returned there last night for a run through Nov. 15.

title: House Seats Shift Between Major Parties in Patchwork Pattern
description: Democrats and Republicans exchanged House seats in a patchwork pattern from Con necticut to New Mexico yes terday, with the Democrats winding up with a relatively modest net gain in their Con gressional strength.

title: BANK AIDE IS HELD IN 572,937 FRAUD
description: The operations supervisor of personal accounts at a branch of the. First National. City Bank was arraigned yesterday on charges of having embezzled almost $73,000 from the bank.

title: Girl, 9, Beaten and Raped At Polo Grounds Project
description: A 9yearold girl was beaten and raped yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds housing development, 2999 Eighth Av enue. She was taken to Harlem Hospital?? where she was report ed in a semicoma.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT DEFENDED BY F.A.A.
description: The Federal Aviation Ad ministration defended Kennedy International Airport yesterday against charges that transport was deteriorating from a safety standpoint and was a national disgrace.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Sweep To Victor in Connecticut
description: Republican candidates for Governor and the United States Senate swept to victory in Connecticut yesterday, ending 16 years of Democratic control of the state. Representative Thomas J. Meskill, a 42year old, twoterm Congressman with a conservative voting record, defeated Representa tive Emilio Q. Daddario, 52, by more than 125,000 votes for Governor.

title: NEWEST RANGER TAKES WORKOUT
description: The reluctant Ranger, Pete Stemkowski, looked around the locker room yesterday and said: Yeah, there's a few guys here from Manitoba. Billy Fair bairn over there, he's from Brandon. So at least I got some of my people from back home.

title: MARLBORO MUSIC: A COOLER GROUP
description: The Music from Marlboro concert at Tully Hall Monday night was in some ways typical of that series and in some ways not.

title: Fiancee of Suspect in MailTheft Ring Seized in Courthouse Surprise
description: A young woman who went to the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn to hear a bailreduc tion plea on behalf of her fianc, accused of stealing thousands of welfare checks, left the court a prisoner yes terday.

title: RICHEY VANQUISHES FROEHLING IN 3 SETS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 (UPI) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., reached the quarterfinals of the South American interna tional open tennis champion ships today by beating Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., 75, 60, 64.

title: 1,200 Attend Panther Rally Protesting Trial of Seale
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3David Dellinger, one of the Chicago defendants, told 1,200 people at a Black Panther rally here today that a judge whose chil dren have not been bitten by rats is not fit to judge a Black Panther.

title: Screen: Jacobs's 'a.k.a. Cassius Clay' Begins Run:Kiley Is Narrator of Evslin Script 'Computer Wore Tennis Shoes' Also Opens.
description: By means of film clips, voice-over narration, and even a few instructional skits, "a.k.a. Cassius Clay" attempts to trace the career of Muhammad Ali (also known as Cassius Clay) from the early years until not quite recently enough to include Ali's return to the ring and last week's technical knockout of Jerry Quarry in Atlanta. It is difficult to imagine a dull movie from this material, and "a. k. a. Cassius Clay" isn't dull. But it also isn't as interesting as it might have been with more of Ali and his opponents, more of Malcolm X, more of Cus D'Amatoand rather less of Richard Kiley's pointedly inconclusive narration.Jim Jacobs, the director, and Bernard Evslin, the writer, cast their film as a kind of photo-journalism, so that it commits not only the minor sins of the genrefor example, the editorial stop shotsbut also the major sin of trying to turn its subject into a phenomenon, the embodiment of a trend, when in fact that subject offers in its own right the terms of a significant dramatic essay. Paradoxically "a.k.a. Cassius Clay" becomes more ordinary as it becomes more profoundin dealing with Muhammad Ali's convictions, his draft resistance and what it proposes is his importance for radical youth.But in treating the changing styles of a man who is always producing more or less lovely copy for the press, the film does pretty well. And whenever it enters the ring, of necessity, it does very well indeed.I don't know anything about boxing, and I don't even know what I like. But I am moved by Muhammad Ali's supple body and flashing feet, and by what seems the slightest and most dazzling excess of gesture at the moment before the opponent falls or before he staggers to the ropes, his face, almost unaccountably, a bloody mess.The best things in "a.k.a. Cassius Clay" concern the first Clay-Liston fight, where in the manner, the stance, the mere presence of the two men, a contest as if between two world orders seems to be taking place. Clay is, of course, brash and boastful and victorious. But Sonny Liston, throughout his training, the conferences, above all the prefight medical examination, suggests a grandeur, a kind of desperate invulnerability, like nothing I had seen in a movie before. It is as if the last of the great battleships, knowing its end was near, had transformed all its armament into one superb doomed image of invulnerability.

title: METS OPEN AT HOME WITH EXPOS APRIL 6
description: The New York Mets will open and close the 1971 season at Shea Stadium, Bob Scheffing, the club's general manager, said yesterday. Montreal will be the former world champion's openingday opponent on Tuesday, April 6. The Mats will conclude the sea son on Thursday, Sept. 30, in a 7:05 P.M. game against St. Louis.

title: TaySachs Group Will Gain at Dance
Olof Wallenius Is Dead at 68; Headed Swedish Shipping Line
description: Olof Wallenius, one of Swe den's principal ship owners and a pioneer in automobile ship ping, died of a stroke in Stock holm Monday. He was 68 years old.

description: CALAIS, Vt., Nov. 3 (AP) Lewis F. Manly, a former Tufts University professor and foot ball and basketball coach, died yesterday while visiting a son in Plattsburgh, N. Y. He was 67 years old.

description: The voters have now spoken on the effort of President Nixon and his fellow Republican campaigners to impose a single political theme on this vast, diverse nation with its countless local crosscurrents  an effort that relied on tireless barnstorming and a television blitz. Despite Republican gains in Connecticut and elsewhere, it would appear that this nationwide effort has scored only iso lated success.

title: OWNER UNHAPPY WITH 151 MARK

Calley Jr. on charges stemming from the alleged massacre at Mylai, have been postponed to Nov. 10. Lieuten ant Calley is charged with the slaying of 102 Vietnamese civil ians.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Vaunted hero from yesteryear and distinguished alumnus of the Los Angeles Rams, Tom Fears was singled out for a special tribute during halftime ceremonies in the Tulane Stadium at New Orleans last Sunday. G.M., meanwhile, reported that its sales in the final third of Oc tober continued to fall.

The wedding is planned for next month in Washing ton, D.C.

DeBremaecker had ap pealed the case, asking that he be considered a spokesman for all Texas residents active in the peace movement.

title: The President's Daughter, YiddishAmerican Comedy, Opens
description: All the ingredients are natural ones in The Presi dent's Daughter, the Yid dishAmerican musical com edy that opened at the Billy Rose Theater last night: a handsome widower, a nubile refugee who is acting as his housekeper, an orphan daughter, a scheming di vorce, a spinster sisterin law and cupid in the form of an old butter and egg man (that's right). Through a mis understanding, the widower latches on to the scheming divorce and the problem then becomes how to sep arate the two long enough so that the right couple can get married and provide the orphan daughter with a mother.

Bond, a selfstyled revolutionary, pleaded not ?? in Superior Court today ?? murder and robbery charges ?? the slaying of a Boston police man during a $26,000 bank holdup on Sept 23. The 26year old Bond, who was arrested in Grand Junction, Colo., was ordered by Judge Reuben L. Lurie to undergo 35 days mental observation at Bridge water State Mental Hospital.

title: Books of The Times
description: This is a rare entertainmenta tour de force, but considerably more; the best historical novel in years, yet more various and demanding; a piece of literary spec ulation, not scholarly but wise; a delight. Three Years to Play is not the Colin MacInnes of The London NovelsCity,. of Spades, Absolute Beginners, Mr. Love and Justicebut the MacInnes of Westward to Laughter, only writ large, the imagination ram pant. Which is to say, Three Years to Play is not about our time, out Shakespeare's. It is set in the London of Eliza beth I, the end of the 16th century and the beginning of the 17th. Shake speare himself is a character; his love life and his politi cal intriguing touched on; and a play of his, based on our hero's travail, is produced in the (then brandnew) Globe. Theatre, with the resulting mayhem transcribed in outra geous iambic pentameter. There is the shock of genius in this book, and not all of the genius belongs to Shakespeare.

title: What Does It Mean for 1972?
description: The main thing about the 1970 American election is what it means for the Presidential election of 1972. All this noisy scuffling over the last few weeks was merely spring practice for the opening of the battle for the White House two years from now.

title: Abitibi Paper Lifts Price Of Newsprint $8 a Ton
description: Abitibi Paper Company, Ltd., announced in Toronto yesterday that it will roll back its news print increase scheduled for Jan. 1 to $8 a ton from $10 a ton announced earlier.

title: Offshore Complex Pumps Petroleum
description: NEFTYANIYE KAMNI, U.S.S.R., Nov. 2 (AP)  Twice a month Khamil Rzayev says goodby to his wife, goes down to the Baku waterfront and boards a ship that brings him out to this city on stilts in the Caspian Sea.

title: Taming the Technological Monster
description: In the years after the war, it was widely believed that science, technol ogy and economic measures were the hope of the future; they were to be the great deliverers from drudgery and the promise of a Golden Age. Perhaps we put too much faith in them, perhaps we expected too much from this form of materalism.

title: 2 FROM U.S. ACCUSED BY MOSCOW ON JEWS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (Reuters)  Tass, the Soviet press agen cy, said today that customs of ficers seized slanderous in formation about Soviet Jews from two Americans as they were leaving the Soviet Union after a visit in August.

title: Vietcong Gone, Bombers Gone, but Not Village's Scars
description: CHOTHOM, South Vietnam, Nov. 1All through the nine teensixties this hamlet and much of the surrounding coun tryside in the Mekong Delta belonged to the Vietcong. For a year it has been held by the South Vietnamese Government, and the countryside appears to be secure.

title: U.N. Assembly. Is Ready to Debate 3 Resolutions on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3The General Assembly concluded the policystatement part of its debate on the Middle East today to clear the way for consideration of three draft resolutions that have been put before it.

title: Effies and Clios Backers Planning to Consolidate
description: Against a background of grumbling noises brought on by the proliferation of ad vertising awards, two of the awards promoters have an nounced an incorporation.

title: Johannes Urzidil, Writer, Dies; Close Friend of Kafka Was 74
description: ROME, Nov. 3 Johannes Urzidil, a Czechoslovak writer Who was a close friend of Franz Kafka, the novelist, died here yesterday after a stroke. He was 74 years old.

title: Abortion Is the Issue in Washington State
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Emotioncharged ballot issues, including a referendum on abortion, and unseasonally warm temperatures drew Wash ington voters today in expected record numbers.

title: LONDON STOCKS MUSTER ADVANCE
description: The London Stock Exchange was firm yesterday, but quiet. Some support was apparent at late Monday's lower levels fol lowing the recent shakeout, but buying remained negligible while investors awaited the Government's monetary policy statement, which is expected today.

title: Letters to the Editor
HUMPHREY SENT TO SENATE AGAIN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, Nov. 4  Former Vice Presi dent Hubert H. Humphrey easily cleared the first hurdle in his political comeback last night, easily winning a Senate seat over Representative Clark MacGregor, a Republican.

title: Article 1  No Title
Montoni and Bonde Join for Recital On Viola and Piano
description: Recitals for viola and piano are not so scarce as sonatas for accompanied triangle, but when one does take place the listener often wishes they were. The number of recitalworthy violists is not great, the reper tory is stunted by comparison with those of other solo instru ments, and the viola itself is severely limited in tone color and flexibility. Still, the pro gram presented at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by Raymond Montoni, who teaches viola and violin at Kent State University, and Allen Bonde, a pianist who heads the Hood College music college managed to overcome those challenges rather successfully.

title: GOLDBERG KEEPS DIGNITY IN DEFEAT
description: For Arthur J. Goldberg last night there was a first, last and only hurrah.

title: 4TERM GOVERNOR
description: Governor Rockefeller was elected to a fourth term yester day, easily defeating Arthur J. Goldberg, the former Supreme Court Justice, who was per suaded to run by Democratic leaders convinced that he would be the best candidate they had ever run against the Republican Governor.

title: Bentsen Defeats Bush in Texas Despite Massive Effort by Nixon
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., the Democratic candidate for the Senate, rode to victory today on the crest of an unexpected high vote total. He defeated Representa tive George Bush, a Republican, who had received massive back ing from President Nixon.

title: DUKE POWER NET OFF IN 9 MONTHS
description: The Duke Power Company reported yesterday a decline in net income for the first nine months of 1970 although reve nues for the period ran ahead of yearago figures.

title: Slain Legislator Reelected
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 3 (AP) State Senator Larry N. Kuri yama, who was shot to death Oct. 23 in the garage of his hillhop home, was reelected today because he was unop posed and his death occurred too late to remove his name from the ballot. A special elec tion will be held in January to fill the vacancy.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
Senior Bowl Pay Raised
description: MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 3 (UPI) Senior Bowl officials said to day players pay for the 1971 football allstar game among college seniors would be raised $250 a man. The winning play ers will receive $1,500 each and the losers $1,250.

title: MIDWEST EXCHANGE NOMINATES LEADER
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange announced yesterday in Chi cago that Richard W. Simmons, a partner in Blunt, Ellis & Sim mons, since 1948, had been nominated for reelection as chairman of the exchange's board of governors.

title: McGee Is Reelected to Third Term
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 3 Senator Gale W. McGee was re turned tonight by the individ ualistic people of Wyoming to his third sixyear term in the United States Senate.

title: MRS. SAMUEL TARSHIS
Tydings Loses to Beall in Maryland Senate Race
description: BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Nov. 4Representative J. Glenn Beall Jr., a Republican defeated Senator Joseph D. Tydings yes terday in the contest for the Senate.

title: Gilels and Hurok Mark SovietU. S. Anniversary
description: When Emil Gilels sits down at the piano tonight at Philharmonic Hall, he will be marking the 15th anniver sary of SovietAmerican cul tural exchange, in which he was the first Soviet artist to appear in the United States.

title: U.S. Controller Approves Merger of Jersey Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP)  The Controller of the Cur rency approved today acquisi tion of the Orange Valley Bank, Orange, N. J., by the First Na tional State Bank of New Jer sey.

title: Westchester Vote
SenatorElect Buckley
description: The election of James L. Buckley to the United States Senate is a step backward for New York and a possibly misleading one for the country. The Conservative party candidate is not himself an extremisthe is, in fact, a moderate and cultivated man with a vague and negative programbut he and his party are symbols. More will be read into their triumph than the facts warrant.

title: 2 POLICEMEN SEIZED IN BRIBERY ATTEMPT
description: Two plainclothes policemen in Brooklyn were arrested yes terday after they allegedly ac cepted a $1,500 bribe from a bookmaker they had arrested the day before.

title: A Peanut Farmer Wins Race in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Wednesday, Nov. 4Jimmy Carter, a Democrat who is a peanut farmer, sound ly trounced his Republican op ponent, Hal Suit, a former tele vision newsman, yesterday to become Governor of Georgia.

title: NUDE BALLET SCENE IS DANCED IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Nov. 3  London adjusted easily last night to its first nude ballet scene.

RABBI DAVID ENGLANDER
description: IRVINGTON, N. J., Nov. 3 Rabbi David Englander, father of Rabbi Benjamin H. Englander, Spiritual leader of Congregation B'nai Israel here, died Friday Petach Tikva, Israel. He was 90 years old.

title: Morocco Denies Reports Of U.S. Naval Base There
description: RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 3 Morocco today categorically denied the existence of any foreign military or strategic bases on her soil. The state ment was made after reports from Washington had said the United States continued to maintain a naval communica tions station at Knitra, 25 miles north of Rabat.

title: Three Tests for an Electorate
description: ANN ARBORThe phrase partici patory democracy, used so often by politicians in recent days, can be de ceptive. It clearly suggests that there are kinds of democracy of which some are participatory and some are not. But the participation of the members of a community in their own govern ment is the very essence of democracy. Any government today calling itself democratic that is not participatory is either a failure or a fraud.

title: A Polite Whoop of Victory on East 73d Street

Goldberg in Westchester County, while the Conservative Senate candidate, James L. Buckley, was running well ahead of his two oppon ents, Senator Charles E. title: LOLITA TO APPEAR AS MUSICAL IN 71
description: A musical adaptation of Vladimir Nabokov's novel, Lo lita, will be presented on Broadway in March by Norman Twain.

title: 'The Owl and the Pussycat' Bows on Screen
description: In any compilation of the modern world's 10 most unrewarding stunts, the casting of Barbra Streisand in a straight comedy, especially one as flimsily fabricated as "The Owl and The Pussycat," must rank close to Charles A. Stephens's 1920 attempt to ride over Niagara Falls in a barrel, which turned out to be fatal.Miss Streisand survives "The Owl and The Pussycat," but largely on goodwill, and because even though she never sings, it's possible to remember what happens when she does: through the force of a mysterious, implacable talent, she goes a long way toward making one agree that she isas she proclaimed in "Funny Girl," with an immense desire to pleasethe greatest star.Without a song, she simply isn't.There is still that immense desire to please, but it now seems rooted in belligerency, rather than vulnerability. As Doris Waverly/Wadsworth/Wellington (nee Wilgus), a very improbable New York hooker with a heart of gold, Miss Streisand, the straight comedienne, lacks one essential feature, namely a heart. The performance, which may owe a lot to the manner in which it was written (by Buck Henry) and directed (by Herbert Ross), is mostly cold and edgy and aggressive and loud. There are odd, but only occasional moments  when she suddenly smiles a genuine smile, or when she is listening to someone other than herself (for a change)that recall, if distantly, the real, feeling, thinking performer whose soul is in her music.The screenplay, based on Bill Manhoff's 1964 Broadway comedy (which I did not see), is a fable that lost its innocence some seasons earlier, about the fanciful hooker and the mousy intellectual (George Segal), a Doubleday clerk who, anticipating literary fame, has changed his name from Fred to Felix.In order to be good theater, the discovery by Felix and Doris that they are good for each other need not be as surprising as metaphysical revelation, but it should, at least, be funny. The humor in "The Owl and The Pussycat," however, has to do largely with sarcasm, insult and the sort of logic that has Doris announce: "I may be a prostitute, but I'm not promiscuous."Paradoxically, although the tone of the film is vaguely anti-intellectual, a lot of the humor also depends on language. Much is made of the fact that Doris doesn't understand words like despicable, esthetic, assimilate and intrinsic. Then, reaching for the real boffs, the screenplay has Doris utter some ordinary, if vulgar, four-letter word. On second thought, this may be a perfectly valid comic ploy in a society that takes obscene words, either written on placards or shouted, so seriously that they have become, in effect, political weapons. We are, indeed, a sensitive people.The movie is not without its appealing moments, and most of these belong to Mr. Segal, who manages to retain his innate dignity and comic style, even when he is required to over-react as the quintessential nebbish so dear to the heart of Old Broadway. There is also a moment, right at the end, when Miss Streisand responds to him with something like dignity but, for the most part, the sense of the performance is communicated by her long, claw-like fingernails. This pussycat is a full-grown predator."The Owl and The Pussycat" opened yesterday at the Loew's State 2 and Loew's Cin Theaters.

title: FANNY MAY CITES INCREASED YIELDS

description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 4 Douglas E. Stuart, a former magazine editor, died yester day at his home in Hopewell. He was 58 years old.

title: RALLY EXTENDED ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market extended Tuesday's rally yes terday following the upsurge on Wall Street. Buying sup port was limited, however, while investors awaited the im minent Government monetary policy statement.

title: Advantage of Incumbents Kept House Shift Small
description: Democrats retained control of the House, picking up a handful of Republican seats, in an elec tion that once again demon strated the advantage of being an incumbent.

title: Caso First in G.O.P. in 9 Years To Take the Top Post in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4 Ralph G. Caso, who was elected Nassau County Executive yes terday, ?? will be the first Republican to hold the top county post since Eugene H. Nickerson, a Democrat, was elected nine years ago.

title: CARROLL SEARLS, 76, LAWYER HERE, DIES
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 4Carroll Searls, former gencral counsel and secretary of the Newmont Mining Corpo ration in New York, died at his home here today after a short illnes. He was 76 years old and lived at 15 Courtland Avenue.

title: Entertainment Events
Decisive Decline Laid to Belief G.M. Strike Will Keep Business Slow
VICTORS HELPED BY 2 EARLY GOALS
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 4 (UPI) The California Seals peppered the New York goalie, Ed Gia comin, with 35 shots en route to 31 National Hockey League victory over they Rang ers tonight.

title: Wood Field and Stream: It Pays to Talk to Fish
description: CAROLINA BEACH, N. C. Creeping along the grassy margin of Snow's Cut, a por tion of the Intracoastal Wa terway that links Cape Fear River with Myrtle Sound, Dan Holt of Carolina Beach talked to the fish, asking them to bite.

title: Traluck in No. 3 Post For Messenger Stakes
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 4 Of the three pacers re garded as the most likely to succeed in Saturday night's $123,450.92 Messen ger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway, Max Hochberg's and Louis Resnick's Truluck fared the best in today's post position draw. The son of Torpid and Monel, who will be driven by John, (Tic) Wil cutts, drew the No. 3 berth.

title: Rafferty Is Defeated by a Negro As California Education Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4In one of the most stunning up sets in California's political his tory, Wilson Riles, a tall, earn est black man, yesterday de feated Max Rafferty, the artic ulate spokesman of the far right, for the office of State Superintendent of Public In struction.

title: How to Win Games and Still Have Fun
description: His philosophies violate basic football theory: His de fensive tackles weigh 145 pounds, his offensive players wear shoulder pads only in games, his teams have not practiced a shoulder block in five years and they never scrimmage.

title: Jackson Keeps Senate Seat On 84% of Washington Vote
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Nov. 4 Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, won 84 per cent of the vote yesterday in de feating his Republican chal lenger, Charles W. Elicker.

title: McGrath Asks New LightSecurity jail
description: Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath asked the City Planning Commission yes terday for $2.6million for land to be used for a dormitory, type of prison.

title: Giants Sue San Francisco Over Surcharge on Tickets

description: McCONNELLSBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 (UPI)The bodies of two young women from Queens, both of them shot and one apparently strangled, were found at the foot of an embank ment off Interstate 70 about two miles north of the Mary land border today.

title: Sports Today
Egan Regains Governor's Post in Alaska
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 4 Alaskan voters have entrusted the governorship to William A. Egan, a 56yearold Democrat who guided them through the first eight years of statehood.

description: Richard. K. Manoff, Inc., trotted into the winner's cir cle yesterday after a hot race for the advertising assign ment from the newly formed OffTrack Betting Corpora tion.

title: Will Flood Continue to Pursue Case?

title: BIG FOUR REPORT BERLIN PROGRESS
description: BERLIN, Nov. 4Represent atives of the four victorious powers of World War II re ported today, that they had made progress on essential ele ments of a Berlin settlement.

title: French Climb Annapurna
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Nov. 4 (Reuter)  Two French climb ers have made the first ascent of Annapurna in the Himalayas by the tough south face, it was announced here today. The climbers, Maurice Igicouel and Gerard Devouassoux, both from Chamonix, reached the 24,300 foot summit of the mountain on Oct. 27.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  The United States has decided to withdraw the lone Ameri can division guarding an 18 mile stretch of the Korean de militarized zone, turning over the defense of the entire 155 mile boundary to South Korea.

description: TRENTON, Nov. 4 (UPI)  Nearly half the students of Trenton's public schools were absent from classes today as the controversial busing pro gram that caused racial clashes last week remained in effect.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Tightening Reins After Tranquilizer Case

Here at Roosevelt Raceway, where three pacers were scratched from last night's sixth race and the race was made a nonbetting event for five horses, extra precautions are being taken.

title: Chess:
Sons of Famous Fathers Elected to Senate in California, Ohio and Illinois
Crash Kills Mother and Sons
description: MILFORD, N. J., Nov. 4 (AP) A mother and her two sons were killed yesterday in a car trailer crash near here. The state police identified the vic tims as Mrs. Priscilla Kennedy, 42 years old, and her sons James, 17, and Mark, 14, all of Holland Township. The police said a sixwheel trailer came loose from a dump truck that was towing it and collided with the Kennedy automobile.

Jarring, Secretary General Thant's special representative.

title: ...Portents for 1972
description: These results would make it appear that, although Mr. Nixon has the ambition, the money and the political organization to make the G.O.P. into the nation's major ity party, there is a lack in personal magnetism and in a positive, broadgauged program. He seems unlikely to do for the Republicans what Franklin D. Roosevelt did for the Democrats in a comparable upheaval in the 1930's convert a whole generation of voters to his party.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI)  A Government con tract was let today for con struction of a permanent grave site for Senator Robert F. Kennedy at Arlington Na tional Cemetery.

description: About 20 persons were in jured when a Pan American World Airways 747 jumbo jet hit a pocket of air turbulence and went into a sharp drop of several hundred feet over Nan tucket last night.

title: HRUSKA'S VICTORY WAS A CLOSE CALL
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 4Ne braska's senior Senator, Roman L. Hruska, received the fright of his political life in yesterday's general election before being assured of a third full term.

description: The Maltese is a dog long on history, shaft in figure. publius the Roman governor of the island of Malta, is said to have had one Of the tiny white toy dogs nearly 2,000 years ago. Of the current vin tage, the most famous in America is Ch. Pendleton's Jewel. According to the Ken

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Hazel Park Adds 10th Race
description: HAZEL PARK, Mich., Nov. 4 (UPI)A 10th race was added today to the Nov. 13 card at Hazel Park, replacing the race canceled Monday when four of the seven entries were found to have been tranquilized.

title: 5 MISSISSIPPI BLACKS GAIN SCHOOL POSTS
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 4 At least five Negroes won posts on county schools boards in Mississippi yesterday.

title: 'Bullet for Pretty Boy' Recalls an Era
description: Larry Buchanan's "A Bullet for Pretty Boy," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, recounts the criminal career of Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd from the time when he, a decent fellow, accidentally kills a lout who had insulted his bride and shot his father, until he in turn is killed by Federal agents, also decent fellows, sent to stop his embarrassing bank robberies. I don't believe the movie is especially true to life, but it surely is a lot nicer.I don't know how you can make a murderous gangster movie full of mostly nice guys, and I'm not sure that Larry Buchanan knows how either, but he has tried. Pretty Boy (Fabian Forte, ex Fabian) gulps a lot every time he kills somebody (almost never on purpose), and none of his friends and neighbors turn him in when he hides out with themeven though he carries a handsome reward if caught, and if not caught poses a threat to the friends and neighbors.Both Ruby (Astrid Warner), the girl he marries and leaves behind, and Betty (Jocelyn Lane), the girl who picks him up along the way, really love him, and they fully understand each other's feelings. When Pretty Boy guns down the treacherous brothers of the nice madam with whom he sometimes lives, she also understands and, although upset, doesn't blame him for a minute."A Bullet for Pretty Boy" is not, therefore, "Bonnie and Clyde," though there are many pointed references to the Depression so as to place the action in time, and also many ballad-type songs, so as to make it timeless.Actually, the film looks a little as if they had taken the members of the cast of, say, "Beach Blanket Bingo" and put them in costume and given them old cars to drive and told them to play it for real. For real it isn't. The bank robberies at first resemble trips to the super-market (express check-out) and later, when Pretty Boy gets a gang of his own, with girls, they resemble young people's outings. When somebody gets shot he crumples down in a grotesque posture and rolls up his eyes and plays deadthe way kids might on the playground or in an amateur theatrical.Thus the appeal of "A Bullet for Pretty Boy," which is pretty minor, is in a sense a function of its several insufficiencies. I liked all the cast, though I couldn't reasonably praise any of them, except for Michael Haynes as an old-time bank robber with whom Pretty Boy serves a brief apprenticeship. Both Miss Lane and Miss Warner are very lovely. Miss. Warner especially, who plays the tragic wife in the manner of the girl next door, ought to be everybody's girl next door. In her performance, as in so much else in the movie, there is an awkward innocence, an utterly inappropriate charm.

title: Austrian Aide Hints Support For Red China in U.N. Seat
description: VIENNA, Nov. 4Austria will probably vote for admitting Communist China to the United Nations and expects to open ne gotiations with it on diplomatic recognition, the Foreign Minis ter, Rudolf Kirchschlger, said today. He added that there had been no contacts so far and without United Nations mem bership recognition was unlikely in the near future.

title: NEW YORKERS WIN 7TH GAME IN ROW
Baltimore Democrats Light Vote Held Factor in Tydings Defeat
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 4Ordi nary Democratic voters of both races in Baltimore stayed home in significant numbers yesterday and apparently con stituted the main factor in the defeat of Senator Joseph D. Tydings by Representative J. Glenn Beall.

title: Pakistan Approves Steel Mill
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 4  President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan and his Cabinet today approved plans for the construction of Pakistan's sec ond steel mill. The mill, to be constructed with Soviet techni cal and economic aid totaling $200million, will be at Buleji, about 30 miles from here. The other mill is at Chittagong, in eastern Pakistan.

title: Milton M. Stuart, 66, Founder Of Stock Exchange House, Dies
description: Milton M. Stuart, senior partner of Stuart Brothers, in vestment brokers of 55 Broad Street, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 895 Park Avenue and in Cos Cob, Conn., and Palm Beach. Fla.

description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) Bacuco, a 4yearold from Italy, today became the 10th horse in the field for the $150,000 Wash ington D.C. International at Laurel on Nov. 11.

description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 4 Seven proposals for revisions in the City Charter were all approved in yesterday's election here. The changes had been sought for several years, and some of them had been de feated when placed on the bal lot in previous elections.

title: G.M. SUES TO BALK U.S. SAFETY ORDER
description: DETROIT, Nov. 4The Fed eral Government ordered the General Motors Corporation to day to tell thousands of truck owners that their wheels had a dangerous safety defect, but the company denied the wheels were defective and filed a Fed eral court suit to block the Government action.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 4President Nixon said today that Republicans scored a vic tory in yesterday's midterm elections because the voters had given him a working ideo logical majority in the Senate.

title: C. B.S.'s Harry Reasoner Joining A.B.C.

description: HOLLISTER. Calif., Nov. 4 (AP)  A bomb explosion knocked out windows and ex tensively damaged the store front Hollister headquarters of Cesar Chavez' United Farm Workers Organizing Committee early today, the police said.

description: The Hostess Club of Grace Congregational Church (Unit ed Church of Christ) will honor John L. Motley, the church organist and director and conductor of the AllCity High. School Chorus, at a luncheon Saturday at the Americana.

description: It is a pity that public en thusiasm in this country for male choruses is not what it used to be, because one of the best ones imaginable is now making its first tour of the United States. It is the Royal Uppsala University Chorus of Sweden, and its New York debut took place at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night.

description: The answer to this question de pends on Soviet motivesdo they want real dtente between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, or have they other aims? Where might one look for an answer?

description: Three Negroes from districts where blacks are in the minority were elected to the House of Representatives in Tuesday's election. They will become the only Negro. House members to represent constit uencies that are not mostly black.

title: Woman Jockey, at 45, First to Win in Ontario
description: TORONTO, Nov. 4 (Canadi an Press)Mrs. Joan O'Shea brought home Storkys Pride in the fifth race at Green wood Race Track today and became the first woman jockey to win at an Ontario track. Storkys Pride, a 2 yearold filly, paid $14.40 straight.

title: BOY HELD AS SHOTS ARE FIRED AT POLICE
description: A youth was arrested and charged with attempted murder last night after two shots were fired at two pattolmen who stopped a car for a routine traffic violation in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: Experts Will Try to Resolve BonnWarsaw Issues
description: WARSAW, Nov. 4The Polish and West German Foreign Min isters decided today to turn their thornier problems over to technical experts in an attempt to work out a treaty establish ing normal relations between their countries.

title: Media Experts Doubt Value of TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Television proved to be less than a magic medium in yes terday's elections.

title: Wrigley Sets Extra Dividend
description: CHICAGO, Nov, 4 (AP) Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company directors decided an extra dividend of 75 cents a share today. It is payable Dec. 1 along with a regular monthly dividend of 25 cents a share to stockholders, of record Nov. 16. Monthly dividends of 25 cents a share also were declared for Jan. 2 and Feb. 1 payment.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alan C. Egler has been appointed executive vice president of the Consumer Products Division of Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Aspen Rejects Bid Of Hippie Candidate For Sheriff's Office
description: ASPEN, Colo., Nov. 4 (AP) Hunter S. Thompson, the self proclaimed freak power candidate for sheriff of Pitkin County has lost, and he says he is through with the politics of the vote.

title: New R.C.A. Office Building Planned in Massachusetts
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Nov. (AP)R.C.A. announced today plans to build a $16million of fice building here to house the company's information systems and computer systems division.

title: Visiting Experts Praise Polish Jazz at Festival
description: WARSAW, Nov. 4The 13th annual Polish Jazz Jam boree, considered the biggest jazz event in Eastern Europe, ended here this week with Western experts apparently more enthusiastic about Po lish jazz than Polish critics ere.

title: Extent of Shapp's Victory Gives Democrats Legislative Control
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4  Behind Governorelect Milton J. Shapp, Democrats scored a sweep of historic proportions in the Pennsylvania elections yesterday.

title: $20,000 in Freight Stolen
The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System
R. A. Nathan to Wed Miss Fineberg
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 4The engagement of Miss Carol Ellen Fineberg to Richard Alan Nathan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Nathan of Milton and Pembroke, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Fineberg. A June wedding is planned.

title: Canucks Sell Forward
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (AP) The Montreal Voyageurs of the American Hockey League pur chased a forward, Germain Gagnon, from the Vancouver Canucks of the National League today.

title: NEW METHOD READY FOR DURABLE PRESS
description: A new postcured durable press process for apparel using no resins until the garment is constructed, was announced yesterday by the American Laundry Machinery Industries division of McGraw  Edison Company.

title: Nathan's Found Guilty of Unfair Labor Activities
description: The National Labor Relations Board, in a decision made pub lic yesterday, found Nathan's Famous of Yonkers, Inc., guilty of unfair labor practices, and certified Local 50 of the Ameri can Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union as bargaining agent for the restaurant's em nloves.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS COUNT SUCCESSES
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 Crusaders for environmental protection counted victories from coast to coast today in the elections yesterday, the first in which conservation issues figured prominently on a national scale.

title: LUCIUS LIGHTFOOT, BUSINESS REPORTER
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Nov. 4 Wallace Lucius Lightfoot Sr., a former business reporter for The New York Times, died Sunday in Passaic General Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 226 Luddington Avenue.

title: An Unorthodox Makropoulos Affair
Auburn Prisoners Hold 50 Hostages Eight Hours
description: AUBURN, N. Y., Nov. 4 Prisoners seized control of the state prison here today and held it for eight hours before they returned to their cells and agreed to discuss their griev ances with the authorities.

title: 2 Texas Amendments Drew Enough Voters for Bentsen to Win
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 4Two pro posed amendments to the State Constitution apparently lured enough rural voters to provide the strength that Lloyd M. Bentsen?? Jr., a Democrat, needed to win a Senate seat in yester day's elections in Texas.

title: Black Sweep of County Alarms Alabama Whites
description: EUTAW, Ala., Nov. 4Ne groes swept all major elective offices in Greene County here in yesterday's election, The first such country wide elective sweep since the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Gimeno Upsets Laver
description: ROME, Nov. 4 (UPI)Andres Gimeno of Spain upset Rod Laver of Australia 75, 26, 64. in the fourplayer professional tennis tour of Italy today. Cliff Drysdale of South Africa beat Britain's Roger Taylor. 61, 64.

title: Kinshasa and Brazzaville To Restore Diplomatic Ties
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Nov. 4 (Agence TrancePresse)  President Joseph D. Mobutu announced here today that dip lomatic relations would be re stored on Dec. 15 with the neighboring Republic of the Congo, the former French colony.

title: Course Change Is Blamed In Collision of 2 Tankers
description: LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) A Dutch pilot said today that a collision between the Libe rianregistered supertankers Pa cific Glory and Allegro in the English Channel on Oct. 23 would not have happened if the Allegro had not suddenly changed course.

title: Britain Rules Out a PostApollo Role
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 4Britain took the lead today in rejecting a United States proposal for a European contribution to the postApollo program. The move came at a 13nation conference of members of the two Euro pean organizations for space and launching research.

title: RED CROSS ACCORD DROPPED BY GREECE
description: ATHENS, Nov. 4  The mili tarybacked Government, after denouncing its yearold agree ment granting the International Committee of the Red Cross access to prisoners, hinted to day that it would consider a re vised agreement.

title: The U.N. Against Itself
description: Egypt scored a propaganda victory at the United Nations yesterday when the General Assembly adopted, with heavy abstentions, a modified version of an Afro Asian resolution on the Middle East. But the price of that victory is likely to be a setback for the cause of peacein which Egypt has as vital a stake as anyone and for the world organization.

title: Aaron Wins Gehrig Award
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP) Hank Aaron, Atlanta Braves outfielder, was named the win ner today of the 1970 Lou Geh rig Memorial Award.

title: Mrs. Cushing and T. C. Flood, Stockbroker, to Marry Nov. 21
description: Invitations have been sent out for the forthcoming mar riage of Mrs. Ruth Dunbar Cushing and Terrence Carson Flood of Montreal, where he is a stockbroker with Mor gan, Ostiguy and Hudon. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Carson Flood, also of Montreal.

title: ...Mixed Election Results ...
description: In the 1970 elections President Nixon tried to exploit these upheavals in the South and in the Northern cities to the Republican party's advantage with a campaign narrowly but powerfully focused on the crimeviolence permissiveness issue. The mixed results on Tuesday show how difficult it is for the Republicans to accom plish their purposes.

title: The Reshaping of the Parties...
description: The selfcontradictory results of Tuesday's election provide fresh evidence that the nation is passing through a profound political transition. It is too early to tell whether the final consequence of this transition will be a reshaping of the Republicans and Democrats into ide ologically pure conservative and liberal parties or wheth er the two major parties will fragment into four or five parties on the European model.

title: Jersey Vote Called Blow to Nixo??
description: TRENTON, Nov. 4  Demo cratic and Republican party leaders in New Jersey gen erally agreed today that a major impetus behind the elec tion victory of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. was an overwhelming rejection by the voters of a divisive Republican campaign.

title: Tariff Panel Examines Impact of Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4The United States Tariff Commis sion opened today a wide ranging investigation of Ameri can competitiveness against the industry of foreign countries.

title: Wiltfang Gains Second Victory in Jump at Horse Show
description: Gert Wiltfang, a 24yearold automobile dealer, and Goldika, a 9yearold mare, formed a fast and effective combination to win an international jumping class for the second time at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Gains Made by Muskie, Humphrey and Kennedy
description: The Democratic party came out of the Tuesday elections like a hibernating bear out of a dark cave, savoring the warm sun of success and stretching political muscle it had suddenly rediscovered.

title: Vandals Injure an Engineer, Delaying Eight Trains Here
description: stones tnrown by vandals severely injured an engineer of a New Haven train yesterday and resulted in eight train delays of up to 70 minutes.

title: BURDICK OF DAKOTA HAILS VOLUNTEERS
description: FARGO, N. D., Nov. 4 (UPI) Senator Quentin S. Burdick, a Democrat, cited people power today for his election victory yesterday over his White House endorsed Republican challenger, Tom Kleppe.

title: MAKEUP OF THE HOUSE STARTING JAN. 3, 1971
Muskie Keeps Seat, but Maine Governor Race Is Tight
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 4  Senator Edmund S. Muskie won reelection handily yesterday, as did the two incumbent Democratic Representatives?? But Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis, a?? Democrat, was still locked in a tight battle tonight.

title: Amex Prices Show Slight Drop As Turnover Registers Decline
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly low er yesterday after some late selling pressure erased most of the earlier gains.

title: Eastern Life Cites Record
Mrs. Mitchell Blames G.O.P. for Its Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI)The wife of the At torney General, Mrs. John N. Mitchell, who has a reputa tion for calling them as she sees them, said today that the Republicans had only themselves to blame for their losses in yesterday's elec tions.

title: EUGENE B. M'CAUL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Eu gene B. McCaul, director of sta stics for the American Transit Association from 1946 until his retirement a year ago, died to day after a long illness. His age was 64.

title: FONG AND BURNS WIN IN HAWAII ELECTIONS
description: HONOLULU, Nov. 4Ha waiian voter elected both Sena tor Hiram L. Fong, a Republican, and Gov. John A. Burns, a Democrat, to third terms in yes terday's elections.

title: Miss Judy Rutter Warriner Is Fiancee of S. C. Walke Jr.
description: ARDSLEY, N. Y., Nov. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Lendall P. Warriner of Ardsley and Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Judy Rutter Warriner, to Stephen Condict Walke Jr., son of the Rev. Mr. Walke, pastoral counselor at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Baltimore. The future bride groom is the son also of Mrs. Mary Montagu Walke of Alexandria, Va.

title: Cartoonists Set Show and Auction
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A Piano Prodigy at 3, Now the Conductor of Hair
description: She has skin the color of molasses taffy, eyes as black as olives and a mop of black curls that give her a piquant look. She's Margaret Harris, a musical prodigy who grew up to become one of the few women to conduct a big Broadway musical, Hair.

title: A MISFIRE BY NIXON IS DISCERNED IN UTAH
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 4  Senator Frank E. Moss was not hurt and may have been heleped by President Nixon's unsuccessful attempt to unseat him.

title: Lindsay Is Chided By Detroit's Mayor For Poaching Aides
description: Mayor Roman S. Gribbs of Detroit has gently chided Mayor Lindsay for trying to lure some of his city's top officials to work for New York.

title: Pasadena Bowl Pact Signed
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 4 (UPI)  An agreement under which the Missouri Valley Con ference football champion will meet the winner of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association title in the Pasadena Bowl Dec. 19 was signed today.

title: Meskill Victory Puts Republicans in Power in Connecticut After 16 Lean Years
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 4Politi cal power that has been in the hands of the Democratic party in Connecticut for the last 16 years shifted yesterday to the Republicans with the solid vic tory of Thomas J. Meskill for Governor.

title: House Race in Kentucky Hinges on Absentee Votes
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP)Absentee ballots were ex pected to decide the outcome of a neckandneck race in Kentucky's 3d Congressional district.

title: 2 Students on Colby Board
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 4 (AP)In accordance with a change in governmental struc ture suggested last fall by a constitutional convention and approved by the board of trustees, two Colby College students have been elected to oneyear terms as nonvoting representatives on the board, the college said yesterday.

title: GOVERNORS ELECTED
BACHELOR
Detroit VoteCounting Snarl Delays Michigan Governorship Tally
description: DETROIT, Nov. 4Another massive snarl in Detroit's new punchcard voting system kept Michigan from knowing for sure today who its new Governor would be.

title: Palace Digs in Its Records; Defends Duke in Ripper Case
description: LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP)  Buckingham Palace officials to day came to the defense of Edward Duke of Clarence, great uncle of Queen Elizabeth II, disputing charges that he might have been Jack the Ripper, a ghoulish murderer of the last century.

title: LTV Unit Gets Contract
DON KELLETT DEAD; EXCOLTS EXECUTIVE
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) Don Kellett, who retired as general manager of the Balti more Colts in 1966, died of a heart attack last night at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 62 years old.

title: Aftermath of a Bitter Campaign
description: In the morningafter judg ment of Federal officials and politicians yesterday, the elec tion returns are more likely to affect the politics of the nation than the principal policies of the Nixon Administration. Pres

title: HAWKS TRIUMPH OVER WINGS, 42
Genes Found Key Factor in Child Ills
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Genetic factors appear to be ei ther primary or very signifi cant in the illness of one child in five admitted to the pediatric service of one large hospital studied recently, a doc tor said here today.

title: STAR OUTFIELDER BACK IN BASEBALL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) Curt Flood, who missed last season after bringing legal ac tion against baseball's reserve clause, has signed a oneyear, $110,000 contract with the Washington Senators contain ing the clause, the club's owner Bob Short, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
LEGISLATURE VOTE PLEASES DURYEA
description: The Legislature came out of the Tuesday election a shade less Republican, but Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr., declared yesterday that he viewed the results as tanta mount to an endorsement

title: Advertising: Wool Is Coming Out Bristling
description: The Wool Bureau is going to drop its nice guy pos ture and hit out at those newfangled synthetics with some very competitive ad vertising.

title: 3 Armed Robbers Smash Bank Wall And Get $37,400
description: Three men broke through a concrete inside wall of a Kennedy International Air port cargo building yesterday to enter the airport branch of the First National City Bank, then waited until em ployes arrived to rob the bank of $37,400.

title: 3 Arab Leaders Meet
description: CAIRO, Nov. 4  The lead ers of the United Arab Republic, Libya and the Sudan began consultations here today on the altered situation in the Arab world since the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Connecticut G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) The Pentagon today identi fied Sgt. Manuel D. Domine of Hartford of the Army as hav ing been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: A Goodwill Message to China Planned by Pope During Trip
description: ROME, Nov. 4Pope Paul VI announced today that he in tended to address a goodwill message to Communist China during his visit to Hong Kong on Dec. 4.

title: Evangelizing by Buckleys Pays Off at Last
description: The idea that James L. Buckley run for the United States Senate as a Conserva tive party candidate was ad vanced first by his younger brother, William F. Buckley Jr., a man of many words who has spent two decades as a polemicist and strate gist of conservative rena scence in America.

title: Moonship Put on Rocket
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI)The Apollo 14 moonship was mounted on its Saturn 5 rocket today in preparation for its move from the rocket assem bly building to the oceanside launching pad next Monday. Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., Comdr. Edgar D. Mitchell and Maj. Stuart A. Roosa are sched uled to set out on the nation's fourth moonlanding mission Jan. 31.

title: Books of The Times
ALLIES OF BRANDT FACE A VITAL TEST
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Nov. 2Heinz Herbert Karry, the Free Democratic leader in Hesse, is so confi dent that his small party will win its battle for survival in the state election Sunday by a comfortable margin that he is betting cases of wine on it.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CUT HEAD START FUNDS
description: Federal notices were sent yesterday to New York City, Newark and other major areas nearby announcing cuts of 13.5 per cent in funds for the Head Start program for preschool children. The cuts affect the budget year that started last July 1.

title: Market Place
description: Land development com panies  those enterprises that buy up major tracts and split them into lots for resale to you and me  have been under a cloud as a result of their questionable accounting methods.

title: U.S. BASE IS GIVEN TO SAIGON FORCES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Air Force took over an air base in the Mekong Delta today from the United States.

title: Elections Viewed Lacking As an Economic Mandate
description: Wall Street was counting on an Administration shift toward economic expansion prior to the national elections and found little in the outcome of Tuesday's balloting to alter its expectations. This was the consensus among economists and students of the stock market who were asked yesterday for their views on the economic out look. In general, the invest ment community was neither startled nor relieved with the results.

title: WHEAT FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Improved exports, inclement weather, and short covering sent wheat futures up fairly sharply yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade. Other grains also showed advances, while soybean futures prices were irregular.

title: Gore's Defeat Vindicates G.O.P. Faithin Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 4  All during the long campaign, Rep resentative William E. Brock 3d kept telling everyone that Tennessee had become a Re publican state.

title: Plans to Lower Vote Age Defeated in Most States
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) Proposals to lower the voting age were rejected in most of the 15 states where the ques tion was on the ballot yester day. And while Texans voted to permit saloons to reopen, Kansans voiced a resounding no.

title: Irish Prime Minister Wins Confidence Vote by Seven
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 4Prime Min ister John Lynch won a vote of confidence in Parliament to night by a vote of 74 to 67.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1970

title: ExKing Peter of Yugoslavia Dies on Coast at 47
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 (AP) Former King Peter II of Yugoslavia, who fled the Ger mans in 1941 and never re turned to his homeland, died here today in a hospital. He was 47 years old.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
Article 1  No Title
A Listing of New Books
TOUR CHIEF SAYS BUS HAD DEFECTS
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 4 (UPI)  A tour director from Brooklyn told a National Trans portation Safety Board hearing today that a bus that crashed last July, killing seven Long Island schoolchildren and in juring 52 on a tour to the Amish country, had several de fects.

title: Democrats Show Gain of 11 Governors; Pickup Strength in State Legislatures
description: In addition to making a net gain of 11 Governors offices in Tuesday's elections, the Demo crats increased their strength considerably in a number of the State Legislatures.

title: Sports of The Times
I Got a Song to Put History to Music
description: Joel W. Schenker, co producer of last year's In dians, the Arthur Kopit his torical drama, is preparing two musicals for the New York stage this season.

title: Illinoisan Wants to Exercise His Right Not to Be Voter
description: BELLFLOWER, Ill., Nov. 4 (UPI)Kirk Bristow, 66 years old, walked into the precinct polling place yesterday and ask ed election judges to remove his name from the rolls of register ed voters.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
WPIX Editor Links Distortions To News Writers Inexperience
description: Lee Nelson, news director of WPIX and Anchorman of its nightly hews broadcast said yes terday that several writers who had charged the station with news distortion lacked experi ence in electronic news presen tation Mr. Nelson was the first witenss called by WPIX attor neys as their defense began on the 35the day of the Federal Communications Commission li cense hearing.

title: LINDSAY GETS BIDS
description: The politics of New York will be realigned because of Tuesday's elections, in the judg ment of many state politicians.

title: Tombs Inmate Waiting Trial Hangs Himself in His Cell
description: A 25yearold prisoner who attacked a guard last Sunday committed suicide Tuesday night in his cell at the Men's House of Detention, known as the Tombs, the Department of Correction reported yesterday.

title: BIG TURNOUT LAID TO VICE PRESIDENT
description: Key strategists for Governor Rockefeller acknowledged yes terday that Vice President Agnew and James L. Buckley deserved some credit for the magnitude of the Governor's victory margin.

title: But President May Win In Region in Two Years
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4 The Democrats of the Old Confederacy frustrated the Nix on Administration's socalled Southern strategy in all but one state yesterday and proved that their own party was not so near death in Dixie as some had thought.

title: A Proverbial Feast Of Momentary Pith
description: The new Oxford Diction ary of English Proverbs be gins: Wise men make prov erbs and fools repeat them.

title: Chet Huntley Gets One Vote
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., Nov. 4 (UPI)  Chet Huntley, former commentator for the National Broadcasting Company, re ceived yesterday one writein vote for State Representative.

title: CONSUMER OUTLAY REMAINS SLUGGISH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  Three indicators of behavior in the important personal  con sumption sector of the economy pointed today to a continuation of relatively sluggish spending and high saving.

title: Parnelli Jones Sets Mark in Baja California Race
description: ENSENADA, Mexico, Nov. 4 (UPI)A former Indianapolis 500 winner, Parnelli Jones, clipped an hour from the rec ord time for the first quarter of the grueling Mexican 1,000 mile offroad race down the spiny length of Baja California today.

title: New Jersey Vote SENATOR
U.S. Is Preparing Pressure on Soviet To Free Generals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 The United States is prepar ing to apply increased pres sure, including a protest at the strategicarms limitation talks if necessary, to win the release of an Army plane and four officers still being detained two weeks after it landed in Soviet Armenia.

title: BLAST ON DESTROYER KILLS 2 U.S. SAILORS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 4 (AP) A boiler exploded today on the United States guided mis sile destroyer Goldsborough, killing two crewmen and injur ing four, Navy spokesmen an nounced.

title: Gay Liberation Front Bars An Attempt to Seize County
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 4 (UPI)The Berkeley Gay Lib eration Front held its own elec tion yesterday and rejected a proposal to try to seize Alpine County in the Sierras.

title: Song of Norway Opens at the Cinerama
Delegates Study Positions At Arms Talks in Helsinki
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 4 (Reuters)  Soviet and Ameri can delegations conferred among themselves today in preparation for the resumption Friday of talks on the limita tion of strategic arms.

title: FOREIGN NEWSPAPERS COVER U.S. ELECTION
description: Two London newspapers said yesterday that President Nixon had suffered a setback in the offyear elections. The Moscow press said Republicans had failed in a campaign to take control of Congress. And Japan saw the voting as a swing to ward conservatism in American politics.

title: JOHN H. NOBLE, 82; LED MILLS CONCERN
description: John Harmon Noble, who re tired in 1965 as sales manager and chief executive of the Im proved Machinery Corporation, died Wednesday in a convales cent home in New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 82 years old and lived at 4810 Boston Post Road, Pelham Manor. N. Y.

title: 4 Moderate Democrats in the Mountain States Survive Republican Efforts to Replace Them in the Senate
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 4  The Nixon Administration made a strenuous effort to dis lodge four moderate Senators here in the West, and lost every race.

title: GREAT WESTERN IS SEEKING LFC
description: A definitive agreement under which the LFC Financial Cor poration would be acquired by the Great Western Financial Corporation has been signed by both companies, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: ARREST IS DESCRIBED AT PANTHER TRIAL
description: The detective who arrested Robert Collier, one of 13 de fendants on trial for allegedly participating in a Black Pan ther conspiracy, said yesterday that he had been surprised to find the makings of a dead ly bomb in Collier's apartment.

title: Ali, Bonavena to Sign Today for Dec. 7 Boat
description: Muhammad Ali and Oscar Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight champion, will sign today to meet in a 15 round bout at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, Dec. 7.

title: Stage: Ariosto's Orlando Furioso
description: Orlando Furioso comes to New York much heralded after playing at the Spoleto Festival, in the Piazza Du omo in Milan, the Amster dam Stock Exchange, and an ice rink during the Edin burgh Festival. It was origi nally supposed to appear here on Pier 86, but after a dispute with longshoremen it was removed to Bryant Park, where it opened last night under a big bubble. The longshoremen must have known something.

title: Dobbs Resigns as Athletic Director at Sports  Troubled Tulsa U.
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 4 (UPI)  Glenn Dobbs, stressing in an emotional manner that to stay on at his job would cre ate a divided school, stepped down today as athletic direc tor at the University of Tulsa.

title: Monetary Union Gains Slowly in Europe
description: PARIS, Nov. 4A cautious approach by the Common Mar ket's executive authority in proposing action for monetary union pointed up today some of the difficulties the six mem ber states will have in reconcil ing the need for currency in tegration with the desire to run their own national economic affairs.

title: Debate Opens in Ottawa on Bill For Limited Emergency Powers
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 4The Gov ernment today urged quick par liamentary approval of its spe cial legislation to limit the sweeping war measures that were invoked to combat sep atatist extremists in Quebec.

title: 2D COPPER MAKER SUING PRODUCERS
description: A second independent maker of copper products has quietly filed an antitrust suit against the nation's leading producers of primary copper.

title: Calm Restored in Amman After Scattered Shooting
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 4 (AP) Amman was quiet again to day and a number of shops were open following six hours of scattered shooting in the city yesterday.

title: SHY AND SHAY DUE TO FACE COWBOYS
description: Two members of the New York Giants whose names simply begged for typographical con fusionLes Shy and Jerry Shay may see a lot more action against the Dallas Cowboys Sun day than they expected to a couple of days ago.

title: Track Coach Loses Race
description: ??UGENE, Ore. Nov. 4 (UPI) Bill Bowerman, longtime track coach at the University of Oregon, was defeated by fewer than 900 votes yesterday in a bid for a seat in Oregon's House of Representatives.

title: Xerox Corp. Introduces Sigma 9 Computer Unit
description: The Xerox Corporation an nounced yesterday a new com puter system that it described as the largest and most pow erful of its data procesing line.

title: Bridge:
Talent for Arabesques, Entrechatsand Baking Lucky Cookies
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J.When she was asked once to make a pie for dessert in a hurry, Teena McConnell discovered that the cooky dough she had on hand was a fine substitute for regular pastry cruct in a fruit tart.

title: Professor, 69, Is Suing Fordham For Million, Charging Age Bias
description: Dr. Paul Weiss, retired Ster ling Professor of Philosophy at Yale. University, is suing Ford ham University for $1million for allegedly offering him a po sition paying $100,000 a year, then withdrawing the offer on the groundthat he was too old. He is 69.

title: High on the Jungfrau, Scientists Are Conducting Varied Research
description: Researchers seeking to find out what can be learned about the cosmos, the human body and other phenomena at very high altitudes have discov ered that lungs grow more rapidly in rarefied air, that human taste becomes remark ably acute and that red blood cells proliferate.

title: Dining Room Employes Reach a Tentative Pact
description: The Dining Room Employes Union and the Restaurant League of New York reached a tentative agreement on a new contract last night.

title: BRITON AT U.N. ASKS GERM WARFARE BAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 4  Britain's arms nego tiator, the Marquis of Lothian, called here today for urgent action to ban germ warfare or use of toxins in war because the biological weapon may not be as remote as many of us think.

title: District Attorney Dinis In Massachusetts Loss
description: NEW BEDFORD?? Mass., Nov. 4 (AP)  Dukes County District Attorney Edmund Dinis, who ordered and con ducted the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne last January?? was defeated for reelection yesterday, which Mr. Dinis said he had expected.

title: Briton, After Visit to Red China, Reports Signs of Improvement
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 4After 14 days observing conditions and discussing trade in Peking and Canton, a British trade offi cial portrayed Communist China today as a nation entering a phase of stability, economic growth and increased commerce with the outside world.

title: INCREASE PROJECTED IN OUTPUT OF PAPER
description: Production capacity of paper and paperboard will increase by 4.6 million tons in the three year period from 1971 to 1973, according to, a study by the American Paper Institute of 750 United States paper and paper board mills, released yesterday. The current productive capaci ty of those mills is estimated at 60.300.000 tons.

title: Life in Sweden Grows Difficult for Draft Resisters
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 1They trudge up three flights of steps each afternoon and enter the bleak, dimly lit office at 66B Kungsgatan in downtown Stock holm. They sip coffee and chat quietly.

title: Teachers Strike in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 4  high school teachers throughout Is rael struck today for higher pay and more than 100,000 students were locked out of classes. The strike was nearly completely effective in aca demic schools and partially effective in vocational schools.

title: EDWARD I. LEVINE
description: EAST HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4Edward I. Levine, chairman of the board of the New Haven Comforter and Pillow Corpora tion, died today at his home, 118 Morgan Avenue, after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Mud Slide Hurts Roan
90% of the $3.4Billion in Offerings on Ballot Are Approved
description: The nation's voters, over coming fears resulting from a slack economy and the prospect of higher taxes, ap parently approved more than 90 per cent of the $3.4billion of bond issues placed before them Tuesday.

title: Kenny Pleads Fifth in U.S. Inquiry
description: NEWARK, Nov. 4John V. Kenny, the Democratic boss of Hudson County, invoked the Fifth Amendment against selfincrimination today in an appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating offi cial corruption and organized crime.

title: 6 Christmas Winners Picked by Mrs. Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP)Mrs. Spiro T. Agnew drew the names of a half dozen mothers in the greater Washington area today to win free Christmas telephone calls from sons in the military service overseas.

title: Allende Meets Nixon Representative
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 4 President Salvador Allende Gossens met privately at his request today with Assistant Secretary of State Charles A. Meyer, who represented Presi dent Nixon at Dr. Allende's in auguration as the first freely elected Marxist President in the Americas.

title: Dylan Album Shows Shift in Direction
description: Bob Dylan has released a new collection of songs, including one that appears to comment unfavorably on the honorary degree he received this year from Princeton University.

title: Hartke Holds slight Lead With 3 Precincts Not In
