description: A surprisingly strong de fense, not so publicized or glamorized as several others, but remarkably effective on the field. A twoman running attack of leagueleading caliber.

title: Screen:'Where's Poppa?' Aims to Remove Bachelor's Momma:Reiner Directs Comedy That Stars Segal Other Features Begin Their Runs Locally
description: Sometimes you settle for half a loaf. In movie comedy, even a quarter of a loaf will pass for a feast. So if "Where's Poppa?" which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater, doesn't succeed all the time, or even most of the time, it succeeds often enough, if only by energy and will, to satisfy a taste for comedy that has not had much nourishment this season. And occasionally, when invention, which is in long supply, and execution, which isn't always, get properly together, "Where's Poppa?" becomes a desperately funny film.The situation will seem familiar enough to post-Oedipal America. George Segal plays a small-time New York lawyer, a dutiful son who lives at home with his ancient mother (Ruth Gordon), whom he would dearly love to dump forever into an old people's home. If he can't do that (and his father's dying request says he can't), he would like to scare her to death. And if he can't do that, and he can't because she is unscarable, he is almost willing to drop her fragile body from an apartment windowso that the mess she would make on the sidewalk below might at least signal an end to the mess she is making of his life.To speed her on her way, or to get her out of the way, he hires for her a wish-fulfillment nurse (Trish Van Devere), with whom he immediately falls in loveI mean, within the first 10 secondsand whose lovely presence moves Segal, and the film, to the resolution toward which he, and it, had been tending. The resolution itself is nothing much, and I gather that at this stage the story has been monkeyed withor at least cut short of a few final indignities.But for most of its length "Where's Poppa?" deals with an exceptionably viable mixture of local jokes and black comedy that works as well as it does because everybody in the film possesses either enough good humor or outrageous imagination to promote his own worldview.A kind of benign individualism applies to everybody (except Miss Gordon)even down to a cheery troop of black youths lounging in Central Park, so they can mug all passers-by, except young women, whom they rape.All the performances, except that of Miss Gordon, who continues to play old age without conviction, are pretty good. But Trish Van Devere, whom I had never heard of, proves a commedienne of a complexity, precision and gentleness exactly to balance the broad cruelties of "Where's Poppa?" Carl Reiner's direction also balances those cruelties, and he is absolutely at his best with such magical absurdities as the first meeting between George Segal and Miss Van Devere.Like most New York comedy, "Where's Poppa?" means to score points in its incidental treatment of how we live. But unlike most such comedy, it actually scores a few  as when on Central Park West a Negro lady hails a cab, which almost stops but then drives on to pick up instead a wildly gesticulating giant gorilla.

title: What Is Germany's Ostpolitik'?
description: BONNIt is of transAtlantic sig nificance that Western European unity, so long championed by thoughtful Americans, is nearer reality than ever before.

title: Study Sees Major Changes in Makeup of Labor Force by 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  The American labor force will reach 100 million workers by 1980, including a dramatic in crease in the number of young adults and an explosive in crease in the number of young black workers, the Labor De partment forecast today.

title: Stevenson Delay Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Senatorelect Adlai E. Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, said today he probably would not be able to take office until several days after Congress re turns from recess next Mon day because it was unlikely his election would be certified offi cially before then. Under Illi nois law, Mr. Stevenson can take office as soon as he is certified as the winner.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Telephone Repairman Slain In Brooklyn Street Robbery
description: A 20yearold telephone com pany repairman from Queens was fatally shot and robbed at noon yesterday on a Brook lyn street after he had refused a demand by two men to give them narcotics.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10A key witness in the TateLa Bianca murder trial admitted under crossexamination today that she hears voices and that she has trouble with her mem ory,

Ambassadors, politicians, re tired generals and various reli gious figures have been arriv ing with increasing regularity these days to chat with Gen. Duong Van Minh, the man most likely to challenge President Nguyen Van Thieu in the elec tions next year.

description: Harry Belafonte will be the guest of honor on Nov. 20 when the Foundation for In ternational Child Health spon sors a benefit dinner dance at the Pierre.

title: Las Vegas Line on OffTrack Betting: Can't Miss

Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., commandant of the Marines, praised the corps.

description: EDISON, N. J., Nov. 10The Rev. John L. Callahan, pastor of St. Matthew's Roman Cath olic Church here, died Sunday in the John F. Kennedy Hospi tal after a heart attack in the church rectory. His age was 55.

Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, for their working in helping gain pas sage of the Medicare and Medic aid legislation five years ago.

title: NEW EARHART BOOK CALLED NONSENSE
description: Mrs. Irene Craigmile Bolam said yesterday that a recently published book stating that she was Amelia Earhart, the flier who disappeared in the Pacific in 1937. was utter nonsense.

Mr. Nixon will leave Washington tomorrow morning with a small official delegation, attend the service at Notre Dame Cathe dral in Paris on Thursday, and return to Washington late Thursday night.

title: Letters to the Editor
Respite for Jersey's Wetlands
description: Gov. William T. Cahill has done New Jersey a great service in signing the controversial bill to protect that state's wetlands. These remaining quartermillion acres of salt marshes, estuaries and inlet flatssomething like 5 per cent of the state's entire areawill not be auto matically preserved even now; but their further destruc tion as wetlands can be controlled, limited or stopped by the State Department of Environmental Protection as that agency sees fit.

title: The Last of the Giants
description: PARIS, Nov. 10When, by his own choice, he was still a political exile, General de Gaulle once said to me: Giants can do nothing now. Some years later I asked: if, under any con ditions, he foresaw a new age of Politi cal giants and he replied: I suppose that depends upon the world situation. When that situation is, grave the giants come nearer to a return.

title: Charles de Gaulle
description: Charles de Gaulle was a legend and his name prophecy: Charles of Gaul. His life was constructed on mystical conviction that he was to save France.

As one Treasury of ficial remarked, the move had long ago been discounted by industrial users and silver trad ers, but William Jennings Bryan must be spinning in his grave.

But the pre veiling view is that it may have done Mr. Bush Notes more harm than good. And the official credited by fellow White House aides with hav ing conceived the move de nies that he had anything to do with it.

title: Bridge

The withdrawal of 100 officers and enlisted men and their equipment was to be completed by Jan. 1, the Air Force says.

description: Sesame Street, public television's first sustained smash hit of its own making, returned this week for its second year. It is seen at 9 A.M. and 4 P.M. on Channel 13, with reruns on. Saturdays under a grant from the Gen eral Foods Corporation.

title: A. FLETCHER SISK
description: PRESTON, Md., Nov. 10A. Fletcher Sisk, a retired princi pal in Albert W. Sisk & Son, food brokers here, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 84.

title: Narcotic Dealer Gets UptoLifeTerm

title: U.A.R. Troops Learn Hebrew

The paper published a page from a Hebrew manual distributed to the troops. The caption said: Egyptian fight ers, learn the language of your enemy. The battle with the Is raeli enemy is coming. There is no doubt about that. Memorize these words and sentences which you will be using in your next battle with the hateful enemy.

In this country it has up to now re ceived but one television pro duction, hence the Lyric Opera's current performances are listed as American stage premieres. title: Key Item on Political Agenda: The Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The election has left the Gov ernment with a sizable hang over. There is work to be done, in all three branches, but there are already signs that the next campaign will merge imper ceptibly into the last and leave the politicians reeling for quite a while. Even now, the per formance or me economy, the war in Vietnam, the re form of the wel fare system, the effort to combat crime and the integration of schools are being measured for their effects on the race for President two years hence. In both parties, the thought is taking hold that the economy looms largest in this catalogue and that everything from the budget to the lowliest appro priation bills will therefore be subject to unusual partisan maneuvers. Micir's decision came to full fruition over the weekend when he was named Ivy back of the week for his stellar per formance against Yale.

(Bo) Hagan, director of athletics and head football coach of Rice University, an nounced today he would resign at the end of the current sea son on Dec. 1. Hagan, who was hired in 1956 by Jess Neely, became head coach and athletic director in Nov., 1966.

title: Ursula Andress Appears in 'Perfect Friday' Film
description: Lady Dorset (Ursula Andress), a smashing blonde and an absolutely hideous housekeeper, wants money, or, at least, an attentive lover who is very rich and doesn't mind if she cheats a little. Her husband, the Earl of Dorset (David Warner), doesn't mind if she cheats a little. Neither does he mind a messy house nor even an alcoholic nanny, and he needs money for clothes and fornication. Mr. Graham (Stanley Baker), their friend at a nearby branch of the Metropolitan Bank of England, has become bored with his job. He has access to the moneyand a plan.The Dorsets and Mr. Graham form a relationship, united not only by greed and lust, but also by a code of dishonesty that is as firm as the Rock of Gibraltar. Their elaborate scheme to steal 300,000 from the Metropolitan Bank works, up to a point, as does their movie, "Perfect Friday," which opened yesterday at the Forum and 72d Street Playhouse Theaters.The big caper movie, however, belongs to the most rigid, most uninteresting of genres, and I find it difficult to understand why so many directors, including a man as talented as Peter Hall ("Three Into Two Won't Go"), are eventually attracted to it.Perhaps it has to do with the economics of moviemaking, with the type of movie that can be expected to make a profit on its investment, granted a certain minimum degree of quality. Or, it may simply have to do with the same kind of impossible challenge that might prompt a lyric poet to try his hand at haiku.In "Perfect Friday," Mr. Hall and his script writers observe all the conventions of the genre, up to and including the final obligatory twist that must always be a variation on failure. It's this obligation to fail that makes the caper movie, ultimately, so tiresome. Without it, the movie is left open-ended, without shape, but with it, the movie can only hope to be a basic exercise.Within these very important limitations, Mr. Hall has made an intelligent and quietly funny film about three eccentrics, who are as attractively written as they are played. Miss Andress has something of an edge over her two co-stars, being able to appear as often in the buff as in a lot of rather crazy high styles.Her Lady Dorset also is given some of the film's most characteristic lines, as when she and Mr. Graham are sharing a picnic supper on a small hill overlooking an ordinary field, a highway, a construction crane and a housing development. She is such an inveterate liar that she can't help but say, quite seriously: "Isn't this a strange, pretty place?" As in life, it's not the big caper but the small deceptions that count in "Perfect Friday."

description: The National Audubon So ciety last night awarded special citations to Herbert Johnson, superintendent of the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, and Frank W. McLaughlin, executive di recor of the New Jersey Audu bon Society.

description: TORONTO, Nov. 11 (UPI) Ray Cullen scored two goals as the Vancouver Canucks handed the Toronto Maple Leafs their fourth straight National Hockey League defeat, 42, before a crowd of 16,394 tonight.

title: McGrath Keeps Bowling Lead
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 11 (AP) Mike McGrath of El Cerrito, Calif., who won $700 for fin ishing 13th in the Lincoln open bowling tournament earlier this week, continues to lead the of ficial money standing of the Professional Bowlers Associa tion with a total of $48,749 for the year.

title: GENERAL MOTORS AND UNION REACH TERMS FOR PACT
description: DETROIT, Nov. 11  The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corpo ration agreed today on a pack age of money and fringe bene fits designed to end the union's eightweek strike.

title: British Units Quit Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 11 (UPI)Britain today announced the withdrawal of more than 1,000 peacekeeping troops from Northern Ireland. They are the 41st Royal Marines and Second Coldstream Guards, which will return to their posts in Britain and West Germany.

title: DISSIDENT HOLDERS LOSE BATH CONTEST
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 11 (AP) United States District Judge John W. Reynolds has dismissed a lawsuit brought by Bath In dustries Inc., against a group of dissident stockholders.

title: MRS. ADOLPH COORS JR.
description: DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI) Mrs. Adolph Coors Jr. died here last night of a heart attack. She was 85 years old.

title: Shelling in Jordan by Israelis Reported
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11  Sources close to the palace re ported today that Israeli gun ners fired several shells into Jordanian territory this morn ing, In violation of the Middle East ceasefire.

title: WAN NUNEZ IS HEARD IN A PIANO PROGRAM
description: The Third Annual Interna tional Artists series, jointly sponsored by Carnegie Hall and Jeunesse Musicales, Inc., pre sented a capable young Chilean pianist in his New York debut Tuesday night. The 29yearold Ivan Nunez chose a conven tional program for his Car negie Recital Hall appearance Haydn and Beethoven Sonatas, along with shorter works by Albniz, Debussy and Chopin approaching each score with methodical attention and con trol. Tempos were steady, ar ticplation was clean, phrasings were carefully shaped, notes were always well in hand.

title: Inspector's Rites Planned For Sergeant Slain Here
description: An inspector's funeral will be held tomorrow for Sgt., Henry Tustin, who was killed Monday night on a Harlem street by a man posing as a policeman. The service will take place at 10:15 A.M. at St. Andrew Avellino Roman Catholic Church, 3560 158th Street in Flushing. Queens.

title: Jersey Insurance Aide Slain By Intruder as Wife Watches
description: BRIDGEWATER, N. J., Nov 11An insurance agent was murdered before his wife's eyes during a struggle with an armed intruder at his .home here early today.

title: Uwaifo Band Brings Nigerian Rhythms To Village Vanguard
description: A sevenpiece band from Nigeria is replacing the jazz sounds usually heard at the Village Vanguard with the lively rhythms of the Highlife, the Akwete, the Mutaba and other popular African dances. The band, led by Victor Uwaifo, is making its first American nightclub appear ance. It will be there through Sunday.

title: If the Look Is TattyIt's Intentional
description: What does it take for two young men from the Uni versity of Alabama to land, not on a professional football team, but on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, as proprietors of what must be the only Woodstockgeneration boutique in in area? It takes talent and the faith of a patron who just happens to have a boutique available.

title: MRS. EMILE E. SOUBRY
description: Mrs. Jennie Bennett Soubry, wife of Emile E. Soubry, retired executive vice president and director of Standard Oil Com pany (New Jersey), died Tues day at their home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 74 years old.

title: The Buckley Mystique
description: Father was a man of almost painful, personal modesty. Respecting his chil dren, alas, he abandoned modesty for a pride that, fore all of us, could be even more painful. He fretted over our moral and intellectual backwardness. At dinner parties, on the other hand, he was certain that his poor guests were hugely entertained by hearing us howl through Mexican ballads, or by listening to me, age 7, Charge Through the tight Brigade. We like to died.

title: Executive Changes
description: William S. Mitchell Las been elected president, succeeding Quentin Reynolds who was appointed chairman of the board of Safeway Stores, Inc.

title: Urban League to Honor 8 Black Mayors at Dinner
description: Eight black Mayors repre senting the more than 50 black mayors in this country will receive the 1970 awards of the National Urban League at its annual Equal Oppor tunity Day dinner to be held next Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton.

title: 76% of Adults in Poll Aware of Mrs. Mitchell
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 In less than two years, Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the United States Attorney Gen eral, has become a household word for threequarters of the nation's adult population, according to a Gallup Poll.

title: G.M. Signs Final Contract For Wankel Engine Rights
description: NECKARSULM, West Ger many, Nov. 11 (AP)The final contract has been signed be tween the General Motors Cor poration, AudiNSU Auto Union, A.G., Wankel, G.m.b.H., and the Curtiss  Wright Corporation granting G.M. nonexclusive world rights to the rotarypiston Wankel engine, AudiNSU an nounced today.

title: Carolina Aide Backs Use of Buckshot on Blacks
description: COLUMBIA, S..C., Nov. 11 The state's chief, law enforce ment officer defended in Federal Court today the use of buck shot .against black .students at South Carolina State College in 1968.

title: Waterfront Study Planned
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation yes terday announced that a major study of the New York City waterfront would be made under the direction of Samuel Ratensky, former assistant ad ministrator for planning, design and research in the city's Hous ing and Development Adminis tration.

title: REFORMS STARTED AT MANY SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  Two major recommendations for university reform made by the President's Commission on Campus Unrest have already been implemented or are under active consideration at many campuses across the nation. They are that large universities be decentralized and that stu dents be given the opprotunity to evaluate their instructors.

title: Roiling U.S.Soviet Relations
description: Moscow has finally released the two American generals whose plane strayed into Soviet territory, thus implicitly admitting that there was never any substance to the propaganda claims that this navigational accident was the result of planned, hostile activity. Welcome as is the belated release of the geherals, it will be even more welcome if it proves the end of what seems to be a growing pattern of Soviet acts whose impactas Moscow must well knowis to roil and disturb SovietAmerican relations needlessly.

title: Regents Ask More State Aid to Public Libraries
description: The Board of Regents yester day proposed the coordination and eventual integration of the state's 22 public library sys tems and said that the state should give considerable fi nancial support to the project.

title: EXOFFICIALS URGE TAXEXEMPT RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Eighteen former highlevel Fed eral officials, three of them Re publicans, expressed today the hope that the Internal Revenue Service would not deny tax exempt status to organizations that file lawsuits in the public interest.

title: Size of College Is Not a Factor On East Team
description: Since many smallcollege football players could find a spot on major college teams, an attempt is made here to pick an allEast team consist ing of both major and small college athletes. This melting pot team has 28 players rep resenting eight small colleges and eight major ones, How.

title: Onassis Asks Revision of Greek Oil Deal
description: ATHENS, Nov. 11  Aris totle S. Onassis, who won a lucrative oil concession from the Greek Government last January in stiff competition with his archrival, Stavros S. Niarchos, has taken legal ac tion in a bid to force a re vision of its terms.

title: CHALLENGE LIKELY FOR KENNEDY POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Senator Edward M?? Kennedy is approaching another major test in his political careerthis time over holding his job as Democratic whip of the Senate.

title: Hutchins and Clark. Debate the Constitution
description: To form an even more per fect union, do we need an even more perfect Constitution?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
German Tristan Rides to Rescue of Opera on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 The perils of casting Wag ner are illustrated by the current production of Tris ??an and Isolde at the San Francisco Opera. When the 196970 announcements were made, John Vickers was the ??enor, singing opposite the ??solde of Birgit Nilsson.

title: Japanese Gymnast Victor
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 11 (AP)Teruichi Okamura of Japan won the overall individ ual men's championship today at the world invitation gymnas tics tournament, finishing first in the parallel bars, horizontal bars and vault events.

title: Simone Beck
description: Anyone who has ever stirred up a batch of pt brise knows that Julia Child is a coauthor of Mastering the Art of French Cooking, Volumes I and II, and is the hardbreathing cook on The French Chef television series, bringing a practical, often humorous, message of en couragement to the aspiring cooks of America.

title: 3 LONDON POLICEMEN FACE BRIBE CHARGES
description: LONDON, Nov. 11  Sum monses involving allegations of bribery and corruption have been served on three London detectives with a total of al most 50 years service, Scotland Yard announced today.

title: ENFORCEMENT STAY ON MINE ACT ENDED
description: ABINGDON, Va., Nov. 11 (UPI)An injunction forbid ding the Federal Government to enforce regulations of the Mine Health and Safety Act of 1970 was dissolved today at the request of smallmine operators.

title: Where Are You, Lloyd Seay?
description: ATLANTAThe prototype was Lloyd Seay, a dashing mountain boy from the prolific moonshine country north Georgia. Old Lloyd couldn't read or write, one of his cronies re calls, but he didn't have to. Seay was a whisky runner, one of the most legendary in the business, and It was nothing for him to make two round trips a day between Dawsonville and Atlanta, flying out of the low hills in a cloud of pink dust with a load and then scurrying back empty for another batch.

title: EDUCATORS SCORE STUDENT AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 College educators rebuffed to day a plea by Elliot L. Richard son, Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare, far support of the Nixon Administration's higher education bill.

title: RugShopping the Easy Way
description: Altman's has taken the backache out of shopping by hanging rugs on sliding pan els in its four new floor cov erings galleries on the store's fifth floor. By doing so, it has also increased the number of designs that can be displayed at any one time (up to 72 in each gallery). Rugs and carpeting, domes tic and imported, are filed ac cording to type  patterned, shags, contempo rary and Americanain the four galleries. The variety is staggering, and the range, in cluding moderatepriced do mestic offerings and more costly Moroccan imports, is impressive.

title: Pompidou and ChabanDelmas Fly to Colombey and Pay Their Last Respects to de Gaulle
description: COLOMBEY  LES  DEUX EGLISES, France, Nov. 11 President Pompidou and Pre mier Jacques ChabanDelmas paid private homage to Charles de Gaulle today.

title: Meeting on Copeland Set As Difficulties Increase
description: Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., who has been unavailable for comment since he peti tioned 23 days ago for court protection under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, will face his creditors in an open meet ing on Nov. 24.

title: Philadelphia Teachers Back New TwoYear Contract
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI)Teachers approved over whelmingly today a new two year wage contract, ending a dispute that delayed the open ing of public schools in Septem ber and closed them for three days in October.

title: 3 Networks to Carry De Gaulle Rites Today
description: The three television net works will provide extensive live coverage by satellite to day of the funeral cere monies and burial of Charles de Gaulle.

title: PAKISTANI LEADER HAILED IN PEKING
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 11 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan is be ing given one of the biggest welcomes in Peking ever ac corded a foreign chief of state on a visit to Communist China.

title: MOHAWK AIRLINES STRUCK BY PILOTS
description: Pilots and copilots of Mo hawk Airlines went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today after efforts to negotiate a new contract by midnight failed.

title: Former Philadelphia Pastor Cleared of Diverting Funds
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI)The District Attorney here told a group of Roman Catholic parishioners today that he was dropping his in vestigation into charges that Msgr. Louis A. Risha had diverted $200,000 in funds from his former parish.

title: Beethoven Performed  By Clarion
description: The 197071 season of Clarion Concerts opened at Tully Hall on Tuesday night with a typically Clarion kind of contribution to the com memoration of the bicenten nial of Beethoven's birth.

title: HOME LOAN BOARD SEEKS NEW RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) In a move to spur the na tion's housing market, the Fed eral Home Loan Bank Board proposed new regulations today designed to step up lending by savings and loan associations.

title: High Court Asked to Rule On Vietnam War Objection
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to rule out draft exemptions for men who are conscien tiously opposed to the Vietnam ese war but not to all wars.

title: Ideological Labels Changing Along With the LabelMakers
description: Pinning labels on people or tails on donkeysis a familiar party, tactic.

title: Thurmond Heckled on Coast
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP)Students shouted and threw carrots today at Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, as he made an outdoor speech at the Univer sity of California at Riverside'The students heckled the 67 yearold Senator as he urged support of President Nixon's administration policies. Several carrots were thrown toward the podium in a questionandan swer period. Senator Thurmond called the hecklers a bunch of wild animals.

title: HULLS SET PACE IN HAWK VICTORY
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Bobby Hull and his brother Dennis scored two goals each and Bobby made two assists as the Chicago Black Hawks scored a 71 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in a National Hockey League game. The Hawks widened their lead in the West Division to 4 points over the Flyers and St. Louis.

title: New Michigan Party Sought
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Nov. 11 (AP)State Senator Robert Hu her of Troy confirmed today that he was heading a drive to form a new conservative party in Michigan in time for the elections in 1972. Mr. Huber, who lost in the Republican pri mary for the Senate nomina tion earlier this year, said that a petition, drive would be made to assure the party a place on the ballot.

title: Market Role Envisaged
description: PARIS, Nov. 11Europe's neutral states have just begun negotiating a formula of ac commodation with what may be in a few year's time an en larged Common Market??

title: Grange for New Pesticides
description: BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 11 (AP) The National Grange urged to day that research be aimed at developing safe pesticides. Every effort needs to be made, it was said. to proper ly inform and educate the pub lic to realize that without ap plication of proper kind and recommended dosage of adapted pesticides, production of many crops would drop an estimated 20 to 30 per cent or more and food costs to, everyone would be substantially increased.

title: Falstaff Moves From Ogilvy to Needham, Harper
description: Last March lots of people were expecting Falstaff beer to move from Foote, Cone & Belding to Needham, Harper & Steers. Instead it moved to Ogilvy & Mather, remember? Well now it, is moving to Needham, Harper and Steers.

title: Fort Marcy Takes D.C. International Aqueduct Foul Irks Fans
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11Fort Marcy became a millionaire to day. The 6yearold Virginia bred campaigner owned by Paul Mellon, the financierphilan thropist, won the 19th Washing ton D.C. International, as ex pected by most of the 28,764 fans on hand.

title: French Press Comment Is Ambivalent on de Gaulle
description: PARIS, Nov. 11It was he who saved France. No, it was the Allies who liberated it. He installed the republic. Then he installed, under that name, an almost absolute monarchy. He reestablished order and stabil ityto end up with a May, 1968. He restored economic confidence. How did he leave the franc? He was a unifier. Above all, divisive.

title: MANHATTAN POLICE SLAY MAN, SHOOT 2D
description: A man was killed by a police man yesterday after allegedly holding up a bar in upper Man hattan, and another was criti cally wounded last night in Harlem after he reportedly drew a revolver on two policemen.

title: No End to Food Cost Spiral Expected in  71 by Experts
description: Housewives who have been paying more and more for their groceries as the food prices have risen in the last con secutive 41 months will probably find the situation worse next year, according to econ ornists and food specialists.

title: Alarm Stirred by Quebec Minister's Proposal to Give Police Firmer Controls to Deal With Terrorists
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 11A rash of proposals by the Quebec Government to give the police continuing firmer controls to deal with political terrorism and organized crime is arous ing increasing alarm in this troubled French Canadian prov ince.

title: Suns Top Trail Blazers
description: PHOENIX, Ariz. Nov. 11 (AP)The Phoenix Suns sur vived a midgame Portland Trail Blazer rally for a 114100 National Basketball Associa tion victory tonight.

title: Devon Securities Slate Named As Board of 5th Avenue Coach
description: Samuel C. Coleman, a court appointed special master, or overseer, announced yesterday that the 10 nominees of Devon Securities had been elected as the board of directors of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

title: Bridge.
Lansky, in Israel, Says He Has No Plans
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 11  Meyer Lansky, a reputed financial boss of organized crime in the United States, is visiting Israel on a fourmonth tourist' s visa that expires at the end of this month.

title: Olin and Remington To Lay Off 1,200
description: Two defense contractors, the Olin Corporation and Reming ton Arms Company, yesterday announced that 1,200 workers would be laid off as a result of a Defense Department decision to discontinue procurement of 5.56mm. small arms ammuni tion from private contractors.

title: PAINE IS CHANGING INTO CORPORATION
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, one of the last of the major brokeragehouse partner ships on Wall Street, will adopt the corporate form Dec. 1 after 91 years in business as an un incorporated entity.

title: Japan Dismisses U.S. Plan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11 (UP)  The Japanese textile industry today dismissed the latest Unit ed States proposal to solve the textile dispute as not even worthy of consideration.

title: North Stars Triumph
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 11 (UPI)J. P. Parise scored two goals tonight to lead Minnesota to a 31 victory over Los Angeles as the North Stars tied the Kings for fourth place in the West Division.

title: 60 Minutes Seeks to Fill Reasoner's Chair
description: 60 Minutes, the maga zine of the Columbia Broad casting System's News Divi sion, will soon be searching for a new style.

title: LEADERS OUSTER URGED BY BABDILLO
description: Herman Badillo, who will soon represent the 21st District in Congress, called yesterday for the resignation of all five Democratic county leaders as a first step in rebuilding the party in New York City.

title: STOCK GAINS CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
Dempsey Is Challenged Again on Kicking Shoe
description: DALLAS, Nov. 11 (AP)Tex Schramm, chairman of the competition committee of the National Football League, said today he would again protest the use of the special shoe Tom Dempsey used in kicking a record 63yard field goal for the New Or leans Saints that defeated the Detroit Lions Sunday.

title: Automation Entering Dog Show Ring
description: More people were becom ing involved in dog shows, more dogs were entered in them; costs were raising and suitable places for the events were getting harder to find, said Alan P. Winks, London born president of the Foley Dog Show Organization of Philadelphia yesterday. He

title: HENRY LEACH, 90, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: Dr. Henry Goddard Leach, past president of the American Scandinavian Foundation, died yesterday in Regent Hospital following a long illness. He was no years old and lived at 1021 Park Avenue.

title: INFLATION FIGHT WORRIES EUROPE
description: PARIS, Nov. 11  European monetary authorities, still view inflation as the. No. 1 economic problem of the developed world. And they fear that the still unsuccessful efforts to over whelm it may slow, if not?? check, the present downswing in international interest rates.

title: BROOKINGS GAUGES CURRENT ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  The Brookings Institution pub lished today the second in its new series of technical eco nomic papers on current eco nomic issues. By coincidence rather than design, the conclu sions of the papers tended to point to the need for an ex pansionary government policy in 1971, particularly monetary policy.

title: Notre Dame, ct Paris Hallmark, Has Been a Stage for History
description: PARIS, Nov. 11  Notre Dam?? Cathedral, where the great of the world will pay homage to Charles de Gaulle tomorrow, has been a main stage of French history for more than 800 years.

title: Predictable, $5.40, Wins Garden State Feature
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. II (UPI)Predictable put on a strong rush in the stretch today to overtake I'm For Mama and capture the $25, 000 Jersey Bell Handicap at Garden State Park.

title: The Cheap Handgun Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Another policeman was shot to death in. New York Monday night, leading Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy to call for handgun control on a na tional scale. In Baltimore, on the same day, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, who was chairman of the National Commission on the Causes and Pre vention of Violence, declared in ?? lecture that no American should b?? allowed to own a handgun unless h?? can prove ?? need for it.

title: C.B.S. Directors Declare Cash and Stock Dividends
description: Directors of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., de clared yesterday a cash divi dend of 35 cents a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 11 and a 2 per cent stock dividend payable Jan. 15.

title: STROESSNER VOWS TO BAR TERRORISM
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 10Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, who has ruled Paraguay with an iron hand for 16 years, says he is determined that the politi cal turmoil and terrorism af flicting the rest of South Amer ica will remain barred from his country.

title: Soviet Dissident Tried; Sentence Is Due Today
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11Andrei A. Amalrik, the dissident au thor of Will the U.S.S.R. Sur vive Until 1984?, went on trial today in the Urals city of Sverdlovsk and reportedly de nied that he was guilty of de faming the Soviet Union.

title: GULF TO INCREASE CRUDE OIL PRICES
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, the ??ion's fourth largest petro leum concern, announced yes terday a 25centabarrel in crease in the price it pays for crude oil across the United States.

title: SMITH BEATS RICHEY; ASHE WINS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Nov. 11 (Reuters) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., became the fourth seeded player to be eliminated from the Paris open indoor tennis tournament today when he was convincingly beaten in the sec ond round by Stan Smith of Pasadena. Calif?? 63?? 62.

title: Tories Under Pressure
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP)In ternational pressure increased today on Britain's Conservative Government to abandon its nonintervention economic pol icy and take immediate action to halt the country's accelerat ing inflation.

title: 7 in Tulsa Oil Crew Killed When Truck Explodes
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 11At least seven members of an oil Company's seismograph crew were killed tonight when a truck loaded with explosives blew up.

title: Russians Luna 17 Heading for Noon; Landing Uncertain
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, Nov. 12The Soviet Union's un manned spacecraft Luna 17 ap parently continued to travel toward the moon early this morning on a mission officially described as the scientific ex ploration of the moon and nearmoon space.

title: JAMMED CONTROLS LINKED TO CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Government investiga tors said today that jammed controls in the tail section may have caused the Sept. 8 crash of a jetliner that killed 11 crew members at New York's Kennedy International Airport.

title: LETTER SAYS C.I.A. TRIED TO HIRE DAYAN
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 11 (UPI) A leftwing Iraeli magazine, Haolam Hazeh, published today what it termed a topsecret letter sent to the United States Embassy here in 1959 to try to recruit Moshe Dayan, then a private citizen, into the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Deaths
CALVIN ALLEY DEAD; CARTOONIST WAS 55
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 11 (UPI) Calvin Alley, creator of the syndicated comic strip, The Ryatts, and editorial cartoon ist for. The COmmercial Appeal, died last night of cancer at Bap tist Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: $264,000 for Soccer Star
description: LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 11 (AP)John Toshack was transferred froth Cardiff City to the Liverpool soccer club today for $264,000.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Courthouse in New Delhi Is Beehive Of Inequity for the Poor and Ignorant
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 11The Tiz Hazari Courthouse is a human beehive in whose jammed rooms and corridors can be found a microcosm of the problems and grievances of northern India.

title: Stokes Picks Safety Chief
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 (UPI) George W. O'Connor, 38 years old, chief of the police programs division of the Federal Depart ment of Justice, was named to day by Mayor Carl B. Stokes as the city's new Safety direc tor. He will replace Lieut. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis, retired, who quit as Safety Director last July after six months on the job.

title: Alcindor Gets 44 as Bucks Top Celtics, 123113
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP)Lew Alcindor's 44 points led the Mil waukee Bucks to their seventh straight victory tonight, a 123 113 National Basketball Associ ation triumph over the Boston Celtics before 15,203, the larg est crowd to watch basketball at Boston Garden.

title: Dubos, at 70, Will Head a State U. Ecology Unit
description: Dr. Ren J. Dubos, the micro biologist and experimental pathologist, has accepted an appointment as university pro fessor and director of environ mental studies at the new State University of New York College at Purchase.

title: I.T.T. PROFITS UP 24% IN QUARTER
11,000 to Be Laid Off at Olin
description: EAST ALTON, Ill., Nov. 11 (UPI) About 1,000 persons will be laid off at the Winchester Western Division of the Olin Corporation .here and in New Haven, Conn., because of cut backs in a Government ammu nition contract, it was an nounced today. The company said about 500 persons at each plant would be released prior to the end of December, 1970.

title: Stokowski and Met Group Will Play in St. Patrick's
description: Leopold Stokowski and an orchestra composed of Metro politan Opera musicians will open a, new concert series at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Sunday evening, Nov. 29. The program includes a new work by An drezej Panufnik, Universal Prayer, Bach's Cantata No. 29 and Poulenc's Concerto for Organ, Strings and Timpani.

title: Lose of Employment on Docks Continues in City
description: A downward trend in dock worker employment in the Port of New York is continuing, the Waterfront Commission re ported yesterday.

title: A Doctor's Letter to His Son
description: Dear Nathan:Of course, you know that your mother and I love you deeply. There are limits to that love. Let me discuss one with you today.

title: Campaign 70
description: There should be a certain sophistication in all this, says Bob Murphy, the leading candidate's campaign man ager, unless, of course, we want intercollegiate sports to go the way of our national politics. We've avoided the carnival approach. No posters, bumper stickers, we haven't called influential voters on the telephone and no slogans. They tried to push Plunkettto'Em. Nothing doing.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1970

title: FILLY PACER FAILS TO EARN HER OATS
description: WESTBURY, L. I. Nov. 11 Contrary to the belief of many outsiders, all id not milk and honey for owners of standard breds. To be sure, much is heard about Duncan MacDon ald of Sydney, Nova Scotia, ac quiring Fresh Yankee as a yearling for $900 and proceed ing to win about $800,000 with the trotting mare.

title: Vanderbilt, 58, Succeeds Dreyfus as N.Y.R. A. Head
description: Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, one of the turf's most out spoken and respected voices; succeeded Jack Dreyfus Jr. yesterday as chairman of the New York Racing Associa tion.

title: Article 2  No Title
Mass Offered for Two Assassinated Prisoners
description: A Roman Catholic Bishop celebrated a memorial mass yesterday for two prisoners he said were assassinated in the Tombs last week and he in cluded in his prayers a passage from the writings of Mao Tsetung.

title: Boy's Death Spurs A Safety Campaign In National Parks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11A 9yearold boy named Andrew Clark Hecht died in an accident in Yellowstone National Park last summer. His parents, James and Amy Hecht, refused to accept his death as unavoid able and began a personal cam paign to make the national parks safer for the millions of persons who visit them each year.

title: Charles Lochridge Leading Bridge Player, Dies
Advertising: Ford Airs Consumer Gripes
description: Ford has gotten another, of its better ideas and is getting the jump on the other De troit giants with a massive advertising campaign aimed at major consumer complaints  pollution, safety, service and durability. And, for good measure, Ford is taking on foreign cars.

title: Environment Watchdog
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Political pundits who have predicted that the Nixon Ad ministration would act to soften its hardnosed political image after last week's elections may well begin to say I told you so because of the promotion three days

title: U.S. PLANS BILLION IN AID FOR MIDEAST AND ASIAN NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Nixon Administration has reportedly prepared a supple mental request for roughly $1billion in military and eco nomic aid for Cambodia, Israel, South Korea, Jordan, Lebanon and Indonesia.

title: Pat Valdo, Retired Supervisor Of Circus Personnel, Is Dead
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 11 Pat Valdo, former supervisor of performance and personnel for Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, who became its first director emeritus last year, died here Saturday. He was 89 years old. A requiem mass was, offered today in St. Martha's Roman Catholic Church.

title: City Official Seeks to Aid Jewish Physicist in Soviet
description: A New York City official will go to Washington today to plead with State Department officials in the case of a Soviet Jew who was halted by Soviet policemen recently as he tried to enter the United States Em bassy in Moscow in an effort to establish American citizen ship.

title: JOHN O. RADWAY
Vietnamese Savant Sees Vital Future Role for U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11Nguyen Dang Thuc, One of Vietnam's leading thinkers, be lieves that Americans should play a significant role in post war Vietnam

title: U.S. Hijacker Gets Long Term in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 11Raffaele Minichiello, the United States marine corporal, who hijacked an airliner from California to Rome more than a year ago, was sentenced tonight to sev en and a half years in prison.

title: MERCURY DETECTED IN FISH IN COLORADO
description: DENVER, Nov. 11 (UPI) Colorado health officials said yesterday that concentrations of poisonous mercury had been discovered in fish taken from Navajo Lake on the Colorado New Mexico border.

title: Caldwell Excels As Cougars Halt Nets, 106 to 102
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 11The Carolina Cougars broke a 100all tie with 2 minutes 50 seconds left tonight and went on to defeat the New York Nets, 106102, in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: ENEMY AMBUSHES CAMBODIAN UNITS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 11 (AP)  Two battalions of Cambodian troops were am bushed today 35 miles north of Pnompenh on Highway 7. The scene was about five miles east of the district capital of Skoun. There were no reports on cas ualties. Two companies were sent to reinforce the ambushed units, officers at Skoun said.

title: NIXON IS IN FRANCE FOR THE SERVICES
description: PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 12 President Nixon arrived early today to join the representa tives, of about 80 nations in a last tribute to Charles de Gaulle.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON STAGE LATE RALLY
description: The London stock market rallied yesterday in late trading following reports from Detroit that the General Motors strike had been settled.

title: BRITISH GRANT SET FOR ROLLSROYCE
description: LONDON, Nov. 11  The Conservative Government stepped in today to save Rolls Royce, Ltd., the British aircraft engine company, from loom ing financial disaster.

title: CITY EASES RULES ON DAYCARE UNITS
description: Daycare centers will serve 1,700 more preschool children than had been forecast by the city officials under a temporary relaxation of regulations an nounced yesterday by the Hu man Resources Administration.

title: CRUMB'S SELECTIONS PLAYED AT CONCERT
description: George Crumb is a composer who creates a microcosmic sound world of own, and then uses silences as a sort of aural magnifying glass to draw the listener close.

title: ROBERT HUMBER, LAWYER IN SOUTH
description: GREENVILLE, N. C., Nov. 11 (AP)Dr. Robert Lee Humber, a cofounder of the United World Federalists organization, which supports the United Naa tons, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: 2 Murder Suspects Named
description: BONN, Nov. 11 (Reuters) The police today gave the names of two men sought for the murder of the exiled Alge rian revolutionary, Belkacem Krim, in Frankfurt on Oct. 20, and said that either politics or a dispute over a woman might have been the cause of the kill ing. The police announcement named Ayat Hamid, aged 41, and Ahmed Bouhouche, 47, as suspects in the case, but said they were most likely out side the country.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: New crop soybean futures dropped sharply in early trad ing yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but a late ral ly turned prices around and they closed higher.

title: Oil Shale Corp. Arranges To Eliminate Most of Debt
description: The Oil Shale Corporation has arranged to eliminate ap proximately three  quarters of its total indebtedness by the end of this month.

title: Music: Ohlsson's Chopin
description: Garrick Ohlsson, a 22year old, 6foot4inch behemoth who is still a fully enrolled student at the Juilliard School, has won three inter national piano competitions in the last four years: the Busoni in Italy, the Montreal in Canada and the Chopin in Warsaw. On Tuesday night he made his first American appearance since capturing the Polish prize, as soloist in the Chopin Piano Concerto in E minor. He enjoyed the aid and comfort of Eugene Or mandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall.

title: MRS. J. A. HAGERTY, REPORTER'S WIDOW
description: Mrs. Katherine Kearney Hag erty, widow of James A. Hag erty, former political reporter for The New York Times, and mother of James C. Hagerty, vice president of the American Broadcasting Company and for mer press secretary of Presi dent Dwight D. Eisenhower, died Monday in St. John's Hos pital, Yonkers. She was 91 years old and had lived at the Hudson View Nursing Home, Yonkers.

title: C.A.B. to Tighten Rules On Charter Study Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board moved today to protect foreign study groups against defaults by chartering organizations.

title: New Paterson Police Chief
description: PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 11 (UPI)James T. Hannan was, named chief of police here last night by the Board of Fire and Police. Commissioners.. Mr. Han nan, who is 50 years old, had been acting thief for a year following the retirement of John T. O'Brien.

title: Plutocracy vs. Democracy
description: The United States today is on the road to becoming a plutocracy. It is getting to be almost customary for can didates for major political office to have to possess private fortunes or make entangling commitments to special interests In order to be elected. In certain states such as California, it is now the practice for a few rich men to club together and financially sponsor a candidate.

title: Barenboim's Busy Season: 31 Concerts
description: I don't believe in being pushed, not by the public, not by record companies, not by anybody. I haven't been in a recording studio this year at all, Daniel Barenboim, the 28yearold pianist and conductor whose staggering schedule this season includes 31 con certs in New York, wanted, as the saying goes, to make one thing clear.

title: Nixon Tells of Admiraion
description: PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 12 President Nixon, on his way to Paris aboard Air Force One, spoke to reporters for 20 min utes and described his admira tion for Charles de Gaulle.

title: Seals Beat Canadiens, 20, On Goals in First Period
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPDA pair of firstperiod goals and Garry Smith's per fect work at goal gave the Cali fornia Seals a 20 triumph over Montreal tonight and pushed the Canadiens down to third place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Nigeria Development Plan Calls For National Economic Control
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov, 11 (AP)A fouryear development plan to rebuild wartorn parts of Nigeria and to promote the meaningful Nigerianization of foreign companies was an nounced today by the head of state.

title: Rockets Defeat Royals
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 11 (AP) The San Diego Rockets nearly blew a 12point lead but rallied to defeat the Cincinnati Royals, 127120, tonight, with Stu Lantz collecting 38 points.

title: L.I.R. Station Evacuated After Bomb Is Discovered
description: Several thousand persons were evacuated from the lower level of the Long Island Rail road section of Pennsylvania Station for half an hour during the rush hour last night after a commuter found what looked like a bomb in a locker.

title: PRIME RATE CUT IS SEEN POSSIBLE
description: A cut in the basic interest charge on business loans may well be kicked off by one or more of the major New York City banks this morning. But if this prime rate should be trimmed from its present level of 7 per cent as now ap pears possible  most large banks would follow the move with great reluctance.

title: Whooping Cranes in Texas
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Nov., 11 (AP)  Fiftyfive whooping cranes settled down today, for their long winter stay in south Texas. Eleven arrived yester day, pushed along by a mild weather front from the north. More of the rare birds are ex pected, on their 2,500mile mi gration from the Great Slave Lake area of northern Canada. More important has been the arrival of six young of this species that almost was wiped out.

title: PHILIPPINES PICKS A CHARTER GROUP
description: MANILA, Nov. 11A largely conservative body of delegates was elected yesterday to re write the Constitution drafted in 1935, when the Philippines was still under United States rule.

title: Voting Age Shift Defeated
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 11  A proposed constitutional amend ment reducing the voting age in Connecticut from 21 to 18 was defeated in the election on Nov. 3 by 28,482 votes, the Secretary of State's office an nounced today. The official tabulation completed today showed a no vote of 336,012 and a yes vote of 307,530.

title: Lakers In Front, 117115
description: DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers survived a closing surge by the Detroit Pistons tonight to gain a 117 115 National Basketball Asso ciation victory.

title: Five French Brothers Drown
description: NANTES, France, Nov. 11 (AP)  Five brothers, ranging in age from 17 to 24 years, drowned near here today when their small boat sank in the Atlantic about 100 yards from shore.

title: Rumanian SelfImmolation
description: VIENNA, Nov. 11 (UPI)A young man set himself afire within view of the Rumanian Communist party leader, Nico lae Ceausescu, reports from Bu charest said today.

title: Polish Minister Asserts Pact With Bonn Is Near
description: WARSAW, Thursday, Nov. 12Poland's Foreign Minister, Stefan Jedrychowski, said late last night that we have ap proached the moment when we can complete negotiations with West Germany over a treaty establishing normal rela tions.

title: CATHY HONEY PUT FIRST IN REVERSAL
description: Posing unofficially in the whiner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday, Manta appeared to have successfully stolen the 100th running of the $55,400 Ladies Handicap.

title: Wolfson Wins a New Trial in 1968 Case Invoiving Perjury Charge and False Data
description: Louis E. Wolfson, the fin ancier who completed a jail sentence in January for vio lating Federal securities laws, won a new trial yesterday in another caseone in which he was convicted of perjury and filing false financial state ments with the Government.

title: Screen:'Count Yorga, Vampire' and 'The Crimson Cult' Bow at Local Theaters
description: One of the nicest things about movies, and rarely mentioned by film estheticians, is that they constitute the only art form that you can begin experiencing in broad daylight and finish experiencing in darkest night, giddy with the guilty realization that dusk has fallen without you. I suppose the same claims can be made for matinee theater and grand opera, but you plan for those and know what dislocations to expect But the movies, despite the line-forming mania of the Upper East Side cinema managers, ought to be something you duck into to avoid the fresh air and the sunshineand the hours you lose must be freely given, squandered without thought of moral reward. Three hours seems about the right amount of time to wasteenough to outlast the longest sunsetand by uncanny chance, three hours is about how long it takes to sit through the double bill of "Count Yorga, Vampire" and "The Crimson Cult," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.Enthusiasts of the genre will not need to be told what these films are about ("The Crimson Cult" is a British witch movie), and others probably won't care. I should be hard-pressed to defend "The Crimson Cult" on any grounds other than affection for the subject and for some of the cast, but not so hardpressed to defend "Count Yorga," which has snatches of seedy insight into the paraphernalia of vampirism and, in Robert Quarry, the best chief vampire I have seen in years. But the special appeal of "Count Yorga" may well be its Los Angeles locale; and of "The Crimson Cult," the last performance of the late Boris Karloff.He plays a Professor Marshe, an ancient beneficent believer in the black arts, and his role holds no surprises. But Karloff himself, cadaverous and almost wholly crippled, acts with a quiet lucidity of such great beauty that it is a refreshment merely to hear him speak old claptrap. Nothing else in "The Crimson Cult" comes close to himthough there is Barbara Steele in greenface playing Lavinia, a glamorous 300-year-old and a monumental cast that lists no fewer than seven-party girls, plus several sacrificial virgins.Virginity is not at issue in "Count Yorga, Vampire," for the beds from which the Count summons his doomed lovelies generally belong to their boyfriends. However, the other elements are traditionally in orderbeginning with dockside landing of a crated coffin (but marvelously, at the Port of Los Angeles, followed by a long ride in a red pick-up truck through the city's streets and freeways) and not quite ending with a wooden stake through the heart (a makeshift stake, fashioned out of a kitchen chair, in this plastic world, the only available piece of wood).Count Yorga's ambience is pure Hollywood, and the seamy elegance of Robert Quarry's performance as a mysterious medium who has a handy supply of spirits of the dead lying around down-stairs exactly compliments that ambience. Bob Kelljan's direction, often resourceful, does especially well by Quarry's disdainful civilityparticularly toward Dr. Hayes (Roger Perry), his principal adversaryduring their long, tense conversations that are the greatest pleasure in the movie.There are other pleasures. Count Yorga's rented mansion features a gothic basementcomplete with three toothsome female vampires breathing heavily in diaphanous gowns while waiting to do their master's bidding. If you do choose to lose an afternoon, it is good to lose it in the company of such as thesewho sleep away whole days in sensual darkness.

title: Oil on Water
description: Dramatic accidents like the breakup of the tanker Torrey Canyon off England in 1967 and the more recent blowout of a drilling rig in the Santa Barbara Channel have helped to focus world attention on the devastating effects of oil spills on the seas and seashores. The United States and other maritime nations have begun to take steps through tighter regulations and the fixing of liabil ity to prevent or at least to alleviate the consequences of such localized mishaps.

title: FRANCE TELLS U.N. OF FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11  Jacques Kosciusko Morizet, the French delegate, said today that his Government, in close cooperation with United States officials, had in tensified its efforts to curb illicit traffic in narcotics.

title: Inquiry on Police Corruption Queries Captain Accused of Abetting Bribery
description: A police captain who for three years headed the police unit assigned to the city's De partment of Investigation has been questioned by a Brooklyn grand jury that is looking into police corruption.

title: HARRY HAMMER, 77, GALLERY EXECUTIVE
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 11Harry J. Hammer, vice president of the Hammer Galleries, Inc., 51 East 57th Street, New York, died today of pneumonia at Methodist Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 781 Fifth Avenue. Manhattan.

title: Concession 103: Oil Oasis in Libya's Desert
description: CONCESSION 103, Libya, Nov. 5At eight o'clock ev ery morning, except Sunday, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's F27 takes off from the back side of Tripoli Airport and heads southeast across Libya's great sand desert.

title: House Freshmen Younger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The average of the 55 new members of the House will be about 11 years younger than the members replaced, incom plete statistics indicate. The fig ures show newly elected Demo crats averaging almost 15 years younger than their predecessors and Republicans between four and five years younger.

title: Brimmer Sees Extra Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11A member of the Federal Re serve Board estimated today that imposition of Import quo tas on textiles and shoes, as provided in legislation pending in Congress, would cost con sumers an extra $3.7billion by 1975 and would raise the Con sumer Price Index by almost one full per cent.

title: Army Band Skips Veterans Parade in Rainy City
description: The United States First Army Band did not march yesterday in the annual Veterans Day parade down Fifth Avenue be cause of rain.

title: Jules Laventhol, 34, Dead; TV Film. Editor in London
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) Jules Laventhol, a television film editor and a member of a well known newspaper family, died today after a four  month illness. He was 34 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The gleaming Atlantic salmon, whose incomparable strength, agility, and beauty have delighted man for cen turies, is well on its way to becoming an international cause clbre.

title: Pentagon Rejects Proposal On Draft Board Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Government auditors said today that they had recom mended, but the Defense De partment had rejected, a great er use of private doctors to de cide if youths were fit for the draft.

title: California Board Adopts Curbs on Airport Noise
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPI)A 15year program de signed to reduce noise from California airports has been adopted by the State Aeronau tics Board despite protests by Los Angeles County.

title: Some Service Academy Alumni Ask Prompt Pullout From War
description: An organization of service academy alumni called on President Nixon yesterday to put aside selfserving political goals and promptly withdraw all troops from Vietnam.

title: Files Ending Giant Trend To OneYear Linebackers
description: In 1963, the last time the Giants won a championship, Jim Files was a sophomore at Southside High School in Fort Smith, Ark., playing of fensive and defensive end on the football team. He also was a football fan, and he remembers something about the Giants from that year.

title: MILTON LEVY
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 11 Milton Levy, chairman of the Levy Brothers Department Store and a leader in Jewish com munity activities here; died to day in Beth Israel Medical Cen ter in New York, after a short illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Tighter Division Races Attributed to Expansion
Article 1  No Title
Bond Prices Rise In Quiet Trading; Corporates Active
description: The credit markets, par tially closed yesterday for Veterans Day, continued to reflect the news that six of 12 Federal Reserve banks had reduced their discount rate.

title: TV: Executives Examine Documentaries Decline
description: Three producers and a ma jor program executive, all of whom have had experience in commercial television and three of whom are now asso ciated, with noncommercial TV, agreed last night that fear of low ratings or sponsor disapproval had made today's commercial documentary se ries blander and blander.

title: Undermining Head Start
description: Ever since the Nixon Administration tried, more than a year ago, to give special visibility to a flawed study that questioned the effectiveness of Project Head Start, the future of that preschool education program has seemed in doubt.

title: MORNING UPSWING FIZZLES ON AMEX
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday soared in early trading and then dropped almost as fast in the afternoon.

title: SMYSLOV DEFEATED BY BOBBY FISCHER
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov.10Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eighttime United States chess champion, yesterday defeated Vasily Smy slov of the Soviet Union, a for mer world champion, in the second round of the eighth in, terzonal tournament of Palma de Mallorca. The event, a 24 man knockout, will determine the challenger for the world title.

title: The Trying of a Furnished Mind
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Two of the fabled hotbeds of radicalism will go on the block tomorrow at Brumb leby's, clich?? auctioneer to the filthy, rich.

title: WORTV's New Theater Critic Is Dismissed Before First Review
description: WORTV, Channel 9, which began a nightly halfhour news cast on Monday, dismissed its theater and arts critic, Joel Crothers, five hours before he was to deliver his first review.

title: 76ers Beat Bullets, 119107
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (UPI) Archie Clark and Wally Jones combined for 48 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers de feated the Baltimore Bullets, 119107. It was the Bullets fourth loss in their last five games.

title: Penguins Tie Rangers, 33, With 2 ThirdPeriod Goals
description: The strange affliction that the Ranger defense suffers when Ed Giacomin is in the nets cropped up last night as the Pittsburgh Penguins tied the New Yorkers. 33.

title: Danny Kaye, as Noah, Is Hailed on Broadway
description: Danny Kaye, a truant from the Broadway musical comedy stage for nearly half a life time, came back on Tuesday night in, the role of a 600 yearold man in Two by Two.

title: SUFFOLK ACCEPTS DETERGENTS BAN
description: COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 11 Suffolk County housewives and stores reacted calmly today to the ban on most detergents that was approved yesterday by the County Legislature.

title: 3 Firemen Trapped In Brooklyn Blaze; 1 Critically Injured
description: Three firemen were injured one criticallywhen a blazing fourstory building in the Bush wick section of Brooklyn col lapsed last night, trapping them inside. Two other firemen were treated for smoke inhalation.

title: POOR GAIN A VOICE ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 At a time when citizen partici pation in antipoverty programs is generally declining, parents of poor children are beginning to gain a voice in the adminis tration of Federal education funds for the disadvantaged.

title: 5 Coast Newspapers Agree To Pacts Before Deadline
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 (UPI)Five major newspapers in the San Francisco Bay area have agreed with 16 unions to extend until the end of 1973 contracts that were to expire next February, it was announced today.

title: Entertainment Events
MYLAI PROSECUTOR WON'T FIGHT RULING
description: FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 11 (UPI)The prosecutor in the case of S. Sgt. David Mitchell, charged with assault with in tent to murder in the alleged Mylai massacre of civilians in South Vietnam, says he plans no changes in his case despite a ruling in a similar case in Georgia.

title: Lebanon Turns to Domestic Problems
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 5  Pinball machines have replaced the Arab commandos as prime targets of Lebanese Govern ment wrath under the new ad ministration of President Sulei man Franjieh.

title: Coast Deal Is Terminated
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara, Calif., said yes terday that its previously an nounced negotations to ac quire the San Luis Obispo Savings & Loan Association had been terminated. Financial Corporation said that although the acquisition was recently approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board the com panies were unable to reach a final agreement on terms.

title: Navy to Allow Beer, Beards, Hard Rock
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, who has been Chief of Naval Op erations for the last four and a half months, is taking the Mickey Mouse out of the Navy.

title: Business Inventories Up in September
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Total business inventories rose about $600million in Septem ber, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase, however, was less than July or August.

title: In Memoriam
description: KESSELMANWilliam R. In cherished mem ory of our beloved brother, Bill, Novem ber 13, 1930.

title: Miss. Turisheva, Okamura Dominate Gymnastic Meet
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 12Ludmila Turisheva, the Soviet Union world champion, and Heruichi Okamura of Japan each won four gold medals, in cluding those for the individual overall championships at the world invitation gymnastic tournament.

title: Running Redskin to Give Giants' Trappers a Test
description: The Giants, one game out of first place and one out of fourth in their division race, are favored over Washington by a point in Sunday's game here. The Jets, off to Los An geles to play the Rams, are underdogs again  by 17 points. Sunday contests to be

title: PACERS CONQUER CONDORS, 135132
WHITE HOUSE SEEN LIFTING AID TO CITY
Treasury Aide Calls Budget, Estimate No Longer Accurate, but Will Not Guess at Deficit
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12Treas ury Secretary David M. Ken nedy said here today that the Administration's last official budget estimate was no long er accurate, but he termed es timates of a deficit of as much as $20billion misleading.

title: Thoresen Said to Have Tried To Throw Wife Out Window
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI A friend of William E. Thor esen 3d testified today that he once interrupted the Chicago steel heir while he was trying to throw his wife out a 20th floor hotel window.

title: Kent Case Prosecutor Says Jury Used F.B.I. Report
description: LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) The grand jury that exonerat ed National Guardsmen in the deaths of four Kent State Uni versity students saw portions of a Federal Bureau of Inves tigation document that report edly said the shootings had not been directly provoked, the special prosecutor in the case says.

title: Bridge:
Blues Triumph, 21, As Ecclestone's Goal Topples Red Wings
The Man and His Monument
description: PARIS, Nov. 12The simplicity of General de Gaulle's funeral in the little village of ColombeylesDeux Eglises was suitable to his carefully composed public character and retir ing private personality. The contrast between the modest ceremony accord ing with his dictated wish and the splendid commemoration in Notre Dame, attended by the world's most eminent leaders, served only to un derscore an essential austerity in the Fifth Republic's founder.

title: Fanny May Plans Rights Issue Today
description: The Federal National Mort gage Association is scheduled to make a rights offering to stockholders today for an esti mated 1.13 million shares.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 12 The undefeated women's tour ing field hockey team of Eng land gained its 17th victory to day by defeating the United States squad, 40, today at Cedar College. Mary McNally scored three goals and Barbara Gaylor, one.

title: 20 Quarter Horses Killed In Fire at Oklahoma Track
description: SALLISAW, Okla, Nov. 12 (AP)  At least 20 horses were killed last night when fire de stroyed a barn at the Blue Rib bon Downs quarter horse race track. Cause of the blaze was unknown.

title: PHILIP DECHERT DIES; LONG A LAWYER, 64
description: Philip Dechert, a lawyer in Philadelphia and a civic leader, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hos pital, New Bedford, Mass., after a long illness. He was 64, years old and lived in Nonquitt, Mass.

title: Nancy R. Smith Becomes Bride Of Richard Bate
description: NEW HOPE, Pa., Nov. 12 Miss Nancy Ruth Smith of New York, a freelance writer and fashion publicist, was married here this afternoon to Richard Henry Bate, as sistant vice president and associate counsel for the Beneficial Management Cor poration of Morristown, N. J. Mayor George W. Bailey per formed the ceremony at the country home of the maid of honor, Miss Margot Johnson of New Hone and New York.

title: MayDecember Marriages  When It's the Wife Who's Older
description: LOS ANGELES He, an architect, is 30 years old; she, a teacher, is 45. And because of the age difference, their first six months of marriage supplied a few unpleasant incidents, although they weren't as unsettling as you might expect.

title: Youths Seized in Water Loss
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 12 Vandals early today opened 18 hydrants And reduced water pressure here to a trickle, causing the loss of half a mil lion gallons. William Armitage, 17 years old, Thomas Purcell, and David Pramer, both 16, were arrested.

title: Custody and Clearing Unit Is Set Up by W. E. Huttor
Pork Is on Menu For the Weekend
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: The Indian OceanA Soviet Sea?
description: CANBERRAThe Public Accounts Committee of the Australian Parlia ment has been examining witnesses over a budget allocation for the first stage of a naval base facility at Cock burn Sound near Perth on the West coast of this threemillionsquaremile continent. A pacifist geologist solemn ly raised with the Committee the ques tion of pollution, while a senior naval officer justified the allocation partly in terms of the growing Soviet presence in the Indian Ocean area.

title: Memorial Services
description: CHAPINFlorence M. A memorial service will be held on Sun.. Nov. 15th at 3 P.M. et the Chapel of the Community Church, 40 East 35th St.

title: Atheist, 16, Is Denied Rank of Eagle Scout
description: PROVIDENCE, R, I., Nov. 12 (AP)A 16yearold boy has been denied the rank of Eagle Scout, scouting's high est honor, because he is an atheist.

title: Rev. W. Henry Crane, 49, Church Council Africa Aide
description: GENEVA, Nov. 12  The Rev. W. Henry Crane, secre tary for Africa of the World Council of Churches mission division, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 49 years old.

title: Adrian Phillips, 70, Dies; Active in West Sides Realty
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 12 Adrian H. Phillips of 494 East Saddle River Road, a well known New York realtor, died yesterday in Valley Hospital after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Murray Stockman, ExHead Of Queens County Bar, 69
description: Murray Stockman, president of the Queens County Bar Association in 1954, died yes terday of a heart attack at his home, 12510 Queens Boule vard, Kew Gardens, Queens. He was 69 years old. His law office was in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Mrs. Murchison to Be Remarried
description: DALLAS, Nov. 12Mrs. Virginia Long Murchison, widow of Clinton (Clint) Wil liams Murchison, the Texas industrialist whose financial empire was estimated at a halfbillion dollars after his death in June, 1969, and Ed ward David Linthicum, own er of Deep Creek Ranch in San Saba, southwest of Dal las, plan to be married here on Tuesday.

title: Belgrade Envoy in Vatican
description: ROME, Nov. 12 (Reuters) Yugoslavia's Ambassador to the Vatican today presented his credentials to Pope Paul, for mally ending an 18year rift.

title: ALGIERS TAKES OVER 2 U.S. OIL CONCERNS
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The Government today an nounced the nationalization of the holdings here of Mobil Oil and Newmont Overseas Oil, American cmopanies that it has controlled since 1967.

title: MINORITY STUDENTS TO RECEIVE FORD AID
description: A $2.1million project to pro vide scholarships for about 1,000 minoritygroup graduates of junior and community col leges who wish to further their education was announced yes terday by the Ford Founda tion, The Associated Press re ported.

title: FAKE FOOD STAMPS CIRCULATED HERE
description: The Secret Service reported yesterday that three arrests had been made in a continuing investigation of counterfeit food stamps that have been circu lating in impoverished neighbor hoods.

title: U.S. STEEL WEIGHS A MILL FOR TAIWAN
description: The United States Steel Cor poration said yesterday that, at the request of the Taiwan Government, it had studied the feasibility of building a steel mill in Taiwan.

title: DECLINE REPORTED FOR TRUCK TRAFFIC
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Nov. 7 was 13 per cent below the level of the corresponding week of last year.

title: Hertz ExpandsTruck Service
description: The Hertz Corporation and the United RentAll Corporation announced today an agreement to provide Hertz truck rental service through United's stores. Hertz truck rental service cur rently is available in more than 1,800 locations. United has 300 locations.

title: Wesley L. Fry, 67, Coached California Football Team
description: LA MESA, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP)Wesley L. Fry, former general manager of the Oak land Raiders and coach of the Nniversity of California foot ball team, died yesterday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: Company Records Given by Copeland To U.S. Officials
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 12 Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. voluntarily handed over to Federal agents today the rec ords of the Winthrop Law rence Corporation, a financial holding company that he con trolled with Thomas A. Sha heen Jr. The agents received the records at the company's offices in Cheyy Chace Md.

title: Judge Orders Halt to Union Picketing
description: A Federal judge found yester day that Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack, along, with an official of a Harlem grocery employes' union, L. Joseph Overton, and other union leaders and busi nessmen had conspired unlaw fully to force the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative out of business or into submission by calling a strike against it.

title: PENNSY TRUSTEES BACK INTERVENTION
description: Trustees of the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company recommended yesterday to the Federal district court in Phila delphia that 36 of 43 petitoin ers be allowed to intervene, as they had requested, in the re organization of the bankrupt railroad.

title: Transport Notes: Dumping Ban Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)  The National Air Pollution Control Administration an nounced today that it had asked airlines to halt voluntarily the dumping of 13 million pounds of jet fuel each year into the sky near airports.

title: ALCAN PROFITS DIP ON PEAK REVENUE
Gene Rayburn in Hospital
description: WAREHAM, Mass., Nov. 12 (UPI)Gene Rayburn of televi sion was reported in satisfac tory condition today at Tobey Hospital with injuries suffered in an auto accident in Marion. The 52yearold Mr. Rayburn suffered cuts and bruises last night when his car collided with another as Mr. Rayburn was trying to cross Route 6.

title: CAVALIERS NOTCH INITIAL TRIUMPH
Local Electoral Reform
description: The Citizens Voter Education Campaign, a bipartisan group devoted to electoral reform, has urged the City Council to use greater care in selecting members of the Board of Elections. The board has enormous administra tive power over electoral procedures, including the validation of candidate petitions and the setting of registration guidelines. The terms of all four members expire next month, thus presenting an opportunity for revitalizing the board and extending the franchise to the nearly two million city residents now wrongly denied it.

title: 302 Pints of Blood Donated
description: HENNIKER, N. H., Nov. 12 (AP)  New England College students have rallied to help an ill alumnus and have donated 302 pints of blood to the Ver mont  New Hampshire Red Cross blood program.

title: DEATHS HERE LAID TO LACK OF NURSES
