description: Senior physicins in the city's 18 municipal hospitals charged yesterday that hun dreds of preventable deaths annually were being caused by a critical shortage of nurses.

title: TV: 14 Plays in One Hour
description: Ever since The Time of Your Life, it has been the rare gift of William Saroyan to conjure up in a matter of minutes oddments of individ ual realism and poignant imagery, fleeting glimpses of the reassuring and sometimes puzzling unpredictability of the diversity of human nature.

title: Blount Asks Aid on P.O.W.'s
description: GENEVA, Nov. 12Post master General Winton M. Blount today requested the help of the International Committee or the Red Cross in getting Christmas mail to American prisoners of war in North Viet nam.

title: SHARES ON AMEX IN WIDE RETREAT
description: The American Stock Ex change sustained its biggest daily loss in three weeks yes terday as the list retreated on moderate volume.

title: JERSEY JURY IS GIVEN DATA ON STERNKOPF
description: NEWARK, Nov. 12A lawyer for William A. Sternkopf Jr., a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, delivered to a Federal grand jury here to day financial records that link him with three corporations in which John V. Kenny, the Hud son County Democratic boss, is a principal.

title: Fabric Council Chief Named
description: Theodore M. Kaufman, presi dent of the Norwalk Associates division of the Hat Corporation of America, will become execu tive director of the American Printed Fabrics Council on Dec. 1. Mr. Kaufman will succeed Richard Lowell, executive di rector of the Textile Distribu tors Association, who has been doubling as executive head of the council since its founding five years ago.

title: Sinatra Leaves Dead Right
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 12 (AP) Frank Sinatra has withdrawn from a Warner Brothers movie, Dead Right, because of con Outing pain following a June operation on his right hand, spokesmen said yesterday.

title: Ford and Toyo Kogyo End Talks of a TieUp for Now
CITY BETTING UNIT PLANS 2 SIDELINES
description: The city's OffTrack Betting Corporation will go into two sidelinesconsulting and com puter time lending  accord ing to its president, Howard J. Samuels.

title: Delay on Detergent Chemical Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12A confidential Congressional re port warns that the replace ment of phosphates in house hold detergents by a chemical called NTA would not signi ficantly reduce water pollution and might increase hazards to both people and their environ ment.

title: Drug Raids in Youngstown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 12 (UPI)Police Chief Donald Baker said today that wide raids by 90 policemen may have dried up at least 90 per cent of the area's heroin supply. Raids in 16 homes and busi nesses yesterday resulted in 25 arrests and the confiscation of more than $100,000 in heroin and other hard drugs. The raids were so secret that most police men involved did not know what was going on until they were in their patrol cars.

title: Modern Museum to Honor Hal Wallis in Film Series
description: Starting Wednesday, 43 films made under the banner of Hal Wallis will be presented by the Museum of Modern Art in trib ute to the record of the 72 yearold producer, whose Holly wood career spans over 400 movies. The museum will give a reception for Mr. Wallis on Wednesday night following a screening of The Dawn Patrol (1930). The program will con clude Jan. 12.

title: New Crime Patrol Walks in Shadows
2 L.I. MEN GUILTY IN KICKBACK CASE
description: An accountant and a mort gage broker from Long Island were convicted by a Federal jury here last night of con spiring to arrange kickbacks on a $1million mortgage loan from the teamster union pen sion funds in 1964. Eight other defendants were acquitted.

title: Text of Guidelines for TaxExempt Organizations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Following is the text of the guidelines that the Internal Revenue Service announced it will use in determin ing whether organizations engaged in litigation in the public interest will be granted taxexempt status:

title: GOODELL HOPES LIBERALS SURVIVE
Fete at Pierre Listed By Jamaica Hospital
description: The annual Jamaica Hospi tal fundraising drive, which is in its final two weeks, will be highlighted by the hospi tal's 79th anniversary dinner dance tomorrow at the Hotel Pierre.

title: TOM Q. BLACK DEAD; LED PEANUT CONCERN
description: KNOXVILLE, Term., Nov. 12 Tom Q. Black, University of Tennessee benefactor and ex president and founder of Tom Black, Inc., now the Tom Hus ton Peanut Company, died of heart attack at a hospital here this afternoon. He was 66 years old

title: CIGARETTE CODE ON ADS DROPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The cigarette advertising code has stopped functioning, ending a sixyear experiment in self regulation by the tobacco in dustry.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES MANSON BEAT HER
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 Seventeenyearold Dianne Lake a prosecution witness, ended her testimony at the TateLa Bianca murder trial today say ing that she had been kicked and beaten by Charles M. Man son, one of the defendants.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: HUDSON WILL JOIN JETS' TAXI SQUAD
description: Jim Hudson, one of the he roes of the Jets' Super Bowl season, was waived by the in jurybattered team yesterday, and will be reduced to taxi squad status next week.

title: General Strike Paralyzes Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 With the grip of military gov ernment in Argentina more re laxed than at any time since 1966, organized labor paralyzed the nation today with a gen eral strike and five political parties demanded an immediate return to elective democracy.

title: R.A.F. Copter Crash Kills 5
description: BASINGSTOKE, England, Nov. 12 (AP)Five British air men were killed today when two Royal Air Force helicopters collided over nearby Odiham Base.

title: English Women Win Again
Royals Stop Warriors
LatinAmerican Group Plans 14th Debutante Ball, a Benefit
description: Fourteen debutantes, daugh ters of prominent Latin American families in the greater New York area, will be presented to society at the Debutante Ball tomorrow night by the LatinAmerican Court of the Catholic Daugh ters of America in the Hilton Room of the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Draft Office Fire Bombed
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) A West Side Selective Service office was firebombed early today. The police said they were searching for a long haired bearded suspect.

title: Gorman Beats Paish, Gains Dewar Cup Net Semifinals
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (UPI)  Secondseeded Tom Gorman of Seattle reached the semifinals of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today but needed a tiebreaker to overcome John Paish of England. 63. 76.

title: Mao and Moscow's Navy
description: Although Mao has recently called for the development of the Chinese Navy into a force at least able to defend the coastal lines of shipping communications and the coast itself against attack, the Chinese Navy is at present so weak as to be virtually helpless in face of an attack by the Soviet Pacific Fleet. Accordingly the cover age given to Soviet Navy Day this year in the Soviet Party news paper Pravda can scarcely be interpreted otherwise than as a subtle reminder to Mao and Chou that they are virtually defenseless and open to Soviet assault and invasion by sea at any point.

title: Patman Plans Bill to Aid Savings Units
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 Representative Wright Pat man, long a critic of the bank ing industry, held out the promise today that savings and loan associations would be able to operate more like banks.

title: Winning Season in Cards If Columbia Beats Penn
description: It's now or never for Co lumbia and Penn. The two Ivy League teams go into to morrow's Franklin Field football game with identical records, three victories and four defeats. A triumph will give the victor a chance at a winning season.

title: Rockets Drop Belmont
description: DENVER, Nov. 12 (AP)Joe Belmont was dropped today as coach of the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball As sociation, Don Ringsby, club president, announced:

title: SOVIET TRADE UNIT ARRIVES IN PEKING
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12The So viet Union and Communist China took another apparent step today toward improving their relations with the arrival of a Soviet delegation in Peking for trade talks.

title: Agnew Has a Word Hogwash, For Critics of G.O.P. Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Vice President Agnew defended tonight the tactics used by the White House in this year's elec tion campaign and said that the voters had responded to as positive a message as ever a political campaign offered the country.

title: Baptist Amens Echo in South
description: JACKSON, Tenn., Nov. 12 Sinnot war, crime or so cial discontent, but oldfash ioned sinis hanging heavy over Southern towns like ambivalent Jackson this month.

title: BUSINESS SALES AND INVENTORIES
description: The New York Times Nov. 13, 1970

title: Company Linked to Scotto Denied Pier License
description: A stevedoring company in which Anthony Scotto, the In ternational Longshoremen's As sociation official, allegedly had a financial interest was denied a license to operate in the Port of New York yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BLUEST EYE. By Toni Morrison. 164 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $5.95.

title: MITCHELL TO SEEK SUBVERSION CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12At torney General John N. Mitchell disclosed today that the Nixon Administration would ask Con gress to pass new antisubver sive legislation soon after the new session begins in January.

title: Bias Suit Seeks to Bar Construction in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 12  The National Association for the Advancement of Colored Peo ple filed a suit here today charging that most local con struction unions had a histor ical and continued pattern of racial discrimination that has prevented Negroes from getting jobs on public building pro jects.

title: Great Art Works In a HiFi Setting
description: The exhibition called Mas terpieces of Fifty Centuries, which opens tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is at once one of the most pleasurable and one of the most irritating exhibi tions ever mounted. Since the exhibition is enormous more than 500 objects, ac cording to the museum both its pleasures and its ir ritations are sizable.

title: Bauffalo Scientists Report Synthesis of Living Cell
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo reported, yes terday that scientists there had achieved the first artificial synthesis of a living [and re producing cell.

title: Metropolitan Opens Show Without Imports
description: There are not so many im ported masterpieces in the Masterpieces of Fifty Cen turies show as the Metropol itan Museum would have liked. The reason? The high cost of borrowing works of art.

title: De Gaulle Is Buried With Quiet Simplicity
description: COLOMBEY  LES  DEUX EGLISES, France, Nov. 12  Charles de Gaulle was buried today as he wished, in sim plicity, surrounded by his family, his fellow villagers, his comrades of the Libera tion and thousands of his grieving countrymen.

title: A Shopper's Guide to Codes
description: Cryptography is coming to the checkout counter as con sumer groups have begun to pressure supermarket chains to take the secrecy out of the codes now stamped on almost every item.

title: Arcaro Extremely Well Following Heart Surgery
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 (UPI)Eddie Arcaro, the only jockey to win horse rac ing's Triple Crown twice, was reported extremely well today following sur gery to repair a blocked coro nary artery.

title: U.S. EASES STAND IN DEBATE AT U.N. ON SEATING PEKING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12  The United States, which has long pursued a Pol icy of allout opposition to Com munist China's admission to the United Nations, today argued instead against the expulsion of Nationalist China.

title: The Weakness of Greatness
description: Now that Charles de Gaulle is gone, it is clear that the remaining political managers of the world are a different breed from the heroic leaders of the last generation, Even on his way to the grave, the dead de Gaulle some how managed to retain the gift of grace, even a glint of magic, and make the living Presidents and Prime Ministers seem rather plain.

title: Calley CourtMartial Opens Officially at Ft. Benning
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 12Two probable themes in the defense of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. emerged to day when his courtmartial for the premeditated murder of 102 South Vietnamese civilians of ficially opened more than two and a half years after the al leged massacre at Sonmv.

title: From Bonnie Cashin, Cheerful Colors
description: Bonnie Cashin is as American as, well, apple pie. There aren't too many fashion designers around who can make that statement. Most of them keep themselves busy jetting to Europe to admire the newest interpretations of the cowboy look or to swoon over the way French girls tiedye a scarf.

title: ANTIQUES FAIR OPENS AT GREENWICH HOUSE
description: The Greenwich House annual antiques show, which opened yesterday at 27 Barrow Street, is for browsers with patience and determination. For though the antique is present it is overwhelmingly outnumbered by elderly odds and ends.

title: Abrams Seeks a Shift of Power From Mayor to Borough Heads
description: A plan to restructure radi cally the municipal government by shifting authority for many essential city services from the Mayor to Borough Presidents was offered yesterday by Bronx Borough President Rob ert Abrams.

title: Huff Terms Webster's Giants a Vastly Improved Team
description: Sam Hutt, his old Giant jersey and helmet still part of his living room decoration, re turns to Yankee Stadium Sun day with mixed feelings.

title: Stars Beat Floridians
Pay TV Station on Way
description: CHICAGO, NOV. 12 (UPI) The way has apparently been cleared for operation in Chi cago of the nation's first pay television station. The Chicago Federation of Labor, operators of Station WCFL, voted to transfer its construction permit for a 5,000kw UHF channel to the Zenith Radio Corporation. Zenith plans to use the channel for its phonevision subscription television system, the only payTV system to be approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: October Retail Sales Slip
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (Reu ters)  October retail sales dropped 1.5 per cent to a sea sonally adjusted $30.396billion from $30.813billion in Septem ber, according to preliminary figures released by the Com merce Department today. The October total was 2.5 per cent above the $29.62billion in re tail sales in October, 1969.

title: TOP W.M.G.A. POST TO MRS. STEELE
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association elected a new slate of officers yesterday at its annual meeting at the Hotel Delmonico.

title: Contract With G.M. Is Approved, 9 to 1, By U.A.W. Council
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12Rep resentatives of the striking United Automobile Workers overwhelmingly approved to day a contract agreement with the General Motors Cor poration. The strikers are expected to approve the con tract by a week from tomor row.

title: Kenya Gets Satellite Link
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 12 A 60second telephone call from President Jomo Kenyatta to the United Nations Secretary Gen eral, U. Thant, today marked Kenya's entry into space age communications. The call opened a satellite communica tion station in the Rift Valley, about 50 miles from here.

title: GATT Head Says Textile Issue Should Be Studied Within Unit
description: GENEVA, Nov. 12The over  all problem of interna tional trade in textiles should be examined within the frame work of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the execu tive head of this intergovern mental agency said today.

title: 59 Children Rescued at Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov: 12 (AP)Fiftynine children were safely evacuated from the Opportunities Industrialization Center here before the 78year old building housing its burst into flames today.

title: Decision to Bar Contract Pros From U.S.L.T.A. Play Put Off
description: CLEVELAND, Noy. 12Ths United States Lawn Tennis Association delayed a final de cision today on whether to bar all contract professionals from U.S.L.T.A.  sanctioned prize money tournaments in 1971.

title: Judge Delays Suit to Curb Wild, Wild West
description: A Federal judge postponed action yesterday on a suit that sought to restrain the Colum bia Broadcasting System and its Washington affiliate, WTOP TV, from showing the program Wild, Wild West because it contains fictionalized vio lente and horror harmful to the mental health and wellbe ing of minor children.

title: Dodge to Market Japanese Subcompact
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 12  The Chrysler Corpora tion, whose entry in the sub compact market is still on the drawing boards, an nounced today that it would do battle against Ford's Pinto and General Motors's Vega with a Japanese import.

title: TAXFREE STATUS KEPT FOR GROUPS SUING FOR PUBLIC
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Internal Revenue Service, under pressure from a wide co alition of conservation, consum erprotection and other inter ests, backed down today and agreed to continue to grant tax exempt status to organizations that bring lawsuits in the public interest.

title: Cellist Assails Curbs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12  Msti slav Rostropovich, the virtuoso Soviet cellist, is reported to have written an impassioned defense of the author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, whose selection for the 1970 Nobel Prize in lit erature has been officially de nounced here.

title: RICHARD A. DREW, 62, OPERA COMPANY AIDE
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 Richard Arthur Drew, business manager of the Los Angeles and San Francisco Civic Light Opera Associations for 30 years who was widely known among company managers of touring, Broadway shows, died of can cer yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Burbank, Calif. He was 62 years old.

title: Ryan's Daughter To Be Advertised Without a Rating
description: MetroGoldwynMayer an nounced yesterday that its new film, Ryan's Daughter, will be marketed nationally with no mention of its or re stricted, rating by the Motion Pictures Association of Amer ica.

title: Colombia Puts Toll at 200 From Storms and Quakes
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 12 (AP)More than a month of rains, high winds and an earth quake have taken the lives of more than 200 persons in the rich cattle land of northern Colombia, officials reported to day.

title: Article 1  No Title
Defendant Pleads Not Guilty In California Slayings of Five
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. Nov. 12 (AP)A shaggyhaired former auto mechanic, charged with killing five persons at a hilltop mansion Oct. 19, pleaded not guilty today.

title: BEETHOVEN GIVEN A PROPER TRIBUTE
Chicago Bank Opens Unit
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) The First National Bank of Chi cago announced today the opening of a new merchant banking subsidiary in London to provide complete and fully integrated international finan cial services for its customers at home and abroad.

title: 3YearOld British Boy Part of Burglary Gang
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Nov. 12 (Reuters)A 3year old boy was the most im portant member of a school boy housebreaking gang, a juvenile court was told here today.

title: F.A.A. Official and Pilot Die In Pennsylvania Air Crash
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI)  Gerald C. Weeks, of East Northport, L. I., a Federal Aviation Administration official, and David McKay, of Wayne, Pa., were killed yesterday when their twin  engine Cessna slammed into a heavily wooded mountaintop near here.

title: Bullets Get Lakers'
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets acquired a forward, John Tresvant, from the Los Angeles Lakers today for a high future draft choice, a club spokesman said. The 6foot7inch, 31yearold Tres vant has played seven seasons in the National Basketball As sociation.

title: Cocktail Dance Set For Health Service
description: A cocktail dance has been arranged for Sunday evening at the Pierre in behalf of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association. The event, to start at 6 P.M., will include a buffet.

title: Amalrik Gets 3 Years
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12  Andrei A. Amalrik, the author of a book predicting the doom of the Soviet state, was reportedly found guilty today and sen tenced to three years' confine ment in a labor camp on charges of having defamed the Soviet Union.

title: In the Public Interest
description: The decision of the Internal Revenue Service to uphold the tax deductible status of public interest law firms is a victory for every citizen. The guidelines made pub lic yesterday by I.R.S. Commissioner Randolph W. Thrower protect the charitable classification of the many new law firms which have sprung up in recent years to defend the environment and the consumer both in the courts and before administrative agencies. A threat has also been removed from older organizations such as the Audubon Society which reinforce their edu cational activities by occasional intervention in conser vation cases in a friend of the court capacity.

title: Council Asks Ronan to Testify On Problems in City Subways
description: A City Council committee in vited Dr. William J. Ronan to testify before the committee yesterday and said it would hold up an appropriation for the Transit Authority until he did so.

title: Walter J. Donnelly. Dead at 74; With Foreign Service 25 Years
description: Walter J. Donnelly, who dur ing his 25 years with the For eign Service won distinction as one of this country's leading experts on Central and South American affairs, died yester day of a heart attack in Bo gota, Columbia. He was 74 years old and had lived in Caracas. Venezuela.

title: MRS. ALLAN BROWN
description: Mrs. Christine Chipman Brown, wife of Allan Brown, a retired vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday at her winter home in Tuckerstown, Bermuda. She was 68 years old and also lived in Montclair, N. J., and Man chester ??

title: Luncheon at Hilton to Aid Menorah Home
description: The 20th annual luncheon to benefit the Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm, Brooklyn, will be given by the 19 auxiliaries of Menorah at noon Monday at the New. York Hilton. Pro ceeds will help support the beneficiary's programs for its 500 residents, 300 day center members and 200 aged in the outpatient psychiatric clinic.

title: For Parisians a Sodden Day of Mourning
description: PARIS, Nov. 12This morn ing was for the dignitaries President Pompidou, who ar rived at Notre Dame foul minutes late. President Nix on, alone and somber in his black limousine. Kings princes, presidents, prime ministers.

title: Stockholdings of Insiders
Heart Experts Disagree on Desirability of a Diet That Is Low in Saturated Fats
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 More than 60 years after the re lationship between fat and diet and the development of harden ing of the arteries was first noted, physicians are still de bating whether to recommend a low saturated fat diet to the American public in hopes of stemming the current epidemic of heart disease.

title: LONDON STOCKS REGISTER DECLINE
Bonn Steps Up Drive on Sale and Use of Narcotics
description: BONN, Nov. 12The federal Government announced an in tensive drive today against the peddling and possession of drugs and narcotics in West Germany.

title: 396 Pilots Strike Mohawk Airlines; Talks Break Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)A pilots' strike ground ed Mohawk Airlines today and Federal mediation efforts to get contract talks started again failed after a twohour meet ing.

title: Norman, Craig Resigns T.W.A. Cargo Account
description: Norman, Craig & Kummel resigned yesterday the dwin dling Trans World Airlines air cargo account to make itself available for other up intheair business.

title: Rosales Down for 20 Days
description: Rudy Rosales received a sus pension of 20 days yesterday for rough riding during the run ning of last Wednesday's Ladies Handicap. His mount, Manta, was disqualified and placed sec ond, with Mrs. Hastings Har court's Cathy Honey being named the winner.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1970

title: SHAW, LIBERAL, WINS IN COURT OF APPEALS
description: A unanimous decision by the Court of Appeals yesterday ended the last hope that the Liberal party's state leader ship might be able to oust J. Stanley Shaw as the party's county chairman in Queens.

title: Not Guilty Plea on Coast
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP)John Linley Frazier, 24 years old, pleaded not guilty to day to five slayings at a hilltop mansion near Santa Cruz last month, after his lawyer got per mission to switch the plea to insanity if he wished. A tenta tive Jan. 25 jury trial date was set.

title: NO U.S. WAR DEAD FOR 2DAY PERIOD
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Nov. 13 (AP)The United States command reported yes terday that on Tuesday and Wednesday American forces in Indochina had gone through two days without a combat fatality for the first time in five years.

title: Sirhan's Death Sentence Appealed by His Attorneys
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov .12 (UPI) Attorneys for Sirhan B. Sir han appealed today his death sentence for the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: U.S. TO GIVE ISRAEL 18 MORE A4 JETS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Nixon Administration is sched uled to deliver 18 more Sky hawk A4 jet attack planes to Israel under a $500  million pledge of arms made to induce that country to accept the United States proposal for the Middle East ceasefire, which began on Aug. 7.

title: Chile Restores Formal Ties With Cuba; End of Alignment With U.S. Policy Seen
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 President Salvador Allende Gos sens announced today that Chile, the country he has gov erned for 10 days, had reestab lished full relations with Cuba.

title: N. E. A. Finds School Bias in Two States
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 12The Na tional Education Association has criticized public school de segregation policies in Louisiana and Mississippi.

title: Luna 17 at Halfway Point
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP) Luna 17, the unmanned Soviet spacecraft, passed the halfway point to the moon today when it reached a point 144,000 miles from the earth. The spacecraft is scheduled to carry out lunar exploration after landing on the lunar surface Saturday or Sunday, the Russians said.

title: AMOS S. BASEL, 59, JUDGE SINCE 1965
description: Criminal Court Judge Amos S. Basel died yesterday at his home, 45 East Ninth Street, after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Women's Lib, Rocking the Boat, Is Barred From Outboard Race
description: Speed records, boat dri vers and women's rights will find themselves in jeopardy at the outboard world cham pionship Nov. 28 and 29 at Lake Havasu City, Ariz.

title: SOYBEANS ARE HIT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking halved an early rise in the price of nearby soy bean futures options but the deferred, or new crop con tracts, held their advance on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Witness Tells of a Panther Bombing List
description: Two weeks before they were indicted here for an alleged bomb conspiracy, the Black Panthers set up a priority list for bombings of public places, a police undercover agent testi fied yesterday.

title: Ridana Registers 2Length Victory In Jersey Sprint
NONBETTING PACE IN NEW POST TIME
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 12 The $44,083 Lady Maud Pace will be held between the fourth and fifth races on Saturday night as a nonbetting event, Roosevelt Raceway announced today.

title: New Security Watcher
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Perhaps it was inevitable that Robert Charles Mardian would some day wind up in the Justice Department as head of its Internal Security Division.

title: WOMEN PRELATES URGED IN CHURCH
description: GARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 12 More than 200 priests, nuns and laymen met at a Roman Catholic monastery this week in an attempt to determine the women's liberation movement's meaning for religion.

title: GROMYKOANDPOPE HAVE A LONG TALK
description: ROME, Nov. 12The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, had an unusually long audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican this afternoon after three days of talks with Italian Government leaders.

title: Leaders From 80 Nations Join the French in DayLong Farewell to de Gaulle
2 SOLOISTS OFFER MUSICAL IMAGES
description: There has been much talk in the concert business of making the concert and recital format less rigid in order to attract the informally minded young. On Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, two of New York's wellknown and wellliked musicians made a mild stab in this direction.

title: U.S.CHINESE THAW REMAINS DISTANT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Eighteen months after they began, the Nixon Administra tion finds its efforts to improve relations with Communist China frozen, a casualty of Chinese intransigence and American dis traction with other problems.

title: NIXON DENOUNCED ON HUNGER POLICY
Tourney Greens Muffle Trevino's Chattering
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 (UPI)Lee Trevino almost stopped chattering today.

title: Carolina Steeplechasers Seek Lottery Tie for $100,000 Race
description: Steeplechase devotees hope to perpetuate the $100,000 Colonial Cup by hitching it to a lottery similar to the Irish Sweepstakes.

title: Market Place
description: Oh, the Rock Island line is a very fine line! Chances are you'd be hard put to find a railroad analyst who would agree with the folksing er's romantic assessment of the deeply troubled Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Rail road.

title: Loans to AllWhite Schools Protested by Rights Group
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 12 (UPI)The biracial Mississippi Council on Human Relations announced today that it would withdraw its funds from two Jackson banks that allegedly made loans totaling $600,000 to private, segregated schools here.

title: Exchange Urges Members To Back Goodbody Rescue
description: An urgent plea for approval of the proposed rescue of troubled Goodbody & Co. by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., was issued yester day to the membership of the New York Stock Exchange by its president, Robert W. Haack.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Defense Department to day identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Routine Otello Is Given by San Francisco Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 The San Francisco Opera has a new production of Verdi's Otello on the boards. It had its premiere last Saturday, was repeated last night, and seems to be made of stone. The entire motif of the production, by JeanPierre Ponnelle and Davis L. West, is stone. In each act a section of Oteilo's castle rises from the stage, seemingly made of handhewn rocks, solid and menacing, but clearly untenanted  a great ruin rather than a healthy structure. The sym bolism is clear.

title: Canadian Bill Rate Off
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 12 (Reuters) The Canadian Government auctioned today $160million in 91day treasury bills at an av erage yield of 4.88 per cent, down from 4.97 last week, and an average price of 98.798, up from 98.776 last week. The yield this week was the lowest since Oct. 5, 1967.

title: UTILITIES ARE URGED TO CONSERVE ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of New York State's Public Serv ice Commission, called on the electric power industry to re frain from encouraging the wasteful use of energy.

title: Corporate Bond Yields Continue to Move Down
description: Corporate bond yields continued to move down yester day, pushed lower by the reduction in the prime rate by all Major commercial banks. The Consumers Power Company sold $50million of Aaarated bonds that were priced to yield 8.55 per cent, or 10 basis points less than a similarly rated issue of Cleveland Elec tric Illuminating Company bonds marketed Monday.

title: Antitrust Agency Decides Not to Fight Drug Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)The Justice Department announced today it would not oppose the proposed merger of two of the nation's largest pharmaceutical concerns, the WarnerLambert Pharmaceuti cal Company and Parke, Davis & Co.

title: Ruling on $71Million Estate
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP) Mrs. A. G. Bush 91yearold widow of the multimillionaire industrialist who once con trolled the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has been declared incompetent by an Orange County judge and her $71million estate has been placed under guardianship. Judge Richard Keating named the Commercial Bank at Winter Park, which Mr. Bush founded in 1954, and an Orlando lawyer, David R. Roberts, as guardians of her estate.

title: O.E.O. Chief Rejects Legal Aid Changes
description: WASHINGTON, NOV. 12A proposed reorganization of the controversial Federal program of legal services for the poor, which leading lawyers feared would weaken the program, has been killed.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Amman's Garbage Waits for Trucks
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 12 Old figs, goat bones, Ara bian coffee grounds, wadded newspapers aflame with red headlines: all the tent trash and villa sweepings of this desert capital have become a problem for its tidy ruler, King Hussein.

title: Leader of Black Panthers Seized by F.B.I. in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 12 (UPI) Sherry Lynn Brown, described as a Black Panther party leader, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today during a raid on a Pan ther committee headquarters.

title: Dinner and Concert to Aid Children's Scholarships
description: The 32d annual dinner and concert arranged by LADO in behalf of its scholarship fund will take place Nov. 22 in the Plaza's Grand Ball room. Boris Goldovsky, lec turer on opera and an impre sario, will be guest of honor. Gail Robinson, Metropolitan Opera coloratura soprano, will sing.

title: Strengthened P.S.C. Opens Hearing
description: MONTGOMERY, N. Y., Nov. 12The state's Public Service Commission opened its first public hearing today under the new authority it has to allow power lines to run through any part of the state despite local opposition or even local laws.

title: MERIT POSTMASTERS WILL BE NAMED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount will soon appoint the first merit, nonpolitical post masters in the nation's history, Post Office officials said to day.

title: STOCKS RETREAT IN SELLING WAVE
Australia Leads Cup Golf by 3 Shots
INQUIRY ON RISES IN OIL PRICE SET BY GOVERNMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12  The Government announced to day a major investigation into the increase in crude oil prices posted yesterday by the Gull Oil Corporation and followed today by the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: Overton, Harlem Leader, Main Figure in Strife at Cooperative Market
description: Among the poor and the powerful in Harlem, L. Joseph Overton has long been a force to be reckoned with.

title: French Food in Cozy Setting
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Seale Jury Plea Spurned, Trial Will Begin Tuesday
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey today denied a de fense challenge to the jury selection system and ordered the murderkidnapping trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins, the Black Panther leaders, to begin Tuesday.

title: Merck in Layoffs
description: Merck & Co. said yesterday that it had laid off 200 em ployes last week as an economy measure. Most of the layoffs occurred at facilities in Rah way, N. J., and West Point, Pa

title: BIG BOARD VOTES TO SUSPEND SCHICK
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yes terday voted to suspend trading in the common stock and 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Schick Electric, Inc. because its net tangible assets and average earnings no longer meet the exchange's re quirements.

title: The Soviet Naval Program
description: The Soviets are embarked on a program which reveals a singular awareness of the importance of sea power, and an unmistakable resolve to become the most powerful maritime force in the world. They demonstrate a thorough understanding of the basic elements of seapower: knowledge of the seas, a strong modern merchant marine, and a powerful new navy.

title: Settlement at G.M.
description: The terms of the national strike settlement at General Motors make more imperative than ever action by the Nixon Administration to check the wageprice spiral.

title: Nixon Meets Podgorny For Brief Chat in Paris
description: PARIS, Nov. 12  President Nixon chatted briefly and in formally late this afternoon with Nikolai V. Podgorny, the Soviet President.

title: Theater
Notre Dame and Square Jammed With Mourners
description: PARIS, Nov. 12The people of France and leaders from more than 80 nations took part today in a daylong farewell to Charles de Gaulle.

title: Building Tour For Auxiliary
description: The annual tour and recep tion sponsored by the Wom en's Architectural Auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects will take place Wednesday at the new City University of New York Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. The benefit event, to aid the auxiliary's scholarship program, will be held from 4 to 8 P.M. in the 18story building.

title: CREDIT EXPANDS AT A MILD PACE
Joya G. Pays $138.40 and Brightens Aqueduct Gloom With $1,869.20 Exacta
description: Clear Spring Stables' unsung Joya G., a 2yearold colt who had spent much of his short career chasing victory at Rockingham Park with unim pressive results, suddenly was thrust into the spotlight yester day at Aaueduct.

title: ATTENDANCE CUT BY I.S. 142 BOYCOTT
OHIO PROPANE BLAST KILLS 4, INJURES 2
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 12 (UPI) A propane gas plant ex ploded today killing four per sons, including a woman and her two children who burned to death when flames enveloped their car.

title: A Soviet Hijacking Trial Involving Jews Is Foreseen
description: LONDON, Nov. 12A Jew ish organization here said to day that it expected a Soviet trial of accused hijackers, in cluding at least 20 Jews, to open in Leningrad about Nov, 20.

title: Poles and West Germans Put Final Touches on Treaty Text
description: WARSAW, Nov. 12West Germany and Poland began to day to put the final touches to their treaty on normal rela tions, with Bonn agreeing to Warsaw's demand that the controversial ethnic German issue be excluded.

title: It's for Men Only: A Mink by Cardin
description: And now the man to whom a Cardin label in his clothes is as important as the key to his Jaguar can sport the French couturier's imprint in his mink coat. Pierre Cardin, who fathered the peacock revolution in the 1960's with his nippedin men's fashions, has done his first complete collection of masculine furs.

title: Emphasis Shift on China
description: The United States has finally shifted the emphasis where it belongs on the question of China's representa tion in the United Nations. It is stressing the importance of retaining a U.N. membership for Taiwan rather than the bankrupt case for barring the door of the world organization to a Peking Government that controls a quarter of the world's population.

title: MRS. JOSEPH JACKSON
description: NEW PROVIDENCE, N. J., Nov. 12Mrs. Evelyn Cosby Jackson, the wife of Joseph Jackson and a former teacher of biochemistry at Middlebury College and at the College of New Rochelle, died Monday in Summit Hospital. She was 50 years old and Jived at 233 Mountain Avenue.

title: Jewish Federation Seeks To Bar Disruptive Acts
description: The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies obtained a show cause order in Manhattan Su preme Court today barring the Jewish Defense League from committing any disruptive acts at federation headquarters, 130 East 59th Street.

title: GROZA APPOINTED COLONELS' COACH
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP)Gene Rhodes, who had his team in second Place in the American Basketball Associa tion's Eastern Division, was dismissed today by the Ken tucky Colonels.

title: Princeton Ballet Fete
description: The committee of the Princeton (N. J.) Ballet So ciety will hold its fourth an nual dinner dance at 8:30 tomorrow at the Nassau Inn, Princeton. Tickets at $60 a couple may be obtained at the society, 262 Alexander Street, Princeton. Proceeds will benefit the scholarship fund of the Princeton Re gional Ballet.

title: Dust Commander Is Second To Admiral's Shield, $22.80
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12 (AP)Admiral's Shield ended a fiverace losing streak today at Churchill Downs by sweep ing past the Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, near the finish line to win the $5,000 Bold Ruler Purse by a neck and return $22.80 straight.

title: FISCHER TRIUMPHS IN MAJORCA CHESS
A Warning Against Mao
description: In the Soviet Union under Josef Stalin, at least 700,000 members of the Soviet Communist party were mur dered or perished in labor camps, in addition to millions of peasants who were deliberately starved to death.

title: PRIME BANK RATE REDUCED TO 7%
description: Major banks across the na tion lowered their basic interest charge on business loans yes terday. The cut, amounting to onequarter of one percentage point, brought this prime lending rate down to 7 per cent, as compared to the record high of 8 per cent the banks were posting last winter.

title: Deadlock in Taxi Negotiations Called Critical
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, continued his efforts yesterday to break the dead lock in the taxi negotiations, but he described the situation as extremely critical.

title: Knicks Bow to Bullets, 110108, and Lose Russell With Broken Left Wrist
Kansas Official Voids The Election of Hippie
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 12 (UPI)The Kansas Attorney General nullified today the election of Philip C. Hill, a hippie, as justice of the peace.

title: New Demonstrations Planned
description: The Women's Strike Coali tion, a group of 30 feminist or ganizations, announced plans yesterday for a mass march here on Dec. 12 to demand free abortions and more free com munitycontrolled daycare cen ters.

title: Museum of Natural History Plans to Display Moon Rock
description: Tomorrow is the first anni versary of the launching of the Apollo 12 lunar mission, and to commemorate the event the American Museum of Natural History will display a sample of moon rock brought back by the astronauts of that mission.

title: Air Force Instructor Freed
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 12 (AP)A sevenman courtmar tial panel acquitted an Air Force instructor today charged with maltreatment of recruits at Lackland Military Training Cen ter. S. Sgt. Rolando Sada was found not guilty on all seven counts.

title: NEW TESTS BACK EINSTEIN THEORY
description: The most serious recent chal lenge to Einstein's socalled general theory of relativity appears to be in serious trouble, but its coinventor is not yet ready to give up.

title: Science, Sewers and Soap
description: Thanks to a new county law banning the sale of most laundry detergents now on the market, residents of Suf folk County will no longer have to blow a head of foam off their drinking water. For many inhabitants of that part of Long Island, dependent on well water, as the vast majority are, detergent ingredients that resist de composition have given the water so sour a taste and so noxious a smell that it is often undrinkable.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It's no secret that mail deliveries are neither as fast nor as efficient as they were in earlier years. But that wasn't the reason why Willi Daume bypassed the post office and traveled several thousand miles the other day with an envelope care fully tucked away in his briefcase. It was to be a special delivery of considerable significance.

title: AN ALUMNI MEDAL IS GIVEN CORDIER
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, presi dent of Columbia University from 1968 to 1970, was given Columbia's highest alumni award last night for holding the university together and creating a more harmonious campus with the skill of an experienced administrator and the deftness of a practical dip lomat

title: Whetzle, Lopez Card 68's To Lead by Shot on Coast
Sadat Declares Moscow Promised ore Support
description: CAIRO, Nov. 12  Presi dent Anwar elSadat reported tonight that the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, had prom ised to increase support of the United Arab Republic to offset pressures on the country after the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: COURT BACKS CITY ON POLLUTION LAW
description: ALBANY, Nov. 12Dismiss ing the arguments of over 400 landlords as ponderous and fallacious, the Court of Ap peals today upheld New York City's law governing the con trol of pollutants emitted from apartment house incinerators and fuel burners.

title: City May Purchase 450 School Buses Left Idle in Strike
description: The Board of Estimate is expected to act today on recommendation that the city purchase for about $1million 450 school buses involved in a strike that has stranded 29,000 Manhattan and Brooklyn stu dents, including 3,000 handi capped children.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Defuse Population Bomb

title: Three Premieres Will Be Presented By the City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet will present three premieres in its 13week season that opens Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Advertising: Creating Your Own Clients
description: Lois Holland Callaway, Inc., may have the ultimate solution to the agencyclient relationship problemcreate your own clients.

title: Article 3  No Title
Wood, Field and Stream
description: Woodcock hunters in New York State, Maine and Mas sachusetts who were con cerned about whether the birds they shot were danger ous to eat apparently have little to worry about.

title: Dynamite Suspect Indicted
description: LYONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 (AP) A man who was arrested by the state police after they said that they had found 144 sticks of dynamite in a truck he was driving was indicted today on a charge of unlicensed posses sion of explosives. The indict ment, returned by a Wayne County grand jury, named Douglas A. Bullock, 26 years old, of Rochester, who was ar rested on Oct. 20.

title: Revolving Showcase Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 A New York manufacturer has borrowed the idea of a revolving display case from Sweden and expects it to benefit American retail

title: Black Homecoming Queen
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 13 (UPI)Florida State University tonight crowned Doby Lee Flowers as its first black home coming queen. Miss Flowers is a 21yearold senior from Talla hassee.

title: Gov. Licht Threatened
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 13 (AP)The office of Gov. Frank Licht was evacuated about 10 A.M. today after a telephone caller said a bomb would ex plode at that hour. The State Police searched the office and found no bomb.

title: Other College Football Games on Today's Card
description: Home teams are listed first.

title: BIG A MILE WON BY HOBEAU RACER
description: Knight of the Road of the Hobeau Farm romped to a con vincing triumph in the main joust of a mile at Aqueduct yesterday. Guided by John Ruane, Knight of the Road beat Alley Fighter by 1 lengths, with Indulto next in the field of seven.

title: NEW PANEL CALLED FOR CALLEY TRIAL
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 13Attempts to complete a military jury, for the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. failed again today after extensive questioning of a panel of Army officers,

title: Parseghian Frugal With Superlatives
description: It has been a satisfying and stimulat ing autumn for Coach Ara Parseghian of Notre Dame. The Irish are unbeaten in seven games and are back on top in the national polls; a Parseghianendorsed Indi ana Democrat, John Brademas, won re election to Congress, and Parseghian, the jogger, has lowered his time for the morn ing mile from 9 minutes 38 seconds to 6:45.

title: C.F. & I. Steel Corporation To Close Palmer Wire Mill
description: The C. F. & I. Steel Corpora tion, a subsidiary of the Crane Company, said yesterday it would close its Palmer, Mass., wire mill by the end of this year, because it had adequate capacity for the products af fected at its Trenton, N. J., plant. The Palmer plant employs about 600 men.

title: N.B.A. to Meet Here
description: The National Basketball As sociation's board of governors will meet at the Biltmore Hotel next Wednesday.

title: NEW CAR SALES UP AT FORD AND A.M.C.
Taxi Pay Negotiations Continue; Fleet Owners Weigh a Fare Rise
description: Fleet taxicab owners attempt ed yesterday to decide how large a fare increase they would require to settle their contract dispute with the taxi drivers.

title: Peace Plan Offered World Tennis Unit
description: LONDON, Nov. 13Whether the top tennis pros will play at Forest Hills and Wimbledon next year may hinge on secret talks that were concluded this morning. The meetings of Brit ish Lawn Tennis Association officials and Mike Davies, exec utive director of World Cham pionship Tennis, which controls the contracts of 32 leading pro fessionals, were held to ward off warfare between W.C.T. and the International Lawn Tennis Federation.

title: Art: Recent Sculptures by Noguchi
description: Isamu Noguchi's recent sculptures at Cordier & Ek strom, 980 Madison at 76th Street, should strike anyone as beautiful, not only indi vidually but as a group beau tifully installed. The stones marble and granite  are beautiful in themselves, for one thing, but it is only the most obvious thing. Some of the forms are beautiful as in ventions, some are arresting in what seems their defiance of gravity.

title: MARKET DROOPS AS VOLUME FALLS
In Old Canada, the Problems of the New
description: TORONTO  In Toronto, a civic battle has been raging over the proposed Spadina Ex pressway, which would bring suburban commuters to Bloor Street, the equivalent of 59th Street in Manhattan.

title: Budge Will Leave S.E.C. When Congress Adjourns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 Hamer H. Budge has resigned as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, ef fective at the end of this year's session of Congress.

title: Carolina Patrolmen Cleared of Liability In Orangeburg Suit
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 13 An allwhite jury took 55 min utes today to clear nine South Carolina highway patrolmen of liability in a $300,000 civil suit stemming from the slaying of three black students more than two years ago.

title: Market Place
description: There is at least one man who would object to Big Board economist William C. Freund's argument that the New York Stock Exchange is not a monopoly.

title: A Correction
description: A typographical error in yes terday's New York Times made it appear that $3million in shares of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. are held as security for some loans to Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr.'s interests. The shares are of the du Pont family's Christiana Se curities Company.

title: CLAUDE HOPE, 77, RETIRED LAWYER
description: Claude Allison Hope, a pro minent New York lawyer, died Thursday at his home here, 40 East 66th Street, after a long illness. He was 77 Years old.

title: A Beautiful Ride to Nowhere in Australia
description: ABOARD THE GHAN TRAIN, to Alice Springs, Aus traliaAlthough scheduled air routes crisscross the vast Australian countryside like a gigantic spiderweb, the rail road remains the principal lifeline for many an isolated settlement in the empty hin terland known as the Great

title: Okamura, Miss Turisheva Win Again in Gymnastics
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press)  Teruichi Okamura of Japan captured his fifth and sixth gold medals dur ing the final day of the world invitation gymnastics tourna ment yesterday. The 22year old student became the top in dividual gold medal winner for the tournament when he scored in the parallel and horizontal bars.

title: TYDINGS CLEARED IN LATIN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  A State Department investigation has found no wrongdoing in the handling of a Nicaraguan hous ing guaranty project involving Senator Joseph D. Tydings.

title: Licking Speed Is First
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 13 (AP) Winner of the fea ture race at Freehold Raceway today was Licking Speed, who covered the mile in 2:12 45 over a wet track, and paid $5.80 for $2 to win. The driver was Herve Filion.

title: Dance: Young Soloists
description: BAYPORT, L. I.The Amer ican Ballet Theater Players, an offshoot of American Bal let Theater, have taken a very sensible attitude to the need of encouraging young choreographers. The group itself, comprised of young so loists of the Ballet Theater, was founded to play engage ments where ballet was need ed yet the complete Ballet Theater company could not possibly perform.

title: WILLIAMS SHOWS GUITAR MASTERY
description: As a technician on the classi cal guitar, John Williams must be peerless. The Australian was a virtuoso by the time he was 17 years old. Now, at 29, his playing has a technical prefec tion that seems superior even to that of his great teacher, Andres Segovia.

title: ARGENTINA NEXT AT HALFWAY MARK
Keeneland Horse Sale Nets $8.7Million for 925 Head
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13 (AP)The Keeneland fall auc tion of thoroughbred breeding stock was termed by officials today as the second most suc cessful sale in 27 years.

title: Mrs. Albert Roothbert, 71, Dies; A Photographer and Benefactor
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Nov. 13 Mrs. Albert Roothbert, who as Baroness Tony Von Horn was a leading fashion and ad vertising photographer in the 1920's and 1930's, died yester day at her home at Topstone Road. She was 71 years old and also lived at 120 East 48th Street in Manhattan.

title: LIMIT TO REASON RULES 31 CHOICE
African Experts Back Curb on Animal Skin Trade
description: SERENGETI NATIONAL PARK, Tanzania, Nov. 11A conference of African wildlife management officials has been urged to support further ef forts to curtail drastically the trade in the skins of leopards, cheetahs, zebras and ostriches.

title: ERNEST L. JONES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 13 Ernest L. Jones, a retired stock broker and former mem ber of the board of governors of the New York Stock Ex change, died Wednesday at Stamford, Conn., Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 595 West Putnam Avenue here.

title: Ky Will Arrive Tomorrow For a 2Week U.S. Visit
description: Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam is to arrive in New York tomorrow after noon for a twoandahalfweek visit to the United States, the spokesman for Saigon's observer mission at the United Nations said yeaterday.

title: U.S.I.A. CHIEF SEES A SOVIET FERMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  Frank J. Shakespeare Jr., Direc tor of the United States Infor mation Agency, said today that he saw increasing indications of ferment within the Soviet Union

title: Marriage Planned By Miss Anderson
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 13  Miss Denise Margaret Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Loy H. Anderson, plans to be married on Nov. 27 to Daniel Andrew Han ley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Fleming J. Hanley.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Episcopal Church to Pay For Repairs for Squatters
description: The Episcopal Diocese of New York agreed yesterday to pay for the repair of heating facilities in three buildings near the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine that have been occupied by squatters since July 25.

title: Canada, in Shift, to Vote in U.N. To Give China's Seat to Peking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13  Canada told the General Assembly today that she would cast her vote next week for a resolution calling for Communist China's admis sion to the United Nations and the expulsion of Nationalist China.

title: A Meeting Where Nobody Walked Out
description: UNION, N.J.Joseph Weinberg of Boonton, N. J., missed half the meeting but he knew it was a success. No one walked out. Mr. Weinberg, the dinner committee chairman of the Purchasing Management Association of New Jersey, usually spots deserters when he positions himself outside the door to count dinner receipts. But, he asked rhetorically, Who would walk out on a meet ing like this?

title: Sabres Win, 4 to 2, End Seals' Streak Of Victories at Four
NEW YORK GAINS CONTROL AT START
6 U.S. P.O.W.'s Dead, Hanoi Reports
description: North Vietnam has informed an American peace group that six United States servicemen it held prisoner have died. Hanoi also confirmed the iden tities of four additional Ameri can prisoners.

title: G.M. SAYS ACCORD COST $2.4BILLION
description: DETROIT, Nov. 13 (UPI) The General Motors Corpora tion said today that its new, tentative national contract with the United Automobile Workers would cost the company $2.4 billion in wages alone over three years.

title: Early Discharges For Christmas Set; Furloughs Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) Many American servicemen whose terms of service are just about up will be given a Christmas bonus in the form of a discharge up to two weeks earlier so they can shed their uniforms before the holidays, the Pentagon said today.

title: Scholars Carry On in Franklin Tradition
description: PHLLADELPHIA, Nov. 13 The question before the au gust body of scholars was: Did Jefferson misquote Frank linand from which manu script?

title: Dreams and Realities
description: Charles Reich is correct that America faces a spiritual crisis. But like the young people he idealizes, he attacks the wrong enemy. We are not victims of a mindless and irrational corpo rate state, at war with its inhabi tants. Rather we are victims of our selves and our substitution of the values of the performance chart for the values of our historical and spir itual traditions.

title: Emergency Rule Imposed in Guatemala
description: Guatemala, Nov. 13 (UPI) The Government imposed a 30day state of siegemodified martial lawthroughout Guate mala today to halt a new wave of terrorist violence.

title: Cost of SelfDefense
description: LONDON, Nov. 13One of the strong men of Mr. Heath's Cabinet is Lord Carrington, the Minister of Defense, whose very British exterior of amiable jocularity covers a tough intelligence. Early in the game, he is having his qualities of resilience suddenly and unexpectedly tested.

title: Airlines Study Dumping Of Jet Fuel Residue in Air
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) An airline industry spokes man says the nation's air car riers are investigating ways to prevent dumping 6,700 tons of jet fuel residue into the atmos phere each year.

title: Bessie Braddock, Outspoken Labor M.P., Dead
description: LONDON, Nov. 13  Bessie Braddock, one of the last of a dwindling band of Labor members of Parliament whose socialism was fashioned in the days of soup kitchens and hunger marches, died today in Livrerpool Hospital after a long illness. She was 71 years old.

title: Dr. Henry Slonimsky, 86, Dead; Educator Also Active in Religion
description: Dr. Henry Slonimsky, dean emeritus of the New York School of Hebrew Union Col legeJewish Institute of Re ligion, died Thursday at his home, 375 West End Avenue. His age was 86.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
Mergenthaler Decision: Last of Linotype Line
description: PLAINVIEW, N. J., Nov. 13 (UPI)The end of the manufacture in the United States of Ottmar Mergen thaler's linotype, will come about early next year. Its sole competitor, the Inter type, will continue to be made in Brooklyn.

title: G.E. Gets GasTurbine Order
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 13 (UPIThe General Electric Company has received an order for two 17,500horsepower Model 500 heavyduty gas tur bines from the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Ltd., of Melbourne, Australia. The gas turbines are to be used for marine propulsion.

title: FISCHER WINS AGAIN; TIED FOR FIRST PLACE
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 13Bobby Fisher of Los Angeles won his third straight game in the eighth in terzonal tournament here today when he defeated Dr. Miroslav Flip of Czechoslovakia. The victory moved Fischer into a firstplace tie with Tudev Uite men, champion of Mongolia, who has surprised the chess playing world. Uitemen drew with Svetozar Gligoric, a many time Yukoslav titleholder.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS REBUFFED IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13The General Assembly voted a rebuke to South Africa today over her policy of racial separation by refusing formal confirmation of her credentials as a member of the United Nations.

title: Marland Hearing Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee has sched uled on Thursday a hearing on the nomination of Sidney P. Marland as United States Edu cation Commissioner. Mr. Mar land, former Pittsburgh school superintendent, is opposed by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations because of his past views on teachers' unions.

title: Humble Oil Is Accused by U.S. Of Having Unsafe Wells in Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)  The Government charged the Humble Oil and Re fining Company today with un safe operation of oil wells off the Louisiana coast in the Gulf of Mexico, where a huge oil spill by another company last winter resulted in a $1million fine.

title: EARNINGS REPORTED BY NATIONWIDE CORP.
description: The Nationwide Corporation, parent company of the fifth largest auto insurer in the na tion, reported yesterday that net earnings from operations rose in the nine months ended Sept. 30 to $6,145,000, or 60 cents a share, from $5,725,000, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Bonn Aide Says Rightists Offered Him Bribe to Defect
description: BONN, Nov. 13A member of Parliament from West Ger many's small Free Democratic party charged today that right wing politicians had tried to bribe him to defect to them and thereby reduce the Gov ernment's parliamentary major ity from six to four.

title: Miss Baird and P. G. Merlin Are Wed Atop Glacier
description: Miss Margaret Baird and Pierre Guy Merlin were mar ried yesterday atop Fitzsim mons Glacier, a spot so inac cessible that the wedding party of 15 had to be flown in by helicopter from the base lodge at Alta Lake, British Columbia.

title: U.S. Drops Tracking Site
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) The United States will discon tinue the use of the $9million Guaymas tracking station in Mexico Nov. 30, the space agen cy said today, declaring: Changes in the Apollo mission profile have reduced tracking and data acquisition needs and removed the requirement for continued support from the Guaymas station.

title: Car Maker Cites Strikes
description: LONDON, Nov. 13The Brit ish subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation today reported a record loss of $26.1million for the fiscal year ended July 31.

title: VERDICT OF GUILTY REJECTED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn refused to accept a jury's ver dict of guilty, yesterday against two former Federal narcotics agents after a poll of the jury showed that two members were not convinced of the defendants' guilt.

title: Black Dissent and High Cost Snag Philadelphia Bicentennial Plans
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 A Philadelphia group is in Europe this week to drum up interest in the nation's bicen tennial exposition year in 1976. But back home the plans already have run into major snags.

title: State Prison Chief to Quit
description: ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP)State Correction Commissioner Paul D. McGinnis said today he would retire before Jan. 1. I'm 66 years old and I've worked for state for 46 years, Mr. Mc Ginnis said. He added that he also had health problems.

title: Oil Front: Contracts and Prices
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 13 (UPI)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the Shell Oil Company and the Mo bil Oil Corporation were de clared winners today of the first new oil fields opened in Venezuela in more than a dec ade.

title: Orthodox Jews to Open Drive For $35Million for Schools
description: Orthodox Judaism tomorrow will start a campaign with a goal of $35million over the next 10 years to establish 200 new Hebrew day schools in the United States and Canada.

title: Hartke Leading by 4,482; Roudebush Hints at Recount
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 13 The Indiana Secretary of State announced unofficial election returns today that showed the Democratic incumbent, Senator Vance Hartke, beating his Re publican challenger, Represent ative Richard L. Roudebush, by 4,482 votes out of 1,737,696 cast.

title: McKeon Is Leader On NewIssue List
description: A California company that produces housing units made a spectacular stock market debut this week, but other newissue activity was again lackluster.

title: ItalianAmerican League Pickets A.B.C. Over Film
description: More than 100 members of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League picketed the of fices of WABCTV last night to protest the showing by the sta tion of a film and programs that allegedly link persons with Italian surnames to organized crime or make referenes to the term Mafia.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Nov. 13, 1970 THE PRESIDENT

title: 2 Yosemite Climbers on the Vertical Face of El Capitan Refuse Rescue
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 13Two mountain climbers who have spent 22 days on the nearly vertical face of 3,400foot El Capitan waved off rescuers today and said they could still make it to the top. The National Park Service tem porarily postponed a compli cated rescue operation after Warren Harding, 46 years old, shouted from his perch more than 2,000 feet above the Yosemite Valley floor that he and Dean Caldwell, 27, would go on. They had 1,000 feet to go to reach the top, and Mr. Harding esti mated they could make it in five days if the weather held. The Park Service said the climbers had requested that they be rescued on Wednes day and then refused help today. Members of the climb ers ground party said help had not been requested. All but four members of an 18 man team of expert climbers flown by helicopter to the top of the mountain yesterday were ordered withdrawn. But rangers said the operation was so dangerous that if the climbers get in trouble later and request help it may not be justified to risk the lives of 20 men for two. Mr. Harding, who led the first ascent of El Capitan 12 years ago, and Mr. Caldwell were in the fourth week of their climb up a sheer cliff called The Wall of the Early Morning Light. Although El Capitan has been climbed many times since Mr. Harding and two others first climbed it in 1958, the Morning Light route has never been successfully negotiated.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1970

title: Most Quebeckers, Though Proud of Differences, Want to Be Canadians Too
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 13  An angry exchange developed at a recent meeting to discuss whether instruction in an Ot tawa high school should be in French or English.

title: ALARIUS ENSEMBLE OFFERS EARLY MUSIC
description: The Alarius Ensemble of Brussels explored relatively un charted territory Thursday night in Carnegie Recital Hall: 17th century trio sonatas, can zonas and suites for violins, violas da gamba and harpsi chord in various combinations. Like other European ensembles specializing in music of this era and earlier, the four members of the Alarius played on au thentic period instruments, and the mellow tone of their gam bas and harpsichord were a de light in themselves.

title: A.B.C. Revamps Network TV Lineup
description: The American Broadcasting Company television network, in a massive overhaul of its evening primetime schedule, will drop six of its weekly programs in January, all of them series that had premieres in September.

title: Official of Colorado College Gets Top Bridgeport Post
TV:Nader Report Bows
description: Ralph Nader, the lawyer in terested in consumer causes and citizenship rights, opened his own television program last night on the Public Broad casting Service (Channel 13) with a study of Charles A. Cannon, chairman of Cannon Mills, whose textile concern controls the town of Kanna polis. N. C.

title: 3 ARRESTED IN RAID ON FLAG ART SHOW
description: Three artists were arrested last night and charged with desecrating the flag after a raid the People's Flag Show at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South.

title: Businessmen Find Diplomats Good Company at U.N. Ball
description: During the day they may have fought about whether Communist China should be admitted to the United Na tions, but last night repre sentatives of more than 90 countries amiably sipped cocktails, dined on filet de boeuf and danced in the Grand Ballroom of the Wal dorfAstoria.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Herbert Walter Ranson, 87, Actor in Character Roles
description: Herbert Walter Ranson, a character actor, died on Thurs day at his home, 15411 12th Road, Beechhurst, Queens, after a short illness. He was 87 years old.

title: REV. EDGAR S. JACKSON
description: CHELSEA, Vt., Nov. 13The Rev. Edgar S. Jackson, who had held many Methodist pastorates in the New York metropolitan area, died in a nursing home here today. He was 93 years old.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: BLOOD FAT LEVEL TIED TO HEREDITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 A special study group of the American Heart Association re ported here today that as many as one child in every 100 may be born with an inherited blood fat condition that predisposes him to premature death from heart disease.

title: Hermit Treats Guests To His Lavish Cooking
Chicago 7 Judge Ordered To Review Link to Jury
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 13  The United States Court of Appeals ordered Judge Julius J. Hoff man today to hold a hearing as soon as possible to determine the nature of any communica tions between the judge or Fed eral marshals and the jury in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

title: RCA Notifies Its Customers To Stop Use of a TV Model
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 13 (AP) A spokesman for R.C.A, said today the company had notified customers to suspend the use of a black and white television model being tested for a pos sible defect.

title: Parents as Partners
description: The announcement of a new policy by the United States Office of Education to give a greater voice to parents in the administration of Federal school aid funds has predictably evoked dire predictions of conflicts between the lay citizenry and the local and state educa tion establishment.

title: Baxter Ahead by 3 Strokes With 139 in Golf on Coast
Start of an Incomes Policy?
description: The Nixon Administration has initiated a major inves tigation into the 25centsperbarrel increase in the price of crude oil and the 0.7centpergallon increase in the price of gasoline, posted earlier this week by Gulf Oil and followed by Atlantic Richfield. The Government will consider abandoning, at least temporarily, oil import quotas and freeing Federal offshore leases from state controls, in order to boost oil supplies and beat back the price hike.

title: Kent Coach to Resign Over Campus Fatalism
description: KENT, Ohio, Nov. 13 (UPI) The Kent State University football coach, Dave Pudding ton, has announced that he will quit at the end of the current quarter because of negativism on campus since the killing of four stu dents during disorders May 4.

title: Hormone Action Found Complex
description: Recent animal studies indi cate that the manner in which the male hormone, testoster one, operates within the body is far more complex than was previously believed.

title: Cruise, Top Trainer and Driver, Lends Helping Hand as Doctor
Katims Conducts The Philharmonic For the First Time
description: Milton Katims, who was Tos canini's first violist with the N.B.C. Sympnony and since 1954 has been musical director of the Seattle Symphony, made his New York Philharmonic conducting debut on Thursday night with a creditable per formance of Beethoven's Eighth Symphony. But, with gentle manly grace, he yielded the bulk of the evening to Gina Bachauer, who appeared as soloist in piano concertos by Beethoven and Prokofiev.

title: At Issue: Peaceful Change or Civil War
description: The Sixties were a decade of frus trated protest proving the inadequacy of the present constitutional system and pointing up the need for a new foundation to guarantee life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

title: A Jet Carrying 82, Headed for Dallas, Is Hijacked to Cuba
description: MIAMI, Nov. 13 (AP)  An Eastern Airlines DC9 jet bound from Virginia to Texas was hijacked today and forced to fly to Cuba with 82 persons aboard.

title: 450 Celebrate 15th Year of National Review
description: To celebrate 15 years of con servative chic, the National Re view convoked the faithful to a party that tried their devo tion from Thursday evening un til yesterday morning.

title: Thomas Barber, ExAide Of R. H. Macy, Is Dead
description: Thomas V. Barber, a former senior vice president of R. H. Macy & Co., died Thursday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 501 East 79th Street here.

title: CLASH BREAKS LULL IN REGGIO CALABRIA
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP)  Some 3,000 young demonstrators fought the police today in a clash that shattered a monthold lull in rioting in this southern city.

title: Budge and Wall Street
description: The resignation of Hamer H. Budge as chairman of the Secu rities and Exchange Commission caught Wall Street by surprise not because it was unantici pated, but rather because of its timing. Chairman Budge, widely known as Judge Budge because he served on the bench in Idaho, was understood to be tired of serving as an over seer of a troubled industry, but it was felt he would stay on until some of the more press ing problems had been solved. There was immediate specula tion yesterday that the public might interpret the resignation as additional evidence that Wall Street's current distress, stem ming from the long stock market decline and numerous operational problems, was deep er than anybody thought and that the S. E. C. chairman fore saw a heavy burden for his agency.

title: Federal Electric Contract
description: The Federal Electric Corpora tion has been awarded a $20.5 million contract from the Space and Missile Test Center for op eration and maintenance of the Air Force Western Test Range.

title: Gulf to Cooperate in Inquiry on Rises
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it would cooperate fully in any inves tigation the Government might make into the company's re cently announced 25centa barrel increase in the price of domestic crude oil.

title: MELBOURNE GROUP PLAYS HUGHES WORK
description: For the second of its two concerts on the Carnegie Hall International Festival of Visit ing Orchestras the Melbourne Symphony Thursday night again gave the first local per formance of a work by an Aus tralian. Robert Hughes.

title: New Image of Sound Program Opens Series at Hunter College
description: It was the New Image of Sound series that began at Hunter College Playhouse on Thursday night, but the instru ment around which the pro gram was built was an old timerthe Ondes Martenot, an electronic instrument invented in 1928. It was created by Maurice Martenot (ondes is the French word for waves), and it attracted the interest of quite a few musicians over a period of two decades or so.

title: U.S. LACKS NEW DATA ON RUSSIANS IN CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) The State Department said again today that despite the re turn of two Soviet naval ves sels to the Cuban port of Cien fuegos, it still had no informa tion to indicate that the Rus sians were trying to establish a naval base there.

title: Seasoned Negotiator
description: TOKYO, Nov. 13  The Japanese Ambassador to the United States, who is repre senting his country in the crucial textile negotiations in Washington, does not be lieve in telling his wife what time he will be coming home to dinner. In marriage, as in diplomacy, he says, one should beware of making rash promises that may cause dif ficulties later. In a dinner speech some months ago, he cited the case of Kaishu Katsu, a 19thcentury statesman who as a young naval captain casually told his wife he was inspecting a ship in the har bor, then set sail on a five monthlong voyage to the United States.

title: J. C. Penney Sues On Japan Imports
description: The J. C. Penney Company Inc., filed suit yesterday seek ing to enjoin recent Govern ment policies on Japanese tele vision imports.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS U.S. STILL OPPOSES PEKING U.N. SEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The White House said today that the United States, had not al tered its policy of opposition to the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. SAID TO DELAY ECOLOGY REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) The Nixon Administration ap pears to have decided that it can withhold environmental im pact studies from the public un til the decisions they influence have been made and announced.

title: Bridge:
AIRLINES RATIFY FARE INCREASES
description: GENEVA, Nov. 13The cost of air travel across the North Atlantic is to increase an aver age of 5 to 8 per cent beginning April 1 next year under a new fare package announced today by the International Air Trans port Association.

title: COCOA FUTURES SHOW PRICE DIP
description: With the nearby December contracts the weakest, cocoa futures prices declined as much as the trading limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday.

title: COVEN OF FRANCE IS AMONG VICTORS
description: PARIS, Nov. 13(Reuters)  Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., and Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., advanced to the semifinals today in the $33,600 Paris open indoor tennis tourna ment.

title: 2 HELD WITHOUT BAIL IN KILLING OF L.I. BOY
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 13 (AP)  James Sugden, 20 years old, and Patricia Berglund, 19, were held without bail today on murder charges in the thrill killing of a 13yearold boy.

title: Another Wordor TwoFrom Martha Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Martha Mitchell, the outspoken wife of Attorney General John N. Mitchell, said today that she wouldn't want to live in the White House because I get claustrophobia every time they close the gates.

title: NEW RANGER GOAL: PROTECTING CAGE
DRUG COMPANIES COMPLETE DEAL
description: The merger of Parke, Davis & Co., and the WarnerLam bert Pharmaceutical Company, two of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies, was completed yesterday.

title: Detective Goes on Trial in Sale Of Data Despite Plea of Illness
description: The Police Department's trial of a detective accused of sell ing confidential police informa tion to one of the nation's larg est private detective agencies was begun yesterday even though the detective is still re covering from a stomach opera tion in a Long Island hospital.

title: 22 JUMPERS LISTED IN $100,000 RACE
