For Tal's games show brilliant combinations, witty strokes and spectacular recoveries. Excitement ga lore, for example, with the mark of Tal is evident in the CaroKann Defense, Tal against A. Kolarov of Bul garia in the Kapfenberg 1970 international tourney.

title: CHARTER NEW YORK SEEKS UPSTATE BANK
description: The Charter New York Cor poration, the $6billion bank holding company led by the Irving Trust Company, said yes terday that it had agreed to acquire the Nanuet National Bank, based in Rockland Coun ty, N. Y., under a formula that provides for Charter to ex change shares worth at least $11.3million for stock of Nanuet National. The transac tion, which must he approved by stockholders and regulatory authorities, would add $55mil lion in assets to Charter's total.

title: Pros Set Back Condors; Floridians Top Squires
PANEL ACTS TO STEM DOCTOR TAX EVASION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The Senate Finance Committee approved today a proposal intended to make it harder for doctors to evade taxes on income earned for treating patients under Medi care and Medicaid.

title: Antipoverty Director Is Accused Of Curbing Legal Services Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Donald Rumsfeld, the director of the Office of Economic Op portunity, was accused today of cutting the authority of the director of the legal services program, thereby administra tively putting into effect a re gionalization plan he had re jected.

title: A Correction
description: LONDON, Nov. 18  Because of an error in transmission, John Francis Prideaux, newly appointed chairman of the Na tional Westminster Bank, was incorrectly described in The New York Times today as joint deputy chairman of the bank since 1955. He has held this post since 1969 and has been a member of the board of man agement since 1955. Mr. Prideaux will succeed David Robarts on Jan. 1.

title: Off Broadway Theater Strike Closes What the Butler Saw
description: The first casualty of the Off Broadway theater strike, which entered its third day yesterday is the Joe Orton play, What the Butler Saw, at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater.

title: Zoning Proposal Would Allow Higher Apartment Structures
description: The City Planning Commis sion proposed a new rule yes terday that would allow build ers of highrise apartments to exceed the maximum height permitted under current zoning restrictions by purchasing the unused air rights above nearby buildings.

title: Montclair State Takes Bid To Rockne Bowl on Nov. 28
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 18Montclair State Col lege accepted an invitation today to play in the second annual Knute Rockne Bowl at Convention Hall in Atlantic City on Saturday evening, Nov. 28.

title: MARKET DECLINES ON A BROAD FRONT
description: After two days of fractional gains, the stock market dropped sharply yesterday, with prices closing at the low water mark of the trading ses sion.

title: Fuel Oil Outlook Held Hopeful
description: Steps taken by the Govern ment and the oil industry will probably avert a major fuel crisis this winter. Mau rice H. Stans, Secretary of Commerce, told a meeting of the American Petroleum In stitute yesterday at the New York Hilton.

title: Frazier Knocks Out Foster With Left Hook at 49 Seconds of Second Round
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18As if he were a rhinoceros stomping on a cobra, Joe Frazier knocked out Bob Foster with a crushing left hook tonight in the second round and retained the world heavyweight championship.

title: Mr. Haack Speaks Out
description: Wall Street has been shaken in the past two years as it has not been since the Great Depression. Since the start of 1969, eighty member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have gone out of business (though not all because they were failing). The dangers to others are far from over.

title: Irene Gubrud Sings A Taxing Program As Debut Recital
description: There are not many singers, experienced or otherwise, who would risk their reputations on a program consisting of songs by Schoenberg, Webern, Ives, Hindemith, Debussy and Wolf, but that is what Irene Gubrud did at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, and she came out very much the winner.

title: L.I. LAB OPERATES NEW ATOM DEVICE
description: BROOKHAVEN, L.I., Nov. 18  Scientists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory success fully projected today the first beam through their new pro ton linear accelerator, the na tion's largest.

title: FISCHER IN JEOPARDY IN CHESS PLAYOFFS
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 18Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles adjourned his game today with Milan Matulo vic, a former Yugoslav cham pion, in the seventh round of the eighth interzonal tourna ment of Palma de Mallorca, a 24man knockout round robin to determine a challenger for the world chess championship.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dispute Over Pilots
description: DACCA, Nov. 18 (AP)A question of which country's pi lots should fly relief helicop ters has delayed delivery of urgently needed aircraft from the United States and Britain, Pakistani relief officials said today.

title: Bankruptcy Petition Is Filed By Sea Host, Inc., Chain
description: Sea Host, Inc., a New York chain of seafood restaurants filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Southern Dis trict Federal Court listing lia bilities of $1,698,836 and assets of $806,828

title: Cue From the President
description: The protectionist forces in the House of Representa tives got a scare yesterday when the importrestricting Mills bill came close to being smothered in test votes. The thinness of the protectionist majority provides basis for hope that this dangerous trade curb can still be stopped if President Nixon comes out strongly against it.

title: Gilbert Conducts Concert by Orchestral Association
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: C. B. Burnett has been ap pointed chairman and W. Rich ard Goodwin was named presi dent and chief executive officer and director at the JohnsMan ville Corporation. Also J. B. Jobe was made executive vice president and chief operating officer and Francis H. May Jr. was promoted to executive vice president of finance and ad ministrative officer at Johns Manville.

title: Washington: For the Record
Colonels Rally to Win
Blacks and Puerto Rican Win Strike at N.Y.U. School
description: Black and Puerto Rican stu dents at New York University's Graduate School of Social Work ended a twoday strike yester day after winning an agree ment for direct representation on all facultystudent commit tees.

title: A 32MAN CABINET IS FORMED IN EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Nov. 18  President Anwar elSadat issued a decree today establishing a new 32 man cabinet under Premier Mahmoud Fawzi as part of a program to improve adminis trative efficiency and raise liv ing standards in the United Arab Republic.

title: STEER FUTURES RAISED IN SIZE
description: Taking note of changing con ditions in the cattle industry, the Chicago Board of Trade an nounced yesterday major inno vations in its fouryearold choice steer futures contract.

title: 3 Judges Order Wisconsin Not to Punish Abortionists
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 18 (AP) A threejudge Federal panel ordered Wisconsin today not to prosecute any physician ac cused of violating the state's abortion law.

title: Mann Leaving U.S. Post for Bank
Rangers Down Kings, 53, Tie for Lead in East
Bank Purchases Lead
description: The bond market extended its recent gains yesterday paced by surging demand for United States Treasury issues.

title: Data From U.S. Lunar Station Show a Cold Moon Regularly Bombarded by Meteorites
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 After a year of studying data sent from an automated lunar station. American scientists to day described the moon as a cold, stiff body bombarded reg ularly with grapefruitsize me teorites and exhibiting some newfound and puzzling physical traits.

title: Bankruptcy Petitions Up
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18. (UPI) Bankruptcy petitions rose 5.1 per cent, to 194,399 in the United States in the fiscal year ended June 30, the Commerce Clearing House reported today. A record 208,329 petitions were filed in 1967. Almost 92 per cent this year, or 178,202, were nonbusiness bankruptcies and these rose by 8,701 over 1969.

title: CAR EXPLODES, 4 DIE IN BROOKLYN CRASH
description: Three adults and one child were killed early today when the car in which they were riding exploded after a collision in the BedfordStuyvesant sec tion of Broklyn early today.

title: Lords Aide Won't Amplify On Roldan Murder Charge
description: Pablo (Yoruba) Guzman, minister of information for the Young Lords, refused to an swer questions yesterday re garding his earlier charges that a Puerto Rican prisoner named Julio Roldan had been mur dered by guards at the Man hattan House of Detention for Men.

title: Bridge:
DeGaulle Ms. to Library
description: PARIS, Nov. 18 (AP) Charles de Gaulle gave manu scripts and proofs of the latest book of his memoirs to the French National Library before he died, it was reported today. He had previously given manu scripts of his earlier memoirs to the library.

title: Crowd Is Second Smallest At Heavyweight Title Bout
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18 (AP)  Tonight's crowd of 6,300 at Cobo Arena for the Frazier Foster fight was the second smallest turnout for a heavy weight championship in the modern era. The low was the 2,434 at the Cassius Clay Sonny Liston bout at Lewis ton, Me., on May 25, 1965.

title: Seizures of Drugs Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 18 (UPI) The Customs Bureau says its agents seized 37,212 pounds of illicit drugs, mostly marijuana and hashish, in July, August and September. The bureau said the amount was more than dou ble the 15,720 pounds of such druggs taken in the same period last year.

title: Man Indicted in Girl's Murder Is Freed as Another Is Seized
description: A 22yearold youth who had been indicted on a charge of strangling his fiance walked out of a courtroom yesterday a free man because another man had been arrested in con nection with the killing and rapes and robberies in and near public parks.

title: How the 'Skins Pulled One Out
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18One of our neighborhood's more manic football zealots works for President Nixon at the White House. His name is Chuck, and he is passionately involved with the Washington Redskins.

title: Polarized City: The Tombs
description: Injustices in New York's courtrooms and jails have been underscored this week for the Puerto Rican com munity and for other residents of this city whose frus trations because of language, color and plain poverty result in wild rebellion and wounded lives.

title: Gonzales Quits Tourney
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 18 (UPI)  Pancho Gonzales upset the organizers of the Stockholm open indoor tennis champion ship today by deciding not to play here next week.

title: How the Big 3 Settled on OderNeisse
description: The cession of German ter ritory to Poland up to the OderNeisse line at the end of World War II may have hinged in part on the out come of a British election during the Potsdam Confer ence of 1945.

title: Stage: Castro Complex
description: Betsy Kress has a compul sive crush on Fidel Castro. Hence the title of the play, The Castro Complex, that opened last night at the Stair way Theater.

title: White House Said to Regret Naming Some to Unrest Unit
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP)Harry S. Flemming, a special assistant to President Nixon, says the White House regretted certain appoint ments it made to the Presi dent's Commission on Campus Unrest.

title: Kits for Old Peruvian Textiles, Modern Frames
description: Shop Talk

title: Frazier Stops Foster
description: Joe Frazier retained the heavyweight boxing cham pionship last night by knock ing out Bob Foster, the light heavyweight champion, in the second round at Detroit. At Madison Square Garden, George Foreman also scored a secondround knockout of Boone Kirkman in a bout be tween heavyweight contend ers. Details on page 59.

title: Freeman Helps Stars Deal Chaparrals a 130115 Loss
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 19 (AP)  Donnie Freeman's 22 points led Utah to a 6948 half time lead tonight and the Stars rolled to a 130115 American Basketball Association victory over the Texas Chaparrals.

title: The Real Lee Harvey Oswald
description: On that Friday of November, 1963, we tried to believe that the course of democracy in America would go on as it always had. Our Founding Fathers had foreseen the possibility of violence and had secured the succession.

title: A Fantastic Chairman Plays Star Role at the Fan Ball
description: A clutch of elegants of one sort or another turned up at the Plaza Hotel last night for the Fan Ball, for 21 years a substantial fix ture of the New York social scene and an event that's making even more money this year despite the reces sion.

title: Medals System Under Study by U.S.; Many Awarded Though War Wanes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19  The awarding of medals to United States ser vicemen has come under review here and in Washington to de termine how much represents accomplishment and how much has been allowed to lapse into procedure and public relations.

title: Nixon to Meet With Head Of Federal Reserve Board
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 19President Nixon will meet to morrow with Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Re serve Board, as part of a series of appointments with high economic officials of the Gov ernment, the White House dis closed today.

title: Secret Satellite Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 19 (UPI)A secret satellite was launched into earth orbit today atop a ThorAgena combination rocket from this military aerospace center. The launching was conducted by an Air Force and industry team. No other details were released.

title: RICHEY DEFEATS TAYLOR IN 3 SETS
description: WEMBLEY. England, Nov. 19 (UPI)Cliff Richey of San An gelo, Tex., needed two hours and three sets today to defeat Roger Taylor, a British left hander. and gain the semifinals lof the $60,000 Embassy indoor tennis championships, but Pon cho Gonzales and Dennis Ral Iston were beaten.

title: DEATHS OF G.I.'S LAID TO DRUG IN VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP] A large influx of highly po tent, cheap heroin in Vietnam has increased the drugrelated death rate of soldiers there, an Army official told Congress today.

title: 7.4% Gain Reported
description: Despite the General Motors strike and unfavorable weather conditions, chain store sales last month rose 7.4 per cent from the level of sales in the corresponding month of 1969.

title: F. &
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corpo ration announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Arnold Bakers, Inc., Greenwich, Conn., for a maximum of $9.5million of Schaefer's preferred stock.

title: Books of The Times
description: Let us not patronize George Jackson's prison letters. They are irritating, disturb ing, anxietyprovoking, and one reads them as if at knifepoint. One would like to fix blame for themon society, the author, oneselfbut one can't. One wishes they would go away. They won't. They are introduced by a now all too familiar set piece by Jean Genet, in which he wonders about a judge's power to pronounce sen tence: What, then, is this intel lectual operation, which changes a simple act (a mur der, if there was one) into some thing quite dif ferent; into an other death, or a life sentence, or a period of time served?  as if two thousand years of legal his tory were but a muffin. They proceed with an autobio graphical epistle by Jackson to his editor, filled with loathing for the Amerikan system and what it does to lowerclass blacks, but vague on how this system landed Jackson himself in prison (vague at least in comparison with Eldridge Cleaver's his own criminal disposition).

title: NIXON AIDE BACKS REPORT ON SHIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The White House allowed to stand today  without serious or direct challengewidespread reports that some shifts in the Nixon Cabinet Were likely be fore the second half of the President's term begins next January.

title: PISTONS TOP SUNS, END LOSS STREAK
description: DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP)Steve Mix's driving layup on a pass from Bob Lanier with four seconds left enabled the Detroit Pistons to beat the Phoenix Suns, 112110, in a National Basketball Association game tonight. The victory snap ped a sixgame losing streak for Detroit.

title: JURORS ON STAND IN CHICAGO 7 CASE
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19The con spiracy case of the Chicago Seven was returned to open court today as Judge Julius J. Hoffman began a hearing to determine whether he or any of the Federal marshals at the trial had improper communica tions with the jurors while they were deliberating.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Tree of Anthropology Is Sprouting Many Buds
Television
description: 7:00 (2)News Report

title: F.H.A. Chief Backs Its Consumer Stand
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19The head of the Federal Housing Administration, defending his agency against charges of be ing a handmaiden of private industry, said today that the F.H.A. was in fact becoming more consumeroriented.

title: Winter Sports Exposition Opens 4Day Coliseum Run
description: The International Ski and Winter Sports Show opened its annual fourday stand at the New York Coliseum yesterday with ski exhibits representing 150 resorts from the Sierras to the Rockies and from Canada's Laurentians to the Alps.

title: Israeli Orthodox Opposing Car Race Set for Sabbath
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 19 The first international auto race in Israel is being fiercely opposed by Orthodox Jews because it is scheduled for the Sabbath. Pro test rallies and counterprotests have been scheduled at the site.

title: Wendy Watson, Michael Harrah To Be Married
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Nov. 19Mr. and Mrs. Aldren Auld Watson of Putney and Truro, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Wendy McLeod Watson, illustrator and free lance writer of children's books in New York, to Michael Donald Harrah, a member of the New York City Opera Company.

title: House Panel Votes $17.7Billion Bill To Fund Agencies
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 19(AP) Bowing to White House pres sure, the House Appropriations Committee approved today new $17.7billion omnibus mon ey bill, $300million below an earlier measure that President Nixon had vetoed.

title: Lawyer Gets 16 Months
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP)William R. Ming Jr. a lawyer. was sentenced today to 16 months in jail and fined $5,000 for failing to file income tax return for four years. Ming is former counsel for the Chicago Board of Election Commis sioners and for the Contract Buyers League, a group of Negro home buyers.

title: New Tests Aiming to Establish Virus Link With Breast Cancer
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 19 The National Cancer Institute has begun a new series of tests that its scientists hope will es tablish a strong link between viruses and human breast cancer  and might suggest a method of earlier diagnosis and more effective treatment.

title: 3 Stamps Mark U.N. Anniversary
description: Two stamps of the United Nations and a single United States stamp commemorat ing the twentyfifth anniver sary of the peace organiza tion will be issued here this morning.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL TO RESTRICT IMPORTS, 215165
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The House passed and sent to the Senate today a manysided trade bill that would impose re strictions on some imports.

title: Study Questions Handling of Police Misconduct
description: The Rand Institute of New York City said yesterday that the findings of a study on how the Police Department punished policemen raise doubts about how the department dealt with police misconduct.

title: Books of The Times
description: Europe is the nightmare from which Jan Myrdal is trying to awakethe Europe of his famous father, Gunnar Myrdal; the Europe of imperialistic impulses, of corpo rate statism, of racist vaporizing. The nightmare has caused him to go on many journeys to the East, and the journeys have resulted in several extraordinary books, including Report From a Chinese Village and Confessions of a Disloyal European. The latter was a particularly disturbing combination of fiction, report age and allegory, in which the figure of a doomed loved one was made to stand for Agia, and in which the social reformism of Mr. Myrdal's parents was reviled. As an intellectual autobiography, Confes sions was inevitably compared to various earlier texts by Andre Malraux. Indeed, the Malraux of The Temptation of the West, The Royal Way and Man's Fate is bound to exist in some sort of polarized relationship with the Myrdal of Confes sions and Angkor; two such similar sensibilities came to such a brutal parting of the ideological ways.

title: JURY HERE INDICTS 16 IN STOCK FRAUD
description: A Federal grand jury charged: yesterday that members of three organized crime syndi cates in New York and Florida had infiltrated the stock mar ket by taking over a Miami investment company through threats and beatings and then parlaying the value of its shares up to artificially high selling levels to make large Profits.

title: EASTERN HOCKEY LEAGUE
description: Clinton 2, Syracuse I.

title: MILD PACE SHOWN IN CREDIT GROWTH
Chile's Christian Democrats Begin to Oppose Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19  The Christian Democratic party, whose support assured the election of President Sal vador Allende Gossens by Chile's Congress last month, has begun opposing his new government.

title: CHAPMAN'S DRIVE FOR NO. 200 STALLS
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. I9John Chapman had eight driv ing assignments at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Before the action began, he hoped to win at least three, the number needed to give him 200 for the first time in any of his 23 years as a harness driver.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 19  An exciting exhibition match be tween the world champion Dallas Aces and a team of Houston experts served as a curtainraiser here for the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Cham pionships, which begin at the Rice Hotel tomorrow.

title: LATE GAINS SHOWN BY GRAIN FUTURES
description: Wheat, corn and soybean fu tures prices fell from 1 to cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but recovered late in the session.

title: PRICES ON AMEX OFF FOR 4TH DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive day in light and featureless trading.

title: T.W.A. Plans to Lay Off 1,500 to 2,000 Employes
description: Layoffs in the airlines continued yesterday with the announcement that Trans World Airlines, Inc., plans to dis miss between 1,500 and 2,000 employes between now and the end of the year. A spokes man said the layoffs were due to the present critical situation of the airline.

title: Judi L. Hochman, a City Aide, Is Bride of Allan M. Rudnick
description: Miss Judi L. Hochman, a program officer for the Com munity Development Agency of the Human Resources Ad ministration, was married here last evening to Allan M. Rudnick, an investment portfolio manager with the Oppenheimer A.I.M. Fund.

title: Cyprus Sentences 4 Men For Trying to Kill Makarios
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  Four Greek Cypri otes were each sentenced to 14 years in prison today for at tempting to murder President Makarios and his helicopter pilot last March.

title: 26 More Are Seized in Gambling Raids
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation yesterday arrested 26 more persons, including two Jersey City policemen, in New Jersey, in its crackdown on in terstate gambling operated by organized crime.

title: Kid Domino Wins Pace
description: FREEHOLD, N. 1, Nov. 19 (AP)Kid Domino won the Menlo Park Pace at Freehold Raceway by a length and a half today and returned $8.60 straight.

title: CARL KALLGREN, 76, EXDEAN AT COLGATE
description: WEST REDDING, Conn., Nov. 19Carl A. Kallgren, dean emeritus of Colgate University, died at his home here after long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: White House Guest List Omits Five Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)Newly elected Gov ernors and members of Con gress and their familiesbut not the five new Demo cratic senatorshave been invited to join President Nixon Sunday for a worship service in the White House East Room.

title: To Save 54 Trees, Paris Discards Parking Lot Plans
description: PARIS, Nov. 19Strollers, children, mothers and all the plain pedestrians of Paris have won an important vic tory against the forces of the automobile.

title: Farm Bill Is Sent to Nixon; Limits Subsidy Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Senate gave final Con gressional approval today to a farm program that would limit Federal subsidy payments to any one farm to $55,000 a year on each of three basic crops cotton, wheat and feed grains.

title: Trinidad Frees Prisoners; State of Emergency Expires
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov, 19 (UPI)  All political prisoners held by the Govern ment under state of emergency powers have been released, it was announced today. The prisoners include labor, student and black power leaders.

title: Woodall Makes Believers Out of Jets
description: The Giants and Jets are favorites in the weekend wars, the Jets by 9 points over the Boston Patriots here on Sunday and the Giants by 6 over the Eagles in Phila delphia on Monday night. Games to be televised here Sunday are Baltimore at Miami, Channel 4 at 1 P.M., and St. Louis at Kansas City, Channel 2 at 4 P.M. Here is a preview of all the games, with won losttied records in parentheses.

title: MARLAND PRESSES SCHOOLS POST BID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Dr. Sidney P. Marland Jr., opened his bid for confirmation as the nation's education chief today by rebutting allegations of organized labor that he op poses collective bargaining for teachers.

title: DAVID BURSTEIN
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP)Da vid Burstein, senior partner of the Boston law firm of Hale and Dorr, died yesteday after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Brookline.

title: Ivan Modercin, 71, ExAide For Yugoslav Information
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 19 Ivan Modercin, the first New York representative of the In formation Ministry of the Tito Government to be recognized by the United States, later pro gram director of Radio Free Europe, died here today after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: STOCKS WOBBLE TO A MIXED CLOSE
description: The stock market continued to drift yesterday as prices ended mixed in relatively quiet trading.

title: PANED APPROVES GREENBELT ROUTE
description: Over opposition from con servationists, the TriState Transportation Commission ap proved a new route yesterday for the Richmond Parkway through the edge of the Staten Island Greenbelt.

title: Man Held in Shooting of a Soviet Sentry Escapes in West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Nov. 19  A West Berliner being held in the shoot ing of a Soviet sentry earlier this month escaped from a police guard here today and fled through a subway tunnel.

title: SYRIAN CHIEFS ACT TO GAIN SUPPORT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19 The new rulers of Syria moved today to garner popular sup port by staging a demonstra tion in Damascus and by an nouncing that a people's as sembly would be convened to elect a new head of state.

title: Cambodia: One Inside Story
description: On August 10, 1969, Prince Siha nouk asked the very reticent General Lon Nol to form a government. This decision by the Cambodian chief of state was surprising. Indeed, for many years, Sihanouk had done his utmost to make Lon Nol a scarecrow for his opposition on the left.

title: FISCHER STILL LEADS IN CHESS IN SPAIN
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 19Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eighttime United States champion, es caped with a draw against Re nato Naranja of the Phillipines; in the eighth round of the eighth interzonal elimination and qualification round robin here today.

title: Policemen Overlook 3 Quebec Suspects Hiding Behind Wall
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (Cana dian Press)When the police arrested Bernard Lortie a stu dent sought for conspiracy in the kidnapping of Labor Minis ter Pierre Laporte, at a Mon treal apartment two weeks ago, three other key suspects were reportedly hiding behind a false wall in the same apartment. They later escaped.

title: How to Stop the Trade Bill
description: After two days of debate between protectionists and liberal traders, the House of Representatives has passed the traderestriction bill. The margin of victory was much narrower than seemed possible even two weeks ago. What it demonstrates is that, at minimum, there would be enough opposition to this bill in the Houseand almost certainly in the Senate where it now goes  to sustain a Presidential veto.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. Met with National Security Council. Met with Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy, and later with Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans. Met this afternoon with the President's Coun cil of Executive Reorgani zation and later hosted a dinner for the same group.

title: A Listing of the New Books That Have Been Recently Published
description: Alchemy and Academe: A Collec tion of Original Stories Concern. ing Themselves with Transmu tations, Mental and Elemental, Alchemical and Academic, by Anne McCaffrey (Doubleday, $4.95).

title: Sales Show a Rise
News Summary and Index
description: The United Nations ended its annual de bate on the admission of Communist China yesterday soon after the Soviet Union re quested the floor for a special plea that the Peking Government be seated. Soviet support for the move had previously been lukewarm. The vote on the admission scheduled for today, following the expected adoption of a requirement that a twothirds majority is needed. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: The Politics of Money
description: If you've had experience running against one million aire, you should try running against two millionaires corning at you from both directions.

title: Canadiens Turn Back Maple Leafs, 51, and Regain Lead in East Division
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 19 (UPI)Serge Savard scored two un assisted goals in the first period and Peter Mahovlich added two more to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 51 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. The triumph put the Canadiens back into first place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Parrish Charges N.F.L. Put Him On a Blacklist
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 (UPI)  Bernie Parrish, a former defensive back for the Cleve land Browns, said today he be lieved indictments involving blackballing of players would result from a current Federal grand jury investiga tion of the National Football League.

title: State Looks to Congress
description: ALBANY. Nov. 19Gover nor Rockefeller, in a grim as sessment of the state's fiscal condition, said today that the members of the Democratic controlled New York Congres sional delegation were the only ones who have the capac ity to take the kind of action on a scale that will save New York City and New York State from destruction.

title: Sadat Is Firm on Issue of Occupied Land
description: CAIRO, Nov. 19President Anwar elSadat, setting forth the policy of the new Egyptian Government, declared tonight that on the issue of Arab terri tory occupied by Israel he would never compromise for the sake of a peaceful settlement.

title: Harvard Aiming to Provide Yovicsin With a Last Hurrah

title: RATE RISES URGED IN SAVING POWER

title: SOVIET MOON CRAFT SCOUTS SEA OF RAINS
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP) Lunokhod 1, Russia's moon rov er, completed its second pa trol of the lunar surface today after rolling nearly 300 feet across the Sea of Rains, taking pictures and conducting scien tific experiments.

title: Stage: Trio of Red Horse Animation
description: What is the concept of a museum? Let me be tougher. Now do museums join the human race? Art objects, even modern art objects, petrified by time and sancti fied by taste must provide almost all of the museum story. And rightly so. And yet more and more we can see the idea of a museum being a place where things happen rather than a place where things are preserved.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EUTAW SPRINGS. S. C.Arriving at South Carolina's famed Santee Cooper im poundment, where, since World War II, a remarkable fishery for landlocked striped bass developed, I was filled with confidence.

description: New charges were exchanged yesterday as the controversy continued over the removal of an East Harlem junior high school priricipal by the district superintendent.

title: The President's World Report
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19Behind the scenes in Washington these days, Dr. Henry Kissinger and others are preparing the Nixon Administration's second annual report on the State of the World. This is a useful and ambi tious project, introduced by President Nixon last year for the first time, and It could, if it is carefully prepared and presented, add order and perspec tive to the national debate.

title: Peking's Algerian Sponsor
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19Fifteen years ago, when Algeria was fighting for independence from France, a husky young Algerian with a nonchalant air appeared at the United Nations and quick ly became known here as the voice of rebel Algeria. To day, as the General Assem bly discussed the China questionon which a vote is expected to morrowthe same Algerian, who now is Algeria's dele gate, was scornfully described by the Chinese Nationalists as Peking's spokesman or more precisely the voice of Mao Tsetung in the United Nations.

title: BOOZER REPORTED SET FOR PATRIOTS

title: Young Says U.S. Leaders Ignore Blacks Plight
description: Whitney M. Young Jr., ex ecutive director of the National Urban League, accused the na tion's public and private lead ership last night of willfully ignoring black America's full fledged depression.

title: Delights of 13 Chinese Landscapes
description: For the next six weeks, the most peaceful spot in the Metropolitan Museum. with the possible exception of the storage vaults. is likely to be a small gallery on the second floor where 13 Chinese land scape paintings selected from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Morse are installed in an exhibition that opened yes terday. In contrast with the two big centennial exhibi tions nearby, Before Corts with its high drama and Masterpieces of Fifty Cen turies with its aggressive theatricality, this quite per fect little show has been un derplayed in a manner appro priate to the contemplative spirit of its subject.

title: A Professional Radical Reproaches the Far Left
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19Saul D. Alinsky, who has spent a lifetime preaching and prac ticing radicalism, today called the New Far Left a hor ribly sick cult, which, if un checked, would inevitably make a police state of America.

description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19Pre mier Golda Meir is engaged in a delicate political technique familiar from her dealings with Washington, the tactic of keep ing all the options open. Daily, it is becoming more difficult.

His answers follow.)

Parnell Thomas, a sev enterm United States Repre sentative from New Jersey who gained national notice as an antiCommunist crusader in the late 1940's and later went to prison for padding his Con gressional payroll, died here tonight after a long illness. His guns fire so ceaseless a fusillade that appears he never will run out of ammuni tion. It took the recognized heavyweight champion of the world less than four min utes to dismantle Bob Foster last night in the Cobo Arena and two left hooks de livered the destruction.

description: The attack by, the Elementary School Principals Asso ciation on Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner is particularly depressing because it follows a scenario that is at once predictable and obsolete. It is based on the assumption that to criticize the school system is to damage and subvert it. It holds that to call for reform is to encour age militancy, pressure politics and discord.

title: A PolicePanther Confrontation Ends Peacefully in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19The New Orleans Police Super intendent called off an armed fourhour confrontation with a Black Panther group today to prevent what he saw as an im pending blood bath. Neither side fired a shot.

description: BOSTON, Nov. 19The arti ficial synthesis of the active portion of the parathyroid hor mone, a body chemical that helps regulate bone formation, has been achieved by a team of scientists at the Massachu setts General Hospital.

description: Three individuals and nine business organizations were honored for their contribu tions to the arts yesterday at the New York Board of Trade's fifth annual Business and the Arts luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.

title: 'Scrooge' Varies Ritual In Version at Music Hall
description: It is Christmas Eve, the kind pictured most often on Hallmark's less imaginative greeting cards: an old English street, snow, carolers are singing, people bustle by with packages that look like props. Ebenezer Scrooge sits in his counting house, counting out his money. His clerk, good, loyal, optimistic Bob Cratchit, works in the next room, happy to have a candle to warm himself by.The clock strikes seven and Bob hesitantly asks for his wages. Scrooge is not surprised, but he is, nevertheless, appalled. He screws up his face so that it has more folds than a prune. He squints his eyes as if he'd just been tear-gassed. "The trouble with you, Crachit," he says, using a high, nasty falsetto, "is that all you think of is pleasure!"One of the pleasures of "Scrooge," this latest movie adaptation of Charles Dickens's "A Christmas Carol" (the first, I think, to be a musical), is the very outrage of Albert Finney's marvelously hokey performance as literature's most easily salvaged misanthrope.Mr. Finney walks more or less bent into an L-shape. He works his mouth as if trying to dislocate a troublesome raspberry seed, lodged between two front teeth. He snarls and giggles and, at one point, threatens to repossess the puppets of a street impresario who owes him money. When the time comes, he even dances enthusiastically at his own funeral, not knowing, of course, that it is his funeral, thinking, instead, that it is some belated civic demonstration in his honor.In Mr. Finney's performance, and in those of one or two others (especially Alec Guinness's as Marley's Ghost, done entirely in battleship gray), "Scrooge" has something of the free-wheeling quality of one of those London pantomimes. It is absurd, sentimental, pretty, never quite as funny as it intends to be, but quite acceptable, if only as a seasonal ritual.Except for the undistinguished Leslie Bricusse score, which persists in orchestrating the obvious (Scrooge's two big numbers are "I Hate People" and "I Love Life"), the movie that has been directed by Ronald Neame, from a screenplay by Mr. Bricusse, is a surprisingly faithful adaptation, including flashbacks to Scrooge's youth that seem to be more extensive (and more Freudian) than I remember similar sequences in other adaptations to have been. These sequences also give Mr. Finney the opportunity to walk upright from time to time.There is one sequence that might, conceivably, worry very small children, a rather livid and supposedly comic descent into Hell, during which Marley's Ghost helps fit Scrooge with his eternal chains. For the most part, however, the movie is a fairly literal translation of the Dickens morality tale, dramatizing the enduring old Protestant ethic that them that has canby spreading it aroundget into Heaven.Dame Edith Evans, looking very stately and old, plays the Ghost of Christmas Past, who escorts Scrooge back to his youth. Kenneth More, dressed in a costume that makes him look like a Christmas tree and photographed in such a way that he looks almost as big as the Rockefeller Center tree, is the Ghost of Christmas Present, who shows Scrooge all the fun he is missing by being a beast. And Paddy Stone is the deathlike Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, Scrooge's guide to what will be if he doesn't mend his ways.David Collings is a very pleasant Bob Cratchit and Richard Beaumont is Tiny Tim. I'm not all that fond of the original Tiny Tim or "A Christmas Carol" to begin with, so it's a measure of the general decency this film that I didn't have any urge to swat the kid.Mr. Neame has directed the movie with all of the delicacy possible after a small story has been turned into a comparatively large, conventional musical. The settings  London streets and interiors, circa 1860 (updated from the original 1843)are very attractive, somewhat spruced-up variations on the original John Leech illustrations.This adaptation, however, is very properly titled, for the movie belongs to Mr. Finney. Even Scrooge's fingernails are dirty, and while I don't think that Dickens intended to equate greed with unwashed hands, he probably would not have objected."Scrooge" opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall as the Christmas attraction, approximately five weeks early. The last "A Christmas Carol" to play the Hall, a version produced by Joseph L. Mankiewicz in 1938, was unveiled three days before Christmas. When the next version opensI estimate in 2001it may be on the Fourth of July.

title: SEALE TRIAL GETS FIRST TWO JURORS
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19After more than two clays of questioning prospective jurors, lawyers in the murder trial of Bobby G. Seale found two per sons today who were accept able to both sides.

description: LOS ANGELES. Nov. 19 (AP)The Los Angeles Dodg ers announced today that Richie Allen had signed his 1971 contract. The club does not disclose salary figures but a reliable source said it could be estimated at $100, 000.

title: BOB COOPER PROVES EFFECTIVE IN RECITAL

Accom panying himself on guitar and banjo, Mr. Cooper sang songs by Woody Guthrie, by Lead. belly, by Jimmie Rodgers, by Hatt and Scruggs and, occa sionally, songs of undetermined origin.

title: Achievement at the U.N.
description: The overwhelming endorsement by the General As sembly Political Committee of a draft treaty to bar weapons of mass destruction from the seabed is a posi tive achievement for the United Nations. The significance lies not so much in the treaty itself as in the manner in which it was negotiated.

Whether it's Old Mother Witch or D'Artagnan, there's something about the swashbuckle of a cape that ap peals to the drama in women.

Mr. Goldman joined the Music Hall staff as assistant manager when the house opened in 1932. His duties will be assumed by Charles R. Hacker, a vice presi dent of the corporation since 1964.
