description: Francis Moscrop, who retired five years ago as a financial vice president of James Talcott, Inc., commmercial financing and factoring, died Friday at his home in Leesburg, Fla. He was 70 years old and formerly lived in New York and Mend ham, N. J.

title: Last Day Of Show
In Affluent, Conservative Tulsa, Okla., Revivalist Religion Is a Big Business
description: TULSA, Okla If you pick up the phone and dial 7432197 in Tulsa these days, you will hear the following recorded message: Our heavenly fa ther, we thank you for your love and concern. And now I pray for my friend who has called me for prayer.

title: The Cradle, Now the Grave?; Long Island Aerospace Cutbacks Cause Rise In Jobless
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I.  The aerospace industry, which can trace its beginnings to Long Island, is in, a tailspin and dragging a lot of elec tronics companies in Nassau and Suffolk counties with it.

title: Missing Plane Is Found Upstate With Pilot's Body
description: WESTPORT, N. Y., Nov 21 (AP)A search team found a badly damaged plane and the body of its pilot today in this rugged Adirondack Mountain area. The plane had been re ported missing Thursday on flight from Burlington, Vt., to Chicago.

title: Chess
Okla. State Wins, 3627, As Cole Scores 3 Times
description: STILLWATER, Okla., Nov. 21 (UPI)Bobby Cole scored three touchdowns today to lead Okla homa State to a 3627 victory over Iowa State. He picked up 237 yards rushing in 49 car rips.

title: Nude Ballet Dancers Find the Rub's an Itch
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 (UPI) A nude ballet performance by the Netherlands Dance thea ter troupe ground to a scratching halt here Friday because someone had thrown itching powder on the stage.

title: YEARROUND USE OF SEAWAY SOUGHT
description: The Department of Transpor tation has undertaken an ex panded research program to make navigation through the Great LakesSt. Lawrence Sea way system a yearround ac tivity. At present the season on the waterways system begins on March 1 and ends in early to midDecember, a period of 250 days.

title: U.N. Urges Withdrawal
Excerpts Describe Excesses of Farm Collectivization
description: Collectivization was begun the year before I was trans ferred from the Ukraine, but it wasn't until after I started work in Moscow that I be gan to suspect its real ef fects on the rural population and it wasn't until many years later that I realized the scale of the starvation and repression which accom panied collectivization as it was carried out under Stalin.

title: Dr. William M. Siskind, 69, Dermatologist Since 1927
description: Dr. William M. Siskind, a dermatologist, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 760 Pelham Parkway South, the Bronx. His age was 69 and his office was at 1901 Grand Concourse the Bronx.

title: The Cast
Barenboims Play a PianoCello Recital
description: Jacqueline Du Pr, cellist, and her husband, Daniel Baren boim, pianist, offered a pro gram of music by Beethoven for their two instruments yes terday afternoon at Philhar monic Hall, and as sometimes happens with cello and piano, they were in different sound universes together.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
JOHN J. EMERICK
description: BOONTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 22John J. Emerick, coal traffic manager of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, died today at a hospital here. He was 60 years old.

title: Lightship to Get Higher, Drier Role
description: LONG BEACH, N. J., Nov. 22 (AP) A Coast Guard lightship that has guarded the South Jersey entrance to the Delaware River for 47 years will soon become a landbased science center for seven New Jersey colleges.

title: EINHORN REGAINS POST FOR 2 WEEKS
description: Dr. Arnold H. Einhorn, who, was replaced as chief of pedi atrics at Lincoln Hospital by a Puerto Rican doctor last week for allegedly political and ethnic reasons, will be rein stated on Dec. 1.

title: Peace on the OderNeisse
description: In completing the PolishWest German treaty. which affirms the OderNeisse line as Poland's western border, Bonn has taken another long step toward the Central European settlement. The importance of the new pact is almost as great as that of the SovietWest German treaty which preceded it.

title: Trampler Gives Walter, Recital In Mixed Media
description: Walter bombed at Tully gall on Saturday night. Yes, Walter, the muchtouted mixedmedia work commis sioned for Walter Trampler, the violist, by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Cen ter and given its first (and last?) performance by him in his recital on this occasion. It was created by Larry Austin, a composer of and spokesman for avantgarde music.

title: Wages in Building Trades Rise 7.1%
description: Workers in the New York City building trades scored larger average wage increases from last year to this than in any year of the nineteensixties, the regional Bureau of Labor statistics reported yesterday.

title: KIDNAPPED BRITON SAID TO SEND NOTE
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 22News papers here printed a note sup posedly written by James R. Cross, the kidnapped British trade commissioner, saying his health and treatment were good.

title: INVENTORY BUYING OF STEEL BEGINS
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22The first signs of inventory buying appeared in steel markets last week.

title: JACOB GRANOWITZ
description: Jacob Granowitz, who retired in 1953 as proprietor of the Knickerbocker Textile Com pany here, died Saturday in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: Johnny Mabon
description: SCHWEINFURT, West Ger manyS. Sgt. Johnny Mabon, a short hair and a lifer, smiled to himself when he watched a black soldier care fully comb out his Afro hair style.

title: Article 8  No Title
HENRY HOKE, AUTHOR AND TRADE EDITOR
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 22Henry Hoke, a leader in direct mail advertising for many years and an author, died today in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: WINGS 3 IN SECOND DOWN FLYERS BY 42
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) The Detroit Red Wings scored three goals in the sec ond period tonight, then with ;stood a charge by the Philadel phia Flyers for a 42 victory.

title: Faith by Adoption
description: A New Jersey judge has ruled that a couple who have cared for a child for sixteen of the seventeen months since she was born may not adopt her because they do not believe in God. Judge William J. Camarata, of the Essex County Superior Court, concedes that John Burke and his wife have been found to be persons of high ethical and moral standards and the adoption agency itself favors their application. But the judge contends that the child's eventual decision between belief and nonbelief must not be prejudiced by prospective parents without pretense to any religion at all.

title: Rising U. S. Trade Barriers Stir Canadians Ire
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 22  Risings protectionist sentiment in the United States Congress and the Nixon Administration, as it is detected here, has met a bristling response in Canada.

title: Taxi Negotiations Near Accord
description: The contract talks between 36,000 fleet taxi drivers and the owners of 72 garages came close to settlement early today. The details were not released, and fiscal details must be acted on by the City Council before an agreement can be reached.

title: KENNETH B. ARRINGTON
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 22 Kenneth B. Arrington, who retired last year as vice presi dent for advertising and mar keting of the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, died of a Mart attack here today. He was 62 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Numbers of Black Women Say They Will Not Date White Men
description: A clearly enunciated chal lenge to the desirability of interracial relationships, par ticularly dating and marriage, is being voiced more loudly today by a number of com mitted black women.

title: IRISH EXPECTING BATTLE FOR TITLE
Weather Reports and Forecast
It Tolls for Thee
description: LONDON, Nov. 22George Orwell could not have improved on Defense Secretary Laird's phrasing in the an nouncement of renewed American bombing in North Vietnam. There was not even any bombing in itjust protective reaction strikes. They had been made against missile and anti aircraft gun sites and related facili ties in response to attacks on our unarmed reconnaissance planes. It all sounded so clean and just.

title: Democratic Party in State Found Broke and Divided
description: Three weeks after their latest statewide election defeat, many leading Democrats agree that their party is in such desperate straits that for all practical purposes, there is no Demo cratic party in New York.

title: PAKISTANIS FEAR CHOLERA'S SPREAD
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 22 Fears of a Iarge outbreak of cholera and typhoid mounted in East Pakistan today despite steppedup foreign relief efforts in the race to keep alive the sick and hungry survivors of last week's cyclone and tidal wave.

title: Television
Issues in the Taxi Dispute
description: PARTIESLocal 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers' Union, representing 36,000 drivers and 1,200 inside workers; the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, repre senting owners of the bulk of the 6,816 fleetowned cabs; the City Council, which has the power to set fares, and Mayor Lindsay, who has recommended a fare rise.

title: BRUINS CONQUER PENGUINS, 4 TO 2
description: BOSTON, Nov. 22 (UPI)  I Ken Hodge scored a pair of secondperiod goals tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 42 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins. The triumph kept the Bruins tied with the New York Rangers for first place in the National Hockey League's East Division.

title: Murder Charge Against Author in Negro's Death Stirs Passions in a Tennessee Town
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., Nov. 22 This little town's official his tory records but two residents, past and present, as outstand ine personalities.

title: Pilot Lapses Called Cause Of River Crash Fatal to 17
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP)Lack of adequate com munication between pilots was the probable cause of a fatal collision between a freighter and barge on the Mississippi River on March 16, 1968, the National Transportation Safe ty Board has decided.

title: Moroccan Restaurant's Fare Is Superlative
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco It has been rumored for some time now that a rest aurant based on the Al Mounia of Casablanca would open in Manhattan. If it comes to pass, if the authen ticity is maintained and if there is no condescending to what some people seem to consider the restricted Amer ican palate, it will be a bit of rare good fortune.

title: Army Post Gives Addicts Help Instead of Censure
description: FORT BRAGG., N.C., Nov. 22 No barracks ever looked quite like Ward 29 here at the Army's sprawling airborne training center. A glance around the room suggests that the drug culture has gained a strategic foothold.

title: Pro Football: Blanda's Late Kick Wins Again: Landry of Lions Outduels Brodie
description: The motto of the Oakland Raiders is Pride and Poise. After this season, though, they might have to change it to Pride and Poise and George Blanda. Blanda is the Raiders premier place kicker and substitute quarter back, who, at 43, is nine years older than his coach, John Madden, and two years older than Al Davis, the man who pays his salary. Davis can be credited with bringing both the motto and Blanda to the Raiders, but while it is debat able what the motto has done for them, the Raiders know what Blanda has done.

title: U.S. Physician Is Silent On Khrushchev Lunch
description: Dr. A. McGehee Harvey, an American physician who is shown with the former Soviet Premier in a photo graph accompanying the first installment of Khrush chev Remembers, declined yesterday to talk about the incident. I'm not at liberty to tell you at this time, he said from his home in Balti more. I will be telling the story later, probably in a later issue of Life.

title: CITY OUTLAWING MISLEADING ADS
description: The city's Consumer affairs Department has adopted a new regulation making it illegal for vocational schools to promote their courses by promising that graduates can earn unrealisti cally high salaries.

title: Women Assail French Births Policy
description: VERSAILLES, France, Nov. 22  Defense Minister Michel Debit was hooted today when he told a convention of women that they had a duty to increase the birth rate.

title: Poor Scores Over Malley In Squash Racquets Final
description: Tom Poor of Boston won the Joe Lordi Memorial National squash racquets tournament yesterday by defeating Red Malley of Boston, 1512, 1510, 157, at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Miss Deborah Doran Rinehart Is Engaged to Michael F. Chmaj
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 22Miss Deborah Doran Rinehart, a greatgrand daughter of the late Mary Roberts Rinehart, writer of mystery stories, plans to be married next summer to Michael Frederick Chmaj. Both are students in Syra cuse, N. Y., where she is a sophomore at Syracuse Uni versity and he is a junior at the State University College of Forestry.

title: Symington Finds Flaws in NATO's Warhead Security
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI)A Senate subcommittee said today that there had been unspecified incidents involving the security of some of the 7,000 United States nuclear warheads stationed overseas in NATO countries.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 22 The national mixedpair cham pionship, opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals here, ended last night in a victory for two Southern players.

title: New Books
description: A Theme for Reason, by Elisabeth Ogilvie (McGrawHill, $6.95). The reaction of three people to one another and to their future plans.

title: Free Trade Move Held Best Solution For Atlantic Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22A leading authority on Atlantic relations forecast today further trouble in the economic sphere unless governments agree upon some kind of major new Initia tive, probably one leading to essentially free trade.

title: GUINEA WAS BORN A MAVERICK STATE
description: Guinea has been an ideol ogical battleground since she gained independence from France in 1958. The East and the West have competed for the allegiance of the West African nation, which is non aligned and socialist.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Indications mounted in Washington yes terday that a main reason for the weekend bombing of targets in North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia was to block offensives ex pected throughout Indochina in the coming months. Administration officials said that they would not rule out similar air strikes at areas in Laos and Cambodia containing concentrations of enemy soldiers and sup plies. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: To Control Campaign Costs
description: WASHINGTON One thing is agreed on by virtually all candidateswin ners or losersin the recent election: Campaign spending has gotten wildly out of hand. Historically speaking, that is the most notable fact about the whole election.

title: GOODELL INDICATES HE MAY QUIT PARTY
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell indicated yesterday that he might leave the Republican party if the Nixon Administra tion continues a, practice of reading out liberals from the G.O.P.

title: Dunn Chats With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) Gov.elect Winfield Dunn of Tennessee, the first Republican to capture the office in half a century, chatted today with President and Mrs. Nixon after White House worship services in the White House. With him were his wife, son and daugh ter.

description: Forty symphony orches tras in 26 states have been awarded grants totaling $1, 820,060, it was announced by Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Private sources provided $333,000 of the en dowment, with the remainder coming from Federal funds. Last August, grants totaling $1,680,000 were awarded to 34 orchestras.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Amsterdam: A Cultural Revolt at Bay
description: AMSTERDAM, the Neth erlandsArtistically and so cially there is a lot of commotion among many painters, actors, musicians and others on the Dutch art scene. Ten months ago the longlasting but until then latent unrest and discontent exploded into revolutionary action from the side of the paint ers and other plas tic artists. Hun dreds of them occupied the Am sterdam Stedelijk Museum, one of the bestknown tryst ing places of modern art in Western Europe, and had to be removed from there by the police. They also occu pied the Amsterdam Rijks museum (where Rembrandt's Night Watch is hanging). Indignation among the Estab lishment was widespread be cause of the infringement of these sacred halls. During this same period groups of young actors and students of the Amsterdam Academy of Dramatic Art threw tomatoes at the stages during the per formances of Shakespeare's The Tempest, and other plays in the Amsterdam Mu nicipal Theater, which was shaken to its foundations be cause of these unprecedented occurrences. The tomato pro test was directed against the traditional and antisocial repertories chosen by Gov ernmentsupported theatrical companies. The demonstra tors said the artistic policies of the companies should have much more social and politi cal relevance and the actors themselves also should have in these matters.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
Screen: Seeking Manhood in Africa:Japanese Home Builder Focus of Hani Film Spirit of Cooperation Caps Story Action
description: "Bwana Toshi," which opened Saturday on a double bill with Pudovkin's "The End of St. Petersburg," as part of the New Yorker Theater's excellent series of Russian and Japanese films, was made in 1965 by Susumu Hani, a director for whose work, the little I know of it, I have mixed feelings.On the one hand there seeme to be in Hani a heavy strain of quite conventional inclusive humanism (for example, "She and He," 1963), and on the other hand there is a possibly heavier strain of comparatively unconventional eroticism (for example, "Nanami, Torment of First Love," 1968).In its emotional density and its cool compansion, Hani's eroticism seems a good deal more humane than his humanism. It is also, of course, more erotic."Bwana Toshi," unfortunately, belongs to Hani's humanist side. And if its point of view suggests the decency and good wishes of, say, an adult United Nations Children's Fund greeting card, that suggestion is wholly intentional  and, I guess, not wholly dishonorable.Toshi (Kiyoshi Atsumi) is a technician who travels by ship and truck to deliver and construct a base camp, a prefabricated house, for a Japanese expedition engaged in "discovering the secrets of East Africa." When he arrives, he learns that the expedition, struck by sickness, has temporarily moved onand he is left to build his house as best he can. He sets about engaging help, and despite his rudimentary Swahili (the first man he tries to hire hires him instead and Toshi spends a day herding cattle), he succeeds in getting an assistant (Hamisi Salehe), whose relationship with him forms the modest central action of the film.That action, nobody will be surprised to learn, is the educationthrough humiliation  of Toshi. Whereas many years ago movie heroes went to Africa so that they might become men, Hani's very modern hero goes to Africa so that he can become a mensch. A lot has been lost in the process, and not just the Fuzzy-Wuzzies. For in achieving the spirit of international cooperation that finally gets Toshi's house built, the film flattens human understanding into something too optimistically simple. Although it is full of admiration for black Africa, "Bwana Toshi" does also rather dangerously condescend toward that countryif only in the eagerness with which it stacks all the cards against the Japanese outlander.For reasons that I don't understand, but that seem to have nothing to do with irony, Hani has put into the hands of all peaceloving Africans (the film's crises follows when Toshi shows himself "violent" by striking a man) an absolutely terrifying collection of sharp-pointed spears and bows with needle-thin arrows.There is a secondary theme in "Bwana Toshi" that is more interesting, and that has to do with what I guess should be called "vanishing Africa." Not merely vanishing wild Africa, though there is much of that, especially in an excursion to the mountain home of the few remaining great apes, but also the curious effect of having almost everyone Toshi first goes to for advice or help politely turn and walk awayso that Africa seems to keep vanishing before our very eyes. Eventually Toshi is accepted by his helperswho are indeed his hostsbut before that happens the movie seems funnier, wiser, and more encouragingas if there were a more privileged life hidden behind the mysterious shyness of all those figures in the landscape.

title: Aqueduct Entries
Books of The Times
description: That the Roman participation in the death of Jesus was politically motivated appears to be generally accepted by the scholars. Whatever the ideological bicker ing, Jewish doctrinal differences held little interest for the men in Rome. To the rulers of the empire, Judea was a contentious, turbulent and touchy province that needed watching and from time to time chastise ment. But whether Jesus healed on the Sabbath, consorted with harlots, spoke to those beyond the pale like the Samaritans, taught with authority or had his own views about the messiah interested the Romans about as much as ritual differences of a black tribe in darkest Africa interested the House of Lords in 1890.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Eight years after it was authorized, the Government has at last be gun to provide adjustment as sistance to individual compa nies harmed by import competi tion, and no one has any idea yet how it is going to work.

title: East Road Runners Title Won by Fleming in 40:18
description: Tom Fleming of Paterson State College won the ninth an nual Eastern Regional road run ners crosscountry champion ship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The 19yearold Fleming covered the ninemile course in 40 minutes 18 seconds.

title: Personal Finance
description: Playing with yearend in come can be a worthwhile game for many taxpayers. The idea is to figure out in which year it is best for the individual to receive extra income and then plan how to make sure it is taxable next year and not this year, or vice versa.

title: Guinea Reports Invasion From Sea by Portuguese
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 22 President Skou Tour of Guinea said today that Portu guese forces had invaded his West African nation.

title: W. GERMAN RIDERS WIN AT TORONTO
description: TORONTO, Nov. 22 (AP) West Germany took first and second last night in the final event at the Royal horse show and completed a sweep of the international jumping team championships in four shows on the North American fall circuit.

title: History and Khrushchev Text
description: What does Khrushchev Re members add to historical knowledge of the Stalin era?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Approaches to Railroad Problems

title: Various Reasons for Invasion
description: Special to The New York Times

title: F. JEROME M'NULTY
description: F. Jerome McNultry, an as sistant city corporation counsel during the administration of Mayor James J. Walker, died Saturday in Tulsa, Okla., of injuries suffered in a riding accident. He was 67 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: CONTEST CRUCIAL IN DIVISION RACE
description: The Giants try to stretch their winning streak to seven tonight as they take their po tent offense to Philadelphia to battle the Eagles crapshoot ing defense.

title: CHILEANS TO INSPECT U.S. ISLAND STATION
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 22 (AP)Chile's Government an nounced today it would send a special commission to inspect a United States Air Force scien tific installation on Easter Is land before allowing it to be dismantled.

title: Terrell Bout Set Dec, 15
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 22 (AP) Ernie Terrell will come out of retirement Dec. 15 to meet Tony Doyle of Salt Lake City here,

title: Bond Introducing a Monetary Symbol
description: PARIS, Nov. 22The first borrowing in a European mone tary unit is being arranged by the executive authority of the European Economic Community in cooperation with seven banks in the six member states.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Journal, The Crisis, Observes Its 60th Anniversary
description: Some people in Chicago, Philadelphia, Atlantic City, Co lumbus, Ohio, and other North ern cities are quietly trying to establish separate colored schools, the late W.E.B.I DuBois wrote in the first edi tion of the N.A.A.C.P.'s month ly magazine, The Crisis, in November, 1910.

title: Article 1  No Title
New Governors to Meet
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Nov. 22 (AP)  At least 15 of the nation's newly elected Governors are expected to be in Southern Pines next week end for an orientation session and a meeting of the Execu tive Committee of the National. Governors Conference. Mem bers of the executive committee will art as faculty members at the orientation sessions.

title: Bond Traders Feel Yields Are Heading Still Lower
description: Interest rates, which dropped spectacularly last week, appear to be headed still lower, Wall Street investment bankers and traders believe.

title: Dunk Victor by 5 Strokes
description: COFFS HARBOUR, Australia, Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Bill Dunk of Australia scored a five stroke victory today in the $6, 000 North Coast open golf championship. Dunk shot a par 72 for a 54hole total of 212 Randal Vines and Peter Har vey of Australia tied for sec ond at 217.

title: New Quarterly Publishes Excerpt From Roth Book
INDOCHINA RAIDS SAID TO BE AIMED AT FOE'S BUILDUP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22  There were increasing indica tions today that the big United States air strikes against North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia this weekend were ordered by President Nixon to deter the enemy from offensives through out Indochina in the coming months.

title: Nat'l Football League
Yankee, Please Stay a Little While
description: SEOUL, KoreaThe one country in the world where an American is least likely to be greeted with that bitter slogan Yankee Go Home is the Re public of Korea. This is not because the Korean people are fonder of Amer ican troops than the people of other countries where United States forces are stationed and where the American presence is pervasive and American influence ubiquitous. It is simply be cause the South Koreans, vividly re membering what happened twenty years ago, want the Americans on hand if they have to face another invasion.

title: CONSTANCE SMITH, AN EDUCATOR, 48
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 Dr. Constance E. Smith, dean of the Radcliffe Institute, a center for continuing educa tion, died today of cancer at her home. She was 48 years old.

title: Article 7  No Title
BUCKS OVERCOME BLAZERS FOR 14TH
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 22 (AP)  Lou Alcindor and Bob Dandridge sparked a 71point secondhalf surge that gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 126104 vic tory over the Portland Trail Blazers, their 14th straight in the National Basketball Asso ciation tonight.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX FINISH WITH GAINS
description: The American Stock Ex change managed to finish higher yesterday although late selling erased some of the earlier gains.

title: Coast Arms Cache Seized
description: COMPTON, Calif., Nov. 23 (UPI)The police raided what they described as a Black Pan ther fortress during the pre dawn hours today, arresting one man and confiscating 40 sticks of dynamite, military type rifles and ammunition, homemade bombs and smoke grenades. The police said they believed another man escaped through an underground tunnel leading from the house.

title: United Jewish Appeal Show Attracts 20,000 to Garden
description: The United Jewish Appeal's 37th annual Night of Stars benefit show attracted more than 20,000 people to Madison Square Garden last night and collected more than $350,000 for the appeals program of refugee aid and resettlement in Israel.

title: U.S. RESCUE FORCE LANDED WITHIN 23 MILES OF HANOI, BUT IT FOUND P.O.W.'S GONE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird disclosed today that a small task force of Army and Air Force men landed about 23 miles west of Hanoi over the weekend in an unsuccessful at tempt to free American prison ers thought to be held at a camp there.

title: Brandt in Rome for Talks
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Dubuffet Is Doing 40Foot Sculpture for Chase Plaza
description: It is called Group of Four Trees but it looks more like a weird crosspollination of mammoth AliceinWonder land mushrooms and a jig saw puzzle for giants.

title: Pennsy Is Seen in Need of $175Million
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)Trustees for the be leaguered Penn Central Railroad told Congress today that unless the line can borrow $175mil lion immediately it would go broke by next March.

title: Dukedoms for the Spittoon League
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23Because a minority of our remote forebears were revolutionaries in the eighteenth cen tury, we still deny ourselves the House of Lords so necessary to a workable American political system.

title: PRO SKIERS DRAW UP A 9RACE SCHEDULE
Market Summary
description: Monday, Nov. 23, 1970

title: Israel Charges Egyptian Planes Crossed Canal for Surveillance
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 23Is rael accused the United Arab Republic today of three air in cursions across the Suez Canal, in violation of the ceasefire agreement.

title: Voting for Popes Is Barred to Cardinals Over 80
description: ROME, Nov. 23Pope Paul VI ruled today that Cardinals who had reached the age of 80 years could not take part in the election of a new Pope.

title: Chiropractor Service Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) The Senate Finance Commit tee voted today to add chiro practor services to the Medicare program. The annual cost wae estimated at $75million.

title: Moscow and Peking Conclude OneYear Agreement on Trade
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23  The Soviet Union and Communist China today signed a trade and payments agreement in Peking.

title: Brooklyn Diocese Schools To Increase Tuition $100
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn announced yester day that tuition in its 10 high schools would be raised $100 to an annual total of $700, starting next September.

title: Rates for U.S. Treasury Bills Show Sharp Decline at Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Treasury bill rates declined dramatically at today's auction from last week's levels, re corded a threeyear low, the government reported late this afternoon.

title: Flushing G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP1)The Defense Depart ment today identified 13 serv icemen as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia, including Pfc. James M. Meehan of Flushing, Queens, of the Army.

title: Books of The Times
description: At one point in this bookWhich is a popular introduction, an intellectual biog raphy and an act of homageRobert Coles describes Erik Erikson as a man who first sees, and then responds with written thoughts. Erikson was an artist before he became a psychoanalyst. His seeing isn't done, through goggles of dogma, nor does it take place in an armchair in a library. It is a naked sort of see ing, a search for c o n figurations, whether the loca tion is a clinic for children, a subma rine, a Sioux or Yurok Indian res ervation, Missis sippi, Germany or Pakistan. It is also a seeing in his tory, anthropology and social rela tions. The man who gave us the concepts of iden tity and morato rium, who wrote Childhood and Society and Young Man Luther and Gandhi's Truth, considers public events and insti tutions more than just peripheral factors in a child's development. The artist knows that foreground and background in a configuration are tricks of perspective which the observer can always perform and the participant often can not.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A handbook for those who wish to join in the struggle to save our estuarine areas from development, dredging or pollution has been pub lished by the American Lit toral Society.

title: Amer. Hockey League
Shaw Judge Is Ordered Ousted Over His Arrest in a Vice Raid
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP)Judge Edward A. Hag gerty Jr., who presided at the Clay Shaw conspiracy trial, was ordered today to be re moved from office by the Louisiana Supreme Court in a 6to1 ruling stemming from the judge's arrest in a vice raid a year ago.

title: REUSS SAYS CONGRESS WON'T REVALUE GOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Representative Henry S. Reuss reiterated today that Congress would never assent to any in crease in the value of monetary gold.

title: Pilots Elect President
description: Special to The New York Times

title: British Soccer Standings
description: By The Associated Press

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
PENN STATE IS 2D TO IVY CHAMPION
description: Dartmouth College, unde feated and untied in its nine football games this season and winner of the Ivy League cham pionship, was named yesterday as winner of the 1970 Lambert Trophy for the outstanding Eastern major college perform ance during the season.

title: GUINEANS BATTLE INVADERS 2D DAY
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 23  Radio broadcasts from neighboring Guinea said that Government forces battled a band of fascist invaders today for the second day.

title: A HOSPITAL PANEL ASKS HEALTH PLAN
No Progress Is Reported After Big 4 Discuss Berlin
description: BERLIN, Nov. 23The Big Four ambassadors failed to make any progress here today in the eleventh round of talks aimed at improving the situa tion in and around Berlin.

title: Patrolman Denies Robberies
description: A patrolman was held in lieu of $10,000 bail, set yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, on charges that he stole heroin and money from two men in sepa rate incidents last Nov. 11. Rod ney Culpepper, 23 years old, who has been suspended from the police force, pleaded not guilty before Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi to two indictments ac cusing him of firstdegree rob bery. He lives at 29 Moore Street, Brooklyn.

title: QUIT DONNELLY CASE, MURPHY IS ASKED
description: The lawyer representing a police captain accused of not cooperating with a Manhattan grand jury investigating police corruption asked yesterday that Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy disqualify himself as the final judge of the depart mental charges pending against the captain.

title: Prices of 1971 G.M. Cars Raised by Average of $24
description: The General Motors Corpora tion announced yesterday its final prices for its 1971 model cars, tacking on an average of $24 to the tentative increase of $208 announced last Sept. 24.

title: Murtagh Rehears on Earphones Recordings at Panther Trial
description: Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh donned earphones yesterday in an effort to deter mine whether tapes of Black Panther conversations obtained surreptitiously by a police un dercover agent were suitable for a jury to hear.

title: P.B.A. Chief Charges Witchhunts
description: The president of the Patrol men's Benevolent Association charged yesterday that many of the investigations of police cor ruption here were designed to cover up the Lindsay adminis tration's failure to deal with crime on the street.

title: CHARGES SHELVED AT JACKSON STATE
Victory Through Air Power?
description: There is now good reason to believe that the wide spread weekend air assault on North Vietnam repre sented an effort to block a new Communist buildup South Vietnam through American air power and did not simply constitute a protective reaction, as billed.

title: S.E.C. Chairman
description: The resignation of Hamer H. Budge from the chair manship of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which will be effective when the current legislative ses sion ends, comes at a time of severe stress within the nation's securities industry.

title: Elizabeth Rosenberg Zetzel Dies; Harvard Psychiatry Professor
description: Dr. Elizabeth Rosenberg Zet zel, associate clinical professor of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School and a vice president of the International PsychoAnalytical Association, died Saturday while visiting her mother in Scarsdale, N. N.Y. She was 63 years old.

title: Police Use Tear Gas to Halt Fight at Rome University
description: ROME, Nov. 23  Policemen used tear gas to break up a fight between neoFascist and leftwing students on the Rome University campus today.

title: Recruits Join Housing Police
description: Simeon Golar, chairman of the City Housing Authority, an nounced yesterday that 52 recruits had been added to the housing police force, bringing its total strength to 1,556.

title: Classes for 300 Resumed In Disrupted Harlem School
description: A Harlem junior high school that was shut down last Wednesday after students went on a rampage was partially re opened yesterday without inci dent.

title: U.S. Wins in Baseball, 71
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, Nov. 23 (AP)Dick Troedson held Venezuela to one hit until the eighth inning as the United States scored an easy 71 vic tory in the amateur world baseball series today. It was the fourth victory for the United States, which leads in the standing.

title: Vasquez Gets Aqueduct Triple; Champion Is Sold for $107,000
description: Jacinto Vasquez entertained the 22,175 customers at Aque duct yesterday by guiding home three winners In seven attempts in the ninerace pro gram.

title: Joins Other Companies
description: The Humble Oil and Refin ing Company, the chief do mestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), an nounced yesterday that it had raised its wholesale gasoline prices by seventenths of a cent a gallon.

title: SENATE SUSTAINS VETO OF FUND CURB ON TV CAMPAIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The bill to limit spending for television and radio time in po litical campaigns died today when the Senate failed to mus ter enough votes to override President Nixon's veto.

title: CREDIT NEEDS TIED TO BELL RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The American Telephone and Tele graph Company has formally relayed to the Federal Commu nications Commission a warn ing from Wall Street that the company could lose its present topquality credit rating unless its earnings improve substan tially.

title: TWO PATROLMEN SHOT BY GUNMEN
description: Two transit patrolmen were wounded, one seriously, in a shootout with two armed men yesterday afternoon at the sub way station at Columbus Circle. Two suspects, both of whom were wounded, were arrested later.

title: Kadar, at Party Congress, Looks to Ties With Bonn
description: BUDAPEST, Nov. 23 (UPI) Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist party leader, said today that Budapest was ready to forge diplomatic ties with Bonn if the West Ger mans succeeded in cement ing relations with other countries of the Soviet bloc. In a fourhour keynote speech to his party's quad rennial congress, held in a union hall here, Mr. Kadar noted that West Germany's recent reconciliation treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland were yet to be rati fied.

title: Judge Gets Suspended Term
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23 (UPI)  Judge Neville Tucker, of Police Court, son of the African Methodist Episcopal Bishop who gave the Invoca tion at President Nixon's inau guration, received a sixmonth suspended sentence and was fined $500 today for failure to file income tax returns in 1964 1965 and 1966. Tucker, a Democrat who became the first Negro ever elected a Louisville Police Court judge, pleaded no contest in United States District Court here.

title: Multimillion Bet Center Raided Here
description: A bookmaking operation de scribed as one of the city's largestwith records showing $50,000 worth of bets on last night's professional football game alone and $10million worth of illegal action in the last three weekswas broken up last night by the police.

title: Foot of Snow Falls Upstate, Blocking Thruway
description: The first big storm of win ter, swirling out of Canada, dumped more than a foot of snow in parts of western New York State yesterday and forced the closing of a 124 mile stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.

title: HIGH COURT RULES ON TRAVEL UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)  The Supreme Court ruled today that the travel agent industry can legally chal lenge the right of national banks to compete in the travel service business.

title: Ali Insists Garden Increase TV Sites For Bonavena Bout
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 23  Muhammad All demanded to day that Madison Square Garden which expects a sellout for his Dec. 7 heavyweight bout with Oscar Bonavena, use several closedcircuit TV locations in the New York area to accom modate the overflow of those unable to purchase $10 tickets.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REBOUND IN PRICE
description: After declining sharply soon after the session's opening, largely on weakness in the com modity's endproductsoil and mealsoybean futures prices bounded back yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Schlesingers Are Divorced;
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 (UPI)Mrs. Marian C. Schlesin ger, wife of the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., was granted a divorce today in Middlesex Probate Court.

title: Scribner Orders High School Security Measures
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scrib ner directed the city's high schools yesterday to tighten security and take other meas ures to promote the welfare and safety of our students and staff members.

title: Roosevelt Results
3 CITY AIDES DECRY AGENCIES SECRECY
description: Three city officials, using a state legislative committee hearing on public information as a forum, charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had put a veil of secrecy over city agencies.

title: Edwin I. Marks, 82, Is. Dead; Held No. 2 Post at Macy's
description: Edwin I. Marks, who retired in 1949 as chairman of the ex ecutive committtee of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., died yester day at his home, 128 East 73d Street. He was 82 years old.

title: Repairs for 2 City Bridges
description: The Manhattan and Wil liamsburg Bridges, have been partly closed until emergency repairs are completed. Two of the three lanes of the Manhat tan span will be out of service for four months, to allow re placement of deteriorated ex pansion joints. Two upper road ways remain open. The south outer roadway of the Williams burg Bridge will be closed from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. for the next two weeks, to permit re surfacing approaches at each end of the span.

title: Normal Operations Resumed By U.S. Planes in Indochina
description: SAIGON, Nov. 23American aerial warfare over Indochina resumed its normal course to day, with United States jet strikes reported against sus pected enemy positions in Cam bodia, Laos and South Vietnam, and reconnaissance flights over North Vietnam to assess the results of Saturday's raids.

title: College, School Results
7 COLLEGES JOIN POLLUTION BATTLE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 Seven major New England universities agreed today to pool their training and research talents in the fight against air pollution and other environ mental problems.

title: Professional Football
Text of Pentagon News Conference on U.S. Rescue Mission Into North Vietnam
description: I want to give you now the details of the only opera tion that took place north of the 19th Parallel this past weekend.

title: The System's Dropouts Are Turning to Handicrafts in Search of New Values
Sports of The Times
description: A continent apart, George Blanda of the Oakland Raiders and Gino Cappelletti of the Boston Patriots did their things again the day before yesterday. They kicked field goals. For Blanda it was another of his lastsecond dillies to rescue the Raiders from defeat and keep them alive for pos sible Super Bowl nomination. For Cappy it was a relatively empty gesture because the Pats are going nowhere, unless it be to a cruel New England winter.

title: RICHEY CONQUERS GIMENO, 2321, 61
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 23 (AP)  Cliff Richey outlasted Andres Gimeno in a threehour match, 2321, 61, in the first round of the Swedish indoor open tennis tournament today and clinched a tie for first place in the Grand Prix international series.

title: Bank Set to Liquidate Part Of Copeland Loan Collateral
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 23 (AP)  The Wilmington Trust Company notified creditors of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. today that it was liquidating part of the collateral put up against a $3.7million loan.

title: Theater: The Candyapple Arrives at the Edison
description: Every critic sooner or later is asked the question: Why are critics so cruel? The an swer, I suppose, is related to a play such as The Candy apple, which was written by John Grissmer, produced by William F. Deseta, and opened at the Edison Theater last night.

title: Queens College Head
description: Joseph Samson Murphy likes to fly and likes to sail, but his earthbound pursuit is education. Yesterday it was announced that the tall, trim, 37yearold educator had been named the new president of Queens College by the city's Board of Higher Education. It is a post to which the ener getic Dr. Murphy brings a back ground of scholar ship in philosophy and political the ory, three degrees, experience as an instructor and professor, and expertise in administration in posts with the Peace Corps, the Job Corps, the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare andat the present time with New Jersey's Depart ment of Higher Education.

title: ENVIRONMENT SUIT IS FILED IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Nov. 23  A $300 million shareholder suit charg ing environmental mismanage ment was filed today in Federal Court against the Florida Power and Light Company.

title: Nat'l Football League
Hickel Bans Imports Of Whale Products;
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)  Walter J. Hickel, Secretary of the Interior, banned United States imports of whale products today to help prevent the extinction of whales.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, November 23, 1970

title: Legal Aid and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 When a former Princeton wres tler named Donald Rumsfeld and a former Harvard lineman named Terry F. Lenzner tangled Friday night, the wrestler won, as he nad to do. As director of the Office of Economic Oppor tunity, Mr. Rumsfeld had ap pointed Mr. Lenzner to run the remarkable legal services program of the antipoverty agency, and he had full authority to remove him and Frank Jones, Mr. Lenzner's deputy.

title: Treasury Statement
Tournier Wins Prix Goncourt With His 2d Novel
description: PARIS, Nov. 23France's highest literary award, the Prix Goncourt, was given to day to an outstanding, diffi cult and baroque novel, Le Roi des Aulnes (The Elf King), by Michel Tournier.

title: Nigeria Offers Military Aid
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 23 (AP)  The Nigerian Government said today that it had clear evidence of foreign involve ment in Guinea and offered Guinea military assistance.

title: Portuguese Troops on Alert
description: LISBON, Nov. 23 (Reuters) Portuguese forces along the Portuguese Guinea frontier with Guinea have increased their usual state of alert following the invasion of Conakry, ac cording to official reports reach ing Lisbon today.

title: Compromise Version Set On MutualFund Fee Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Joint SenateHouse Con ference Committee completed work today on a compromise version of the mutualfund legislation, thus bringing to an end, except for formalities, a legislative fight that has consumed four years. Passage of the compromise version by both the Senate and the House and President Nixon's signa ture are still required before the bill becomes law, but there appeared to be no like lihood of any snags.

title: CORRUPTION JURY INDICTS GAMBLER
description: Hugh Mulligan, described by authorities as a major book maker and key corrupter of policemen, was arrested here yesterday on a 19count indict ment that charged him with criminal contempt for refusing to answer questions in a grand jury investigation that focused on gambling and corruption.

title: HICKEL REAFFIRMS HE WILL NOT QUIT
description: Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel reaffirmed yesterday his decision not to leave the Cabinet unless the President dismissed him.

title: LAWYER, 66, IS HELD IN POLICE BRIBE CASE
description: A 66yearold lawyer who al legedly offered a young patrol man money to alter his testi mony in a narcotics case was arrested yesterday on charges of bribery and tampering with a witness.

title: Fijians, Here for Rugby, Play for Fun, Not Money
description: When Ilaitia Tuisese stepped off a jet from London here yesterday, a local rugby booster in the British Over seas Airways Corporation terminal at Kennedy Airport gasped in mock horror.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Ambassadors Left in 1966
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 23With the arrival in Moscow today of its new Ambassador, Liu Hsin chuan, Communist China re paired a breach of more than four years in relations at the ambassadorial level.

title: $1BILLION TO BACK HOME MORTGAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today that the board's new mortgagebuy ing subsidiary would purchase $1billion of Governmentback ed mortgages next year.

title: Soviet Accuses Portugal
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Commerce Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) President Nixon has accepted the resignation of Myron Tri bus, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for science and tech nology. The White House said that he was joining the Xerox Corporation as a vice president for research and development in the business products divi sion at Rochester, N. Y.

title: Knicks, Seeking More Height, Sign 71 Fillmore, ExCheyney State Center
ASIAN BISHOPS MEET ;
Fulbright Committee Asks Explanation for Air Raids
4 Killed, 2 Hurt in Bar Holdup Here
State Asks Fresh Talks For Off Broadway Peace
description: Meyer Drucker, director of mediation services of the State Mediation Board, has sum moned both parties in the Off Broadway theater strike to meet with him at the agency's offices, 270 Broadway, at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

title: The Pope and Population
description: Pope Paul continued to oppose the weight of scientific evidence and growing concern within his own church the other day when he strongly reaffirmed the Roman Catholic Church's traditional ban on all forms of birth control except the unreliable rhythm method.

title: U.N. Names 5Man Mission
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23A factfinding mission consisting of the chief repre sentatives to the United Na tions of Colombia, Finland, Ne pal, Poland and Zambia will leave for Guinea tomorrow, in formed sources today said.

title: RAIL NEGOTIATIONS FAR FROM ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) Railroad industry and union negotiators said today that they were far apart in efforts to set tle a wage dispute involving 500,000 workers and to head off a nationwide rail strike set for Dec. 11.

title: 100 Servicemen to Join Nixons on Thanksgiving
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  President and Mrs. Nixon will sit down to turkey dinner at the White House Thursday with more than 100 servicemen and women from three local military hospitals.

title: Major Independents
Television
LUNCH VOW NOT KEPT, PRESIDENT REMINDED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Nineteen church, social serv ice and civil rights leaders said today that President Nixon had not kept a promise to give free or reducedprice lunches to all needy school children by Thanksgiving.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest per centage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: U.S. Reports Little Information
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (Reu ters)  A State Department spokesman. asked whether Por tugal was involved in the attack on Guinea, said today that the United States had not talked with Lisbon on the matter and had no information on whether the Portuguese or any other government was involved.

title: PILOT TELLS OF ROLE IN DUMMY COMPANY
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 23 (AP)  An Indianapolis pilot said today that his name had been used to set up a dummy company through which Gol den Eagle Aviation Inc. leased some planes.

title: Nixon and the Rescue Mission
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  There is a single threat of con cern that binds together every one of President Nixon's spec tacular military ventures in Vietnam this year: his anxiety about the consequences of the American withdrawal.

title: Tully Captures Final
description: Bill Tully defeated Del Fuller in the final of the Eastern States veteran singles squash racquets invitation tournament here yesterday, 1516, 1512, 158, 158.

title: A.C.L.U. Plans Dinner to Mark Its 5Oth Year
description: The American Civil Liber ties Union will mark its 50th anniversary Dec. 8 at a din ner in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom. Former Chief Jus tice Earl Warren of the United States will be guest of honor.

title: GamePlan Government
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23Everybody is reshuffling the Nixon Administra tion Cabinet, Including members of the Nixon Administration Cabinet and the kind of White House officials who eat breakfast on a background basis with political reporters. The very air of the capital city is vibrant these days with reports of changes in the game plan new programs, new approaches, new rhetoric, even new abovethebattle statesmanlike images for Mr. Nixon and Vice President Agnew.

title: Dudley B. Lawrence Dead at 91; Realty Operator in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov., 23Dudley B. Lawrence, senior member of a family long prom inent in real estate here, died in his apartment in the Grama tan Hotel yesterday. He was 91 years old.

title: CUT IN PRIME RATE SPURS STOCK RISE
description: The stock market shed its heavy hag of worries long enough yesterday to produce a rally that responded to the latest cut in the prime rate.

title: $465Million Budget Approved By Board for the City University
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion last night approved a rec ord budget estimate for the fiscal year 197172 totaling $465,500,000, an increase of $142,600,000 over the current budget.

title: Guinea's Crisis in the U. N.
description: The origin, objectiveseven the compositionof the force that has invaded Guinea remain unclear. Hope for clearing away the confusion will rest heavily on a fact finding team that was organized yesterday and will be dispatched to Conakry today by the United Nations Security Council.

title: OTTO BLACKWELL, 86, HELD PHONE PATENTS
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Nov. 23 Otto B. Blackwell, a retired executive of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday in a nursing home in Sands Point. He was 86 years old and lived at 15 North Drive here.

title: 76 Hurt in Propane Blasts At Facility in Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Nov. 23 (AP)A chain of ex plosions ripped a propane stor age area today on Charlotte Amalie's eastern edge, injuring at least 76 persons.

title: College Degree Reforms Asked in Carnegie Report
description: The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education rec ommended yesterday a series of sweeping reforms that would liberalize the traditional degree structure of Ameri can colleges and universities:

title: Pentagon Aide Calls for Fight on Racism
description: A Pentagon official said yes terday that strong, aggressive and committed leadership at the top that was dedicated to racial equality was the pre scription for solving growing racial problems among Ameri can soldiers in West Germany.

title: The Proceedings
Women Raid Center
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP)A group of women iden tifying themselves as part of the women's liberation move ment raided the Harvard Cen J.er for International Affairs to day, shouting and daubing slo gans on the walls with cans of spray paint. The women cov ered their faces with scarves. They scattered before the po lice arrived.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday. Nov. 23, 1970

title: Tom Clark to Aid Court
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 23 (AP) Tom Clark, a retired Asso ciate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, tem porarily will join the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, here, beginning Nov. 30. He will help to relieve the case load of the court during the first week of its threeweek session in December.

title: Dividends Announced
PEACE TALKS OFF WEEK IN PROTEST
description: CHOISYLEROI, France Nov. 23 North Vietnam and the Vietcong said today that they would not attend this Wednes day's scheduled session of the Vietnam peace talks to protest the American air attacks on North Vietnam last weekend.

title: CITY LAYS OFF 63 IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: The first of 500 provisional city employes to be laid off because of the current budget crisis received pink slips yes terday.

title: Meadowlands Plan Will Help Ecology
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Nov. 23  Five miles due west of Man hattan, there are large num bers of muskrats, and an oc casional mink or raccoon, in a vast, largely undeveloped area called the Hackensack Mea dowlands.

title: Dennis Michael Dunn to Wed Alice Lynn Jacobson
description: SCARSDALE, N Y., Nov. 23Mr. and Mrs. Neal R. Jacobson have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Alice Lynn Jacob son, to Dennis Michael Dunn, son of Mrs. Francis Marcheso of Yonkers.

title: Why Not LendLease for Israel?
Nock Answers When Jets Opportunity Opens Door
description: In pro football, necessity breeds opportunity and George Nock has made the most of his.

title: Aqueduct Entries
Alaskans Begin Test to Raise Hogs and Crops
description: DELTA JUNCTION, Alaska Nov. 20 Fiftysix individually selected head of Iowa's finest cornfed hogs were flown in this week to become pioneer participants in a closely watch ed Arctic agricultural experi ment.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On TV Spending Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)Following is the 58 to 34 vote by which the Senate refused to override President Nixon's veto of the bill set ting limits on radio and tele vision campaign spending (twothirds vote required to override):

title: Court Says Man Alleging Innocence May Plead Guilty to Avoid Stiff Term
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  The Supreme Court ruled to day, 6 to 3, that a person accused of a crime should be permitted to plead guilty to a lesser offense and avoid the possibility that a jury might impose a stiffer sentence, even if the defendant insists that he is not guilty.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1970

title: Clue to Mets' Economy: Jones Gets $55,000 Again
description: If the Mets were worrying about the economic forecast for 1971, they received a clue yesterday: Cleon Jones signed his contract for $55,000, the same money he made this year.

title: ADS ARE BEAMED FOR PILL OVERUSE
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 23 (UPI)  Two doctors blamed Madison Avenue image makers today for enticing Americans to take pills for every imaginable purpose, including sometimes utterly ridiculous reasons.

title: ISRAELI TAPESTRY ON DISPLAY HERE
description: Pictures of many colors some with as many as 200of sophisticated works of art in tapestry that come out of a village in Israel are making their foreign debut here, at the Jean de Roche Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue.

title: 3 U.S. AIDES PROMISE NO HEAD START CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)Three Government of ficials told a crowd of angry parents today that the Admin istration would oppose any cut in spending on the popular Head Start program for needy children.

title: From Music Boxes to Coffee Beans in 4 Holiday Shops
A HOFFMAN ORDER TO JURY RECALLED
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 23A Fed eral deputy marshal, Ronald Dobroski, testified today that he had taken a note from the Chicago conspiracy jury to Judge Julius J. Hoffman during the jury's deliberations and had been ordered by the judge to tell the jurors to continue their deliberations.

title: Einhorn, Reinstated at Lincoln, Indicates He May Not Go Back
description: Dr. Arnold H. Einhorn indi cated strongly yesterday that he might never return to Lin coln Hospital, despite his re instatement over the weekend as chief of pediatrics.

title: Eagles Upset Giants, 2320, in Seesaw Battle, Ending New Yorkers' Streak
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23  The sixgame winning streak that had transformed the hap less Giants into a pennant con tender froze to death at Frank lin Field tonight in a 2320 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, who had won only one of nine pre vious games.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CITY PLANS TO END WELFARE ABUSES INVOLVING HOTELS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced reforms designed to stamp out safety hazards and squalid conditions in hotels oc cupied by welfare families and to reduce huge rents paid to the hotels by the city.

title: A Girl in Saigon Gives Christmas Her Own Touch
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 23A small Vietnamese girl in pajamas, who has no idea of what Dec. 25 means to others, is a sudden reminder of Christmas on a noisy Saigon street.

title: CONSPIRACY TRIAL OPENS IN TACOMA
description: TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 23  The trial of the Seattle 8, the second major Federal prosecution of radicals on charges of conspiracy and violation of the antiriot act, opened here today.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SURGE UP AGAIN
Rogers in Ottawa Talks; Japan Firm on Textiles
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 23 Secre tary of State William P. Rogers assured Canadians to day that their American neigh bors would help them develop a nation distinct from the United States. However, he re minded them that Canada was heavily dependent on United States markets and capital.

title: East Pakistani Leaders Assail Yahya on Cyclone Relief
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 23 (Reuters)East Pakistani polit ical leaders today condemned what they termed the central Government's gross neglect fol lowing the cyclone and tidal wave that struck the province 10 days ago.

title: NATIONAL BISCUIT SEEKS TOY MAKER
description: The National Biscuit Com pany yesterday announced plans to enter the toy and hobby field by agreeing in principle to acquire Aurora Products, Inc., for about $17.6 million. Under the agreement, Na tional Biscuit will pay $11 in cash for each outstand ing share of Aurora. As of June 30, the toy producer had nearly 1.6 million shares outstanding. Directors of both companies approved the agreement yesterday.

title: Soviet View of Raids Termed Relatively Mild
description: MOSCOW. Nov. 23The Soviet Union reacted official ly today to the latest Ameri can bombing raids over North Vietnam with a statement affirming support for Hanoi but avoiding direct involve ment.

title: High Court Rejects Appeal On Baseball Pension Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  The Supreme Court declined today to hear an attack on major league baseball's pension system by Allie Reynolds, one time Cleveland and New York Yankee pitcher.

title: J. E. Basil Naumann, 49, Led International Coffee Corp.
description: J. E. Basil Naumann of 300 East 57th Street, president of the International Coffee Corpo ration, died on Sunday in Win chester, England, where he was visiting his mother. He was 49 years old.

title: Social Studies Council Opens Meeting Here on Thursday
description: The National Council for the Social Studies held preliminary conferences yesterday at the New York Hilton in prepara tion for its 50th annual meet ing, which opens on Thanks giving Day.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 23  A Midwestern pair led the field into the final session of the Life Master Men's Pair cham pionship at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals here tonight. Hugh MacLean of Edina, Minn., and Ronald Anderson of Madison, Wis., totaled 569 points at the end of the first final ses sion.

title: Senate Unit, 100, Denies U.S. Must Defend Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23, Reu terThe Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee today unani mously approved a resolution declaring that an agreement with Spain to lease military bases did not represent a United States commitment to defend the Madrid Government.

title: PENTAGON ADMITS SHARING DRUG LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23, (UPI)  The Pentagon con firmed today that for six years it had been giving the Federal, Bureau of Narcotics and Dan gerous Drugs the names of thousands of men rejected for military service because of drug addiction.

title: Oregon's Prefontaine Wins Run, but Villanova Asks Review on Team Title
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 23 (AP)  Steve Prefontaine, a sophomore, won the individual title today and apparently led Oregon to the team crown in the National Collegiate cross country championship.

title: Net Drops Sharply At Whittaker Corp.
description: The Whittaker Corporation's operating profit for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 slumped to $7.7million, or 36 cents a share, from $29million, or $1.41 a share, restated in fiscal 1969, the company's prelimi nary statement disclosed yes terday.

title: 58 House Democrats Act
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) Fiftyeight Democratic House members asked President Nixon in a letter today to impose wageandprice guidelines and stand ready to impose con trols to fight inflation. They suggested he call labor and management leaders to the White House and work out guidelines.

title: A.B.A. IS SEEKING TO RESUME TALKS
College Conference Standings
Money
description: Monday, Nov. 23, 1970

title: Theater: The Candyapple Arrives at the Edison
description: Every critic sooner or later is asked the question: Why are critics so cruel? The an swer, I suppose, is related to a play such as The Candy apple, which was written by John Grissmer, produced by William F. Deseta, and opened at the Edison Theater last night.

title: 2 Car Makers Sales Off
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  The Commerce Department reported today that new orders for durable goods in October declined $1.2billion from the September level.

title: Egers's Injury Stirring Controversy Over Use of Hockey Helmets
description: Except for pains in his neck and the back of his head, Jack Egers said from his hospital bed yesterday that he felt fine.

title: WageandPrice Guidance Urged by Business Group
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23A sizable majority of a study group composed mainly of prominent present and former businessmen concluded today that the time has come for the Government to try to influence private price and wage de cisions, though not by manda tory controls.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: A City of 200,000 Is Envisioned in Jersey Meadows
The Haack Controversy
description: Wall Street traditionally goes to great lengths to avoid con troversy and dissension, but the long and destructive stock market retreat and the precari ous financial condition of many brokerage houses have strained the normal diplomacy of the securities industry. Today, a week after a speech by Robert W. Haack, presi dent of the New York Stock Ex change, aroused the wrath of many of the in dustry's leaders, questions are being asked about subjects that once were taboo. Wall Street is still taking sides over Mr. Haack's position and nobody knows how the controversy will be resolved.

title: SITE FOR SCHOOL IN QUEENS ARGUED
description: Sharp words, shouted charges and even a football were tossed around at a tumultuous City Hall hearing yesterday on the controversial location of a fu ture midQueens high school.

title: 6 Policemen Slightly Hurt When Car Hits Barricade
description: Six policemen were hurt last night, none seriously, when a car was driven into wooden barriers set up in front of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations during a demonstration by the Jewish Defense League.

title: Dry Dock Savings Picks Chief; Queens County Bank Fills Post
description: Chief executive appointments at two major banks were an nounced yesterday.

title: MAISEL QUESTIONS MONEYFLOW VIEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23  A member of the Federal Re serve Board issued a strong warning today against simple statements and con clusions based on movements in the nation's money supply.

title: Political Cynicism Triumphant
description: The failure of the Senate to override President Nixon's veto of the bill to regulate political spending on radio and television is a victory for cynical partisanship. The Presidential arguments against the bill were specious. Republicans who voted for the bill in September and against it yesterday have no excuse except that the status quo works to the advantage of their party.

title: Rock Music Turns To Spiritual Ideas
description: It is perhaps too much to say that rock music is get ting religion, but a large number of current records are dealing sympathetically with religious and spiritual ideals.

title: Mann Elected Executive At Pennsylvania Bank
description: The Western Pennsylvania Bank has elected Maurice Mann as executive vice presi dent, effective next Tuesday. In making the announcement yesterday, Henry Tunny, pres ident of the bank, said Mr. Mann will organize and im plement a newly created cor porate communications group for the bank and its parent, WPNB Corporation.

title: Results of Racing at Laurel
description: By The Associated Press

title: French Newsman Sees
Shipping/Mails
50,000 Cubans Add Prosperity and Problems to Jersey
description: UNION CITY, N. J. If it weren't for the Cuban popu lation here, Bergenline Ave nue would be nothing but a parking lot, said Lieut. Paul G. Kelly of the Union City Police Department. Ten years ago most of the stores were empty, but now when a vacancy occurs, it is rented immediately.

title: Philip Osterman, 92, Led American Gas Furnace Co,
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 23 Philip Osterman, chairman of the board of the American Gas Furnace Company here, died yesterday at his home. He was 92 years old and lived at 19 Stiles Street.

title: Thant Terms U.S. Raids Disturbing Development
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Nov. 23Secretary Thant to day said that American air strikes against North Vietnam over the weekend were a dis turbing development.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, Nov. 23, 1970

title: Tropical Fish Imports Called a Threat
description: MIAMI, Nov. 22 Ichthyolo gists have warned that the environment is being seriously threatened by the importation into Florida of 50 million live tropical fish yearly and the in advertent release of many spe cies, including the rapacious piranha.

title: U.S. Information on P.O.W.'s Appears Limited
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Conversations with Administra tion officials suggest that the information the United States has on American prisoners of war in North Vietnam is lim ited and imprecise.

title: Soviet Asks Tight Ideology Curb
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23The So viet Communist party called today for a firm stand against Western ideas to prevent the shadow of liberalism from falling on the Soviet Union.

title: Governor Sees Disaster Unless U.S. Aid Grows
Playoffs' Use of 2dPlace Club Keeps More Contenders Alive
description: Sixteen of pro football's 26 teams remain in contention for the postseason playoffs with four games remaining. The statistic compliments the balance between the teams and the ingenious playoff system conceived by Commis sioner Pete Rozelle's staff.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Postal. The President ap pointed Howard Elliott, Jr., 37 years old, of St. Louis, and John L. Ryan, 49, of In dianapolis, to be members of the Postal Rata Commission.

title: Paterno Is Ruled Offside In a Retort by Blackman
description: When Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, chal lenged Dartmouth to a Dec. 5 game for the Eastern cham pionship, it appeared to be something of a grandstand play. Paterno, an Ivy League graduate from Brown, knewthat Dartmouth, the unde feated Ivy champion, was bound by league rules that have prohibited post season games by its teams for many years. Pa terno made the offer after his team beat Pittsburgh last Saturday to finish the year with a 73 wonlost rec ord. Dartmouth, which beat Penn that day for a 90 sea son mark, was quick to give the expected reactiona strong No.

title: U.S. and Mexico Sign Pact To End Territorial Disputes
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 (UPI) Mexico and the United States signed a treaty today to end territorial disputes between the two countries.

title: ChildCare Unit To Fete Donors
description: About 350 guests are ex pected to attend the annual donor luncheon of the West chester HartmanHomecrest League of the Jewish Child Care Association next Tues day at the Plaza.

title: Physicians Laud Progress of Harvard Health Plan
House Panel Shelves Nixon Plan For Tax on the Lead in Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee today shelved Presi dent Nixon's requested antipol lution tax on lead in gasoline. The action killed the proposal for this year,

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Killer of Highway Patrolmen Sentenced to Gas Chamber
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Nov. 23 (UPI)  Bobby Augusta Davis, who had been convicted of murdering four California high way patrolmen last April, was sentenced to the gas chamber today by a jury of five men and seven women.

title: Foreign Relief Spurred
description: DACCA, Nov. 22The for eigndominated relief effort for the victims of the cyclone and tidal wave increased in inten sity today, but it still was be lieved to be far short of what is needed.

title: Two Mylai Witnesses Say Citations Were False
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov 2.3 Two key Government wit nesses at the murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley, Jr. stated under crossexamina tion today that the decorations they received for rescuing chil dren during the alleged Mylai massacre were based on false citations. One of the two further said he was an occasional user of marijuana.

title: CAB TALKS REACH UNDERSTANDING; STRIKE PERIL EBBS
description: The city's taxi drivers and fleet owners appeared last night to have reached a general understanding for resolving their contract dispute, but both sides refrained from saying they had a full agreement.

title: Market Place
description: Some of you may not re member Leasing Consultants, Inc., a specialty leasing com pany that was dropped out of the Standard & Poor's Stock Guide with the Sep tember issue.

title: For Part of 7th Ave., Midi's Not Even an Issue
description: The uproar over hemlines this fall may have en livened dinner parties and given television talk shows topic of endless interest, but the midiskirt has hardly been booming at the mass volume companies that dress the average American.

title: Injured Neighbor Dies; Cries for Help Ignored
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) A wounded man who the po lice say begged his neighbors for help early today, only to be turned away, was found dead later in the day.

title: City Drug Program
description: Deaths from drug abuse, higher in New York City than anywhere else in the nation, continue their inex orable climb. The 1970 total was at the 935 level the other day and officials say that deaths may actually have passed the 1,000mark because records necessarily lag.

title: Okinawa Town Has a Black Enclave That White G.I. Enters at His Peril
description: KOZA, Okinawa, Nov. 16 MamaSan longs for the good old days when black and white American servicemen drank together and flirted with her hostesses in her spacious cab aret.

title: POST OFFICE EASES LOTTERY NEWS CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  Federal law prohibits the mailing of information on lot teries, but the Post Office has bent the rule slightly in the case of drawings run by two states.

title: Stock Prices in London Show Decline in a Quiet Trading Day
description: The London stock market drifted down in quiet trading yesterday. The Financial Times index of 30 industrial stocks closed at 3274, off 2.2, and the 500stock index settled at 136.42, off 0.47.

title: All Quiet Along the Other DMZ
description: SEOUL, Korea  The disclosure a few days ago that the United States Second Infantry Division is going to be withdrawn from its frontline positions in Korea reminded a great many Americans who had forgotten all about it that there is in fact a frontline in Korea and that American troops have formed part of it for more than twenty years. The Korean War came to a halt though not to an endin July, 1953; but ever since, that war has been in state of suspended animation with strange life of its own. Along the sta tionary frontline runs an undercurrent of tension; American soldiers confront Communist soldiers; small but bloody encounters occasionally erupt; there are the elements of war without a war.

title: Red Cross Sends Aide
description: GENEVA, Nov. 23Kai J. Warras, a Red Cross official, left for East Pakistan today to in vestigate the delay in distrib uting relief supplies.

title: BIAS UNIT TO STUDY HIRING IN SCHOOLS
description: The City Commission on Hu man Rights announced yester day that it would hold full scale public hearings in Janu ary to investigate the employ ment practices of the Board of Education.

title: FISCHER PLAYS DRAW WITH SOVIET MASTER
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Nov. 23Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eighttime United States chess champion, drew with Lev Polugayevsky, a Soviet master, in the 11th round of the eighth Palme de Mallorca elimination and quali fication roundrobin tourna ment for the wolrd challenge match today.

title: Met. Squash Racquets
City Board Approves York College Campus Plan
description: The master plan for a $62.5 million York College campus to replace a 50acre blighted area in Jamaica, Queens, was approved last night by the city's Board of Higher Educa tion.

title: Advertising:
description: Edward L. Bond Jr., chair man of Young & Rubicam, Inc., has turned his title of chief executive officer over to Edward N. Ney, who has also been named president of the agency worldwide.

title: Six Are Indictid Here in Plot To Smuggle Heroin In by Plane
description: The Federal Government charged yesterday that five Paraguayans and a Frenchman conspired to bring almost 94 pounds of pure heroin, said to be worth at least $10million, into a small airport in Florida, where customs agents seized the narcotics shipment last month.

title: GRETE G. GLOBUS, MEDICAL EDITOR
description: Mrs. Grete Gans Globus, leader in neuropathology and neurology, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 960 Park Avenue.

title: Izvestia Likens Memoir to Forgeries
description: Izvestia, the Soviet Govern ment newspaper, charged in today's issue that the purport ed reminiscences of Nikita S. Khrushchev were a Western propaganda canard.

title: Backers of Palestine State Face Trial, Fatah Asserts
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 24 (Agence France  Presse)Any Palestinian supporting the idea of creation of a Palestinian state on the westbank terri tory of Jordan will be regarded as a traitor and tried by a Palestinian revolutionary court, the guerrilla daily, Al Fatah, announced today.

title: Maelstrom of Inflation
description: The most trenchant comment on the Committee for Economic Development policy statement, Further Weapons against In flation: Measures to Supplement General Fiscal and Monetary Policies, comes in a footnote by Frazer B.
