Wilde, chairman emeritus of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Com pany and a for mer chairman of the C.E.D. This statement, says Mr. Wilde, is an excellent presenta tion of our country's major problem. It does not offer an adequate remedy. No adminis tration can be tough enough in its use of general fiscal and monetary restraints to contain inflation, given the political re quirement of full employment, Mr. Wilde observes.

title: Nixon Refusal of Resignation By Kennedy Is Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 President Nixon has rejected a proffered resignation of Sec retary of the Treasusy David M. Kennedy and Mr. Kennedy will stay at his post indefinitely, official sources said today.

title: STOCKS FIRMER ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market, helped by the rise on Wall Street, was slightly firmer yes terday, but trading was quiet.

title: Jane Fegan Betrothed To Thomas W. Covey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Fegan of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Jane A. Fegan, to Thomas W. Covey of New Britain, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Covey of Wethers field, Conn. The wedding is planned for January in West brook. Conn.

title: Gulf and B.P. Raise Payments to Kuwait
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 24 The trend toward higher oil costs in North Africa and the Middle East spread further to day with the announcement that the Kuwait Oil Company, jointly owned by the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, had agreed to a $90million increase in payments to the Kuwaiti Gov ernment.

title: Harried on Ground by Starving East Pakistanis, U.S. Relief Group Resorts to an Airdrop
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 24 We have been here since yes terday. We wanted to get into the affected areas immediately and start helping people, but we can't get anywhere with the Government.

title: Star's Light Yields Data on ShortLived Element
description: Prometheum, a chemical ele ment so shortlived that it normally is not seen on earth, has been detected in a distant star.

title: Southern Airways Co. Accused Of Selling Army Faulty Shells
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 24 (UPI)A Federal grand jury today indicted the Southern Airways Company, Inc., a Dela ware corporation, and 12 of its employes on charges of con spiring to defraud the Govern ment by supplying it with de fective artillery shells.

title: ROBERT C. WILKE, 62, OWNED RACING CARS
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 24 (UPI) Robert C. Wilke, a racingcar owner and president of Leader Cards, a printing concern, died of a heart attack today in Florida at the age of 62.

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Senate Committee Hearing on P.O.W. Rescue Effort
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's open hearing Washington yesterday on the rescue mission in North Vietnam as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News. Among those questioning Secretory of Defense Melvin R. Laird were Senators J. W. Fulbright, Frank Church and Claiborne Pell, Democrats, and Georce Aiken. Republican.

title: Class 4  4: Up the Reading Ladder
description: Javier Romero moved with the solemnity of one engaged in a ritual. In his own mind it was a tiny commencement, for he had just climbed up a rung in Class 44's reading program, becoming the fifth member of a small lite able to read slightly above what is calculated to be their grade level.

title: Author Weds Arlene Nadel
description: Miss Arlene Nadel, an ac tress with the New York Shakespeare Festival, and Richard Hammer, an author and a writer on the staff of The Week in Review section of The New York Times, were married here yesterday evening.

title: Roosevelt Entries
Radcliffe Art Tour Planned Dec. 5
description: The 18th annual art tour of the Radcliffe Club of New York will be held Dec. 5. The tour is the club's chief meth od of raising funds to pro vide scholarships to promis ing students from the New York area.

title: Blocking Airport Crime
description: With time running out on Capitol Hill, the airlines seem determined to create an endless wind tunnel stop Congressional approval of the New YorkNew Jer sey compact empowering the Waterfront Commission to combat cargo thefts at metropolitan airports.

title: Smithsonian Exhibit Resembles Goldberg Cartoon, Which It Is
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Rube Goldberg is the car toonist who invented the fan tastic machine that struck the universal chord. His drawings spoofed man's abil ity to make the simple com plex and showed man a lot lower than the angelsdown right human.

title: U.S. Bill Rates Decline Sharply At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Treasury bill rates at today's monthly auction of 274 and 365 day bills, announced by the gov ernment late this afternoon, were dramatically lower com pared with rates reported by the government a month ago.

title: Rights Groups Call School Plan a Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The new Federal program to ease school desegregation with money has amounted so far to a fraud upon Congress, six civil rights groups charged to day.

title: Multilingual Leaflets Tell Why Pupil Is Suspended
description: Similar messages, in different languages, are being dis tributed to the parents of other pupils in the city schools. The leaflets500,000 copies printed in English, 300,000 in Spanish and 5,000 each in Chinese, French and Italian are intended to acquaint par ents and schoolchildren with pupil  suspension procedures, a matter of considerable con troversy here in recent years.

title: Food Prices Expected to Rise Again in the Spring
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24  While food prices dropped last month one of the few heartening elements in a rising Consumer Price Index  all indications point to another rise next spring.

title: TIMES TO MICROFILM LIBERTY MAGAZINES
description: The New York Times an nounced yesterday plans to publish on microfilm the entire collection of Liberty magazine, one of this country's leading family weeklies from 1924 to 1950.

title: TIE MOVES BRUINS AHEAD OF RANGERS
HOUSE APPROVES JOB SAFETY BILL BACKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The House handed organized labor a major legislative defeat today by rejecting the union version of the occupational health and safety bill and adopting instead the bill backed by business interests and the Nixon Administration.

title: Gaullist Deputy Is Beaten And Stabbed by Four Men
description: PARIS, Nov. 24  A Gaullist member of Parliament, Michel de Grailly, was beaten and stabbed by four men tonight as he was parking his oar in front of his home in the residential Passy district here.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS MISSISSIPPI FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  The Mississippi Democratic party that won recognition by the national body at the 1968 Democratic convention in Chic ago is organizing a challenge to the seniority of the five members of the House from that state.

title: BOSON RECEIVES 70 ROOKIE AWARD
SCOTCH SYMPHONY PROVES DANCE VALUE
description: The New York City Ballet's Scotch Symphony, an un abashedly enchanting work, had its first performance of the season last night at the State Theater.

title: RubaDubDub, Tubs They're AChanging
description: Once, people bought bathtubs to bathe in. Times have changed. Nowadays, bathtubs are doubling as aquariums, settings for baths a deuxand even as objets d'art.

title: Series of Six Benefit Dances Set for Hospital in Harrison
description: RYE, N.Y., Nov. 24Mrs. Carlton M. Fishel and Mrs. George J. Gillespie will again serve as cochairmen of the series of six benefit dances to be held at two country clubs here, to aid St. Vin cent's Hospital in Harrison. Last year, $23,000 was raised from these parties. The ben eficiary provides psychiatric hospital and outpatient care for disturbed adults and children.

title: EXCHANGE STIFFENS ACCOUNTING RULES
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had enacted new rules requiring member firms to make periodic counts of securities under their control.

title: Bolivia Expected to Free Debray Under an Amnesty
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 (UPI)  The Cabinet will meet in extraordinary session tomor row to draft an amnesty for all political prisoners, including Regis Debray, a French Marx ist writer sentenced to 30 years imprisonment for participating in guerrilla activities in 1967, it was reported in Government circles today.

title: Union Head Cites Gain in Hospitals As Center Opens
description: Leon J. Davis, president of the Drug and Hospital Union's Local 1199, said yesterday that 20 per cent of city hospital workers received such low wages 10 years ago that they were on welfare but that his union had raised the pay scale so that none were welfare re cipients now.

title: Ky Says He's an ExHawk Turned Dove
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  Nguyen Cao Ky, South Viet nam's often controversial Vice President, pictured himself to day as a misunderstood mod erate, an ex  hawk turned dove, whose primary interest is in ending the fighting that has wracked his country for 20 Years.

title: Books of The Times
description: RADICAL CHIC & MAUMAUING THE FLAK CATCHERS. By Tom Wolfe. 153 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $5.95.

title: Floridians Get ExBullet
description: MIAMI, Nov. 24 (AP)The Floridians of the American Bas ketball Association acquired to day Dennis Stewart, a 6foot7 inch forward who had played for the Baltimore Bullets.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Speculation and profit taking sent nearby soybean futures prices down the limit yester day on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: L.I.U. TOLD TO DROP PLAN FOR LIBRARY
Chains Are Mixed
description: Retail merchandise chains showed a mixed pattern in their thirdquarter results, with four out of the nine companies that reported yes terday turning in higher sales and earnings over last year. However, for the ninemonth period, only two made more money, reflecting the slow down in the economy, slug gish consumer purchasing and in part the conflict over fashion styles.

title: Concrete Company Is Fined $25.000 on Pollution Charges
description: A Federal judge fined TransitMix Concrete Corpora tion $25,000 yesterday on a plea of guilty to discharging waste concrete into the East River at the foot of 20th Street.

title: Both Sides Continuing Efforts To Work Out Taxi Agreement
description: Lawyers and fiscal experts for the taxi drivers union and the fleet owners continued their efforts yesterday to reach final agreement on a new contract.

title: COLUMBIA ARTISTS CHOOSES NEW HEAD
description: Ronald Wilford has been elected president of Columbia Artists Management, Inc. and chairman of the board of Com munity Concerts, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Columbia. He succeeds Kurt Weinhold, who has held both posts for 11 years.

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Harvard Beats Brown, 21, Gains Soccer Quarterfinals
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24 Harvard's unbeaten soccer team advanced to the quarter finals of the National Collegi ate playoffs today by beating Brown, 21, for its 12th victory and second straight New Eng land title.

title: Hussein to Visit Nixon Early Next Month
AMERICAN EXPORT ON BROOKLYN PIER
Official's Dismissal Asked In Welfare Hotel Dispute
description: The New York Urban Coalition called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to dismiss Housing and Development Administra tor Albert A. Walsh, saying that Mr. Walsh had, in effect, rejected its plan to rehabili tate abandoned slum build ings for welfare families that are now housed at high rents in hotels.

title: British Soccer Results
description: By Reuters

title: 17 DEAD IN VIETNAM AS AIRCRAFT COLLIDE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 24 (AP)A helicopter carrying South Vietnamese troops col lided today with a light United States plane in the Mekong Delta 80 miles south of Saigon.

title: CHAMBER PLAYERS OFFER FRESH FARE
description: There are so many good young instrumentalists around town that it is not surprising that chamber ensembles keep popping up all the time.

title: Penn State Bows in Soccer
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 124 (UPI)Jean Baldini scored on a penalty kick midway through the third period to give unbeaten Philadelphia Textile a 21 victory over Penn State to day in a National Collegiate Eastern regional soccer playoff.

title: Heisman Winners Fluctuate as Pros
description: More Heisman Trophy win ners have failed than suc ceeded in professional foot ball, Gary Beban of the Uni versity of California, Los An geles; John Huarte from Notre Dame and Terry Baker, Ore gon State, being the prime examples of the last decade. Jim Plunkett of Stanford is expected to be one of the suc cesses, like Mike Garrett, O. J. Simpson and Paul Hornung. Plun kett has all the assets that pro scouts seek in evaluating quarterbackssize, the pass ing arm, quickness, a com petitive attitude.

title: ALAN RICH RECEIVES TWO WRITING PRIZES
description: Alan Rich, music editor of New York Magazine, received two prizes yesterday in the presentation of the ASCAP Deems Taylor Awards given by the American Society of Com posers, Authors and Publishers for books and articles on music published in 1969.

title: An Assistant to Watson Gets New Post at I.B.M.
description: The appointment of Jane P. Cahill as secretary of the management review commit tee of the International Busi ness Machines Corporation was announced yesterday. Miss Cahill had been execu tive assistant to Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of I.B.M.

title: Harassed Jersey Star Chooses Coast College
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 24Six years after he picked up a basketball for the first time in a schoolyard and thought. Hey, I can make a living at this game, Leslie Cason announced today that he had selected Long Beach (Calif.) State as the college of his choice.

title: Cancer Cell Extract Immunizes Guinea Pigs Against Leukemia
description: A New York scientist has succeeded in immunizing guinea pigs against leukemia using a technique that may some day provide an approach to cancer prevention.

title: Theater: Ododo, a Militant Musical
description: While the Negro Ensemble Company has hitherto been very highly regarded by the white community, including the white critics, I have been slightly conscious that its standing among some blacks was less, say, than that of the Lafayette Theater of Ed Bullins. Perhaps something of this can be detected in the company's fourth season, which takes as its general subject matter Themes of Black Struggle.

title: Money
ROCK SALT KEEPS TRACK PROTECTED
Dividends Announced
description: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY

title: The Puzzling Economy
Sports of The Times
description: The bus driver was from New York and he was therefore not familiar with the pat terns and the flow of Philadelphia traffic as he began the homeward journey toward the original starting point, the Yankee Stadium, from his intermediate stopover, Franklin Field.

title: Army and Navy Rivalry Is No HitorMiss Affair
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 24 Col. Gus Dielens, Army's di rector of athletics, explained the ArmyNavy football rivalry as something rarely felt by athletes in any competition these days. He said it was a contest in which you hit that other guy like it was the last time you'd hit anyone in your life.

title: Theater: 2 Plays by Brucke Troupe
description: The firstrate Germanlan guage troupe Die Brcke has every right to return home smiling like the audience last night at the Barbizon Plaza Theater. Having opened last week with a perfectly ele gant, earthbound Amphitry on by Heinrich von Kleist, the company rounded out its visit, through next Wednes day, with two even earthier goodies, a pair of oneacters with no leftover crumbs in either play playine.

title: VIRGINIA JUDGE SHOT ON ANSWERING DOOR
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 24 (UPI) A City judge was crit ically wounded early this morn ing by five pistol shots when he answered a knock at his door.

title: Head Start Parents Form National Unit As H.E.W Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 About 700 parents of children in the Head Start program, after daylong demonstrations yesterday, announced the for mulation of a board to advise the Federal Government on running the programs.

title: Guinea Charges Further Incursions by Mercenaries
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Nov. 24 (AP) For the third day, the Marxistoriented Government of neighboring Guinea broadcast reports of incursions by Por tuguese fascists and their mer cenaries.

title: N.B.A. LineUps
Muriel Cigars Chooses DKG, Inc., as New Home
description: Muriel has got a new ad dress. No, not that Muriel, the cigar Muriel. Squeezed out of Lennen & Newell by a conflict that developed with a new Lorillard assignment, the Consolidated Cigar brand is moving in with DKG, Inc., along with her $2million in billings.

title: Western Air Gets New Merger Bid From Continental
description: Western Air Lines announced yesterday that it had recessed a special meeting of its board of directors until Dec. 7 to study a new and enhanced mereer nronosal made by Con tinental Air Lines. The special meet ing, which was held in Los An geles yesterday, was to have con sidered the previous offer made by Continental and one made by American Airlines to acquire Western. J. Judson Taylor, pres ident of Western, said the board was expected to take action on the rival bids at the reconvened meeting. Robert F. Six, president of Continental, said that we are hopeful that further review of Continental's new and revised proposal will initiate further negotiations be1 tween Western and Contin ental.

title: Student Involvement or Detachment?
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Nov. 24On the campuses of the United States these days politics seem to be in a slump and pretty girls have made a remark able comeback. The postelection mood seems comparatively calm, se rious and personal after the spectac ular mass rumbles of last spring.

title: A Holiday Boutique For Cancer Group
description: The American Cancer So ciety has arranged its Holi day Boutique for Dec. 3 through Dec. 18 in its offices at 44 East 53d Street. The sale, a weekday project of the society's women's com mittee, will be from 11 A. M. to 7 P.M.

title: Nuptials Set Jan. 2 By Lynn Spalding
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 24 Miss Lynn Murray Spald ing and George Arvid Peter son will be married Jan. 2 in Palm Beach.

title: PRESIDENT OF BAR SCOLDS RUMSFELD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The president of the American Bar Association rebuked Donald Rumsfeld, head of the Federal antipoverty program, today for suggesting that the dismissals of two top poverty law officials were endcrsed by the A.B.A.

title: MILWAUKEE TOPS BULLS BY 117108
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) Oscar Robertson, with three baskets in 75 seconds, lead a fourthperiod rally that gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 117108 triumph over the Chicago Bulls tonight in a National Basket ball Association contest.

title: Cambodian Farmers Fear War May Hurt Harvest
description: BATTAMBANG, Cambodia, Nov. 16As usual at this time of year, yellowgreen seas of rice stalks stretch to every hori zon in this most fertile of Cam bodia's provinces, but the ap proaching harvest season seems to be bringing with it a sense of foreboding.

title: Market Place:
description: Your neighbor is out of workand there are several on your block in the same boat. They may not be aware of the corporate process that put them on the bricks, but it is an interesting one.

title: Article 2  No Title
M'CORMACK OFFICE CENTER OF INQUIRY
description: A new Federal investigation of possible misuse of House Speaker John W. McCormack's office, and of other Government agencies, was disclosed yester day.

title: LaidOff City Employes Face a Bleak Existence
description: What can I say to my chil dren? asked Mrs. Elaine Wil son, a sadeyed mother of five, who was one of the provisional employes laid off by the city yesterday for economy reasons. Many of them will have to go back on welfare.

title: Hard Climb to Fame
description: Jim Plunkett calls himself just a simple guy, but his friends, football teammates and officials at Stanford Uni versity in Palo Alto, Calif., know better.

title: RAYMOND TUCKER, ST. LOUIS MAYOR
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) Raymond R. Tucker, an engi neer and educator who became the first threeterm Mayor of St. Louis, died here last night. He was 73 years old.

title: Philadelphia Parley Aims to Join Unionists, Students and Faculty
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24  Plans for a coalition of blue collar workers and members of the academic community to seek solutions of problems fac ing the nation were discussed last night at an informal meet ing at the University of Penn sylvania.

title: Article 1  No Title
Advertising: 3 Big Agencies Join Hands
description: The much rumored, long awaited merger of D'Arcy Advertising and MacMinus, John & Adams was an nounced yesterday, along with a little surprise. Inter marco, Europe's fourth largest agency, is in on the act.

title: Ray's Brother Acquitted In Shooting of Nazi Youth
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 24 (UPI)A jury of 11 men and a woman today acquitted Jerry William Ray of a charge of ag gravated assault in the shooting of a 17yearold Nazi. Mr. Ray, 35 years old, is the brother of James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: $2Billion City Relief Costs Seen by '72
description: Welfare officials estimated yesterday that the city's relief budget for the next fiscal year would increase to $2billion, with the average monthly case load rising to 1.27 million per sons.

title: Israeli Tankers Ply Gulf of Suez, Officially Unnoticed by U. A.R.
description: RAS SHUKAIR, United Arab Repubjic, Nov. 23In a silent chapter of the ArabIsraeli con flict, Israeli tankers sail boldly down the Gulf of Suez past this EgyptianAmerican offshore oil site, headed toward Elath, Israel's southern port, with oil produced from fields in the Israelioccupied Sinai Penin sula.

title: F.B.I. Raid Seeks Radical
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Nov. 24 (AP) A dozen Federal, state and county agents raided a farm in this southeastern Vermont township today in an unsuc cessful search for Bernardine Dohrn, a student radical on the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion's mostwanted list.

title: Weapons Against Inflation
description: The Committee for Economic Development, a group business leaders, has put its finger on what is wrong with the Nixon Administration's program to stop infla tion: It depends almost entirely on slowing down the economy and boosting unemployment while neglecting other weapons to check the wageprice spiral. That ap proach simply does not work.

title: Turkey's Eyes Soften The President's Heart
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)President Nixon today received a 45pound live white turkey for Thanksgiving but said he did not have the heart to eat it.

title: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS
Ashe and Rosewall Win at Stockholm, Keep Grand Prix Tennis Hopes Alive
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 24 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., and Ken Rosewall of Australia kept alive their hopes of sharing the first prize in the international tennis Grand Prix with easy firstround victories tonight in the Stockholm open indoor tournament, the last event of the $150,000 series.

title: FISCHER AND GELLER ADJOURN CHESS GAME
description: PALMA, Spain, Nov. 24The two top players in the Palma climination and qualification knockout roundrobin tourna ment for the world challenge match, Yefim Geller of the So viet Union with 83, and Bob by Fischer of Los Angeles, with 72, and two adjourned games, met in the 12th round today and their game was adjourned.

title: CITYGRAFT INQUIRY SEEKS U.S. FUNDS
description: The special commission in vestigating allegations of cor ruption among New York po licemen, despairing of winning additional funds from an econ omyminded City Council, has applied to the Federal Govern ment to finance its graft in quiry for an additional six months.

title: CUBICULO MATCHES DISPARATE DANCERS
description: Essentially there are two types of choreographers, those who laugh and those who do not. Robert Streicher does not and Jan Van Dyke does. Last night they shared a program at the Cubiculo.

title: U.S. SCALES DOWN PLAN FOR RAIL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Nixon Administration scaled down its offer of loan guarantees for troubled rail roads from $750million to $500million today.

title: Rockefeller Campaign Cost $6.7Million
description: ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) Governor Rockefeller spent al most $6.8million on his suc cessful campaign for re election, according to figures filed with the Secretary of State's office.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
AMERICAN MOTORS EXPANDS SALES 34%
description: The American Motors Cor poration announced yesterday that its sales of new cars in creased 34 per cent in the Nov. 1120 period. During the middle 10 days of November the na tion's fourth largest major car maker sold 6,111 automobiles, up from 4,551 in the yearearli er period.

title: Wrong Man for the U.N.
description: When Presidentelect Nixon in late 1968 named Charles W. Yost to be chief United States representative at the United Nations he said it was probably one of the best appointments I have made.

title: Alexander's Lags
description: Alexander's Inc., the chain of specialty stores, told stockholders at its an nual meeting yesterday that earnings declined in the first fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 17, although sales grew 4.6 per cent from a year before.

title: Delaware Team Takes 3d Lambert Cup in Row
description: The University of Dela ware was named yesterday winner of the Lambert Cup for the third consecutive year. The award is given annually for outstanding per formance by a middlesized Eastern college football team.

title: Javits May Oppose a G.O.P. Label for Buckley
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator Jacob K. Davits raised the possibility today that he might try to block Senator elect James L. Buckley of New York from joining the Republi can minority when the Senate reorganizes next January.

title: One Killed, 22 Hurt in Harlem By Poison Gas From a Furnace
description: A 70yearold building super intendent was killed and 18 tenants were overcome by poisonous gas emitted from Harlem tenement's defective coal furnace yesterday.

title: Entertainment Events
ACTION BY U.S. ON OIL URGED BY PROXMIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator William Proxmire urged the Administration today to suspend oliimport quotas and immediately free crude oil production in the Federal do main.

title: Strike Lifted, Harlem Coop Is Optimistic on Its Future
Bar Association Group Proposes Decentralized City Government
description: A reorganized city govern ment with about 45 neighbor hood districts, headed by elected local directors and taking over many functions from City Hall, was proposed yesterday in a study sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

title: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASE BY 0.5% FOR SECOND MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24A strong rise in consumer prices in October for the second con secutive month was reported today, reversing the improve ment in the inflation picture that emerged last summer.

title: Neighborhood Houses Director Honored by 500 on Retirement
description: More than 500 persons, in chiding former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, attended a dinner last night at the Plaza Hotel in honor of Miss Helen M. Harris, the executive director of the United Neighborhood Houses, who is retiring at the end of the year.

title: Aqueduct Entries
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Henry G. Barnhurst Dies; Provident Life Manager
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, Nov. 24Henry G. Barnhurst, a manager for the Provident Mu tual Life Insurance Company in New York, died today in his office at 270 Madison Avenue, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived here a 11 Pokahoe Drive.

title: Television
5 Men and Bogus $250,000 Are Seized in Jersey Raids
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 (AP) Five alleged counterfeiters were arrested today as Secret Service agents confiscated $250,000 in counterfeit money and raided a North Bergen printing plant where they took possession of numerous items allegedly used in an interstate counterfeiting operation.

title: Trojans Up for the Irish With the Aid of an Omen
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 If history can repeat itself, Southern California's Trojans do have a chance Saturday against the undefeated Fight ing Irish of Notre Dame.

title: Consumer Confidence Declines; Panel Studies Inflation Problem
Westvaco Profits Decline 22% But Sales Advance to a Record
description: Sharply rising costs in the midst of the economic down turn penalized earnings of the Westvaco Corporation for the year ended Oct. 31 by 22 per cent, but sales set a record for the 18th consecutive year, David L. Luke 3d., President, reported yesterday.

title: Harlem: Beauty, Dreams, Children
description: On Madison Avenue and 129th Street there was an empty storefront used now and then by some neighbor hood kids to while away the day. I was told I might use it as I saw fit when I returned to New York in the fall.

title: U.S. Marshal in Chicago 7 Trial Recalls Only One Deadlock Bid
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 Under persistent questioning by a de fense attorney, Deputy Federal Marshal Ronald Dobroski said today that the jury in the con spiracy trial of the Chicago Seven had sent only one dead lock message during five days of deliberations and this had been sent on Saturday, the day the deliberations began.

title: Retailing: Profit Woes and Sales Strides
TV Review
description: As a sequel if not an answer to Channel 13's re cent controversial program on Schoolhouse or Jail house, the noncommercial outlet offered 90 minutes last night under the title of Schools Can Work. The value of the program was that it underscored the fact that in a complicated urban school system no one has a single pat answer to all the system's problems. Not prin cipals, Board of Education officials teachers, parents, students or bystanders.

title: PRICES OF BONDS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices swung down yesterday as traders and in vestors took profits following nearly a week of the most intense demand for fixedin come securities in recent years.

title: CITY'S NOTES SOLD AT A 3YEAR LOW
description: After a week of fiscal gloom about budget deficits, service cuts and employe layoffs, New York City's government pro duced some good economic news yesterday.

title: YAHYA DIRECTING DISASTER RELIEF
Welfare's Burdens
description: The Nixon Administration's highly desirable welfare reform proposal is trapped in an ironic crossfire of criti cism from both conservative and liberal members the Senate Finance Committee. It must not be left die in this political noman's land.

title: Vietcong Using Different Name For Shadow Regime in the South
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 24The Vietcong shadow government apparently has changed its name from the Provisional revo lutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam to the Government of the Re public of South Vietnam.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S. Court Backs Discharge For Antiwar Navy Officer
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 24 (AP) A young Navy officer who signed a petition to the Penta gon objecting to the war in Vietnam is getting his discharge by order of a Federal judge.

title: Israelis Feel Suez Canal Could Be Opened Quickly
Eyssell Ending 37 Years at Rockefeller Center
description: I wanted to go to college and I couldn't afford it, Gus tav S. Eyssell said yesterday.

title: Windows at Stanford Broken In a Vietnam Bombing Protest
description: STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP)Rockthrowing demon strators broke 49 windows at Stanford University last night in a protest against the United States bombing of North Viet nam last weekend.

title: CHAPMAN DRIVES HIS 200TH WINNER
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 24 It took 23 years, nearly 15,000 races and lots of blood, sweat and tears, but John Chapman finally achieved his goal200 winners in a single season.

title: How to Roast Holiday Turkey
description: To thaw a frozen turkey, place the bird on a tray in the refrigerator in the original wrap, which has been punc tured for two to four days or about 24 hours for each five pounds of turkey.

title: Railroads Accept Panel's Proposal for Pay Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) In a surprise move, the na tion's railroads announced to day that they were reluctantly ready to accept a White House panel's proposal for a contract settlement providing a 37 per cent wage increase over three years.

title: Soviet Agrees to Deliver Heavy Water to Canada
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (AP) Canada has concluded a deal with the Soviet Union to buy 55 tons of heavy water to help meet a shortage in the nuclear power program.

title: SEEK'S PROGRAM WILL END IN JUNE
description: City College announced yes terday that it would close its offcampus classroom center for students in the SEEK pro gram at the end of next June.

title: Robert DeW. C. Meeker Dead; Led Media Representative Firm
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24 Robert DeWitt Clinton Meek er, board chairman of the Meeker Company, radio and television sales representa tives, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived here in Deer Park.

title: Colorado Accepts Liberty Berth
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 24 (AP) Colorado accepted today an in vitation to play in the Dec. 12 Liberty Bowl football game here.

title: Gibson Presses Newark Council To Relent and Back Audit Plan
description: NEWARK, Nov. 24Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, whose re quest for a special audit of the municipal finances and fiscal methods he inherited from for mer Mayor Hugh 3. Addonizio was blocked by the City Coun cil in August, has been hold ing informal talks with Council men in an effort to get them to reverse themselves.

title: Black Panther Jury Hears Bugged Talks
MISS MORGEN PLAYS HER SPECIALTY, BACH
description: It is entirely appropriate fog the winner of the Bach Inter national Competitions (1968) to devote the entire first half of her program to that com poser's Goldberg Variations.

title: SST FUNDS VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
FRENCH CRACK DOWN ON RACING BET RING
description: PARIS, Nov. 24A French court cracked down hard to day on a Belgian book maker and his network of cafe owners operating just across the border in northern France.

title: BOARD CERTIFIES CITY VOTE TALLY
description: The final New York City vote tally, certified by the Board of Elections yesterday, shows that Governor Rockefeller finished only 17,041 votes behind Arthur J. Goldberg, his Democratic Liberal opponent, in winning reelection Nov. 3.

title: Winter Glow Ball to Assist the Retarded
description: The fourth annual Winter Glow Ball will take place Dec. 4 at Rod's Shadowbrook, Shrewsbury, N. J. The evening will begin with cocktails at 7:30 and dinner will be served at 9.

title: $17.7BILLION VOTED FOR AGENCIES FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The House passed a $17.7 billion appropriations bill today as a replacement for an $18 billion version that President Nixon had vetoed on the ground it was inflationary.

title: $2.845Billion U.S. Deficit $63Million Under Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Federal Government re ported today that it wound up the fiscal year that ended June 30 with a deficit of $2.845billion. It was $63bil lion less than had been forecast earlier.

title: Rogers Gives View
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 24United States and Canadian ministers worked toward a policy of freer trade between the two countries at a conference com pleted here today.

title: Renowned Author Raids Tokyo Military, Ends Life
A CHILL DESCENDS ON GIANTS' HOPES
LESTER J. ROSNER, BARUCH DEAN, 55
description: Lester J. Rosner, dean of administration at Bernard M. Baruch College, collapsed dur ing a faculty meeting yesterday and died shortly afterward at nearby Columbus Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 60 Gramercy Park South.

title: Do Not Lose Hope
description: These comments are from a recent talk by Leonard Bernstein to students at the Berkshire Music Center.

title: FOREIGN AID BILL GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The Senate Appropriations Commit tee today restored $555million that the House had cut from the foreign aid appropriations bill for this fiscal year and sent the $2.2billion measure to the Senate floor for an early vote.

title: Macy's 3Month Earnings Down 19%
description: Earnings plummeted dur ing the first fiscal quarter at R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., New York's largest retailer and operator of 61 department stores, but sales since a slug gish August have continued to rise, shareholders were told here yesterday.

title: Production of Cars and Trucks is Resumed at Five G. M. Plants
description: DETROIT, Nov. 24 (UPI) Cars and trucks rolled off five General Motors Corporation as sembly lines today for the first time since the United Automo bile Workers struck 10 weeks ago.

title: Music Draws Strains Direct From Brains
description: Are you ready for brain wave music? David Rosen boom is. If he had his way, he would wire us all up, plug us in and groove on the music of our minds. When Mr. Ro senboom, a 23yearold corn poser, who will present a sample of his work on Dec. 4 at Automation House, hit on his plan for investi gating the relationship of musical waves to encephalo graphic waves, he recalls that he overresponded. My first reaction, he said in an interview the other day at Automation House. was: Wow! I'll plug into the head and out will come Mo zart. But then I began to think and I realized that really wouldn't be much dif ferent from playing Mozart on the piano.

title: Another Spasm in Vietnam
description: PARISThe peace negotiations in Paris have changed very little during the past eighteen months but the war in Indochina has. Nothing confirmed this fact more strikingly than last weekend's U. S. air raids on the North.

title: Rate Rises Granted Railroads For Jersey Intrastate Riders
description: More than 37,000 commuters who ride the Penn Central and Jersey Central Railroads within New Jersey face increases Jan. 1 in their monthly commuting rates ranging from 15 per cent to 25 per cent.

title: Barcelona Traces The Early Picasso
description: BARCELONA  The ex traordinary trail of Picasso's early assertions, disguises, concealments, reappearances and transformations winds through five rooms of Mont juich Palace on a hill over looking Barcelona.

title: City Asks Time for Study Of Unpaid Medicaid Bills
description: The city requested more time yesterday to examine 4, 587 unpaid Medicaid dentist bills totalling $358,690 that date back more than three years.

title: FRANK ILYA SAMET
description: Frank Ilya Samet, an elec tronics engineer, died of cancer on Sunday at his home, 230 Riverside Drive. He was 68 years old.

title: VILLANOVA GIVEN N.C.A.A. RUN TITLE
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 24 (UPI) After a review today of films of the finish of yester day's National Collegiate Ath letic Association crosscountry race, Villanova University was declared the team champion in stead of Oregon.

title: DEFENSE REBUFFED AT TACOMA TRIAL
description: TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 24 Defense attorneys and two de fendants in the conspiracy trial of the Seattle Eight repeat edly last pleas today that pro spective jurors be asked to make statements regarding their social and political attitudes rather than merely giving yes or no answers to questions from the judge.

title: MARKET EXTENDS PRIMERATE RALLY
description: The stock market extended its primerate rally yesterday as the Big Three automakers, selected glamour issues and some of the oils joined the list of gainers.

title: JOSEPH I. DOBROW
description: TEANECK, N. J., Nov. 24 Joseph I. Dobrow, a sales en gineer with the Berton Plastics Company in Hackensack, and formerly president of the Pater son Tallow Company, died to day. He was 58 years old and lived at 637 Maitland Avenue.

title: The Council's Responsibility
BANKER ASSESSES INFLATION IMPACT
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 Deval uation of the dollar is In pros pect unless the United States curtails its inflation and its con tinuing balance of trade defi cits, Gaylord A. Freeman Jr., chairman of the First National Bank of Chicago, contended here today.

title: Weighs Chemical Outlook
description: Leaders representing the gov ernment, organized labor and industry took a look at the econ omy yesterday and agreed that inflation and unemployment were the most pressing issues.

title: Western Flycatcher Seen in State
description: The National Audubon So ciety said yesterday that it had its first reported sight ing in New York State of the ashthroated flycatcher, which thrives in the heat of Death Valley but also is found in other areas in Southern and Western states.

title: Washington: For the Record
AMEX PRICES GAIN AFTER EARLY DIPS
description: A late upswing helped prices on the American Stock Ex change to end mixed yesterday after stocks had declined for most of the session.

title: RESIDENCY RULES ON RELIEF BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Senate Finance Committee ten tatively voted today to restore to states the right to impose oneyear residency require ments for welfare applicants.

title: Holt, Reinhart Picks Magazine Unit Head
description: Michael J. O'Neill, for the last four years a vice presi dent and advertising sales manager of Look, has been named publisher of the maga zine division of Holt, Rein hart & Winston, which is part of the C.B.S. Educational & Publishing Group in turn part of the Columbia Broad casting System.

title: LAIRD WOULD SEEK BOMBING IF ENEMY BREACHEDACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he would recommend to President Nixon the resumption of fullscale air attacks on North Vietnam if the enemy engaged in major violations of a tacit understand ing with the United States that halted the bombing two years ago.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Idol of French Maoist Students Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
3 on Rescue Mission Saved by Coast Guard
description: Three Coast Guardsman who had been on a search and rescue mission in Long Island Sound were rescued unharmed yesterday after spending the night in rubber wet suits clinging to a life raft.

title: TRIAL OF CALLEY TOLD OF STRAFING
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Nov. 24 A former helicopter gun ship pilot testified today that he saw Vietnamese civilians cut down by strafing as they streamed in paic out of Mylai 4 on the morning of the alleged massacre, March 16, 1968.

title: Panel Backs Copyright Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) The House Judiciary Commit tee approved legislation today to extend all copyrights for an other year, until Dec. 31, 1971. The Senate previously passed the measure,

title: Hughes Disavows His Label as Liberal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator Harold E. Hughes, who nominated Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1968, appears to be moving to the right as he ponders whether to seek the Presidency himself in 1972.

title: CAPTAIN BECOMES 10,000POINT MAN
description: Willis Reed returned to the Knicks' lineup last night and became a 10,000point career scorer as New York defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 128119, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Carnegie Peace Center Picks Head
description: The election of Thomas Lowe Hughes as president and trustee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, 345 East 46th Street, was announced yesterday.

title: Market Summary
Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Nov. 24, 1970

title: Four Blacks Not to Return To Washington U. Eleven
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 24 (AP)An announcement by four sopho more black athletes yesterday that they would not return to the University of Washington football team next year ap peared to surprise the athletic department.

title: LIVING COSTS HERE INCREASE BY 0.6%
description: The consumer price index rose sharply, by 0.6 per cent, in the New York metropolitan area in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yes terday. It was the 42d con secutive month that the index had shown an increase.

title: Draft Revises Rule On Change in Status
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)The Selective Service System today gave deferred draft registrants a firm dead line of midnight Dec. 31 for changing their status to 1A if they feel that wuold be ad vantageous.

title: JETS PLOT TO FOIL PEOPLE EATERS
Pope Plans Vietnam Plea on Trip
description: ROME, Nov. 24 Vatican in formants said today that Pope Paul VI was planning to broad cast an appeal for a negotiated peace in Vietnam and Cam bodia when his plane passes over or near Indochina Friday.

title: UNITAS GETS PACT AS PLAYER, AIDE
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) Johnny Unitas said today he had signed a new threeyear playing contract with the Baltimore Colts. The pact also guarantees him 10 years of employment in the Colts' front office.

title: Screen: 'Floating Weeds':Ozu's Sensitive Work Lifts the Every-Day
description: From 1923 until his death, Yasujiro Ozu (1903-1963) made more than 50 movies. He is frequently discussed in film magazines; he has received important retrospective showings at the Museum of Modern Art; and by admirers of Japanese cinema he is usually ranked with the greatest directors, Mizoguchi and Kurosawa. But just one of his films, "Ohayo" ("Good Morning," 1959), had been released here until yesterday, when "Floating Weeds" (1959) opened at the New Yorker Theater  which makes it two.For the absence of Ozu from American theaters the reason is usually given that he is so quintessentially and inseparably Japanese in his subjects and his moods that translation would not be worth the effort. Such myths die hard, but I should like to help in killing this one, for whatever quintessentials may be hidden, enough can be seen by any eyes with a head behind them, to certify Ozu as perhaps the most accessible and surely one of the most enjoyable Japanese directors for Western audiences.His subjects are not strange. Indeed, they constitute an anthology of the ordinary: scenes from contemporary bourgeois life; problems of growing up, getting married, settling in a job, retiring, facing death; middle-class homes, bars, snack shops, and streets so bright and closely knit that they seem an urbanist's dream. There is no other director so sensitive to the privileges of daily living, and it seems to me that this sensitivity translates into excellent Western idiom. Even Ozu's titles translate well: "Late Spring," "Early Summer," "An Autumn Afternoon," "Tokyo Twilight," "The Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice."Ozu is, however, very special in his technique, which by the end of his career, had become very modest, lucid and lovely. Habitually shooting from a low angle (the position of somebody sitting on a tatami mat, as all the critics point out), rarely moving his camera, Ozu never fades or dissolves but always cleanly cuts between long-held shotsso that his films suggest not so much the rhetorical manipulation of classical montage as the retention and appreciation of the uniqueness of each separate moment.Activity within the frame is also restrained: a family at dinner, kids studying, a young couple kissing, banners fluttering in the wind (a favorite and wonderfully exhilarating Ozu shot)as in "Floating Weeds," to announce the arrival of a troupe of actors.The actors have come to a seaside town to play, without much success, traditional drama. The leader of the troupe (Ganjiro Nakamura) had years before made a local woman (Haruko Sugimura) his mistress, and now they have a grown son, who knows his father only as "Uncle." While the troupe fails, its leader devotes his days to his boyuntil his present mistress and leading actress Machiko Kyo) discovers his secret and in revenge plots to have the troupe's ingnue (Ayako Wakao) seduce the young man and thus, by some form of strict middle-class logic, ruin him.The revenge doesn't work (the boy and the girl merely fall in love), but the troupe disbands, and the leader stands ashamed before his son, until he again deserts the boy's motherto take up a new and more precarious life on the road with his mortal foe, whose loyalty he grudgingly accepts.The story is a bit more melodramatic than most Ozu, but its interest really lies in its affectionate intimacies rather than in its larger passions. The scenes between father and son, between old lovers (who have forgotten everything and get all their fond memories wrong), among the members of the troupe  these are where "Floating Weeds" comes most characteristically to life.And in the humor or sadness or generic truth of its vignettesthe actors at their make-up; a heroically dreadful theatrical performance; an old woman's hard shrewdness in the face of difficult circumstances; rain at night over the village rooftopsthe cinema of Ozu provides the justification for its gentle and unassumine forms.

title: SUTTON DENIES PLAN TO QUIT BOROUGH JOB
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan declared yesterday that he intended to serve out his term despite re ports that he would resign to make way for the selection of State Senator Basil L. Pater son as his successor.

title: TWO BRING LETTERS FROM 320 P.O.W.'S
description: Two American lawyers who were in Hanoi during the Amer ican attempt last weekend to rescue prisoners of war said here yesterday that they had brought back letters from 320 of the known 339 prisoners.

title: Alan Wood Steel Foresees A Brief Shutdown Possible
description: The Alan Wood Steel Com pany said yesterday it would close its plate mill at Consho hocken, Pa., for at least a week before the end of 1970 unless orders pick up at a rate that doesn't seem likely.

title: STANFORD PASSER DECISIVE VICTOR
description: Jim Plunkett, who turned down an opportunity to play professional football this fall, received college football's high est individual honor yesterday, the Heisman Memorial Trophy.

title: LINDSAY, 25 AIDES TAKE $1,000 CUTS
Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 24 Two unheralded Middle Western players captured the life master men's pair cham pionship here last night in the American Contract Bridge League's fall national tourna ment. Heading a field that in cluded several internationally famous experts, Ronald An dersen of Madison, Wis., and Hugh McLean of Edina, Minn., totaled 992 match points to take the title.

title: Anne Jackson and Wallach To Give a Benefit Program
description: Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach will appear in a special program Monday night at the Stage 73 Theater, 321 East 73d Street, to raise funds for the Manhat tan Theater Arts Center, a non profit corporation that is sched uled to oven next year.

title: Fijians Get Cold Reception as New York Scores 1211 Rugby Upset
description: The United States took a stride forward as a rugby playing country last night as a New York allstar team de feated the highly touted Fiji national squad, 1211, at Randalls Island.

title: Ford Sets Off a Scramble For RaceTeam Sponsors
description: As may have been expect ed, the gloomiest reaction to the Ford Motor Company's announced withdrawal from nearly all forms of auto rac ing comes from the four fac tory stockcar teams, which now must look elsewhere for support of their expensive efforts. Typical of the Fordteam managers is Junior Johnson of Rhonda, N. C., who says: The people I have talked to say they can't get a $150,000 return for their money. And it would take at least twice that much to run just the big races. With money as tight as it is, it's awful hard to come up with a sponsor willing to put that much in racing.

title: ROBERT F. JANES
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 24 Robert F. Janes, a lawyer, died today at a convalescent home in Stamford. He was 90 years old and live at 1 Fifth Avenue, New York. He was a retired attorney for the New York Telephone Company.

title: Deep Diving Record Broken
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 (AP)A team of five divers broke the world's deep diving record today by descending to 1,100 feet under simulated conditions. The divers, working for the Taylor Diving Company, were testing equipment for the Navy at Belle Chasse, La. They were scheduled to go only to 1,000 feet but decided to go after the record of 1,025.

title: Roning to Direct Big Sky
description: BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 24 (AP) John Honing, athletic director at the University of South Da kota, was selected today as commissioner of the Big Sky athletic conference. He will succeed 72yearold Jack Friel of Pullman, Wash., who is re tiring effective July 1.

title: Amer. Hockey League
Talks Recessed Indefinitely In Mohawk Airlines Strike
description: UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP)  Negotiations between repre sentatives of Mohawk Airlines and its pilots, who are on strike for higher pay, were recessed indefinitely today after a two hour morning meeting, a com pany spokesman said.

title: Big Board Fills Position Of Retiring Vice President
Harlem School Of Arts to Gain At Recital Dec. 9
description: Andr Watts will give a piano recital the evening of Dec. 9 at the Cosmopolitan Club at 129 East 65th Street in behalf of the Harlem School of the Arts.

title: OHIO CITY SENDS A FINE ENSEMBLE
description: Bowling Green, Ohio, ranks right up there with the great evocative American place names, along with Slippery Rock, Pa., and What Cheer, Iowa. And besides a lovely name, Monday night's concert at Alice Tully Hall gave one to know, the town claims an as tonishingly fine string Quartet.

title: Treasury Statement
Copeland Faces His Creditors
Brother of a Slain Rights Aide Acquitted in Carolina Murder
description: RIDGELAND, S. C., Nov. 24 An allblack jury tonight ac quitted Ben Chaney Jr., the 18yearold brother of James Chaney, slain Mississippi civil rights worker, on a charge that he murdered a white South Carolina man last spring.

title: Japan's Renaissance Man
description: The Japanese Hemingway and Japan Renaissance Man are two of the appellations that were given to Yukio Mi shima, who made himself a living legend in a Japan seek ing new directions and new idols following defeat in World War II.

title: 25 MORE REJECTED FOR SEALE PANEL
NEW GROUP SET UP TO ATTACK RACISM
description: Leaders of four of the na tion's leading civilrights and humanrelations organizations announced yesterday that they had joined forces for a con certed attack on racism and polarization throughout the country.

title: JOHN A. GEIGER
description: ROSELLE, N. J., Nov. 24  John A. Geiger of 618 Sheridan Avenue, a founder in 1945 and a former vice president of the Evans Rule Company in Eliza beth, died last night in St. Elizabeth Hospital. He was 63 years old and retired in 1960 as vice president of the com pany, which makes carpenter rules and steel measuring tape.

title: THOMAS J. COSTELLO, PHONE ENGINEER, 65
description: PAWLING, N. Y., Nov. 24 Thomas J. Costello, who re tired as chief supervising engi neer of the New York Tele phone Company in 1966, died last evening in the St. John's Parish Hall here, where he had been teaching a class in Chris tian doctrine.

title: 2 Coast Papers Raise Price
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (UPI)The two major San Francisco daily newspapers an nounced today that they would raise their street sales prices to 15 cents from 10. The Morn ing Chronicle and the after noon Examiner said that the newsstand increase for their daily editions would be effec tive Monday.

title: In Memoriam
description: HYTOWNNoel, In fond and loving memory of my beloved husband who passed away 5 years ago, always with me. Cell.

title: Simon Cohen, a Manufacturer And Queens Civic Leader, Dies
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Nov. 25 Simon Cohen, a clothing manu facturer and philanthropist, died today in MidIsland Hos pital, of which he was execu tive director. He was 63 years old and lived at 174 Broadway in Lawrence.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  The recent run of bad news on the price front was broken today when the Labor Depart ment reported that wholesale prices declined slightly in No vember.

description: Shopping for a new joban occupational hazard for football coachesbecame a reality yes terday for five men in the colleniate ranks.

title: CONSUMER INDEX A STABLE SPHINX
description: What is the Consumer Price Index, which turns on poli ticians, which often helps de termine the wages of millions of union workers, which is cited by experts in explainin,g inflationary trends and which nuzzle housewives?

title: RAPIDAMERICAN CITES LOWER NET
description: The RapidAmerican Corpora tion, which controls a large retailing empire through a 56 per cent stock ownership of the McCrory Corporation which in turn controls Lerner Stores, re ported yesterday increased sales but sharply lower earn ings for the nine months ended act. 31.

title: Westchester Asks U.S. for More Aid
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 25 Westchester County Execu tive Edwin C. Michaelian re turned today from Washing ton, where he met with Presi dent Nixon and presented a plea on behalf of the Nation al Association of Counties for the Federal Government to assume a greater share of welfare costs.

title: Copeland's Listing Of Trust Valuation Meets a Challenge
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 25 Two lawyers representing creditors of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. questioned today the propriety of listing a value for certain trusts in his per sonal financial statements.

title: They're Never Too Young to Learn
description: Should infants be left In their cribs to examine their toes or be provided with sterner intellectual challenge? Dr. Burton L. White, director of Harvard University's Pre School Project, is all in favor of offering the challenge, In cooperation with Kenner Products Company, he has developed two se ries of toys called Playtentials. Se ries I is designed to help infants be tween 3 weeks and 3 months old discover themselves; Series II is for babies between 3 and eight months. Series I includes FindMe Mitts, which are brightly colored to attract baby's attention but leave his fingers free to explore; Bat and Feel Toys, which remain in the infant's limited field of vision and give random hand motions direction through shape, texture and color; and Animal Grabble, a soft, contoured elephant that may be used to teethe on. The series is $13 complete.

title: Clearing the Air
description: The proposed air pollution code for the City of New York, more sweeping in scope and far stiffer in penalty than the present code, contains an interesting feature which might bring help where it is most desperately needed. This area is enforcement. The present code, not at all a bad one, has never been adequately enforced.

title: Today's Pro Football LineUps
MORHOUSE LOSES TOP STATE APPEAL
Bridge:
description: HOUSSTON, Nov. 25Two of the country's topranked women experts led the field of 56 pairs into the second semifinal session of the Blue Ribbon Pair event at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight. Dorothy Hayden of New York and Emma Jean Hawes of Fort Worth, Tex., led at the half way mark with a total of 427 points.

title: LAIRD REVEALS U.S. PLANNED TO KEEP CAMP RAID SECRET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Nixon Administration disclosed the commando raid last Satur day on the empty prisonerof war camp in North Vietnam to avoid a credibility problem with the American public.

title: CONTRACTS DEMANDS REDUCED BY ONASSIS
description: ATHENS, Nov. 25 Aristotle S. Onassis has reduced his de mands for a drastic revision of his $600million investments contract with the Greek Gov ernment.

title: U.S. Suit Says Carpenters Bar Negroes From 2 Locals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The Justice Department filed suit today against two carpenter union locals accused of exclud ing Negroes from membership and of going on strike when blacks were hired on construc tion projects.

title: Mishima: A ManTorn Between Two Worlds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25The morning before he killed him self, Yukio Mishima reportedly handed to his publishers in Tokyo the final chapter of the fourth volume of a tetrology titled The Sea of Fertility. Perhaps the title helps explain why this 45yearold writer, who enjoyed fame, wealth and criti cal acclaim, took his own life. The, title refers to the moon's Sea of Fer tilitya dry, cold, sterile place. That sea was Mr. Mishima's meta phor for the world and perhaps for Japan, which was for him the world.

title: Charts of Races at Aqueduct
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: Luncheon to Aid Maimonides Institute
description: The 10th anniversary lunch eon and fashion show of the Maimonides Institute Wom en's Division will be held on Wednesday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Proceeds of the event will provide scholarships for mentally handicapped chil dren attending the institute in the Bayswater section of Far Rockaway. Tickets are $25 each from Mrs. Elias Hausman, 875 West End Avenue.

title: American Image and Reality
description: LONDONThe lethargy of an Eng lish society bereft of its empire is not the best position from which to evalu ate the truth about a United States vitality. The United States, I must confess, has always frightened me; or is it only the image of the country conveyed through its culture? Perhaps fear is the wrong word; a shrillness travels across the Atlantic that sets up a warning of disharmony to the nerves; simple values of modesty, honesty, pity and tolerance seem offended. Even the New Left and the Black Panthers, as their image reaches us here, have the dishonest voice to which everything in the States seems reduced by its own harsh brand of intense enthusiasma tone of voice whose shrill pitch strives for those extra singsong decibels of breathless sincerity to compensate for a society whose products and people imagines do not speak for themselves.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Bond prices turned in a mixed performancebut with an upward biasyesterday as many issues gathered strength in the afternoon for what some believe to be an assault on still higher levels.

title: U.S. BOMBERS STRIKE FOE'S SUPPLY ROUTES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 25 (AP)The United States command said today that bomb ing by B25's and fighterbomb ers continued today against North Vietnamese supply routes in Laos and Cambodia and that reconnaissance operations were conducted over North Vietnam.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI)  The Pentagon today identified the following service men from the New York area as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia:

title: NOV. 1120 CAR SALES DOWN 46% IN NATION
description: Sales of new cars in the United States fell 46.7 per cent in the Nov. 1120 period to 150,038 units from 281,145 in the yearearlier period.

title: PISTONS DOWNED BY 11387 SCORE
. . . And Maybe Wine Prices Will Fall
description: The 1970 vintage has been harvested in France, and the word from the vineyards is that the wine not only is of outstanding quality but, perhaps more important for consumers, is plentiful. The result should be an interrup tion in the seemingly endless escalation of wine prices in this country.

title: TAXPAYER LOSES BID TO FIGHT WAR FUNDS
description: The United States Court of Appeals here held yesterday that Walter G. Pietsch, of Rego Park, Queens, could not bring a court challenge to the right of Congress to authorize funds for the war in Vietnam just because he is a taxpayer.

title: Screen: Uneven Drama
description: Paul Almond's "The Act of the Heart," the second film by the young Canadian writer-director who made his debut last year with "Isabel," is a very personal, very civilized movie that finally, like its haunted heroine, comes to indescribable grief. It's not a successful movie. Its failuressometimes of simple dramatic coherence  are indefensible, but its successes are of an intelligence that is all too rare in this zoom-rock movie age.The film, which opened yesterday at the Murray Hill Theater, is a kind of Holy Ghost story set in Montreal, in winter, among people who live in upper-middle-class houses, like music, play hockey, belong to community associations and seem, in general, to be coping rather well.One girl, however, is different. She is Martha (Genevieve Bujold), a very pretty, pure thing who tutors for her room and board, sings with a local choral group and, in her rather matter-of-fact secret life, dreams romanticaly of Jesus. Martha, a Protestant who marvels at Roman Catholic rituals (of which she has no more real knowledge than most Protestants), falls in love with an Augustinian monk, Father Ferrier (Donald Sutherland), a sensitive, compassionate young man to whom Martha comes to represent the engaged life he is denied.It's a curious love, since it involves her sexual desires as well as her envy of his monastic life, which has, in effect, removed him from what are, to her, the terrors of the real world.Their relationship is lovely and sad and safe, until the monk, in what one feels to be a positive gesture, decides to leave the church and set up housekeeping with Martha. For her, however, his act of renunciation has an inevitably fatal resolution.That a certain extraordinary doom awaits Martha is apparent early on in the movie. Mr. Almond has a way of moving his camera as if he were shooting a mystery story. It seems constantly to suggest unseen presences, and to invest objects with an importance that the characters themselves seem to miss. There are enigmatic encounters, as when Martha goes out of her way to pique the sexual curiosity of a strange, middle-aged man who sits opposite her in a hospital waiting room.At another point, while chattering on about the possible joys of single existence (devoted to something better than a man), she is really inviting a grief-stricken woman-friend to make love to her.Until that point in the film at which it becomes evident that Martha is mad as a hatter (or, at least, so particular, so eccentric, that she is beyond our comprehension), the movie is unequivocally good. Mr. Almond's script, which is about levels of love, eventually becomes something of a mess, as did the one he wrote for "Isabel," but he knows how people talk, how to dramatize conventional versions of love and tenderness, and how to place people in some honest relationship with their settings.He is also a gifted director of actors. Miss Bujold (Mrs. Almond) is lovely in a very mysterious role, and Mr. Sutherland is absolutely right as the fairly mod monk. Equally good are all the supporting players, especially a little boy named Bill Mitchell, a nonprofessional whose work must be credited to the sensitivity of the director.Even with so many things going for it, "The Act of the Heart" that concludes the film, and that is not, I feel, arbitrary (it must be the reason the film was made), is not supportable. Self-immolationI can't avoid saying it any longerdemands a grand, tragic logic if it is to be meaningful. Otherwise its the sort of act that makes a banal news story on Page One Monday and is forgotten by Wednesday. There is no grand tragic logic in "The Act of the Heart." When I left the theater I simply felt that I'd seen a terrible accident.

title: F.T.C. Calls Ads for 3 Toys and Zerex Deceptive
description: W1ASHINGTON, Nov. 25 The Federal Trade Commission challenged today the fairness of advertisements by two major toy manufacturers and the pro ducer of a leading automobile antifreeze.

title: OUSTER PRODUCES MIXED REACTIONS
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 25 (UPI)  Emotions in Congress were mixed today on the ouster by President Nixon of Walter J. Hickel as Secretary of the Interior.

title: Next Step on Job Safety
description: The intransigence of organized labor in urging its Con gressional allies to hold out for a jobsafety bill that did not deserve passage and had no realistic chance getting it has resulted in House adoption of an industry backed substitute too weak to provide the protection that workers need.

title: Hoffman Sets Tomorrow For Trial Recollections
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 25  Judge Julius J. Hoffman decided today that he needed more time to study the Chicago conspiracy trial record before placing into the appeal record his recollec tions of any communications he might have had with the jury.

title: Advise, and So What?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25  A mother stood on a bridge over a narrow stream watching her young son playing below at the water's edge. After watching a moment she decided that the boy re quired advice and raising her voice she shouted it down to him.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International Defense Secretary Laird told the House Committee on Foreign Affairs yesterday that the Government had not necessarily planned to disclose the commando raid Fri day on an empty prisonerofwar camp in North Vietnam. He said the news had been made public to avoid a credibility prob lem after North Vietnam had reported air raids near Hanoi. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Flyers Triumph by 31 and Break Rangers Winning Streak at Four Games
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25  Beating the Rangers to the puck and hitting them harder and more often, the Philadelphia Flyers ended their streak of ties with the New Yorkers tonight by scoring a 31 victory.

title: Television
GROMYKO CONFERS IN EAST GERMANY
WELFARE HOTELS FACE CITY ACTION
description: The city will open a drive in about 10 days to get lower rents and better conditions for welfare families living in hotels.

title: ExProsecutor Denies Coercion Of Witnesses at Murder Trial
description: A former assistant district attorney, Gino E. Gallina, de nied on the witness stand yes terday that he had coerced key witnesses to testify falsely against William A. Maynard, who was charged with the mur der of a marine in Greenwich Village in 1967.

title: Psychiatrist Says Brutalizing Vietnam War Causes Problems for ExG.I.'s
Two Bronx Men Arraigned In Attempted Murder Case
description: Two Bronx men were ar raigned on attempted murder and assault charges in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday in a case that in volved the shooting of an off duty Queens patrolman and an employe of the Provost Auto Salvage company at 3640 Pro vost Avenue last Sept. 30.

title: Welfare Reform Crunch
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 25In the late stages of the Texas senatorial cam paign, Democrat Lloyd Bentsen sharp ly attacked Republican George Bush for his support of President Nixon's welfare reform bill. Appearing in Dallas on Oct. 28, just a week before the election, Mr. Nixon himself came to the defense of his proposalthe so called Family Assistance Plan.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE HOMED AT 4%
description: The unemployment rate in New York State and New York City remained constant last month while the unemploy ment rate in the New York metropolitan area showed a slight decline from its Septem ber level, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: F.A.A. Upheld in Revoking License in Wichita U. Crash
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 25 (UPI)  A hearing examiner ruled today that the Federal Aviation Administration had acted correctly in lifting the air taxi license of the company that provided the crew for a Wichita State University charter plane that crashed Oct. 2.

title: CITY IS CRITICIZED ON MENTAL CASES
description: State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Brust criticized the city administration yesterday for assertedly failing to provide adequate hospital facilities for defendants who, the Legal Aid Society complained, are being unlawfully confined in prison while awaiting courtordered psychiatric examinations.

title: Orthodox Leaders Score Bombing as Irresponsible
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Top leaders of Orthodox Juda ism in this country denounced the Jewish Defense League to day as destructive and ir responsible.

title: Hickel and His Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 Few men have been nominated for Cabinet posts who seemed to have so few qualifications for the job and who aroused so much apprehension and op position as did Walter J. Hickel. Here was a Governor of Alaska, an apparently parochial figure with the selfmade millionaire's limitations of na tional outlook and interest, named to head the Depart ment of the Inter ior, which has authority over the regulation of much of the nation's natural resourcesthe public lands, oil and mineral leasing, wildlife and the national parksand also over the pollution of the nation's waters.

title: Overton Center of Harlem Dispute Over Local School Board Post
description: A dispute over whether L. Jo seph Overton is or is not chair man of the District 5 Local School Board developed in Har lem yesterday after Mr. Over ton apparently resigned, then was discharged and then assert ed that he was still chairman.

title: Witty State Mediator Vincent Daniel McDonnell
description: As he worked with union and taxi industry negotia tors yesterday to bring their contract dispute to a peace ful conclusion, Vincent Dan iel McDonnell was the same easygoing, witty and relaxed mediator that he has been throughout the difficult ne gotiations. One recent eve ning in an earlier Man and critical stage of the bargain ing, he was asked at a news conference what he thought of a statement by City Councilman Thomas J. Cuite criticizing the manner in which Mayor Lindsay had proposed a taxi fare increase.

title: Poverty Protest Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) Poverty lawyers and their clients will demonstrate in Washington Dec. 7 to protest changes in the legal services program of the Office of Eco nomic Opportunity. David Du gan of Camden, N. J., chairman of Poverty Lawyers for Effec tive Advocacy, said the lawyers and their clients would picket the agency's building, hold a rally on Capitol Hill and then lobby with members of Con gress.

title: Belgian Accused in Raid Is Reported in Portugal
description: LISBON, Nov. 25  Jean Schramme, the Belgian mer cenary who was accused by President Sekou Tour of having trained the forces that invaded Guinea Tuesday, is quietly running a chicken farm in Portugal. Neighbors reported seeing him last Sun day on his farm at Oliveira do Sul in the north.

title: Roosevelt Entries
STOCKS IN LONDON SLIP IN SLOW DAY
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed lower yester day after dull trading.

title: William D. Benjes, Served Several Shoe Companies
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 25  William D. Benjes, a major figure in the shoe industry, died yesterday in Goddard Hospital, Boston. He was 62 years old and lived here at 91 Strawberry Avenue.

title: Intensive Rail Talks Set To Avert Strike Dec. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 25 (AP)  A Government official said today that he would call round theclock negotiations next week in an effort to head off a nationwide railroad strike.

title: School Football Today
MICHAEL F. WHALEN

description: The Firenze at Aqueduct to day has attracted a field of eight fillies and mares for its 23d running. The 1 18mile handicap will be over early, for the holiday card will start at 11 A.M. with the main event going off about 2 o'clock.

title: U.S. Said to Plan Cautious Policy on MarxistLed Chile
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 While President Nixon report edly reacted with dismay to the emergence in Chile of a regime headed by a Marxist, he is said to have approved for the time being a policy toward it of patience and diplomatic correctness.

description: MIAMI, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Air Line Pilots Association to day demanded authority for flight crews to carry firearms during commercial flights for use in hijackings.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: U.S.Spain. President Nixon sent to the Senate for ratifi cation an updated treaty on extradition with Sprin that enlarges the jurisdiction to include aircraft hijackings and narcotic offenses. The treaty signed at Madrid last May 29 terminates and re places the existing treaty signed between the two countries in 1907.

Books of The Times

title: Sculptures by Fonseca Are Shown at Jewish Museum
description: Three highly disparate ex hibitionsof sculpture as piring to be architecture, of photography attempting to bring us a sense of religious community and of some chic design ideas desperately hoping to be mistaken for mystical illuminationopen ed yesterday at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue at 92d Street.

title: Northwest Airlines Pilots Threaten Sympathy Strike
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov 25 (UPI) Northwest Airlines pilots plan to stop flying at 5:01 A. M. this Friday.
